HEADLINE: Tuned In to the Past, and Repairing It, Too

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA

 BODY:
BILL MORSE eyed two early-1920's radios in his shop. "The one on the right is homemade," he said. "Normally, back then, somebody on the block would make sets for the neighbors."
Not that he doesn't have newer, fancier models -- like an Atwater Kent table radio that cost about $150 when it came out in 1928. It is now worth about $185. 
 "The Mercedes-Benz of early radio," he said. His 1947 Howard chairside is a radio-phonograph combo in a cabinet that is designed to fit by the side of a chair, for comfortable listening. Mr. Morse's televisions go up to the very early 1950's.
Last September Mr. Morse, who is 42, opened Antique Radio and Television in downtown New London. There he repairs, restores, displays and sells old radios, phonographs, televisions and a few other items.
"I like to bring them back to life and have people enjoy them," he said. He also turns up bits of history, like the tale of a New London manufacturer who took one wrong step into the age of television.
The shop, all 200 square feet of it, is filled with sets, parts and assorted literature, including service manuals with schematics for radios made from 1928 to 1949.
"There's a marriage of art and science in this place," said Mr. Morse, who likes the style and craftsmanship of the old sets, from their consoles of wood or metal to their innards of tubes and wires. "There's a grace to these," he said. He peered at the Atwater Kent's tuning drive belt ("metal," he noted) and at its separate speaker, complete with curved grillwork. He pointed out the "magic eye," a tuning aid on a 1937 True-Tone radio in an Art Deco console. "It was put out by Western Auto," he said.
Nearby stood a 1936 Emerson chairside, with built-in ashtray. "You could sit down, tune in and smoke," he said.
His televisions include a Teleking made in New York City in 1948. Behind them stands the splendid shoulder-high, red, green and yellow 1957 Test-O-Matic Radio and Television Tube Tester. Such machines, found in radio and television shops, "were mostly gimmicks to get people to buy new tubes," said Mr. Morse, who has found another use for his. "I store tubes in it," he said.
In a brochure on display, the singer Kate Smith promotes radios made by the Templetone Radio Manufacturing Company, which operated in New London in the 1940's. Mr. Morse received the brochure from a former Templetone employee, and his inventory includes a 1947 Templetone radio called the lunchbox. It was an economy model that "probably sold for $15," he said. "It'll pick up four or five stations." It is worth about $45 now.
The radios did well, but the Templetone company ran into trouble. "They went out of business in 1949 after they made their first TV, which turned out to be an Edsel," he said, explaining that Templetone built sets with overloaded transformers.
"The transformers burned out," he said. "Templetone made a big mistake; it put them into bankruptcy." Mr. Morse has been listening and learning for a long time.
"My interest started with short-wave listening in the 60's," he said. Often, as a youngster, he tuned in to English-language broadcasts from such world capitals as Moscow and Peking, where coverage of the war in Vietnam was very different from what he heard on American radio.
"I like fiddling with things," he said. "Through a lot of reading, asking questions, and trial and error," he learned about the workings of the old sets. "I was driven by an appreciation for engineering and craftsmanship," he said. "Now, everything is made with plastic."
After years of living in New York City (where he most recently taught English as a second language), he returned to the area where he grew up. "I decided to come back and try to make a business out of a hobby," he said.
So far as he knows, Antique Radio and Television is the only business of its kind in Connecticut. The inventory now includes some 80 radios, televisions and phonographs, along with more than 1,000 tubes. Several items, including two Philco radios from the 1930's that sit in the front window, are on consignment.
Music usually fills the air in the shop.
"The radio you're listening to now is a Zenith AM," he said. Then he put a record (from a stack of 78's) on a Philco turntable. He attends swap meets and auctions around the Northeast, comes back with items that he thinks people will want, and works steadily on everything from the outside finish ("they have to be presentable") to inside wiring.
He pointed to the Howard chairside. "It's solid maple," he said. "It had a lot of scratches in it. I sanded it down, stained it, put on a protective coat."
Then, spotting an area that didn't look quite right, he grabbed a brush and gently worked in a little more stain.
"Probably the trickiest jobs are the TV's," he said, "because of the numerous adjustments that are necessary for the picture to be acceptable." He often resurrects old televisions to be used as video monitors, on which, he pointed out, "You can watch old movies."
His customers include people who simply enjoy having such pieces as Art Deco consoles in their homes and serious collectors who seek things like televisions with three-inch screens.
"Collectors into old TV's are looking for smaller screens, but these are collectors, not Joe Public," he said. Daily, customers call or drop by with problems. (He can be found on the Web at www.tuberadiorepair.com.)
Recently Eric Kendall, a musician from Groton, lugged in an amplifier from a Hammond organ. Then he went back to his car and got a plastic bin full of tubes for the amplifier.
"Can you figure all this out?" he asked. "I will, I will," said Mr. Morse, who tackles anything, including amplifiers, guitars and car radios, with tube equipment. He had to disappoint a fellow, however, who recently stopped in with a fairly new television.
"I can't fix a solid-state TV," Mr. Morse explained to him. "It doesn't have tubes." Mr. Morse said by the early 1960's most televisions were solid state.
His small shop, with a smaller workroom behind it, is cozy, but not adequate. "Where I live, it's also a storage area," he said. "Some people have furniture; I have carcasses, things that are too big to display here, or not restored enough to be displayed."
So in the middle of March he bought a big, stately but dilapidated brick building in the next block. He likes its corner location and large first-floor windows; he said he would renovate it and he plans to have living quarters upstairs with a roomy shop downstairs.
"This time next year," he said, stepping around the chairsides, "I'll be moving down the street."

HEADLINE: The Power of Violent Images

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH ATTEBERY

 BODY:
MATHEW KOSBOB, of Stamford, died recently, three weeks short of his 19th birthday, of injuries he received during a beating by several classmates three and a half years ago. Smashed in the head with cans of beer and kicked in the chest repeatedly, Mathew suffered irreversible brain damage that left him unable to walk, talk or eat.
With the young man's death, four youths convicted in the attack and serving prison terms ranging from 4 to 25 years, now face murder charges and possibly more time behind bars -- all because of a $300 windshield that they accused him, falsely, of breaking. 
 In another outburst of violence two years ago, Germaine Lewis, 18 years old of Waterbury, was shot and killed by a rival gang member. The motive was robbery -- Mr. Lewis ran a lucrative drug-selling operation -- but the inspiration for the attack, according to Mr. Lewis's brother, Jason, was a song with angry lyrics called "Shootout," by the group Nas.
Images of violence have become part of the American media diet and are often blamed for encouraging young people to solve their problems through force. What people do not talk about enough, according to Dr. Steven Marans, of the Yale Child Study Center, is why movies, television programs and songs depicting violence are so popular.
"In many cases," said Dr. Marans, "they're successful because they're exciting, because the idea of destructive power, for many people, can be exciting."
All too often, children exposed to violent behavior become perpetrators of violence, themselves. According to a 1992 study by a Yale team, 41 percent of 6th, 8th and 10th graders surveyed in New Haven had witnessed a shooting or stabbing the previous year and 75 percent said they felt unsafe in their homes, neighborhoods or schools. At Boston City Hospital, one out of 10 children treated in the primary care clinic reported witnessing a shooting or stabbing before age 6.
In an effort to shed more light on violence among youngsters -- its causes, consequences and possible solutions -- a Hartford filmmaker Michael King has created a one-hour documentary titled "Bangin'." The film will be broadcast on Connecticut Public Television on Tuesday at 9 P.M. and next Sunday at 6 P.M. The film has also been endorsed by the Connecticut Department of Education for use in conflict resolution and peer mediation programs in high schools around the state.
At a recent screening of "Bangin'," Mr. King talked about his inspiration for the documentary, which, he said, "breaks some of the myths associated with violence" and transcends racial, geographic and socio-economic boundaries.
"Fifteen children a day die of violence in the United States," he said, "so I thought it would be a good time to look in the mirror and see what we're offering these children. I wanted to generate more awareness of the issue of youth violence and provide a vehicle to promote civic dialogue, civil behavior, anger management and peaceful conflict resolution."
Mr. King, who also produces feature films and music videos, created the film using a combination of theatrical and documentary genres. In keeping with its title, the film opens to the sound of gunshots and maintains a staccato beat as the camera zooms in on a varied collection of street guns. Set against a backdrop of rap and popular music, the film then takes viewers on a fast-paced trip from a suburban ball park to a gang-ruled urban alley, from an arsenal of high-powered shotguns to a hospital operating room during emergency surgery. Along the way, Mr. King's camera cuts to children describing guns they can buy anywhere, at any price, and to photographs of victims killed by such guns.
The film, which Mr. King wrote, directed and produced, profiles five teen-agers who speak from their prison cells about their involvement with drugs, gangs and guns and the devastation that resulted.
The film also features Chuck D, founding member of the hip hop group Public enemy, talking about media influences on behavior, and members of the Kosbob and Lewis families. Speaking from experience of another kind is a former gang member, Dr. Tony Morgan, now chief of surgery at St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center in Hartford, who describes the frustration he experiences when treating young crime victims.
"You ask yourself what put them in that situation," he said. "What's going on in their lives that put them at such great risk?" Dr. Morgan credits his mother for saving him from a life of crime. "It was my mother's will and desire to get me out of the mean streets that saved us both," he said.
Mr. King said he hoped his film would help other young people escape the streets. Another resource that is aimed at decreasing violence among young people is the Child Development-Community Policing project, a partnership between Yale's Child Study Center and the New Haven Police Department. Designed by Dr. Marans about seven years ago, the program pairs veteran police officers with Yale clinicians to help children and adolescents who are exposed to, or victimized by, violence. Similar programs have been developed in at least seven other American cities. Despite these developments, violence will never disappear.
As Dr. Marans says in the film: "There is violence in all of us; this is part of the human condition. What we do with that aggression, what we do with our competitive strivings, with our wish to beat out the other in order to achieve position, etc., there lies the difference."

HEADLINE: Industrial Age Ghosts Granted New Lives

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN

 BODY:
EASTERN Connecticut is dotted with old mills, reminders in brick and stone of a time -- the last half of the 19th century and first half of the this century -- when the region was famed worldwide for its textile industry.
After World War II, the textile companies started to desert the state, heading South for warmer climates and cheaper labor markets. Eventually, some went a step farther, seeking out third world countries where the climates were even warmer and the labor markets, including children not yet in their teens, were even cheaper. Just as an example: if one is flying a UConn Huskies flag these days, chances are it has a little tab that says it was made in Korea. 
 What remained in Connecticut after the exodus of the industry were the aged factories, industrial ghosts perched on the small rivers that had once supplied the energy for the mills. There they sat, year after year, prone to destruction by fire and near-destruction by vandals.
As the 21st century approaches, however, some of the mills have been reincarnated as homes of small businesses, as warehouses and office space as well as for manufacturing on a modern, but smaller, scale. They include the Kirby Mill in Mansfield, the River Mill in Thompson, the Prym Mill in Killingly, and three in Putnam: the Morse Cotton Mill, the Belding Mill Complex and the Rhodes Mill.
The Prym Mill in Killingly is a good example of innovative ways to rescue old mills. The first floor of one building is used as a fitness center, known as the Fitness Factory, and the upper floor, big enough that it was used as a hockey rink previously, has been converted into a ballroom for social functions and conferences.
Without question, the most dramatic example in Connecticut of an old mill brought back to life is the huge American Thread Company complex on Main Street in the Willimantic section of the town of Windham, now known as Windham Mills.
The original mill, created in 1854 by four investors as the Willimantic Linen Company, was almost a disaster at the start. The Crimean War had disrupted the European flax supply, used in making linen, and the investors had to change their plans. By 1857, they had converted the operation to making thread. It was a wise decision.
By the 1890's Willimantic was widely known as the Thread City, and with justification. The American Thread Company was the largest cotton mill in the world, a sprawling complex of stone and brick buildings, totaling more than a million square feet, on 40 acres of land on both sides of the Willimantic River. The company's production was awesome: 1,200 different kinds of thread and 90,000 miles of it each working day.
It was the state's biggest employer with 3,200 workers, and a pioneer of the industrial revolution. All its buildings but one were tall and narrow with lots of windows to let in sunlight. The exception was mill No. 4, a squat structure as big as seven football fields. Built in the 1880's, it was designed by Thomas Edison and is said to be the first illuminated factory. That made a second shift in factories possible; with electric lights, they could be busy 24 hours a day. By the 1990's, though, it was all over in Willimantic.
American Thread had hung on longer than most textile firms in eastern Connecticut -- in the mid-1970's it still employed about 1,300 people -- but in the mid-1980's it finally moved south, to North Carolina.
The big cluster of buildings that for so long had fostered prosperity in Willimantic now constituted a complex of liabilities. "They ran the town's economy, then were looked upon as white elephants," says John W. Shannahan, director of the Connecticut Historical Commission.
Earlier in the 90's the empty, deteriorating mills were eyesores that could not be avoided by anyone who lived in the town, or came to visit. To change that, Mr. Shannahan said, "Walter led the charge."
Walter is Walter M. Pawelkiewicz, now a State Representative from Windham but in the early 90's the First Selectman. He can still recall the woman whose whole family had worked at the mill, who came to the Board of Selectmen to ask if something could be done about reopening it.
It seemed almost an impossible request. The mill buildings, 33 of them in all "were in terrible condition and disarray," Mr. Pawelkiewicz said. Some roofs were in danger of collapsing inward.
But the alternative to trying to do something with the mills was even worse. "It would have taken $35 million to tear them all down, and destroy our history," Mr. Pawelkiewicz said. "We didn't want to do that just to put in a shopping center."
The decision was made to attempt to save the complex -- at least the parts that could be saved. The property was taken by eminent domain by the town and a nonprofit corporation, Windham Mills Development Corporation, established to run it.
The selectmen raised a "small pool of money" for a feasibility study on how best to reclaim the old structures, Mr. Pawelkiewicz said, then acquired $3 million under the state's Regional Development Act.
Early on, it was decided that the brick buildings were too deteriorated to be reclaimed and should be razed. The restoration emphasis would be on the big mills made of gneiss, a granite-like rock that had been quarried from the banks of the swift-flowing Willimantic River.
In the initial period of community ownership, the concept of saving the mills was still very iffy, Mr. Pawelkiewicz admitted, and there were an abundance of naysayers. "There were lots of conversations about 'Walter, he's mad'," he says. Considering Mr. Pawelkiewicz's credentials, that is a real barb. He is a psychologist, with a doctorate in that field.
The prevailing public attitude about reclaiming the mills has changed dramatically in the past few years, Mr. Pawelkiewicz said. "Everybody is on board now, and enthusiastic," he said, and we've kept much of our historical heritage. This is now a jewel in the center of town and it shows that this town can, and will, come back. It's a guaranteed success. The community at large has come to that conclusion after early misgivings. People are excited about it."
So far, the project has cost about $20 million in state and Federal money, some of it in the form of loans that must be repaid. Mr. Pawelkiewicz said he was confident that would be done. Indeed, he said, the project is sparking a renaissance of Main Street near the mills, including plans to resurrect an old theater and make it into a magnet school for the performing arts. There is also a plan to install old-fashioned street lights.
For someone visiting Willimantic for the first time in four or five years, the American Thread Company site has to be a delightful shock. What was a jumble of old buildings of brick and stone, occupying 70 percent of 40 acres, has been transformed into a cluster of stone buildings set well apart from each other, with a backdrop of a river and waterfall that could not previously be seen.
The main building, once identified as mill No. 2, but now the most prominent showcase for what is known as Windham Mills Technology Center, is a huge, gable-roofed structure, 400 feet long, 70 feet wide, 4 1/2 stories high, accented in front by a 110-foot tower. It is so clean that it looks almost new instead of being built in the last two years of the Civil War, 1864 and 1865.
Occupying most of the inside -- totally modernized with two huge staircases that were originally segregated by sex, one for women and one for men -- are the kinds of businesses that Willimantic is betting on to bring prosperity back to the town: small companies, mostly high-tech, some not.
The range of businesses includes absorbent materials used in surgery, bio-sensory pest controls, computer software, fiberoptics, educational materials, temporary employees and a brewery.
The president and chief executive officer of Windham Mills, Jeffrey L. Voce, has a degree in architecture from Wesleyan University and is an enthusiast for the role old buildings can play today in an increasingly technical world "I can envision a biotech corridor from Groton to the University of Connecticut in Storrs," he said.
That of course, would mean a new life for more of the old mills in eastern Connecticut, regarded as useless for a good part of this century, being seen in a new light as it ends.

HEADLINE: For the Market In Second Homes, No Vacation

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
KEN Davis has been looking for a second home in Vermont for several months now, but hasn't yet found what he wants at the right price. "I've put bids on a few properties," he said, "but they weren't my dream houses, so I could afford to let them go."
But with the nice weather coming, he is getting a little anxious. "My intention is to have a place in 30 to 60 days," he said. "I want to take advantage of the low interest rates now and have the house to enjoy in the summer and fall." 
 Real estate brokers say that the problem for Mr. Davis and other buyers is a pronounced lack of inventory in certain desirable categories in almost all markets from as far north as Vermont and the Adirondacks to as far south as the Jersey Shore and Bucks County, Pa.
The lack of inventory in turn reflects several seasons of strong markets in popular second-home areas. In the Town of Southampton on Long Island, the dollar value of property sales last year was $1.4 billion, more than half again the figure for 1997. In Connecticut's Litchfield County, sales were up 20 percent in 1998 over the previous year. And brokers report that, whether in the Berkshires, the Jersey Shore or the second-home market in the northern reaches of Westchester County, demand is especially strong at the highest end of the market, with regular sales of second homes carrying price tags of over a million dollars.
Mr. Davis, and his wife, Margie, are prepared to spend $200,000 to $225,000 for a four-bedroom house, with cathedral ceilings, a winding driveway and spectacular views. "My ultimate dream," Mr. Davis said, "is to sit out on the deck with a cigar and a glass of Grand Marnier, maybe barbecue, and watch the world go by."
At one time the couple thought about postponing their second-home purchase in favor of buying a larger permanent home or upgrading the four-bedroom bilevel they now have in Franklin Lakes, N.J.
"Then we decided that we really want to get out of the daily grind and have a place to go to decompress," said Mr. Davis, who works as a manufacturer's sales representative. "Instead of having my money sitting in a bank or mutual fund, it's better to enjoy it, and buying a second home helps diversify your portfolio."
Vivian Thomas, a sales agent with ReMax Star Properties in Manchester, Vt., has been working with the Davises and is clearly frustrated. "We're out of inventory in their price range," she said. "What we have people don't want, like the dated chalets with avocado appliances and the harvest gold shag carpeting."
And there are plenty of those available, Ms. Thomas said. She now has one under contract, a three-bedroom, two-bath chalet, with a deck and hot tub, that sold for $101,000. They can even go as low as $59,000 for a small two-bedroom, one-bath A-frame. "That's not what most people want today," Ms. Thomas said. "They're really for the bargain hunters."
The Davises represent, in many ways, the typical buyers now coming through her door, Ms. Thomas said. "They're primarily young families in their mid-30's," she said. "They're more sophisticated, less bargain hunters. They have a very specific idea of what they want."
Mr. Davis said that he was concentrating his search in and around Manchester "because I like that it's near skiing." (The closest areas are Stratton and Bromley.) "But there are also other activities, like fishing, hiking and biking. I plan to use the house year-round."
Manchester is, in many ways, a traditional New England community, with an idyllic Colonial-era town center comprised of a collection of white clapboard buildings. It is the kind of place where, in the evening, soft amber lights glow from the windows of historic inns.
"Everything slows down when you get up there," Mr. Davis said. "You can really feel it."
But Manchester is also known for its outlet shopping centers, which have been designed to fit in with the prevailing architecture, and attract large crowds, especially on the weekends. "I like the shopping and activity level," Mr. Davis said. "I want a country house, but I don't want to to be in the middle of nowhere."
Last year the people who walked into Ms. Thomas's office were looking primarily for properties priced from $100,000 to $150,000. Now, she said, it's $200,000 to $300,000.
Brokers in many second-home markets say they find people are ready to buy, and that money is not their first concern. Rather it's finding what they want. In some areas, with higher-priced housing stock, the high end of the market has really taken off, say brokers, even for properties over $1 million. But those, too, are in short supply.
"I think it's a reflection of interest rates," said Nora Preusser, who owns a real estate agency in Garrison, N.Y., where the market for second homes has moved up sharply in the last three years. "Buyers are realizing that the time to buy is now," Ms. Preusser said. "Trouble is, we often can't accommodate them because we don't have the listings. In the 20 years I've been in the business, I've never seen inventory this low. It's one-half what it was a year ago. We have twice as many buyers as properties available."
In the lake communities in the Adirondacks, interest has spiked in the last year and a half for "large houses with waterfront property," said Roger Friedman, a principal of Friedman Realty, in Schroon Lake, N.Y. "But we don't have the product," Mr. Friedman said."
"Inventory isn't low in all categories, only in the ones people seem to want," Mr. Friedman said. "People are interested in houses in the low $200,000's to mid-$300,000's. The majority of our listings are for cottages, selling for $170,000 to $190,000."
The lowest listing now is for a small three-bedroom shorefront cabin for $119,000. "There's very little over $200,000, that's the problem," Mr. Friedman said.
Friedman Realty's sales area encompasses five lakes, including Schroon, Loon, Brant, Friend's and Paradox. His office recently sold a four-bedroom contemporary with 250 feet of waterfront property and 4.8 acres on Schroon Lake for $495,000, which is the area's high end. "It sold for the asking price," said Mr. Friedman, "which is happening more and more."
The Adirondacks attract a particular kind of buyer, said Mr. Friedman's brother, Joel, a partner in the business. "What distinguishes us is the abundance of lakes we have and natural beauty," he said. The residential properties are part of a state park, with six million acres of mostly untouched wilderness, with little development.
"Everything's in its natural state here," said Joel Friedman. "You have to like the outdoors. Buyers up here are more conservative, not as tied in to the stock market and interest rates. They're buying a dream."
David Smith and his wife, Mary, decided to buy a house on Paradox Lake after visiting last summer. "It was the Fourth of July weekend, and there were maybe three boats on the water," Mr. Smith said. "We thought, 'Wow, we're less than four hours from Manhattan and look at this,' "
THE couple bought a three-bedroom, ranch with a knotty pine great room and an 8- by 42-foot screened in porch, "which is important during black fly season," said Mr. Smith, who owns an insurance company in Manhattan.
"I was looking to spend about $200,000 and realized that this same house would be $450,000 on Lake George or Bolton's Landing," he said. "Even if I could have afforded it I wouldn't have wanted those areas because they are insanely busy in the summers and one thing we definitely wanted was peace and quiet."
The commute to the Adirondacks can be off-putting to some, but some actually find it restorative. "When I turn off the Northway and the trees come together over my car," said Emilio Locascio, a Yonkers contractor who owns a house on Schroon Lake, "I feel like I'm entering the enchanted forest."
On most Fridays, the ride takes him about 3 hours and 40 minutes, he said. "The 40 minutes you drive past Lake George is the price you pay for privacy."
In the five-lake region, only Schroon Lake has a downtown, a main street with one supermarket, a convenience store and a few other shops. "For so long Schroon Lake was considered primarily a summer resort," Roger Friedman said. "But now people are discovering it for winter recreation as well." Just this year, the only movie theater in town installed its first heating system.
Such rustic surroundings don't appeal to everyone, which is why some buyers prefer to stay closer to New York City, where the market for second homes has been booming. From the mid-90's, the second-home market in Columbia County has improved between 30 and 50 percent in the areas that are considered the most popular, said Esther Anderson, who owns a real estate agency in Kinderhook, N.Y..
"People are primarily interested in the southern section of the county," she said. "There's also interest in the eastern section bordering Massachusetts. Most people don't want to go north of Kinderhook."
"Inventory is so low that people are now buying properties that have languished on the market for years because they need work, or they're on the main roads," she continued. "Most people want homes priced between $200,000 and $500,000. Bidding wars are common now."
Sales in Litchfield County, Conn., were up 20 percent in 1998 over the previous year, according to Elyse Harney, who owns a real estate agency in Salisbury.
"It was the best selling year in 10 years, since we came out of the 1987 slump," Ms. Harney said. "In 1997 things started to sell and it hasn't slowed down."
Most houses go for $300,000 to $500,000, she said, although it's possible to get something for less. One current listing is for a converted schoolhouse in Norfolk, Conn., with three bedrooms, two baths and cathedral ceilings on 3.4 acres. It is priced at $195,000.
Another area that has benefited from its proximity to Manhattan is Westchester County, where the second-home market has picked up in recent years, according to Ebie Wood, manager of the Pound Ridge office of Houlihan/Lawrence. "Some of our communities, such as Pound Ridge and Bedford, even though they're only one hour from Manhattan, are completely different environments," Ms. Wood said. "It's an alternative from the Hamptons. We're getting people who couldn't stand the commute."
People looking for a second home in Westchester want a unique property with some acreage, Ms. Wood added, noting that the houses tend to start at $650,000 and go into the millions. Second-home buyers are "not looking for a traditional colonial," she said.
In Garrison and Cold Spring, in Putnam County, "60 percent or more of my customers come from the city and use the houses here as second homes," said Ms. Preusser, who owns a real estate agency in Garrison.
"Business is a third better than a year ago," she said. "It's hard to find anything below $350,000. We're also very low in the $500,000 to $700,000 categories. Then it jumps to $1 million and up."
In the Berkshires, brokers are getting a lot of requests for houses that sell for more than $3 million, said Charlotte Isaacs, who owns a real estate agency in Stockbridge, Mass. "Years ago we used to sell one or two in the $1 million-plus category," she said. "In the past year we've sold a dozen."
The high end has also been booming in the ocean communities. "It's wild here," said Cheryl Vetovick, manager of Diane Turton Realtors, in Spring Lake, N.J. "Most listings are staying on for only a week or two," said Ms. Vetovick, who sells mostly in Spring Lake, Sea Girt and Belmar. "Bidding wars are common. A house listed at $600,000 recently sold for $100,000 over the asking price. I haven't seen a market like this in the nine years I've managed the office."
Her office recently sold a house in Sea Girt for $3.9 million. "That's the highest house price we've ever had and it sold in 10 days," Ms. Vetovick said.
Million-dollar properties in Cape Cod have also started to move, according to Larry Peters, co-owner of Cape Shores Real Estate in Wellfleet, Mass. "Everyone, it seems, wants to be near the ocean," he said, "but there's not a whole lot left." Mr. Peters sells properties in Truro and Wellfleet. "We're seeing million-dollar all-cash deals," he said.
In recent years, New Yorkers have increasingly been opting for houses in coastal Rhode Island. "It's like we've been discovered," said Raymond Mott, owner of Properties Unlimited in Charlestown. "We have people coming in pounding their chests with money," Mr. Mott said. "They want something by the water, and we have nothing for them. It's a lot less active a mile away from the water. The price range of $300,000 to $500,000 seems to be the most comfortable zone for most people."
THE east end of Long Island seems almost impervious to the normal fluctuations of the market elsewhere. In the Town of Southampton, for instance, property sales totaled $822 million in 1997, and rose to $1.4 billion in 1998. "The market has gone up 1 to 1.5 percent per month during that time," said Tim Cunningham, president of Cunningham Real Estate in Southampton. "All price ranges are active. The buyers are in their early 30's to mid-50's, at the peak of their careers."
These days, he said, buyers are more particular about being on streets with little or no traffic and they tend to use the houses all year long, not just in summer. "They're making a high investment," Mr. Cunningham. "I guess they feel compelled to use it more."
Sales so far this year have also been healthy on Fire Island, said Rose Ann Larson, who has an agency in Saltaire and also sells in Kismet. "In the last 12 years, sales were a little bit late, at the end of the season," Ms. Larson said. "Sales have already started this year. All price categories are moving, from a low of $225,000 to over $1 million."
While Bucks County, Pa., doesn't have the ocean, it does have the Delaware River and canals, and is a 75-minute commute from midtown Manhattan. "It's been a wonderful market," said Troy Baker, director of sales for Kurfiss Real Estate in New Hope, Pa. "At the end of March, we did $60 million of business, which is exactly the same as the first half of last year."
The so-called "weekender," Mr. Baker said, wants acreage and a swimming pool. "The high end here is $1 million. Anything at the low end, or $200,000, hardly lasts a week," he said. "For that you'd get an attached duplex house or town house, not a single-family home. Most people want a three-bedroom single-family home with a couple of acres for $300,000."
People come to Bucks County for a rural feeling, the recreational opportunities of the Delaware River and the canals, Mr. Baker added. "We get a lot of artists and writers," he said. "We have the Bucks County Playhouse. Sally Jesse Raphael just sold her bed and breakfast, but still maintains a home here." Popular towns include New Hope and Solebury.
"New Yorkers are now also looking into the northern part of the county more than they used to," Mr. Baker said, "places like Durham and Riegelsville. Nine months out of the year we have mild weather. It's a very short winter here.
"We're not for the winter-sports enthusiasts. But if you love canals and recreating by a river, then this is your place."

HEADLINE: WORKING;
First Strikes Against Bias

BYLINE: By MICHELLE COTTLE; Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer.

 BODY:

Q. I am black and a middle manager at a large company. Before joining it several years ago, I made sure the company had strong anti-discrimination policies and rising numbers of black and Hispanic employees. But now it's apparent that members of racial minority groups are concentrated in departments like public relations and human resources, with limited prospects for promotion. Some colleagues are considering a group complaint to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Should I join them, or should I try to find a department that gives blacks the best chances? Or should I leave?
 
A. What you should do depends a great deal on what kind of person you are -- and what cost you are willing to pay -- because there really is no way forward without a price tag. 
 "Some people are revolutionaries," said Ralph Dechabert, director of diversity and employee relations at American President Lines, a shipping company based in Oakland, Calif. "When they perceive injustice, they voice displeasure, push overtly, try to kick in doors. Other people are reformers who say, 'I will work from within.' " The risk for revolutionaries is to find themselves marginalized; for reformers, to appear to have been co-opted.
Filing a complaint with the E.E.O.C. is the revolutionary's path. You will get your employer's attention, but it is often not the best first step.
Executives can "get into a defensive mode," said Kevin Bradley, diversity manager at R. R. Donnelley & Sons, the commercial printer in Chicago, which was sued by a group of African-American former employees in 1996 over allegations of discrimination in layoffs and transfers. Once a threat of legal action is in the air, he said, opportunities to discuss the issue rationally and professionally are more limited.
Opening lines of communication and gathering information about the problem -- the reformer's path -- is generally a smarter way to start, said Mr. Bradley, who advised finding both minority and nonminority managers with whom you feel comfortable airing concerns. "Talk to people who have been in the trenches and may be able to help you," he said.
On a personal level, if you feel undervalued for whatever reason, you may want to transfer to another department. But gravitating toward bosses who are seen as giving blacks the best opportunities may be what caused the imbalance in the first place. Rather than being shunted there deliberately by the company, employees may be choosing to work in peripheral departments because that's where the most enlightened bosses are. Consider whether a move to a more supportive department is "putting you in the mainstream or taking you out," Mr. Dechabert said. "Then decide if you're willing to make that kind of trade-off."
Of course, you can leave the company, but even that has a price. A common corporate excuse for falling short of diversity goals is a lack of good candidates in the pipeline, Mr. Dechabert said. "If you move on," he said, "you make that real."
 
Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer. Each week, she responds to readers' questions about career and workplace issues. Send them by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
Capturing Ears on the Internet

BYLINE: By ALEC FOEGE

 BODY:
"HELL'S BELLS," a raucous anthem by the rock group AC/DC, blared from loudspeakers as Michael Robertson, the chief executive of MP3.com, walked to the podium. It seemed an unlikely introduction at last month's New York Music and Internet Expo for a man who wore a conservative camel hair sports jacket -- and who had an evangelical Christian background.
Yet after his keynote speech, Mr. Robertson, a 32-year-old entrepreneur with blond surfer looks, received warm handshakes from teen-agers with nose rings and hip-hop artists in baggy jeans. In the 16 months since he started his San Diego-based business, which distributes music over the Internet with a digital compression technology known as MP3, Mr. Robertson has been embraced by struggling musicians as a fellow revolutionary. 
 Even though he says he really isn't.
"I'm no revolutionary, I'm a purebred capitalist," Mr. Robertson said later. "I'm just talking about a new way of delivering music."
Still, Mr. Robertson is hoping that his outsider reputation will be a plus. When he introduced his service, which enables musicians to distribute their music cheaply over the Internet, he was virtually ignored by top labels. But now that MP3.com offers free music from 7,000 artists and gets 250,000 visitors a day, the labels, as well as investors, are noticing. That brand recognition should come in handy on Tuesday, when Microsoft will introduce a rival music site and its own compression software, MS-Audio.
Mr. Robertson says he doesn't worry much about competition, even if it's Microsoft. Over takeout chicken and french fries in his New York hotel room, he asserted that in the Internet world, timing and instincts could be as valuable as capital. It is a lesson he says he learned observing his idol, Steven P. Jobs.
"He did it with Apple; he did it with Pixar," Mr. Robertson said. "I've got a lot of respect for him because he zigged when everybody else zagged, and that's what we're doing."
MP3.com began two and a half years ago as the Z Company, a Yahoo-style search engine founded by Mr. Robertson. In October 1997, Greg Flores, now MP3.com's director of sales, showed the MP3 software to Mr. Robertson, who was impressed enough to buy the rights to the MP3.com domain name and to rename his company.
At that point, MP3.com had four employees, including Mr. Robertson, working out of their homes. Last summer, it expanded into a 1,000-square-foot loft. "We had this sign up for new employees," he recalled. "It was the steps you had to do to join the company: Order chair. Put chair together. Order desk. Put desk together." The business has since moved to a larger office and employs about 35 people.
For now, Mr. Robertson's gamble appears to have paid off. In January, Sequoia Capital, a venture capital firm, invested $10 million in the company. Then Tom Petty posted a new song on MP3.com to promote an album. At the end of March, Theodore W. Waitt, chief executive of Gateway, signed on to MP3.com's board. The computer mainstream has, in effect, signaled that Michael Robertson is the leader in his field.
Musicians also like Mr. Robertson's enterprise, which uses free music as a lure to sell compact disks, because he pays a generous 50 percent royalty rate. He can pay more than the 7 to 10 percent offered by record labels because he has none of their overhead or distribution costs and he pays no advances. Like other commercial sites offering free downloads, MP3.com makes money selling advertising and marketing information about its visitors.
Skeptics argue that Mr. Robertson has not built a viable business model and that any free download policy can facilitate piracy. "If he sells music, more power to him," said Hilary Rosen, chief executive and president of the Recording Industry Association of America. "I think it's the notion that music can be given away for free forever and there not be a return that is the economic joke."
But observers like Ken Hertz, a partner in the law firm Hansen, Jacobson, Teller & Hoberman, which represents popular acts like Alanis Morissette and No Doubt, said the association was misinterpreting Mr. Robertson's intentions. "Michael Robertson is not interested in being in the record business," Mr. Hertz said.
Mr. Robertson is the first to say that he is a music industry novice. Before starting MP3.com, his main music credential was playing clarinet in his high school band in Huntington Beach, Calif. He grew up in a working-class, fundamentalist household -- his late father was a handyman -- where listening to popular music was discouraged. He graduated from the University of California at San Diego in 1990 with a degree in cognitive science.
After college, he started a computer consulting firm and later sold software tools he had developed. Looking to expand, he started Media Minds, which sold digital-camera software -- a business that ultimately failed. To start MP3.com, Mr. Robertson, who is married with two young children, took out a second mortgage on his San Diego home. Before getting capital from Sequoia, he said, MP3.com made a modest profit.
These days, he spends most of his time traveling to meet with investment bankers, artist organizations and other Internet companies.
Mr. Robertson anticipates a battle between his company and the recording labels, something that has not been cause for concern so far. "I don't have any friends in the music industry," he said, "so I didn't have to worry about upsetting anybody."

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
Help for the Chutzpah-Challenged

BYLINE: By MARCIA VICKERS

 BODY:
BARRY GREENBLATT, a 911 supervisor for the New York Police Department, was standing in front of a class of eight, somewhat anxiously describing a science show he had watched on television the night before. He fidgeted momentarily and stuttered slightly. Then Mr. Greenblatt was asked to walk across the room in front of everyone.
"How did that feel?" asked the instructor, Charles di Cagno. 
 "I'd say it was a 4," Mr. Greenblatt said. That's 4 on a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 signifying the most intense feelings of social anxiety. But the other participants in this Upper West Side support group said he didn't seem all that nervous.
"I've been pretty shy all my life," said Mr. Greenblatt, 39, who grew up in Queens. "It's hard for me to get dates and to be assertive on the job. I have to force myself not to be overly polite."
In a city famous for brusque waiters, crude cabbies and Howard Stern, there also exists the chutzpah-challenged. "Shy people are just as common in New York as in any other place; you just might not notice them as much," said Dr. Diane Britton, a Manhattan psychologist, whose ad in The New York Observer says she offers counseling on "shyness, conversation skills and dealing with aggressive New Yorkers."
Some 50 percent of Americans consider themselves chronically shy, according to the Shyness Research Institute at Indiana University Southeast. And New York appears to have its fair share, judging from the various programs in the city that offer solace and schooling on the subject.
At the Learning Annex, an adult education center in Manhattan, one of the most popular classes is called "Are You Shy? Is It Holding You Back? How to Live Successfully in an Aggressive World." Another class being offered is "Dating Strategies for Shy New York Singles." There are at least three support groups for shy city dwellers, and therapists who specialize in treating shyness and social anxiety.
"In New York you've got so much coming at you," said Jonathan Berent, director of the Center for Shyness and Social Therapy in Great Neck, N.Y., and a psychotherapist who treats some shy people who live in the city. "It's more fast-paced and intense, so it can be difficult for shy people."
Mr. Berent, the author of "Beyond Shyness: How to Conquer Social Anxieties" (Simon & Schuster, 1994), said that in New York, it is easier for shy people to become anonymous. "There are more people to blend in with, more places to hide," he said.
The catch for shyness support groups, of course, is persuading the shy to attend. Mr. di Cagno, who has counseled shy New Yorkers for eight years, said, "I get a lot of calls from people who are interested, but they're afraid to show up, and many drop out after one or two sessions."
He said that 75 percent of his clients were women. "Men think if they admit they're shy, they're admitting weakness," Mr. di Cagno said. His workshop consists of 10 weekly sessions, costs $260 and offers what he calls "a supportive atmosphere and manageable steps." The steps include such things as standing and responding to simple questions from the group or describing a pet using gestures and movement.
Mr. di Cagno's students also do mock job interviews in front of one other. According to therapists who treat shy people, job interviews and work-related presentations are often big stumbling blocks.
"Especially in a city like New York, where the job market is so competitive and it's often difficult to move up in a job, interviewing and presentation skills can be crucial," said Dr. Bernardo Carducci, who teaches the courses for the shy at the Learning Annex and is the author of "Shyness: A Bold New Approach" (HarperCollins, 1999). "The shy are often at a disadvantage." In extreme cases, Dr. Carducci said, people remain unemployed for years because they are afraid to go on a job interview.
According to Dr. Britton, very shy people often end up working in such fields as computer programming or accounting, where they don't have to interact much with others. And often the timid miss out on promotions, raises and recognition, she said.
Still, some shy New Yorkers do work in intense, high-pressure environments. Charles, 47, a Wall Street investment banker, who spoke on condition that only his first name be used, said his shyness had almost caused him to lose his job. "I've always been somewhat shy," he said. "One negative result was that I was involved in a nasty political work situation and basically, I wasn't aggressive about it."
Soon after he was hired two years ago, Charles said, he realized he was being undermined by two senior managers who had applied for his job. Because he was afraid to confront the situation head-on, his performance wavered. His boss put him on probation. Though he considered quitting Wall Street altogether, Charles said, "Shyness therapy made me realize that I needed to stay and fight it out." Using such tactics as not viewing the situation too personally and focusing on his work rather than on the situation helped him. He has since gotten positive performance reviews, he said, and gained a solid foothold in the company.
Kelly, 28, who also would speak only on condition that her last name not be used, has a job one would not normally associate with a shy person: exotic dancer at a Manhattan nightclub. Kelly said she has been in a shyness support group as well as individual therapy for two years. As a result of her efforts to overcome her timidity, she said, she took to the spotlight a year ago.
"I'm incredibly shy in most one-on-one or group situations, but I've found I don't feel shy when I perform," said Kelly, who worked as a dominatrix before becoming a dancer. "I'm acting a role. It's not really me, so I feel free," she said. Still, she said, she sometimes has trouble dealing with customers. "Sometimes it's hard for me to keep them in line," she said, adding that she is working on being "not afraid to complain or get mad."
Don Gabor, who teaches a class at the Seminar Center in Manhattan called "How to Overcome Nervousness and Speak Up in Any Situation" and is the author of "Talking With Confidence for the Painfully Shy" (Crown, 1997) suggests these strategies for shy New Yorkers: Don't be shy about being the first person to strike up a conversation on the bus or subway. And greet people you see regularly, like neighbors. "Often New Yorkers seem disinterested or in too much of a hurry, but once you break the ice, they'll usually come around," he said.
Mr. Gabor also advises displaying a sense of humor. "New Yorkers are famous for their humor," he said. "Use it."
Finally, say those who counsel the shy, it's important to remember that though shyness can limit one's life experience, there's nothing inherently wrong with being bashful. "We could use a few more shy people in this world," Dr. Carducci said, "particularly in New York where everything is faster and louder and the greasy-wheel-gets-oiled mentality prevails."
Besides, he said, shy people bring a balance to society and their quiet demeanors can be a reminder of the need for civility. They also tend to be good listeners. And, Dr. Carducci said, "Heaven forbid we're all like Howard Stern."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo: Barry Greenblatt works for the Police Department and says it's hard for him to be assertive on the job. (Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "TESTIMONY: CITY SHY-STERS
 
Some prominent New Yorkers confess to being shy . . . or at least formerly shy. Most have found ways to transcend their reticence and often, turn it into an asset. Here are some examples:
 
Jane Alexander, actress and former chairwoman, National Endowment for the Arts
 "I took my cue from Eleanor Roosevelt . . . and accepted every public-speaking engagement asked of me. Over time I became relaxed speaking in front of groups and more easy-going with people generally."
 
Mario Cuomo, former Governor
 "Sometime after I became Governor my old elementary school sent me a copy of my first-grade report card. There was nothing special about it -- except that I was absent so much! I asked my mother why I had stayed home so many days. She said: 'You were afraid. You couldn't speak the language.' In the end, it was my public-school teachers that made all the difference because they didn't lose patience or mock me for being too slow."
 
Ray Romano, actor and standup comedian
 "My best performances have come at times when I was feeling the least confidence, constantly wondering, 'Am I good enough?' 'Did I do this right?' 'Should I do this?' . . .
 "There is a certain shyness in every great performer. Self-doubt, shyness, lack of confidence -- these are all ingredients for greatness."
 
Gloria Steinem, feminist and author
 "I am far from naturally confident. But I realized that male-dominant cultures direct a lack of self-confidence into women, even defining it as feminine. Women . . . have to band together and work to erect an equal confidence."
 
Gay Talese, journalist and author
 "When I was in high school, I was very shy. The way I could (and did) indulge my curiosity most effectively was through my job on the school newspaper. Journalism is ideally suited to people who are both curious and shy; it affords such individuals a license to ask questions and expect answers -- even to questions that, in any other circumstance, would get the interrogator a bop on the nose."
(Source: "How I Overcame Shyness," compiled and edited by Gary Simon (Fireside Books, 1999))

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Whiskey Rare as Fine Wine?

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
A BROKEN barrel stave found in the 1970's. Britain's wartime energy pinch. What could such historical flotsam have to do with modern American liquor chic?
Ask the drinkers who pay up to $980 to taste one shot of fine single-malt whiskey. Their palates and wallets, and their interest in the curious origins of some of their favorite tipples, have set off a scramble by Scottish distillers and their American marketers to uncover ever rarer, more exotic single malts. Unlike blended whiskeys, single malts are those produced in a single distillery in a single production run. 
 Single-malt drinking has become something between a mini-boom and a cult phenomenon in some American bars, and the most prized bottles can be as avidly pursued by as fine old Bordeaux: the Macallan '46, for instance, is sold (mainly to collectors) at $2,500 a bottle, and the Bowmore 40 -- referring to its age, not a year -- brings $7,000.
The cachet of top single malts like these rubs off on sibling whiskies. "In marketing jargon, it's the halo effect," said David Cox, marketing controller for the Macallan brand at Highland Distillers. "It elevates the quality image of the whole range."
Scarcity is part of the appeal. "People love the fact that it can never happen again," said James French, of Remy Amerique, the unit of Remy Cointreau that markets the Macallan in the United States. "Once you've got a bottle of that, there's no more left." The Macallan distillery turns out 220,000 12-bottle cases a year these days, but only 250 cases were ever made of the Macallan '46 -- and 150 of them were exported, mostly to the United States.
The Bowmore 40, produced by Morrison Bowmore Distillers, is even rarer. Just 294 bottles were produced, said Anne Riives, who handles the company's public relations in New York, and only 60 were shipped to America. Burglars stole a bottle from a Canadian store, Ms. Riives said, and told the owner, " 'Pay us $3,000 or the bottle gets it.' " The store did not pay and the whiskey was not returned.
Collectors buy by the bottle, but drinkers buy by the shot, at astonishing prices. A shot of Bowmore 40 fetches $980 at the Hole in One bar on Second Avenue in Manhattan; other rare malts cost up to $385 a shot, and the Macallan '46 usually runs to $250.
Who is paying those prices for a single drink? Recent recipients of fat Wall Street bonuses are often cited. "It's the result of a very healthy economy for six years," said Michael Stoner, of Schieffelin & Somerset, which markets the huge United Distillers and Vintners line in the United States. "This is an indulgence that people can afford."
COMING at a time when Americans are buying less imported blended whiskey, the high-end single-malt phenomenon has distillers hunting for ever more arcane whiskies to offer. "There has been an enormous proliferation of expensive, rare bottlings," Mr. Stoner said. But though the special bottlings grab the headlines, the single malts selling for $30 to $60 a bottle drive the market.
 From 1992 to 1997, imports of leading single-malt Scotch whiskies almost doubled, to the equivalent of 512,000 nine-liter cases, according to the Adams Liquor Handbook; the much larger volume of blended Scotch imports fell 2 percent.
Experts don't think drinkers of blended Scotch are switching to single malts. "They are not the same guys," Mr. Stoner said. "The single malt game is 25- to 50-year-olds coming in without drinking Scotch," or perhaps any whiskey, before. If blended Scotch is associated with run-of-the-mill watering holes, single malts evoke upscale spots where a shot is accompanied by a fine cigar or, at least, a discussion of the whiskey's pedigree.
"There's a fair amount of ritual that goes along with it," Mr. Stoner said. "The first sip is so important: they look and smell it first, swirl it around and they love the ritual of it. For a moment there, they are very alone with their favorite malt."
Single-malt whiskies are usually aged in wooden casks previously used for other beverages, most often Spanish sherry or bourbon. Distillers now try to invent new candidates for special single-malt bottlings by shifting liquor among different combinations of casks as it ages. But the top single malts got their special characteristics largely by chance.
While taking inventory in late 1997, David Robertson, Macallan's whiskey maker, found six vats that had been aging unnoticed since 1946. On tasting it, he found a remarkable smoky "nose," Mr. Cox said, which was traced to a short-lived wartime switch to burning peat for fuel in the distillery when coal was rationed.
The Bowmore 40 was another accident. "When it was made, nobody had any intention of keeping it for 40 years," Ms. Riives said. But, 20 years into its maturing, an apprentice cooper, Jim McEwan, discovered a broken stave on a sherry cask full of whiskey. He salvaged what he could and put it in a bourbon hogshead.
His career took him away from the distillery, and the switched barrel was overlooked for another two decades, until Mr. McEwan returned to Bowmore as general manager and recognized his handiwork.
"It tastes absolutely amazing," Ms. Riives said. "At the end you get a little whiff of spice. If anything, it's exotic tropical fruit.
"The whole thing was a complete fluke."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
In Papers, Making White Excite

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
CAN Great White really do for printer paper what Frank Perdue did for chicken? Can Xerox persuade consumers that a paper by any other name would not print as sweet? Does the public believe that one company's sheet of white stuff is all that different from another's?
Apparently, the answers are yes, yes and yes. "Consumers are not as sophisticated as corporations when it comes to paper, and branding is what they rely on most," said David C. Rocheleau, a director of the Supplies Advisory Service at Lyra Research, a market analysis firm in Newton, Mass. 
 As a result, the consumer paper market, once a quiet backwater, is now burning with high-wattage advertising and branding campaigns. Forest products companies long accustomed to business-to-business marketing have had to learn all about in-store promotions, flashy package design, even the economics of national television campaigns.
"For the first time in this industry's history, you're seeing office papers on TV," said Michael Winters, a national sales manager for the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, which will be eclipsed as the country's largest cut-paper producer at the end of this month when International Paper and Union Camp complete their merger.
It is easy to see the retail market's allure. These days, even the cheapest new printers can produce attractive greeting cards, brochures, presentations and photographs -- but not on plain-vanilla, penny-a-sheet paper. The fancy coated papers that give the best results can retail for as much as $1.50 a sheet; paper makers' margins on such sheets are a guarded industry secret, but they are certainly higher than those on the copier paper that corporations buy by the palletful. High margins and quality distinctions are the classic recipe for a market ripe for building brand names, even on commodity products.
The prices for the high-end papers are not scaring consumers. According to Lyra Research, the overall market for cut paper is growing at an annual rate of only 3.8 percent. But sales are climbing 11.1 percent a year in the SOHO market -- the initials stand for small office-home office, but marketers often use the term for all sales to consumers and small businesses. And branded papers are selling best.
"In the retail arena, brand identity is what separates the survivors from the losers," said Jack Plomgren, president of the Union Camp Corporation's Great White Consumer Products Group, which makes Great White papers.
The printer companies, engaged in fierce competition themselves, have also caught on to the trend. Companies like Xerox and Hewlett-Packard welcome any chance to plunk their names in a consumer's sight line -- particularly if they can profit along the way. So they, too, are peppering the shelves at Office Depot, Staples and other stores with branded specialty papers.
"Xerox-branded paper enhances awareness of our overall brand," said James Lesco, president of Xerox's supplies group. He said Xerox's paper sales to the SOHO market grew 35 percent last year.
The printer companies haven't bought or built paper mills; the paper they sell is made for them by the same paper companies whose branded products compete with theirs in the stores. But the printer companies say their offerings still have an advantage: Because their hardware, ink, toner and paper specialists are on the same product development teams, they say, paper manufactured to their specifications, and bearing their name, will give the best results on their printers.
"Other companies can only guess at what our ink formulation is going to be," said Susan M. Schindelar, marketing manager for Hewlett-Packard's Inkjet Media division, who added that paper "is definitely growing in importance to our top and bottom lines."
IT'S also growing more visible in stores, where competition has transformed the once-staid printer-paper aisles. Gone are the days when white paper came wrapped in white paper; most companies now use splashy colors to catch the eye. And several pack their highest-quality paper in clear shrink wrap to show off its brightness.
Few of the packaging choices are haphazard. Georgia-Pacific's new line of Microprint photographic-quality printer paper comes in a bright yellow package because "packaging consultants said bright yellow would be associated with Kodak yellow, and that would give us great brand awareness," Mr. Winters said.
Until recently, research showed that men bought most home-office supplies, so Great White tried to appeal to its customers' macho side with a package that bore a shark baring a mouthful of sharp teeth. But now that women are buying close to half of all office supplies, Great White has made its shark much less ferocious. "We've softened the teeth, and we're focusing on the fin," Mr. Plomgren said.
Nor are the brand names chosen willy-nilly. Indeed, many companies shove aside corporate egos and venerable trademarks when they believe a fresh new name would do better with consumers.
Georgia-Pacific, which until recently put its corporate name on all of its consumer papers, chose the name Microprint for its most expensive coated papers "because we wanted a brand name with a high-tech sound to it," Mr. Winters said.
Great White, itself a nom de papier for a company few consumers know, decided that even detoothed sharks might not appeal to children, so it licensed the Crayola name for new, brightly colored papers for party banners, stickers and T-shirt transfers.
Hewlett-Packard has made perhaps the ultimate ego sacrifice: it's sharing the logo glory with others. Its photo-quality paper packaging trumpets that it is made for Hewlett by Eastman Kodak, and its new line of restickable paper shares branding with Post-It notes. "In photography, we knew that Kodak's name would enhance the appeal, and most everyone knows what a Post-It note is," Ms. Schindelar said.
International Paper, meanwhile, is ruefully recognizing that its Hammermill brand, long associated with classy writing paper, is not sending the right message for more fanciful uses. So, while it still markets printer paper as Hammermill, that name does not appear on Jetprint Photo papers, Invent-It greeting-card paper, or other products meant more for fun than work.
"We want to appeal directly to the consumer's playful side," said Kenneth J. Krieg, the company's business manager for office papers, "but we don't want to water down the Hammermill name."

HEADLINE: The World: Lonely Hearts;
Libya Wearies of the Cold Shoulder

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
HIGHLY placed visitors invited lately to the palatial desert tent of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi sensed in the Libyan leader's conversation a yearning to be readmitted to the world. Me, a terrorist? he would plead. Of course, he was always an unpredictable loner and he did spend decades bankrolling revolutionaries and guerrilla leaders, especially in Africa. But why are they -- now often heads of government just as he is -- getting all the invitations to London and Washington while he is left stranded in the sand?
Arabs, Africans, a procession of international lawyers and Kofi Annan, the Secretary General of the United Nations, have been telling Colonel Qaddafi for months that only he can end his isolation, by turning over for trial two Libyan intelligence agents accused of masterminding the bombing of Pan Am 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in December 1988, an attack that killed 280 people. Last week, running out of hope for any further concessions from Britain and the United States, Colonel Qaddafi finally agreed to deliver the suspects to a former military base in the Netherlands, where they will be tried under Scottish law. 
 Was it Libya's oil-dependent economy, in a tailspin because of world petroleum prices, that did it? Was it threats from Washington that things could get worse for Tripoli if there was not a break in the decadelong standoff? Was it that Colonel Qaddafi's options had run out and that, like Saddam Hussein, he had failed to persuade his Arab neighbors to defy international law and break sanctions on his behalf? Or was his search for a new kind of Arab nationalism, rooted in the 1950's and 60's, hopelessly out of date, rendering him an irritant as well as an anomaly in the Arab world?
No one explanation seems to suffice, say those who have dealt with the Libyan leader.
In the end, the once-flamboyant Colonel Qaddafi -- who spent much of last year in a wheelchair, on crutches or leaning on a cane after what he brushed off as broken bones but what his critics suspect may have been an ambush or attempted assassination -- had to battle his own secret demons. A quixotic leader who 30 years ago transformed an Arab monarchy into something he chose to call the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, or state of the masses, Colonel Qaddafi took a political risk in turning over two citizens to foreign powers he had spent years vilifying as enemies of his people.
"It was a very important step," said Hussein Hassouna, the Arab League's representative at the United Nations. "It will change everything in the region." Arabs say Colonel Qaddafi was aware he had boxed himself in with his refusal to cooperate in the Lockerbie case and was being bypassed by developments in the Arab world and the Mediterranean, where links between North Africa and the European Union are expanding.
"Everybody said to him, 'Once you take that step, it will open up a lot of potential; you have a lot to gain,' " Mr. Hassouna said. Investors and tourists alike seem poised to pounce on the novelty of Libya, a Mediterranean nation with historical sites as old as Phoenicia.
MORE important than advice, however, were the cover and strong shoulders to lean on that Arab leaders, Mr. Annan and President Nelson Mandela of South Africa gave Colonel Qaddafi. Mr. Mandela went to Libya more than a year ago (to the annoyance of Washington) and honored Colonel Qaddafi with South Africa's highest award for Libya's assistance to the African National Congress during the long years of apartheid. With trust established, Mr. Mandela was able to play a major role -- later to be joined by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia -- in persuading Colonel Qaddafi to accept the creative Arab proposal that the two Libyan agents be tried in a third country.
"It was easier to accede to the urging of Mandela than to be seen to be surrendering to the United States," said Thomas Franck, director of the Center for International Studies at the New York University Law School. "The main task in arranging an outcome like this is to find a way that one of the most eccentric of leaders can climb down the tree he's climbed up without appearing to be giving in."
Clovis Maksoud, a former representative of the Arab League at the United Nations and now director of the Center for the Global South at American University in Washington, said: "Mandela assumed a fatherly approach. Mandela said, 'He helped us in the past, and we will help him now.' "
Contrary to suggestions that Colonel Qaddafi stalled because he feared a foreign court he could not control, Professor Franck said the Libyan leader has been one of the most frequent users of the International Court of Justice in the Hague (unrelated to the specially created Scottish panel that will try the Libyans) and has abided by its rulings -- not a claim that can be made by Washington. The Libyans allowed the international court, better known as the World Court, to adjudicate sea rights in a dispute with Tunisia and Malta, and also obeyed the court's order to return to Chad a strip of territory fought over in a long and costly war.
Last week, international sanctions on Libya, though not separate American restrictions on travel and trade, were suspended as promised. As a result, Libya is now free -- assuming the suspension becomes permanent in 90 days -- to reopen airline links with the rest of the world, upgrade its oil industry, rebuild a decrepit communications system, construct a railroad and pursue other long-delayed development projects with the help of foreign investors.
Yet people who have dealt with Colonel Qaddafi say it was not economic considerations alone that made a settlement possible. The Libyan leader is too complex for that.
Sanctions on Libya, imposed in 1992 and widened in 1993, bit into the economy, but not too hard. Unlike Iraq, Libya was able to continue selling oil and gas, its big money earners, and spend the money on anything it chose except arms and certain equipment for the petroleum industry.
NOR was Washington's threat of wider sanctions crucial, since it was assumed that the Clinton Administration would find it hard to persuade the Security Council to take such a step, given Washington's growing alienation from the United Nations and a general wariness there about the long-term wisdom of embargoes, with their unfortunate side effects on civilians. Moreover, the United States is deeply involved in Kosovo and monitoring a critical Israeli election and an unfinished war in Iraq, among other crises. So Libya has slipped down the scale of policy concerns.
A need to end his isolation and salvage his place in history may have been the most important factor to Colonel Qaddafi.
"He has definitely got out of the cage he was in," Mr. Maksoud said. "But it is not a defeat for him or a triumph for the Americans."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
On Interest Rates, Don't Let the Data Lull You

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
INVESTORS worried about rising interest rates were calmed recently by news of a decline in manufacturing jobs in March and a slowdown in the rise of average hourly earnings, a key measure of inflationary pressures.
The decline in manufacturing jobs offset the "bad news" of the strong rebound in the level of manufacturing, as measured by the National Association of Purchasing Management. Last month, its manufacturing index jumped to 54.30, its highest level since November 1997. Initially, the surge was taken as a sign of a rebound in American manufacturing, which would make it less likely that the economy could slow to the sustainable pace sought by the Federal Reserve without an increase in interest rates. 
 The slowdown in the pace of wage increases helped relieve another fear, that pressure here would become too much for the Federal Reserve, even though there are few signs now that companies can pass along the cost of these increases as higher prices.
That relief, coming on two fronts, helped set off a nice rally in the bond market, bringing the yield on the 30-year bond down to 5.46 percent on Friday from 5.67 percent on April 1, the day before the March jobs data were released. And that rally helped lift the stock market, with the three major gauges -- the Dow Jones industrial average, the S.& P. 500 and the Nasdaq composite -- repeatedly reaching new highs last week.
But investors may be taking more comfort from this new data than they should.
Over the last decade, there has been a pretty good correlation between the movement of the purchasing management manufacturing index and long-term interest rates adjusted for inflation. Right now, that index is pointing to a sharp rise in long-term rates -- into 6 percent territory -- according to Robert J. Barbera, the chief economist at Hoenig & Company in Rye Brook, N.Y.
Mr. Barbera agreed that the decline in manufacturing jobs and the continued weakness in industrial production may mean that that the purchasing management index is sending a false signal. But he said weekly jobless claims, which have remained below 300,000 for 10 weeks, are a signal of strength.
And he argues that if the global economy, especially Asia's, begins to rebound, a recovery in American manufacturing is even more certain. The cut in official interest rates on Thursday by the Bank of England and the new European Central Bank just add to the likelihood that a rebound in global economic growth will give another boost to the United States economy.
"The hard part is guessing what will happen to global momentum," Mr. Barbera said. But if it is picking up, then the past correlation between the purchasing management index and interest rates is far more worrisome for American investors.
Mr. Barbera also has a doubt about the deceleration in average hourly earnings. He agrees that the pace of growth has declined, to 3.6 percent last month from 4.4 percent in April 1998. But he says the underlying data show that the rise of earnings in the service sector is actually accelerating. What has slowed the overall pace is a sharp decline in the growth rate for manufacturing.
But, again, if the purchasing management index is right -- and the bet on a global turnaround is correct -- that trend will also reverse, adding to the pressure on wages.
ALL these trends will be watched closely by Fed policy makers, who next meet in May. If Mr. Barbera is right in his bets, the Fed could be in a tight spot.
Going into this year, policy makers were betting on a growth slowdown to bring the pace of the economy to a sustainable rate that would not add to inflationary pressures.
But even the Fed is acknowledging that the economy will be much stronger than it expected. In the minutes of the February meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, released a week ago, Fed governors and Federal Reserve Bank presidents said it was now possible that the economy, even after slowing from the breakneck annual growth rate of 6 percent in the fourth quarter, could still be running ahead of the central bank's sustainable pace of around 2.5 percent.
That means the Fed will be more likely to lean toward higher interest rates -- and Mr. Barbera's interest rate indicator, which is clearly pointing higher, will be right.
