HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
A Doctorate Too Dry For Its Own Good?

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
THE Depression inspired thousands of young people to become economists. The War on Poverty and the Great Society in the 60's were similarly inspiring, and the upheavals today should be, too. What more noble work, after all, than coming to understand, and perhaps alleviate, the wage stagnation, the global pressures, the layoffs, the job insecurities and the long working days that weigh on so many people.
But, in fact, fewer and fewer Americans are entering graduate programs and seeking careers in economics. 
 The Depression made a hero of John Maynard Keynes, the British economist whose prescriptions for reviving the economy -- and softening capitalism -- seemed so promising and insightful, even romantic. And out of the crowded graduate schools of that era came future giants like Paul Samuelson, Milton Friedman, James Tobin and John Kenneth Galbraith. They are all in their 80's and 90's now, and no longer the role models they were in their heyday.
Who are today's heroes? Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman so often given credit for the current prosperity, is one. So are Lawrence H. Summers, the combative Deputy Treasury Secretary and former Harvard whiz, and Paul Krugman, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor whose fame comes as much from his vivid, prolific writing in newspapers and magazines as it does from his economics. But somehow, they aren't Pied Pipers.
IS it them or the times? Could Keynes do any better if he were resurrected today? Or Adam Smith, who was a popular lecturer and teacher with a wide following? Probably not. The profession is so changed.
The Ph.D. program in economics today, combining a master's degree and a doctorate, calls for five to seven years of hard, technical work, harder perhaps than medical school. For bright young people, higher wages with much less study can be had in management, or consulting, or law, or on Wall Street. "I have a son who went to work right out of Harvard as a currency trader," said Angus S. Deaton, a Princeton economist and a mentor in his profession.
High wages, of course, would not divert a young idealist seeking to help the world through economics. But the graduate school training in economics, with its heavy emphasis on mathematics and mathematical modeling of abstract situations, does not relate easily to the issues of the day. The idealist, in sum, is too often put off.
A commission of august economists recognized this shortcoming in a 1991 report. It recommended more attention to "real-world linkages" -- a bit of advice that graduate schools have so far largely ignored.
"There is something about the nature of economics training that is driving off the student," Mark Blaug, an economics historian, said in a recent interview. "The training is technically demanding but does not seem to be related to anything out there."
The shortage of trained economists is still unfolding. More than 1,000 Ph.D.'s in economics are now granted annually in the United States, a 17 percent increase from 1986. But that is because, until recently, foreign students enrolled in large-enough numbers to more than offset the American decline. No longer: The number of new doctorates will begin to slip next year or the year after, because new enrollment in graduate programs has been falling since 1994.
And this despite the fact that economists are well paid in their first posts relative to other Ph.D's. The median starting salary was close to $75,000 for economics Ph.D.'s who took private-sector jobs last year, here and abroad, and roughly $50,000 for those who took academic posts, mainly as assistant professors. Only engineers are in the same ballpark.
These findings are laid out in a soon-to-be published article in the Journal of Economic Perspectives. The authors, John J. Siegfried of Vanderbilt University and Wendy Stock of Kansas State University, surveyed new Ph.D.'s at 91 universities.
But for economists who take private-sector jobs, money isn't everything. The typical graduate, 32 and married, spent 6.8 years in graduate school, only to land in a job that often underutilizes those hard-won skills. "They get paid a lot more than in academia, but they are grumpy," Mr. Siegfried said.
Americans, who now make up less than 45 percent of each year's graduating class, find the going tougher than foreign students do. The latter often have better preparation in the all-important math, and the prestige of an American doctorate opens all sorts of doors for them back home. The Americans find their training useful mainly in teaching and research, and academia has cut the number of these jobs that lead to tenure.
"People who 20 years ago might have chosen economics are now choosing law," said George Akerlof, an academic economist and a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. "One reason they are doing this: Economics has become a lot harder."
But in that direction might lie a solution, or a partial one. Economics, practical, nonmathematical economics, is increasingly practiced by lawyers and by people trained at graduate business schools or at public policy institutes -- training that belongs in the graduate schools that "license" economists. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LENGTH: 1088 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Sometimes a Tax Cut Can Be a Hard Sell

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THIS is the time of year just as Americans are grousing over their tax returns -- when Republicans and their allies try to stoke the flames of tax rebellion.
Come mid-April, they like to re-enact the Boston Tea Party, America's original tax revolt, or stage mock funerals for the tax code or toss the thick tomes that contain the nation's tax laws into trash cans. This year the National Federation of Independent Business, a lobbying group for small business, is planning to hand out aspirin at post offices to last-minute tax filers. 
 But these stunts seem only to highlight what's missing: the kind of grass-roots uprising that inspired California's Proposition 13 restrictions on property taxes and swept Ronald Reagan into office nearly two decades ago.
This public quiescence is puzzling to the proponents of tax relief who think that now more than ever it is the time for significant tax cutting or an overhaul of the tax code. They point to the fact that Federal tax receipts, which are estimated to reach $1.8 trillion by the end of the Federal fiscal year this October, will amount to 20.6 percent of the gross domestic product. That is a level unmatched since World War II. They also argue that the Federal surpluses that began appearing last year after a decade of deficits make the idea of sweeping tax cuts feasible again.
Americans, however, appear to have turned their political energies and interests elsewhere. It is not that they would reject a tax cut. A private poll that the National Republican Congressional Committee distributed to House Republicans at a retreat in February found that 67 percent of Americans favored a tax reduction of 10 percent across the board.
But voters seemed more ambivalent about tax cuts when they were asked how they wanted the Government to use the Federal surplus. Given a list of options, 31 percent of those polled said they wanted the money devoted to Social Security, 26 percent to reducing the national debt and only 18 percent to tax relief.
Congressional Republicans are now telling Americans they don't have to choose. They argue that the Republican budget plan for the new fiscal year will protect Social Security funds and still have money left over for tax cuts that grow to $800 billion over a decade.
Political analysts say it is economic expansion that has decreased the public interest in tax cutting. The unemployment rate is nearing a 29-year low and the flush times have left most Americans with money in their pockets and blunted the anti-Government animus.
"Anytime you have good times it makes it harder for tax cutters like myself and Republicans to make the case you're being bit in the wallet," said Stephen Moore, an economist with the Cato Institute, a conservative research center. "Ronald Reagan wouldn't have been elected in 1980 with the tax cut proposal if we weren't in a time of economic crisis."
But in charting the change in attitudes, it is also instructive to remember the nature of the 1970's economic crisis. That was when Gerald R. Ford made "Whip Inflation Now" his motto. When Howard Jarvis caught the imaginations of Californians and propelled Proposition 13 to victory in 1978, double-digit inflation was pushing taxpayers into higher brackets unaccompanied by any real increase in income. It was also increasing the assessed values of their homes -- prompting higher property taxes. The biggest victims were lower- and middle-income Americans, who could be easily moved into higher tax brackets.
IN response, Ronald Reagan's 1981 tax act not only cut taxes, it indexed tax brackets, adjusting them so that inflation alone would not push people into higher brackets even if they had seen no real increase in their income.
"Some of the irritants in the tax system, like inflation pushing people up through brackets, have been taken care of now," said Iris Lav, the deputy director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal non-profit research group.
In the 1990's, inflation nearly disappeared. And instead of viewing their home as their most important nest egg, many middle-class Americans are now relying on investments and 401k plans -- wealth that is not taxed until the stocks are sold.
Another reason for the lack of rebellion is that the tax burden is not shared equally. Because of the deficit reduction plans of 1990 and 1993, the rich are paying a larger share of Federal taxes than before. But the tax burden on the middle class and working class has decreased. Examining an array of taxes, the Congressional Budget Office found that the 20 percent of families at the middle of the nation's income scale earned an average income of $38,400 in 1995 and paid 20.2 percent of that in Federal taxes. This year, this group is projected to earn $45,100 on average and pay 18.4 percent.
Such tax trends have led Americans to look beyond the present. "We're in a period now where in a variety of fronts, particularly education, Social Security and Medicare, Americans actually want government to do something," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster. "They are not willing to sacrifice government's ability to deal with those problems for the sake of a tax cut."
The prosperity has even caused some Republicans to question the supply-siders, who still hold enormous intellectual sway in their party. "Republicans have always been dominated by supply-siders who said, 'cut taxes' at every possible moment," said Representative Joe Scarborough, a Florida Republican. "The lesson of '95 and '96 has been if you cut Federal spending, the markets respond, interest rates drop and the economy explodes that way, too.
"I don't know what you call that," Mr. Scarborough said. "It's not Keynesian. It's not supply side. Maybe its Greenspan economics."
Of course, even without a tax rebellion, it is likely that Congress will enact some kind of tax relief this year. President Clinton now uses the tax code as his chosen instrument of social policy instead of direct-spending programs. His budget proposed tax credits for child and health care amounting to $4.1 billion in tax reductions in fiscal 2000 and $32.6 billion over five years.
Republicans, who are determined to put new muscle in what has long been their signature issue, have proposed a modest $15 billion in tax cuts for 2000 growing to $800 billion over a decade.
"My rule of politics is nobody ever lost an election by cutting taxes," said Mr. Moore. "It's always a good bread-and-butter issue for the Republican Party."

HEADLINE: Bringing Markets To Milk

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN

 BODY:
PONDER a perverse question: What public policies would pummel the poor? Here is one answer: Impose a levy that falls more heavily on them than on the rich, singling out a staple in the diet of poor families and driving up its price.
No one would seriously entertain such an idea -- no one, that is, except members of Congress. 
 Federal milk-pricing rules dating from the 1930's drive up the price that consumers pay for milk, in effect taking money from urban parents, among others, and handing it over to rural dairy farmers.
Proponents say the rules stabilize milk prices, thereby assuring reliable supplies across the country. But opponents say the system is archaic, Byzantine and unnecessary -- a giveaway to the dairy farm lobby. And it's regressive: poor families spend about twice as much of their income on milk as do other families, on average.
Consumer advocates took heart three years ago when Congress told the Agriculture Department to improve the program. But their hopes were dashed recently when the department released its proposals, scheduled to go into effect on Oct. 1.
The new rules, the department said, would be "simpler, more market-oriented." But rather than taking a mallet to the program, the department wielded a toothpick. John M. Schnittker, an economist at Public Voice for Food and Health Policy, a nonprofit research group in Washington that plans to merge with the Consumer Federation of America, estimates that the current program raises the cost of milk an average of 18 cents a gallon. The department says its plan will cut prices by about 2 cents -- a trim Mr. Schnittker calls "almost an insult."
The current rules impose a complex set of minimum prices that processors are required to pay farmers in each of the 31 marketing regions.
The department starts by setting a base price for milk used in the manufacture of products like cheese from a survey of prices in Minnesota and Wisconsin. Then it tacks on additional charges, mostly reflecting location, to set the minimum price for so-called fluid milk.
Kenneth C. Clayton, deputy administrator of the agency that runs the system, says the controls stop milk prices from gyrating wildly and make sure that milk flows from areas where there are surplus supplies, like upstate New York and Wisconsin, to areas where there is scarcity, like Boston and Chicago.
But he concedes that those flows would occur without Government guidance. What the rules do, he says, is "divide up the pie -- insuring that diary farmers capture more of the dollar that consumers pay to processors." Another set of complex rules dictates how the processors' payments are divided among farmers.
Many economists challenge Mr. Clayton's benign interpretation. Processors operate in reasonably competitive markets, the economists say, so if they are forced to pay more for milk, they have little choice but to pass on the added cost to customers. Mr. Schnittker points to studies that show consumer prices rising along with Government-imposed charges on processors.
He also challenges another rationale for the milk-pricing rules: preservation of the family farmer. "Two-thirds of milk production comes from only about a quarter of the nation's dairy farmers," he said. "The milk-pricing rules overwhelmingly line the pockets of mega dairy farms."
The Government's overhaul would simplify things by collapsing the 31 regions into 11. But it would also make the system more complicated, by setting the base price for milk used in manufactured products according to surveys around the country, rather than just the Midwest, and by adjusting the price to take into account the milk's protein content and other qualities using complex mathematical formulas.
Add charges to take account of location and some transition rules, and out come 600-plus pages of regulations. Some economists suggest that the rule-making would fit comfortably in the playbook of the former Soviet Union.
And though the proposal would bring down average milk prices a small amount, it would leave most of the high prices intact. Indeed, the proposal would actually raise the minimum price in some places, like Chicago, a decision more political than economic.
Critics point out that this is not the first time the Agriculture Department has sided with dairy farmers over consumers. It also approved the creation of a dairy cartel among farmers in the Northeast that blocks low-price imports. Milk prices in New England rose about 20 cents a gallon after the compact went into effect in July 1997. The New York Legislature, yielding to pressure from upstate dairy farmers, has applied to Congress to join the cartel.
Connie Tipton, a senior official at the International Dairy Foods Association, a group of dairy processors, says the Government should have rethought the entire system. "Sixty years ago, it might have been hard for milk to flow from rural farms to heavily populated cities," she said. "Price spikes and supply shortages were potential threats. But modern transportation and refrigeration have wiped out that threat."

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Taxes 1999: Paying More Without Complaints

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
As the procrastinators among us prepare to send in our tax returns this week, there are a few certainties: Well-off people will be paying a lot, but the companies whose stock they own -- and whose success may have made those people rich -- will pay much less than they would have a generation ago.
That trend is an international one, reflecting the fact that in an increasingly global economy it is much easier for a company to pick up and move. Both states and nations are more likely now than ever before to reduce taxes as a lure to corporate employers. 
 "Even small variations in local tax rates may have important effects on capital flows and, by implication, on the economy as a whole," reported James Hines Jr., an economist now at the University of Michigan, after studying the flow of investment within this country.
In Europe, Ireland has achieved rapid growth by offering low corporate taxes. That infuriated Oskar Lafontaine, the former German Finance Minister who wanted to raise taxes on German business. Before he lost his job in a power struggle, he was pushing for "tax harmonization" within Europe as a way to force Ireland to raise its taxes.
Instead, with Mr. Lafontaine gone, Germany is likely to cut corporate tax rates while also reducing preferences that have allowed favored companies and industries to pay relatively low taxes while those in other industries are hit hard.
To be sure, at any given tax rate corporate income-tax payments fluctuate with the economy, falling in recessions and rising when business is good. American companies are expected to pay income taxes equal to 2.1 percent of the gross domestic product this year, up from 1.6 percent in the recession year of 1990.
But the overall trend can be seen more clearly by comparing the two longest economic expansions of American history -- the one from 1961 through 1969 and the current one, which began in 1991. During the 1960's boom, corporate income-tax collections peaked at 4.2 percent of G.D.P., twice the current level. But individual income-tax collections never got as high as the current figure, about 9.9 percent of G.D.P.
Just how you view the downward trend of corporate taxes depends on your politics. To many on the left, and some on the right, it demonstrates "corporate welfare" that lets powerful companies avoid paying their fair share. Most Congressional Republicans ignore the drop in corporate tax collections, however, while railing against the rising overall level of taxes.
But Republicans have been stunned to see how indifferent voters are to calls for tax cuts this year. In part, that reflects President Clinton's success in making those who call for lower taxes appear to be endangering Medicare and Social Security. But it also reflects the fact that changes in tax law have made it more certain that high-income taxpayers will pay more while moderate-income families are hit less. Thanks largely to the $500-per-child tax credit, a family of four earning the national median income now faces a lower effective tax rate than at any time since the 1960's.
In the current boom, the number of people with high incomes has soared. In 1992, just under a million tax returns showed adjusted gross income of more than $200,000. In 1996, the latest year for which figures are available, that number was up more than 50 percent, to 1.5 million.
The increase reflects surging capital gains and stock-option profits for corporate executives, and taxes on that income help to explain why tax receipts have been higher than expected in recent years.
For the Government, there is a risk in growing increasingly reliant on stock market-generated profits. If those profits stop coming, tax receipts could be surprisingly small. But for now, both the rich and the Government are raking in the cash.

HEADLINE: In America;
Senior Citizens on the Bread Line

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

 BODY:
Getting enough to eat has sometimes been a problem for Dolores Heuser. She lost an arm to cancer and her savings are gone. While much of America was experiencing an economic boom, she was making a demoralizing move from her comfortable home in the Phoenix suburb of Youngtown to a low-income residence in nearby El Mirage. Having reached her 70's ("I won't tell you exactly how old I am," she said), Ms. Heuser, a widow, frequently found herself without money for food.
"I was in a very bad situation," she said. "I only had Social Security coming in and I couldn't get by on that." 
 Hunger is an awful, debilitating companion. You can test this by missing a few meals. Ms. Heuser learned, like many thousands of other elderly citizens, that after her essential monthly expenses were paid, the money she would have spent on food had mostly vanished. She was helped through her crisis by donations of food distributed by the Second Harvest food-bank network.
"Without that, I don't know what I would have done," she said.
Scenes of poverty-stricken Americans standing in bread lines are standard in documentaries about the Depression, which ended more than half a century ago. What is not generally acknowledged -- perhaps not widely known -- is that there are bread lines all over the United States right now.
Early on Thursday morning older residents of El Mirage began lining up at a senior citizens center for donations of food provided by the West Side Food Bank in the neighboring town of Surprise. They did not discuss their portfolios or the surging Nasdaq. The heralded free-market economy had left them far behind.
"Well, this helps, you know," said Carol Lorig, who is 80. "I have to take care of my son, who's ill and can't work. We don't have enough money."
William Yakubik, who is 86, said: "You cut down the food if you have to. Eat less. The cost of living, you know how it is. Robbing Peter to pay Paul. Feast or famine."
Debbi Ennis, one of the directors of the food bank, said the elderly residents who line up for food supplies are especially vulnerable to unexpected expenses. "These are people who cannot afford food if they experience an illness and have to buy medicine, or if their car breaks down and has to be repaired, or if there is some kind of unexpected housing expense, like a leaking roof or a break-in. Then they are in serious trouble."
A study a few years ago by the Urban Institute, a research organization in Washington, found that nearly two million elderly Americans had faced at least one of two terrible dilemmas: whether to pay their rent or buy food, or whether to pay for medicine or buy food. Those are choices no American should have to make.
Referring to the nation's population as a whole, Doug O'Brien, the director of public policy and research at Second Harvest, said: "We are finding a great deal of pain and anxiety and some instances of malnutrition. Hunger is disguised in this country. It's not like it is in North Korea, where people have to eat grass, or in East Africa, where they just waste away. It's not life-threatening in most cases. But it is a serious, insidious problem that affects many million Americans.
"We have a hunger problem. And other Western industrialized nations do not have a hunger problem. And that is just not acceptable when we have such abundance."
Second Harvest is the largest nonprofit clearinghouse in the U.S. for donations to soup kitchens and food pantries. Officials said a recent comprehensive survey showed that over the course of a year, more than 21 million people sought emergency food assistance through the Second Harvest network. The officials stressed that the 21 million figure referred to separate individuals, not the total number of emergency meals served. And they said they believed that there were many more Americans, millions more, who did not have enough money to pay for an adequate diet.
Dolores Heuser, whose situation is typical, is resigned to her new circumstances. "I can't go to a lovely restaurant," she said. "I can't get my hair set anymore. But I am thankful for the assistance. I'll go on Monday for a food box."

HEADLINE: DATABANK: April 5-9;
Europeans Show Appetite for Lower Rates

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE

 BODY:
For rallying stock markets, it was just sugar on the creme brulee: The European Central Bank reduced interest rates on Thursday to one of the lowest levels European nations have ever seen.
 Stocks rose in London for the ninth day in 10 on Friday. The FTSE 100 ended the week 2.3 percent higher, closing at 6,472.80. Other European markets rose, too. The cut in the central bank's benchmark rate, to 2.5 percent from 3 percent, followed a smaller cut by the Bank of England. 
 David Kiddie, the head of European equity management at Hill Samuel Asset Management, told Bloomberg News on Friday that the rate cut was larger than expected. We're likely to see growth expectations pick up, Mr. Kiddie said. With interest rates at these levels, the outlook looks good.
 Shares of companies that rely on consumer spending, including Unilever and the EMI Group, benefited from the rate cuts.
 Key market gauges in the United States responded by surging to new highs. After some profit-taking on Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average ended the week up 3.4 percent, at 10,173.84. The Nasdaq gained 4 percent, to a record 2,593.05. MICKEY MEECE

HEADLINE: Recipients Of Welfare Are Fewest Since 1969

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10

 BODY:
President Clinton announced today that fewer people were on welfare than at any point in the last three decades.
Welfare caseloads have dropped by 4.6 million, or 38 percent, since Mr. Clinton signed the Republican-initiated overhaul of the welfare system into law in August 1996. There are now 7.6 million people on welfare, according to the Government's just-collected figures from December, down from 14.1 million when Mr. Clinton took office in January 1993. 
 As the nation's economy continues its expansion, the new welfare numbers, the lowest since 1969, not surprisingly coincide with record drops in unemployment -- to 4.2 percent in March, the lowest level in 29 years.
In announcing the new welfare figures in his weekly radio address, President Clinton said that the Federal Government had been doing its share to help move welfare recipients into the work force.
He said the Government had hired 12,000 welfare recipients in the last two years, surpassing the goal he set in March 1997 to hire 10,000 welfare recipients by September 2000. Private companies participating in the nonprofit Welfare to Work Partnership have hired more than 410,000 welfare recipients, he said.
Mr. Clinton said he wanted to continue to drive down the number of welfare recipients by implementing the final two rules that were part of the 1996 welfare law. These would hold states accountable for moving people off welfare, and make it easier for states to use their welfare block grants to pay for child care, transportation and other needs to help welfare recipients hold jobs.
More than half the states failed to use the full amounts of their Federal welfare grants last year. State officials have said that their welfare rolls dropped much faster than they anticipated, in part because of the strong economy, making it difficult for them to use all the Federal money they were entitled to. Others have admitted to just socking the money away to use in a recession.
All 50 states have reduced their welfare rolls since January 1993, with 29 states cutting their rolls by more than 50 percent.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Soft Money and Some Not-So-Hard Promises

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10

 BODY:
Bookshelves in the capital are sagging with countless handsomely bound, carefully researched, long-forgotten reports proposing laws and policies that, were they ever to be adopted, would affect millions of Americans.
One characteristic of these studies -- about Social Security, taxes, health policy, education and dozens of other areas -- is that the people who conduct them and make the recommendations often do not themselves follow the prescriptions in their own daily lives that they would impose on the body politic. 
 A case in point involves the report advocating sweeping changes in campaign finance laws published last month by the Committee for Economic Development, an organization of business executives. The report's principal recommendation is that soft money, the unregulated donations that corporations can give to political parties, should be outlawed.
Corporations and unions have long been prohibited from giving money directly to political candidates, but in recent elections, they have gotten around the restrictions by donating large sums to the parties.
In the 1998 elections, corporations and business trade groups gave a record $121 million in soft money.
"The public cannot help but believe that these donors enjoy special influence and receive special favors," the report stated. "The suspicion of corruption deepens public cynicism and diminishes public confidence in government. More important, these activities raise the likelihood of actual corruption."
At a news conference where the report was released, a co-chairman of the subcommittee that conducted the study, Edward A. Kangas, chairman and chief executive of Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, the accounting and consulting firm, declared, "Bad government is bad business."
He added: "We fundamentally look at our campaign financing and election processes, and we see many of the same fissures and cracks in the foundation that led to the collapse of financial markets elsewhere in the world, and we ask, 'What might that hold for us here in America?' "
Afterward, he told a reporter, "Until I understood the depth of the problem, I was like a lot of Americans: I don't think I cared too much."
Now, it appears that Mr. Kangas's firm has no intention of restricting its own soft money donations. For the 1998 elections, Deloitte & Touche, the American subsidiary of Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, gave $185,300 to the Republican Party and $41,725 to the Democratic Party, Federal Election Commission records show.
Mr. Kangas was in Europe this week and told associates to say he was too tied up in meetings to return a reporter's telephone calls. But Ellen Ringel, the spokeswoman for Deloitte & Touche, provided this statement: "Mr. Kangas's views with regard to his participation in the C.E.D. report are his personal views and do not necessarily represent the views of Deloitte & Touche in the U.S. and will not require Deloitte & Touche in the U.S. to do anything but what is in the best interest of the partnership within the law."
Ms. Ringel said Mr. Kangas had approved the statement.
Mr. Kangas is not the first corporate executive to conclude that soft money donations were a bad investment. In 1997, as a Senate committee was exposing widespread abuses in campaign finance practices by both parties, four large American corporations announced that they were forswearing soft money donations.
A review of Election Commission records shows that the companies have basically kept their word, but three have reneged to a minor extent. For example, General Motors, which gave more than $400,000 in soft money in the 1996 elections, gave no corporate money for last year's races, but it allowed its political action committee to donate $40,000 to the Republican National Committee after the 1997 announcement.
Political action committees are run by corporate officers, but the money comes from ostensibly voluntary donations, usually from executives. They are allowed to give up to $25,000 to political committees set up by the parties. Presumably, the Republican Party classified G.M.'s 1997-1998 donations as soft money because they exceeded that limit.
Harry J. Pearce, vice chairman of G.M., said in an interview that the company's policy applied to corporate funds, not to the political action committee. Mr. Pearce said that he was satisfied with the self-imposed ban on corporate spending on politics and that it would not be changed.
The Ameritech Corporation, the Midwest telephone company, which gave nearly $200,000 in the 1996 elections, gave about $60,000 in 1997 and 1998. Some of this was also from a political action committee. Most of the rest, said Gary Lytle, head of the company's Washington office, apparently resulted from executives around the country not understanding what the rules were.
Allied Signal, the aerospace company, which gave about $200,000 in the 1996 elections, gave $15,000 a year to the Republican Party in 1997 and 1998. Ken Cole, vice president for government relations, said that the money had been earmarked for conferences of the Republican Governors' Association and that the company had been assured that it would not be used for election campaigns.
The one corporation that has completely stuck by its guns is the Monsanto Company, which donated about $75,000 in 1995 and 1996 and has given no soft money since then.
"When we said what we were going to do, we meant it," said Philip Angell, a spokesman in Monsanto's Washington office. As for making an exception for PAC money, Mr. Angell said, "Either you are or you aren't, and we've decided we're not."

HEADLINE: Ban Lifted, Libya Is Set To Retool Oil Works

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 10

 BODY:
The decision by the United Nations to end economic sanctions against Libya will give its underdeveloped oil industry access to the spare parts and money needed to expand production.
That should also be a boon to foreign oil companies that do business in Libya, but American companies will be left at a competitive disadvantage because sanctions imposed by the United States remain in place. 
 The United Nations on Monday suspended its seven-year restrictions on trade with Libya, ending a ban on international flights. The move came after Libya handed over two citizens suspected of blowing up a Pan Am jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988, killing 270 people.
"We see a great future in Libya, and certainly the lifting of sanctions will make life a whole lot easier," said Andrew Harber, a manager for the Swedish company Lundin Oil AB.
But the United Nations action is unlikely to set off a fresh wave of European oil companies into Libya, analysts say, because most firms with an interest are already operating there. For them, the sanctions were more of an inconvenience than a real impediment. Still, direct flights to the Libyan capital will save time for visiting oilmen, who previously had to drive to Tripoli from neighboring Tunisia, a five-hour journey.
The new relations will also probably mean faster international money transfers.
With proven reserves of 30 billion barrels, Libya has as much oil as Norway and Britain combined. Its reserves are smaller than Mexico's 50 billion barrels, but larger than those of fellow OPEC members Nigeria and Indonesia. And its low-sulfur crude fetches a premium.
The Libyans have managed to keep up steady levels of crude production despite the United Nations and the American sanctions, pumping 1.39 million barrels a day last year, according to the International Energy Agency. Promising areas of the country remain to be explored.
Conoco Inc., based in Houston, first struck oil in Libya in 1955. Since withdrawing from Libya 13 years ago, Conoco has had to forego the production and sale of 300 million barrels of oil worth $5 billion, said a spokesman, Carlton Adams.
European energy companies like ENI in Italy, Repsol of Spain and OMV in Austria helped fill the void created by the American exodus.
The competitive position of American companies will erode further if non-American firms are the only ones allowed to do business in Libya, Mr. Adams said.
Sanctions have hurt Libya most by blocking imports of certain types of oil equipment. The American embargo continues to deny Libya access to specific technologies. Sanctions also have stifled investment. Since 1996, the United States' Iran-Libya Sanctions Act has barred foreign firms from making new investments of $40 million or more -- a limit European companies seem to be respecting.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 31; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk; Second Front

LENGTH: 1210 words

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Has Urban Allies in Bid to Ease Environmental Rules

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 10

 BODY:
New York's business leaders have long worked with their Republican allies in the Capitol in an unsuccessful campaign to scale back rules requiring companies to conduct extensive cleanups of polluted industrial sites that they want to develop.
But now business has found a new ally: black and Hispanic Democrats from poor inner city neighborhoods where developers say they would transform abandoned industrial sites into attractive commercial properties if it were not for the state's stringent environmental rules. 
 While business groups and minority leaders differ over the details of the changes they support, there is growing agreement that the environmental rules may be stifling economic growth in the state's inner cities as well as other industrial centers.
"To see these properties languish when we have such needs in our community makes you question the principles that we have operated under with regard to environmental protection," said Jeffrion L. Aubry, a prominent black Democratic Assemblyman from Queens.
"It's important to maintain standards of protection for your community," he added. "But at the same time you want to see these properties put back into some economic use. So the question is: how do you spur development of these properties in our community and at the same time retain the public protections?"
The issue is expected to be one of the most hotly contested environmental matters the Governor and the Legislature take up this year. The main element in the state's effort to clean up hazardous waste sites, the Superfund program, is running out of money, and business leaders are pushing to overhaul its rules and standards as part of any final agreement to refinance it.
The budding alliance involving minority politicians, business leaders and civic leaders threatens to fracture the traditional Democratic alliance with environmentalists and give momentum to those who want to see the standards eased.
The Democrats and their allies in the environmental community have generally held that polluted former industrial properties, known as brownfields, should be cleaned to a fairly high standard and that the companies that own them should pay the costs, even if a previous owner was primarily responsible for the contamination.
Business, in turn, has argued that a high cleanup standard is not needed for brownfields that will be used for factories instead of homes and that holding property owners fully responsible for the cleanup costs, no matter their role in the pollution, is sure to inhibit investment. As evidence, they point to thousands of industrial tracts that they say have been shunned by developers because of concerns over legal liability for pollution and contamination.
"Not only are the standards not necessary, but they are self-defeating because you end up with no cleanups at all," said Robert B. Ward, the research director for the Business Council of New York State, a statewide chamber of commerce.
"This is in large part an economic development issue, and the areas in greatest need of economic development tend to have large minority populations," he said, adding: "But it's more than a minority issue. It is an urban issue."
Even the business community's staunchest critics acknowledge that redeveloping brownfields is appealing, particularly to residents of beleaguered urban areas. But the critics accuse business leaders of trying to gut environmental safeguards in the name of economic development, particularly for sites considered dangerous enough to require extensive work under the Superfund program.
"The issue of brownfields redevelopment is a double-edged sword," said Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester County Democrat who is the chairman of the Assembly's Environmental Conservation Committee. "On the one hand, there is legitimate pressure for economic development of these abandoned sites. But on the other hand, that can be perverted into an excuse for lowering cleanup standards and the responsibility that polluters have to clean up their mess."
He added, "The business community is going to have to back off from using brownfields as a beard for an agenda that reduces cleanup and liability across the board."
The critics of the business community's efforts also argue that the current rules have not actually discouraged development. 'We are developing hundreds of brownfields every year," said Walter Hang, a former environmental lobbyist who now helps businesses identify and develop brownfields. "As near as I can tell, the cleanup and liability standards are not a major impediment to developing brownfields in New York. The deals are flowing like crazy."
No one can say how many brownfields exist in the state, according to the state's Department of Environmental Conservation. But in New York City alone, officials have identified more than 6,500, most of which are in the old industrial sections of Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens.
The debate over brownfields comes as a special panel appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, considers a plan to overhaul the laws governing liability and cleanup standards for brownfields, ranging from sites with relatively little toxic waste to those deemed hazardous enough to qualify for money under the state Superfund program. Mr. Pataki and his aides said he intended to introduce a bill on the issue in the current legislative session.
The major questions in the debate over brownfields include whether prospective developers should be granted liability protections from unforeseen cleanup costs and whether the state should continue to require all polluted properties to be cleaned to a single high standard or instead should make the standards dependent on a site's eventual use. Put another way, does a brownfield being used to build a gas station need to be as clean as one being used for a nursery school?
Peggy Shepard, the executive director of the West Harlem Environmental Action Group, said she supported many of the changes being sought by business leaders because the current laws are not working.
"There are many people who argue that brownfields should be cleaned up to pristine conditions," Ms. Shepard said. "And in a perfect world, we would like to return some of them to pristine conditions. But I think the bottom line should be a cleanup that protects public health while promoting economic development."
Roberto Ramirez, a Hispanic Assemblyman and the Democratic Party chairman in the Bronx, said he too saw an opportunity for business groups and minority communities to begin restoring some abandoned properties. But he warned that redevelopment of those sites ought to be done in close consultation with community leaders.
Although he is open to changing cleanup standards, he said, he also has some concerns. One, he said, was that changes might allow a developer to clean a site to a standard that is only good enough for a factory, when, say, new housing might benefit a community.
"What you are seeking to strike here is a balance," he said. "Is there a meeting point where a law can be proposed that allows development of sites that up to now were not economically viable, while at the same time insuring that environmental concerns are addressed?"

HEADLINE: Hundreds Gather to Protest City's Auction of Garden Lots

BYLINE: By ANNE RAVER 

 BODY:
About 500 community gardeners, many from other states, rallied in Bryant Park yesterday, chanting "Stop the Auction! Stop the Auction!" singing along with Pete Seeger and vowing to preserve the 700 community gardens that have been grown on trash-strewn vacant lots.
The administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has put 114 of the city-owned lots on the auction block for May 13. As the date nears, advocates of the gardens on those lots are pressuring the city to save them. 
 "This is our way of letting New York know -- and we hope the Mayor is listening -- that we need community gardens," said Leslie Lowe, the executive director of the New York City Environmental Justice Alliance. "When people say it's houses versus gardens, that's a lie. There are more than 11,000 vacant lots in the city."
Ms. Lowe, a lawyer, said that 29 community planning districts in the city, most of them low income, have less than 1.5 acres of open space per 1,000 people. "Low-income children have no place to play, except on asphalt," she said. "These gardens are where children learn about nature, and we have to fight to save every piece of green space."
The gardens scheduled to be auctioned are the first wave of more than 700 community gardens that the city could sell at any time because they have been leased to gardeners on only a temporary basis. The Giuliani administration has said the purpose of the auction is to promote economic development and the creation of housing.
In January, when the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development confirmed its plans to sell more than 100 garden lots, Deputy Commissioner Hector Batista said that the agency was trying to sell off any city-owned properties not slated for housing or economic development.
The rally was part of a two-day conference called "Standing Our Ground," sponsored by the New York City Community Garden Coalition, the New York City Environmental Justice Alliance and the city chapter of the Sierra Club. The conference began on Friday at St. Augustine's Episcopal Church on Henry Street, in the Lower East Side.
"I feel this is one of the most important battles right here, right now," said Mr. Seeger, who has spent much of his life rallying people to clean up the Hudson River. Now he has turned his attention to another cause: plants. And he has concluded that they will win, anyway.
"A hundred years from now, the city is going to be all green," he said. "It's just a question of whether people are going to be here -- or just vines growing up all the fallen-down buildings."
New York advocates of gardens and open space were joined by others yesterday, from Boston, Philadelphia, Atlanta, and Madison, Wis., to pledge their solidarity and tell their own stories.
Betsy Johnson, the director of Garden Futures, a land trust coalition in Boston, said, "We've saved 150 gardens in Boston. The first thing we did was realize that it wasn't housing versus gardens. Our constituency was the same for both."
New York City Council members Kenneth K. Fisher of Brooklyn and Kathyrn E. Freed of Manhattan, and State Senators Thomas K. Duane of Manhattan and Velmanette Montgomery of Brooklyn urged gardeners to write their city and state legislators to stop the auction, and to support bills that would halt the proposed sales and funnel state and Federal money into preserving urban green space.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Joblessness Is Down. Prices Aren't Up. Go Figure.

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
MEETING in February to review interest rate policy, members of the Federal Reserve fretted, as they always do, about the possible resurgence of inflation. But their discussion soon turned to whether the central bank's system of spotting incipient wage and price pressures might be malfunctioning.
This early-warning system -- built around interrelationships between unemployment, growth and inflation -- assumes that when joblessness falls below a certain "natural" level, prices will rise. As a forecasting and policymaking tool, the framework provided a reasonably accurate way of knowing when inflation would strike and enabling the Fed to head it off by adjusting monetary policy. At least until the last few years. 
 Unemployment has been falling for seven years, and last month dipped to 4.2 percent, its lowest level in nearly three decades and well below any mainstream estimate of the natural unemployment rate. Economic growth, while slowing somewhat, remains robust. Yet the predicted inflation is nowhere to be found. And although theoretical economists have been debating the issue of a natural rate for years, concern about the concept's reliability now are beginning to change the way the Fed thinks about inflation and sets policy.
The sketchy minutes of the central bank's February meeting -- the only account made public -- suggest that even Fed officials are struggling to find answers. The combination "over an extended period of strong economic growth, very low rates of unemployment, and the absence of any buildup of inflation could not be explained in terms of normal historical relationships," the minutes said.
A number of Fed officials, according to the minutes, "suggested that the inflation process was not well understood and that inflation forecasts were subject to a wide range of uncertainty."
The Fed does not understand the inflation process? It is like a conference of top cardiac surgeons deciding that it did not really know how the heart works, or NASA admitting that it was not sure what happens when the countdown reaches zero.
Many economists believe that since the Fed has less confidence in its ability to predict inflation, it will be less likely to act preemptively against inflation -- its strategy through much of the last several decades -- and more likely to wait for evidence that wage and price increases are actually accelerating.
The natural-rate theory, which is encompassed in such arcane concepts as the Phillips Curve and the non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment, still has its advocates, including some Fed officials. Even skeptics acknowledge that there is a long-term tradeoff between unemployment and inflation. The question is whether the tradeoffs are consistent enough in a rapidly changing economy to be of any use in predicting inflation and setting interest rates at the appropriate level.
"These various road maps or rules that we use are valid at times," said L. Douglas Lee, chief economist at HSBC Securities. "But what you always have to remember is that the U.S. economy is a very dynamic creature and things don't remain fixed. What works at one point in terms of understanding inflation may not work at another, but then may change and work again."
The trick for policymakers, Mr. Lee said, is to remain flexible and to recognize when their old assumptions are no longer working -- something that he and many other economists credit Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, with doing well in the last few years. Mr. Greenspan has consistently resisted pressure to raise rates over the past few years just because the old models have been sending warnings signals.
"Policymakers have to keep on top of what's going on so they don't use the old road map on a new road," Mr. Lee said. "We've had quite a lengthy period of time now where the economy has grown faster and inflation has been less than the Fed's forecast expected. The longer the economy surprises you, the more you have to question your fundamental assumptions."
ECONOMISTS have offered a raft of explanations for the apparent breakdown in the old relationships between employment, growth and inflation, some suggesting that the change is temporary, others seeing it as emblematic of a fundamental shift in the way the economy works.
Those in the fundamental change camp, which includes an increasing number of Fed officials, say that inflation is being dampened by improved productivity in American business. Faced with a shortage of labor, employers are paying somewhat higher wages. But because of intense competition, at home and abroad, they are unable to pass on the higher costs to consumers. So they are investing heavily in computers and other cost-saving equipment, and re-examining the way they operate to reduce expenses at every turn.
Although the statistics are fuzzy, economists increasingly believe that the result has been the first lasting improvement in productivity -- output per worker -- since it inexplicably turned down in the early 1970's. Higher productivity means the economy can sustain higher rates of non-inflationary growth.
The relationship of inflation to unemployment, Mr. Greenspan told Congress earlier this year, "is clearly a far more complex process" than implied by the natural-rate concept. "At some point," he said, "the general notion that a different type of process is involved here is going to probably gain, in my judgment, a majority view among economists."

HEADLINE: The News at The Daily News Is Not Good;
Financial Problems Bring Cutbacks and a Growing Sense of Distrust

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
Helen Kennedy, The Daily News's reporter in the Balkans, is heading home. On-the-spot coverage of the war and refugee crisis in Kosovo is more than her newspaper can afford right now; its newsroom budget has just been trimmed by 5 percent. She is returning to a newsroom where no raises will be given this year and where reporters must get approval before taking a source to lunch.
The Daily News, the in-your-face tabloid that in the early 1990's survived union confrontation, revolving-door ownership and bankruptcy, has been knocked back on its heels by a series of financial reversals. Just when the newspaper was ready to print a snazzy new color edition, balky pressroom equipment scuttled the attempt. The newspaper's owners, Fred Drasner and Mortimer B. Zuckerman, have had to pay more than $2 million for replacement parts and overtime by its pressmen in the last few months. 
 Just when The News had amicably reached terms with its eight craft unions, a labor arbitrator a month ago gave a ninth union, representing the drivers, a far more expensive settlement. Since the craft unions are entitled to the same raises, the paper faces unexpected costs of $18.5 million in 1999 alone, executives say, and millions more in the future.
Just when the paper was unveiling its expanded Sunday edition, in which it is investing about $2 million, the new Sunday staff finds itself coexisting with colleagues who are on a severely restricted financial diet.
No, this is not a reprise of the paper's near-death experience less than a decade ago. But the pinch is making the paper's owners testy, its journalists angry and its union leaders nervous. "If you're asking, is the timing exquisite," Mr. Drasner said dryly, "the answer is no."
Mr. Drasner and Mr. Zuckerman said they would ask for help from all the newspaper's constituencies -- from employees to advertisers to suppliers. But such assurances do not resonate in a newsroom already bruised by cutbacks, low raises and the departure in the last 18 months of "enough colleagues to make up a baseball team," as one reporter put it.
The newspaper's editor, Debby Krenek, says the problems are manageable.
"Now, the key is to be very judicious about what you spend your money on," she said. "You can do that. It's not fun. But it's just managing things a little tighter. And if you do that, you don't have to make the major cuts none of us want to make."
There will be no layoffs, she said, and no cuts in the space that the paper devotes to news.
But no amount of explanations can dispel the suspicion and resentment the latest cutbacks bring. For nine months, the monthly budgetary bulletins from The Daily News have seemed an exercise in mathematics. Spend. Cut. Spend. Cut. Look, we are really investing in the Sunday paper. Look, this labor arbitration award is going to cost a lot -- we will have to make some real cuts.
 
A Newsroom Buffeted By Financial Reversals
And while all newsrooms are roiled about something at any given time, roiled is too mild to describe the feelings at The Daily News, the country's sixth-largest newspaper, where anger and financial unease have made the place seasick.
In part, the nausea has been provoked by unforeseen reversals -- or, from a less forgiving perspective, failed gambits. The paper might have gotten more relief from the pressroom labor and equipment bills if it had not lost a lawsuit against Goss Graphic Systems, which supplied the $62 million press equipment. It might have faced lower labor costs if it could have reached accommodation with the drivers' union two years ago. Now, it is appealing the March award to the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union of New York, which represents 418 drivers who ferry 723,000 copies of the paper across the five boroughs and into the suburbs every day.
These unexpected bills come on top of significant investments the owners have made in the paper over the years. A new Unisys newsroom computer system is costing at least $4 million, and hundreds of thousands of dollars are supporting two extra reporters and seven extra pages a week devoted to Brooklyn and Queens.
The newspaper's most heralded investment -- an expanded Sunday section, for which the newspaper hired a marquee editor, Edward Kosner, a former editor of Newsweek, New York magazine and Esquire, -- was upstaged by the most stinging reversal, the labor arbitration agreement. The Sunday expansion added about 6 people to a newsroom staff of about 370. Mr. Zuckerman said he has increased the newsroom budget by 50 percent since 1993.
All the upheaval has left the newsroom bruised. And what makes the chronic discontent far worse, some on the staff say, is their belief that the pain is not being shared equally. For all the demoralizing cuts in the rest of the newsroom, Mr. Kosner's Sunday budget appears untouchable.
"The best reporting we have on the story of the year is being yanked," said one senior newsroom executive of the Balkans coverage. This person, like all but two of the newsroom employees interviewed extensively, spoke on the condition of anonymity. The cutbacks "send an extremely unfortunate psychological message," the executive added. "It suggests that we don't have the money to gather the news in the traditional way. Internally, the juxtaposition of this and the Sunday launch is sending people into orbit."
Even some of those who resent the Sunday staff's special status readily concede that the new edition, with its expanded opinion pages and pull-out feature sections, is clean, well-packaged journalism that may pull in more readers. And an emphasis on the Sunday paper would appear to make economic sense, since Mr. Zuckerman says it brings in about one-third of the newspaper's advertising revenues.
But when reporters and editors learned that the Sunday staff had held a congratulatory dinner for 24 people -- employees and some others -- at the pricey restaurant Cite on Wednesday, they were quick to calculate how many days of Kosovo coverage that money would have bought.
Mr. Kosner, who said he had paid for the dinner himself, said that the Sunday staff was already "very lean." He added, "I haven't been approached about cuts, and I'm not making them."
 
Despite a Price Cut, Readers Drifted Away
In December 1995, after the demise of a rival, New York Newsday, The News's Sunday circulation reached about one million. By last September, it was 815,000. The clear culprit in the decline was the Sunday edition of The New York Post, the tabloid owned by Rupert Murdoch. Its original price was 25 cents -- much less than The Daily News, which responded by cutting its Sunday price to $1 from $1.50.
But the readers still drifted away. At a time when all three city dailies -- The Post, The News and The New York Times -- were losing circulation, The News suddenly started hemorrhaging Sunday readers. More than 20 percent of the circulation disappeared in three years.
The decline coincided with a period of rapid-fire newsroom turnover, as Martin Dunn, the editor, left in 1996, to be replaced by Pete Hamill, whom Mr. Zuckerman ousted nine months later. Mr. Zuckerman then selected Ms. Krenek as editor, but after a little more than a year, he diluted her authority by naming Mr. Kosner to run the Sunday paper.
"I've never viewed the world of journalism as static," Mr. Zuckerman said in an interview. "It's always ongoing. I never have been satisfied and will never be satisfied with any work in progress. We've worked to improve it year after year after year. I haven't taken money out of these entities. I've put money into them. The editorial product is more important than anything. More of the money has been invested in the editorial side of my products than anything else."
In the month since the bad news on the labor front, no one in management has publicly uttered the words "bankruptcy" or "sale." "Those are the least agreeable options," Mr. Drasner said in a telephone interview last week. If The News had the corporate equivalent of galloping pneumonia with its strike, sale, bankruptcy and resurrection in 1990 and 1991, the current situation is "a bad cold," he said.
But the two owners of this privately held company have little inclination to open their books. Mr. Zuckerman says that the paper's advertising revenues have risen every year. Mr. Drasner says that "The Daily News was profitable from the time we acquired it until we began experiencing significant production problems resulting from breaking in the new plant" in late 1997 and early 1998. "These problems negatively affected distribution and circulation," he added, in a reference to the balky printing equipment.
Mr. Drasner added, "The recent arbitration decision will have a substantial adverse affect on our profitability going forward."
Without a public balance sheet, it is impossible to know how badly the labor arbitration ruling could hurt the business. People are treading cautiously.
Leaders of the eight labor unions that make up the Alliance of Printing Trades, whose battles with previous owners were visceral and violent, say almost nothing about the current situation, on the record or off. Those eight unions already have negotiated wage agreements.
But as they were negotiating, all were aware that the one maverick union, the drivers union, had reached an impasse with Mr. Zuckerman and Mr. Drasner, and that the parties had entered binding arbitration in April 1997. The craft unions' agreements stipulated that whatever the drivers got, the craft union members would get as well. Those "me too" clauses added millions of dollars to the total labor bill when the arbitrator's award was announced.
A tenth union, the Newspaper Guild, has no part of any of those agreements, and the journalists in it are less hesitant to criticize management. "I think that the owners of this paper have given short shrift to the people who produce it day in and day out," said Tom Robbins, a reporter who covers labor. "I think that Mort and Fred take a lot for granted in this newsroom."
Some reporters have asked one another if savings could not be achieved by cutting back on contracts with suppliers, particularly since some of them are companies in which Mr. Zuckerman and Mr. Drasner hold an interest.
One of these, Applied Graphics Technologies Inc., helps prepare advertisements for publication for clients like General Motors, The Walt Disney Company, The New York Times -- and The Daily News. For several years, Applied Graphics personnel have created ads for the newspaper and helped to digitize its photo library, services that cost $6 million in 1997.
Such dealings between companies with common ownership are legal, providing that all the services are provided at market rates. "Whatever we do, we do on a market-based basis," Mr. Zuckerman said. "One of the things you learn in business is you don't subsidize one company with another."
If newsroom employees are concerned about such matters, Mr. Drasner said, they would be better advised to worry about their own work.
The effect on the paper's journalism is not immediately evident. The newspaper that offered a ground-breaking series on the spread of asthma among inner-city children a year ago is also breaking ground on aspects of the Amadou Diallo shooting. The Washington columnist, Lars-Erik Nelson, is probing to find the appeal of potential Presidential candidates like Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona. And reporter Helen Kennedy, through this weekend, was putting a face on the Kosovo crisis.
But that kind of coverage is less affordable than it used to be. And, as Ms. Krenek observed: "When we covered the war in Bosnia we didn't cover the war the entire time. And for the amount of time we did cover it, we ran up a bill of $70,000.
"We're not giving up on the commitment to cover" the Kosovo crisis, Ms. Krenek said, "but we're trying to be judicious about it. Helen went over on a relief flight. She's coming back on a reasonably priced commercial flight. If the United States sends in ground troops, we'll send somebody back."

 CORRECTION:
An article in some editions on April 11 about The Daily News's recent financial setbacks referred incompletely to circulation at The New York Post. While The Post's circulation decreased from March 1992 to March 1994, its daily circulation has since increased in each twice-yearly reporting period, reaching 437,467 in September 1998. Since 1996, when The Post began Sunday publication, its Sunday circulation has increased, not decreased; it stood at 382,382 last September.

DEC. 18, 1981 -- The Tribune Company of Chicago announces plans to sell The Daily News, citing losses of $11 million a year and sharp drops in circulation and advertising. The company changes its mind the following May, but warns union leaders that steep cost cuts are necessary.
 
JANUARY 1990 -- Collective bargaining begins, bitterly. Management demands an end to what it calls overstaffing and waste. It seeks up to $70 million in labor savings and free rein to make huge cuts in staffing and other changes.
 
OCT. 25, 1990 -- After months of stalled negotiations, a confrontation at The News's Brooklyn plant provokes a walkout by nine of the paper's 10 unions. Using replacement workers, the paper keeps publishing during the five-month strike, but circulation plummets.
 
MARCH 20, 1991 -- The Tribune Company agrees to pay Robert Maxwell $60 million to take over The News. Union members agree to go back to work.
 
NOV. 5, 1991 -- Mr. Maxwell is found dead at sea. His publishing empire, deep in debt, soon collapses. The next month, The News files for bankruptcy.
 
JAN. 8, 1993 -- Mortimer B. Zuckerman and Fred Drasner take over The News.
 
MAY 4, 1995 -- The News leaves its landmark building on 42d Street for cheaper office space on the West Side.
 
MARCH 8, 1999 -- Truck drivers at The News win large wage increases in arbitration. Under a contract clause, the paper's craft unions are entitled to the same raises.
