HEADLINE: Big Name For Senate In Virginia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
George F. Allen, a Republican known for his congeniality and conservatism when he was Governor of Virginia, is expected to announce on Tuesday that he will run for the Senate next year, challenging the two-term incumbent Democrat, Charles S. Robb.
Highly popular in the state from his years in the Virginia Legislature, Mr. Allen became Governor in 1993, winning 58 percent of the vote. After his single four-year term, which is all Virginia law allows for governors, he returned to private practice as a lawyer and began planning for a Senate campaign by raising money and speaking across the state. 
 Terri Hauser, a campaign spokeswoman, said she did not want to pre-empt Mr. Allen's announcement plans but added, "He's been testing the waters, and they're feeling mighty fine."
Even before Mr. Allen indicated that he would run for the Senate, forming an exploratory committee in December, Mr. Robb was viewed by many political analysts as one of the most vulnerable of the 14 Democratic senators seeking re-election next year.
While Republicans were winning control of Congress in 1994, Virginia voters found Mr. Robb's admitted marital infidelities only slightly less objectionable than the role his opponent, Oliver L. North, the former Marine lieutenant colonel, played in the Iran-contra affair.
But Mr. Allen, 47, has no such baggage, and already, statewide polls have shown that he would defeat Mr. Robb, 59, by a comfortable margin. Neither candidate is expected to face a major challenge before the general election.
"He enters this race as an incumbent underdog," Robert Holsworth, a professor of political science at Virginia Commonwealth University, in Richmond, said of Mr. Robb. "I think the race is likely to be close, but the early polls show Allen beating him in a head-to-head race."
As Governor, Mr. Allen left a firm legacy, reflecting Republican ideals that are popular among many Republican governors. He pushed through one of the country's toughest welfare-to-work programs, and he led an effort to eliminate parole for violent offenders.
He also worked to establish standards of learning in Virginia's public schools, setting them so high that only 2 percent of the state schools passed them last year when they were measured for the first time.
Mr. Allen would also seem to benefit from a state Republican Party that is more unified now than it was six years ago.
Mr. North won the party nomination after a bruising fight with James C. Miller 3d, a former budget director in the Reagan Administration. Then he failed to win the endorsement of the state's most popular Republican, Senator John W. Warner, or his Commander in Chief, President Ronald Reagan, a setback that effectively split the party through the fall campaign season.
With Mr. Warner backing J. Marshall Coleman, a Republican-turned-independent, Mr. Robb won in the general election with 46 percent of the vote to 43 percent for Mr. North and 11 percent for Mr. Coleman.
State Democratic officials say they expect Mr. Robb to attack Mr. Allen as a conservative who is out of step with most Virginia voters.
Craig Bieber, chairman of the state Democratic Party, says that though Mr. Allen "cultivates a moderate facade, he is really as right-wing as North was."
Mr. Bieber also said Mr. Allen could prove vulnerable for taking credit for state economic expansion that would have occurred anyway and for policies that have made Virginia a leading importer of prisoners and garbage from other states.
"Senator Robb will run on the fact he is a moderate voice of reason in the United States Senate," Mr. Bieber said. "It will be up to us to point out that Allen is as extreme as Ollie North was."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Behind a Badge, Confronting Issues of Race

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

 BODY:
LIEUT. ERIC ADAMS'S police career began with a beating. His own.
He was 15 and had a nose for trouble, which was easy enough to find in South Jamaica, Queens, where his mother met the mortgage payments and raised six children cleaning houses by day and office buildings by night. 
 Lieutenant Adams was the kind of child who "wore my mother's knees down praying for me." This long-ago night was typical. With his 16-year-old brother, he was arrested for criminal trespass, entering the home of a prostitute to take money the boys said she owed them.
His mother waved the police away when they came to the door, true to her rule that any child of hers who was arrested could go straight to jail. Next stop was the 103d Precinct House for booking. There, Lieutenant Adams said, he and his brother Conrad were pummeled by two white officers. By the time a black officer intervened, the 15-year-old had passed out. For a week afterward, he said, he urinated blood.
"They asked, 'Do you feel like a beating?' like you might ask, 'Do you feel like a hamburger?' " said Lieutenant Adams, a platoon commander in Brooklyn and president of 100 Blacks in Law Enforcement. "When the ordeal was over, my brother," who has become a building contractor, "hated the thought of the police and I wanted to be part of it."
As he explained the revelation that bad cops have the power to inflict pain and good cops the power to stop it, Lieutenant Adams polished off a platter of waffles, fried chicken and grits at Sugar Hill, a Bedford-Stuyvesant restaurant. He had just come off the midnight-to-8 shift at the 94th Precinct in Greenpoint and spent the day studying for his captain's exam and planning the next move in an effort to get Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Police Commissioner Howard Safir and the City Council to confront issues of race in policing in the wake of the Diallo killing.
Lieutenant Adams, 38 and single, has been a gadfly since leaving the Police Academy in 1984 with the highest grades in his class. He held top positions in the Guardians, the fraternal organization for African-American police officers. In 1995, he formed 100 Blacks in Law Enforcement in response to the election of Mayor Giuliani, whose reputation for awkward race relations preceded him.
The organization began with 10 black officers, each of whom enlisted 10 more. The officers donated $120 apiece for a fund to aid residents in their precincts, such as a girl who needed books for medical school and a child whose bike had been stolen.
These modest good works continue, but lately the group has been speaking out about the Diallo shooting, as the Guardians have not. They have held seminars for young black men on how to behave during a stop-and-frisk so as not to inflame the officers from the Street Crime Unit, to keep them from mistaking a man fumbling for a wallet or a child with a candy bar for an armed criminal.
"Reaching while black shouldn't be punishable by death," Lieutenant Adams said. "But I can't teach kids on the way it ought to be. I have to teach them on the way it is."
PAINFUL truths about race, Lieutenant Adams said, are avoided by the department. "Lying is at the root of our training," he said. "At the academy, recruits are told that they should not see black or brown people as different, but we all do. We all know that the majority of people arrested for predatory crimes are African-American. We didn't create that scenario, but we have to police in that scenario. So we need to be honest and talk about it."
There is similar disingenuousness in precinct assignments, Lieutenant Adams said, as one of the few blacks in the 94th Precinct, a largely white area with many Polish immigrants. Postings are not affected by race or ethnicity, but Lieutenant Adams says they ought to be.
Jewish officers assigned to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, he said, would try to avoid putting Orthodox suspects into police cars on the Sabbath. Italian officers might not misunderstand the body language of compatriots in Bensonhurst. And if a lieutenant like him was platoon commander in Brownsville, young men would say: " 'Wow, there's one of us inside.' I'd be a welcome mat."
Lieutenant Adams said Commissioner William J. Bratton welcomed his views. But Commissioner Safir avoided a meeting for the first two years of his tenure, and only sat down with representatives of 100 Blacks after the Diallo shooting. Marilyn Mode, a deputy police commissioner, described that meeting as "frank" and "candid," words usually associated with failed diplomacy.
Without the influence of Mr. Bratton, Lieutenant Adams sees a hardening of policy, such as what he described as overly aggressive crowd control at the Million Youth March in Harlem. He scorned Mayor Giuliani's initiatives since the Diallo shooting, like palm cards telling the police to say Ma'am and Sir.
Lieutenant Adams, who calls himself a conservative Republican, says he was as pleased as any New Yorker who owns a co-op (his is in Prospect Heights) and a stock portfolio when a reduction in crime produced economic windfalls.
"The good people of this city were willing to give up civil rights for safety and prosperity," he said. "But we took a short cut. We were so fed up, we told the police agencies to do what you want. We are all to blame for Diallo."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries' Prices Rise, Aided By Purchases Made by Fed

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose on optimism that Government reports expected today will show subdued inflation, and after the Federal Reserve bought Treasuries.
"Bonds are attractive" given the outlook for tame inflation, said Alan Day, who helps oversee $4 billion at Stratevest Group in Burlington, Vt. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 7/32, to 97 4/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.45 percent, from 5.46 percent Friday.
Bonds got an extra lift from the Fed, which bought $587 million of Treasuries maturing between 2007 and 2019. The Fed makes purchases periodically to add money to the banking system. The Fed needs to add money now to counteract drains caused as people pay their taxes, economists said.
The reports are expected to show a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent in consumer prices and a half-percent rise in retail sales in March from February. Such figures would signal that inflation, already near its lowest rate in more than a decade, is not about to accelerate, investors said.
"Inflation is benign," said Gary Zeltzer, who oversees $1.8 billion at J & W Seligman & Company in New York.
Many investors are fretting that the strong pace of economic growth will increase inflation, though that has not happened yet. Inflation erodes the value of a bond's fixed payments.
Bond gains were limited as companies prepared to sell up to $13 billion of debt, which may draw demand away from Treasuries, traders said.

HEADLINE: Caucasus and Central Asia Look to Pipeline Opening Saturday to Cut Reliance on Russia

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: BAKU, Azerbaijan, April 11

 BODY:
The new nations of the Caucasus and Central Asia will take a giant step away from their former masters in Moscow this weekend.
Several Presidents and a host of other political and business leaders are expected to gather on Saturday at the Georgian port of Supsa for a ceremony opening a 515-mile pipeline that will carry oil from the Caspian Sea. By opening the pipeline, they will symbolically cut an old umbilical cord that has bound this region to Russia. 
 Many people in the region believe that oil is the key to their prosperity, but until now, all pipeline routes have led through Russia. That has given Russia the power to control and even choke the region's economic growth.
The new pipeline breaks this monopoly. It gives an important option to countries that are beginning to exploit the vast oil reserves under and around the Caspian.
"It means the world to us," said Vafa Guluzade, chief foreign policy adviser to President Heydar Aliyev of Azerbaijan. "This pipeline gives Caspian countries a reliable way to export our oil without going through Russia. It is hugely important in an economic sense, but it is even more important politically. Now, for the first time, we have direct access to the West. We are freeing ourselves from Russia after 200 years."
The new pipeline begins at Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan, and will carry 115,000 barrels of crude oil daily. After the oil reaches Supsa, tankers will carry it across the Black Sea to the Mediterranean and to Western markets.
Oil for the pipeline is being produced by a consortium of 11 companies from eight nations, including the United States. With new pumping stations, and lubricants to make it flow faster, the capacity of the line can be more than doubled.
Until now, oil from the consortium's undersea field has been shipped by rail and through an unreliable pipeline from Baku through the turbulent Russian republics of Chechnya and Dagestan to Russia's Black Sea port of Novorossisk.
The pipeline is intermittently closed by the separatist rulers in Chechnya, and shivering Russians who live along the way often drill holes in it to divert oil for their needs.
The new line has taken the consortium more than two years to build and cost about $1.5 billion. At the peak of activity, more than 3,000 people worked on it.
Besides the oil companies, the most immediate beneficiaries of the project will be Azerbaijan and Georgia, the two countries through which it runs. Leaders of both countries complain that Russia is trying to destabilize their fragile Governments, and they are eager to find new friends in the West.
The Baku-Supsa pipeline cannot carry the large amounts of oil that are expected to be produced by Caspian nations in the coming years, though. Production is expected to exceed one million barrels a day by the end of the next decade. The United States wants that oil to be exported through a pipeline that would run from Azerbaijan across Georgia and Turkey to the Mediterranean, but no contract has been signed.
Although most of the Baku-Supsa pipeline runs underground, there are security concerns. It runs near areas of Georgia where separatists could pose a threat. But Georgian leaders are as enthusiastic about it as their Azerbaijani counterparts.
"It is a vitally important project for the entire region, defining the region in the broadest sense as stretching from Ukraine all the way to Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan," said Zurab Zhvania, Speaker of the Georgian Parliament. "It gives us a chance to connect ourselves to each other and to the world in a way that keeps us free from political pressure or influence or manipulation."
"It means a great deal to us," he continued, "which is why not everyone around us likes the idea. I'm talking about Russia, but also about Iran. They are not happy, and I can understand why. Actually, I think our enemies understand the importance of this project better than our friends."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: SLAVIC ALLIANCE;
Yugoslavs Seek Support Of Russia And Belarus

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, April 12

 BODY:
The Yugoslav federal Parliament voted today to join an alliance with Russia and Belarus, apparently with an eye toward getting Russia's military involved in stopping NATO air raids.
Serbia's Premier, Mirko Marajnovic, said after the vote that the proposal is "another way to resist NATO aggression," adding that it was normal for Yugoslavia to join a union with its historic Slavic Orthodox allies. 
 Russia's Foreign Minister, Igor S. Ivanov, said that Moscow regards the idea of Yugoslav membership in the union positively and that his ministry would study it. But he cautioned Yugoslavia that membership could not be granted quickly.
The NATO air strikes, which began on March 24 to force Yugoslavia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, to accept a peace agreement in Kosovo, have severely crippled the nation's industrial infrastructure and destroyed numerous military targets.
Mr. Milosevic called the Parliament vote a "historic step on the road of integration, security, stability and peace at the turn of the century."
The vote was based on an initiative by the Serbian nationalist Radical Party following a visit last week by Gennadi Seleznyov, the Communist who is the Speaker of the Russian Parliament's lower house.
Meanwhile, officials in Montenegro, the smaller republic of the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav federation, rejected the plan and said they would rather see their future in the European Union and NATO's Partnership for Peace program for non-member countries.
"Whatever they decide at today's federal Parliament session will not oblige Montenegro to follow suit, just like none of their other decisions bind us," the deputy speaker of the Montenegrin Parliament, Predrag Popovic, told reporters before the vote.
The idea of a union between Russia, Belarus and Yugoslavia is particularly popular among Russian and Yugoslav Communists and hard-line nationalists who regret the breakup of the Soviet Union.
The idea is also popular among many politicians in Russia, although some, including President Boris N. Yeltsin, have said that now is not the best time for it.
However, liberals have warned that Russia should be wary of aligning itself with the authoritarian President of Belarus, Aleksandr Lukashenko, and of burdening the already limping Russian economy with another economic drain.
It was unclear what formal steps need to be taken for Yugoslavia to become a member of the alliance.
Russia and Belarus had haggled for months before the union deal was completed in 1997 -- and it remains largely an agreement on paper.
Even if Yugoslavia were admitted, it would not automatically mean military aid. The union calls for military cooperation, but also envisions extensive political and economic relations, including the possibility of a single currency.
This is the first time since its founding in 1918 that Yugoslavia has tried to join an alliance with other nations.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
At G.M., Speculation on Chairman's Successor

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 12

 BODY:
Harry J. Pearce, the vice chairman of the General Motors Corporation, has largely recovered from leukemia and is again a leading candidate to succeed John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, who turned 61 last Tuesday, auto industry executives said.
Mr. Smith had been delegating considerable responsibility this year to Mr. Pearce, 56, and to G. Richard Wagoner Jr., 46, who became G.M.'s president and chief operating officer last October. Mr. Wagoner is likely to play a prominent but slightly more junior role in combination with Mr. Pearce after Mr. Smith retires, said industry officials, all of whom insisted on anonymity. 
 Mr. Smith's increasing delegation of responsibility and often visible weariness has prompted considerable speculation here that he might retire, possibly within the next year. He has avoided giving any clear, public indication of whether he would like to stay until he turns 65. Steven J. Harris, G.M.'s vice president for worldwide communications, said today that Mr. Smith had "no plans at this point" to retire.
Continuing discussions of Mr. Smith's eventual successor come as G.M. is profiting handsomely from a vigorous economy. But the world's largest auto maker is also losing market share at home, partly because it failed to foresee the strength of demand for full-sized pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles. The company's stock has risen sharply since the end of a crippling, two-month strike last summer but has generally trailed shares of G.M.'s archrival, the Ford Motor Company.
G.M.'s shares rose $2.50, to $88.125 yesterday, as the company announced that next month it would spin off its 82.3 percent stake in its auto parts division, the Delphi Automotive Systems Corporation. The United Automobile Workers union has opposed the spinoff but declined to comment this afternoon on G.M.'s action.
J. T. Battenberg 3d, Delphi's chairman and chief executive, said that Mr. Pearce "has been an active participant" in the spinoff.
Mr. Pearce, a lawyer who rose through the general counsel's office at G.M., is again playing a central role in setting G.M.'s strategy, officials said. He is guiding policy on a wide range of issues, including the spinoff of Delphi, while overseeing subsidiaries like Hughes Electronics and tackling strategic problems that are not part of the daily management of the auto business, which Mr. Wagoner handles.
Mr. Pearce was diagnosed early last summer with leukemia, but continued doing considerable work from home so as to remain involved with the company. He said in a brief telephone conversation last week that he was feeling fine and on the path to recovery; he has begun giving interviews again this month as the company presents him as once more a physically fit executive able to carry broad responsibilities.
Mr. Harris, G.M.'s vice president for worldwide communications, said today that that no decision had been made on who would become G.M.'s next chairman. He said that Mr. Pearce was working at least four days a week now, characterizing that schedule as "full time."
"He is back full time and fully engaged -- as far as what he'll be doing longer term, that is for the board," he said. "The board routinely and regularly discusses succession issues but there's nothing new to report."
Mr. Pearce was treated at the Mayo Clinic. Dr. Esperanza Papadopoulos, a bone marrow specialist at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, said that many leukemia patients fully recover from their illnesses these days, particularly those who receive early treatment. Dr. Papadopoulos said that while she had not treated Mr. Pearce, it was "certainly possible" that he was well on the way to a full recovery, although it might take one to five years to be completely certain, with the period depending on the type of leukemia and the treatments used.
After Mr. Pearce began bone-marrow treatments for his illness, Mr. Smith's successor had appeared to be Mr. Wagoner, who had been G.M.'s executive vice president for North American automotive operations before becoming president and chief operating officer last October. But Mr. Pearce is much better known among board members than Mr. Wagoner and a decade older; Mr. Wagoner is the youngest member of G.M.'s board by three years.
Mr. Wagoner is also relatively little known to the board. He became a member last autumn and attended meetings infrequently in previous years. By contrast, Mr. Pearce has been a favorite with many board members since becoming general counsel in 1987, frequently attending board meetings thereafter because of the numerous legal issues the auto maker faced, a former G.M. board member said.
"Harry did an outstanding job and he came to the attention of the board," the former board member said. Mr. Pearce joined the board in January 1996, when he became vice chairman.
The most likely scenario is that Mr. Pearce will play the senior role in some sort of partnership with Mr. Wagoner, with Mr. Pearce serving as chairman and possibly as chief executive for a while, too, several auto industry officials said. The result would be the latest in a series of two-member leadership teams at big auto makers, an approach that Ford and DaimlerChrysler A.G. are using now and that G.M. itself tried from 1992 through 1995, when Mr. Smith was G.M.'s chief executive but John G. Smale, a powerful outside director, was G.M.'s nonexecutive chairman.
Warren Bennis, a business professor at the University of Southern California and the author of a recent book on dual leaders at large corporations, said that auto makers were particularly suited to such leadership because of their sheer size. G.M. is the world's largest company in terms of sales and Ford is the second largest.
Always reluctant to be in the spotlight, Mr. Smith has cut back his public appearances even more than usual this year. Mr. Wagoner gave most of the company's semiannual presentation to Wall Street analysts in January, with Mr. Smith making only a few, brief remarks. Mr. Wagoner also gave the keynote speech at the New York International Auto Show earlier this month.
Conspicuously absent from auto industry officials' discussions of who might succeed Mr. Smith is Louis R. Hughes, G.M.'s executive vice president for new business strategies. The new title, which does not include operational responsibilities, was created for Mr. Hughes last October when his previous job, overseeing G.M.'s international automotive operations, was added to Mr. Wagoner's responsibilities. Mr. Hughes was a finalist for the post of chairman of United Airlines earlier this spring.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

On-Line Auctions Turning Millions Into Bidders
Millions of people have begun embracing the on-line auction, an Internet phenomenon that in a matter of months has captivated the nation's bargain hunters and spawned a market for nostalgia.
While retailers spend furiously to draw more customers on line, the Internet is suddenly teeming with buyers and sellers making their own markets. Testimonials about bargains abound in the chat rooms where the auction aficionados gather, and some will admit that the thrill of the game is worth it even when they lose or overpay. Page A1. 

Goldman Raises Price of Offering
Goldman, Sachs, Wall Street's last large, privately held investment bank, said that it would raise the price range of its highly anticipated initial public offering to $45 to $55 a share, up from a range of $40 to $50. And that promises to create some fat wallets on Wall Street. For example, the firm's co-chairman and chief executive, Henry M. Paulson Jr., who owns the largest individual stake in Goldman, could see his shares valued at as much as $227 million. C2.
 
Tyco to Eliminate 4,000 AMP Jobs
Tyco International, the top maker of electrical connectors since its purchase a week ago of AMP, said that it would cut 4,000 AMP jobs and that it expected profit to rise by 25 percent in five to six years. The reductions are on top of 4,200 already planned by AMP. C6.
 
Savings Associations' Shares Fall
Golden State Bancorp shares fell, as did other securities tied to lawsuits by savings and loan associations against the Government. On Friday a judge awarded Golden State less than investors had expected, although he agreed the Government had broken a promise of special regulatory treatment. C6.
 
Ford to Buy Car-Repair Chain
Ford Motor agreed to buy the European car-repair chain Kwik-Fit Holdings for $1.63 billion in cash. Analysts said the move would allow Ford to compete with independent repair shops and to sell more Ford parts. C11.
 
I.B.M. and Real Networks in Deal
I.B.M. said that it had enlisted Real Networks, the on-line multimedia company, to help its effort to create a standard for sending music over the Internet. The cooperation between the computer industry giant and the Internet start-up is the latest development in the race to market a consumer-friendly way of distributing music on line while guarding against piracy. Shares of Real Networks rose $39.50, to $247. C6.
 
Chinese Exports Fall in Quarter
China's exports fell 7.9 percent in the first quarter, as sharp declines in shipments to Europe more than offset increased exports to the United States. The report was worrisome because economists fear that China's economy, the largest in Asia after Japan's, may stumble, as did those of other Asian nations. C8.
 
Adelphia Expanding in Cable
Adelphia Communications, moving to become the fourth-largest cable-television company, agreed to buy Harron Communications' cable systems for $1.17 billion in cash to expand in New England and Philadelphia. C4.
 
Profits Up at Newspaper Companies
Gannett and two other newspaper publishers, Dow Jones and E. W. Scripps, reaped better-than-expected quarterly profits as advertising revenue grew and newsprint prices fell. C4.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
China's Exports Fall 7.9%, Though Those to U.S. Grow

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, April 12

 BODY:
China's exports fell 7.9 percent in the first quarter, the Government said today in a report that illustrated a weakness in one of the most important growth engines in the Chinese economy. Sharp declines in exports to Europe more than offset increased exports to the United States.
Economists are anxiously watching for signs that China's economy, the largest in Asia behind Japan's, may stumble into the same downward spiral that has hurt several Asian nations. A fall in exports, in particular, could increase the pressure on China to devalue its currency, the yuan, to help make those exports cheaper and more competitive. 
 But economists said that even with falling exports, it was unlikely that China would devalue any time this year. A devaluation could also force other developing countries to devalue their currencies.
Economists also point to other signs of economic strength in China, notably an 11.6 percent increase in first-quarter imports and an 8.3 percent overall economic growth rate in the January-March period.
The trade figures were released as business executives in China expressed disappointment at China's failure to win entry into the World Trade Organization, the group that makes the rules for global commerce, during a trip to the United States by Prime Minister Zhu Rongji. That setback was apparently caused more by politics in Washington than by serious differences among trade negotiators.
Mr. Zhu, Beijing's strongest advocate of dismantling China's trade barriers, may now be vulnerable to critics in Beijing who oppose making significant concessions that open China's markets to greater international competition.
But China's politics are so secretive that any diminishing of Mr. Zhu's standing would only become evident slowly. Today, China's media reported positively on the W.T.O. negotiations, stressing secondary agreements that were made and the commitment by Washington and Beijing to reach agreement on China's membership in the trade organization by the end of the year.
China's fall in exports came principally from weaker demand from Europe, Chinese officials said, citing a 9.1 percent drop in exports to Europe in the first two months of the year. In contrast, China's exports to the United States grew by 8.4 percent in the first quarter.
"China's exports to the European Union do not look promising in the first half of this year," Sun Zhenyu, deputy foreign trade minister, said at a weekend seminar on the euro, Europe's single currency. "The launch of the euro has created more competition to Chinese exports."
Mr. Sun said that the euro's decline against the dollar of roughly 9 percent this year depressed demand for Chinese goods in the European Union. Southern members of the European Union that produce goods at relatively low costs gained some price advantages over Chinese goods.
China's exports to neighboring countries in Asia have fallen sharply over the last year as the Asian economic crisis has diminished demand in countries like South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand.
The New China News Agency reported that exports to those countries rose in the first quarter, though the agency gave no figures.
For all of 1998, exports grew by just one-half of 1 percent, compared with 20.9 percent in 1997.
Positive signs also lurked in the mixed economic data coming out of China today. The most notable was a 21 percent rise in March imports, which suggested an increase in domestic demand -- evidence of economic strength.
Rising imports are also seen as another reason why a devaluation of the yuan is unlikely for the time being. Those imports include many materials for assembly into products that are exported, so a devaluation would make those materials more expensive for Chinese exporters to buy.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1986 words

HEADLINE: On-Line Auctions: Let's Make a Deal Without the Haggle

BYLINE: By By AMY HARMON and LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
There was no question that Bill Rue wanted the toy car, a childhood object that set off memories of 1969, when the Mets won the World Series and his parents bought their first color TV. But it wasn't until he found himself bidding against an anonymous foe in an Internet auction one evening that he knew he must have it.
Mr. Rue, a Brooklyn realtor who has no regrets about paying $101 for a used toy that opened at $9, is hardly alone in his embrace of the on-line auction. It is an Internet phenomenon that in a matter of months has captivated the nation's bargain hunters and spawned a market for nostalgia. Day and night, millions of Americans are sweating silently at their computers, bidding electronically on things they have never seen, tendered by people they have never met. 
 While retailers continue to spend furiously to draw more customers on line, the Internet is suddenly teeming with buyers and sellers making their own markets. Items range from a 50-gallon fish tank (four goldfish included) to painted plaster hula girls to the 1987 Mercedes 300 turbo diesel that Bill Steinhour of Herndon, Va., landed with a $5,800 bid.
Whether buyers make out better on the on-line auction block than in a more familiar fixed-price world is unclear. Logic is often lost in the heat of a bidding war. And plenty of people are buying things they never knew they needed. But testimonials about bargains abound in the chat rooms where the new auction aficionados gather, and some will admit that the thrill of the game is worth it even when they lose, or overpay.
Economists say the blossoming of on-line bidding is no surprise. Auctions are theoretically a very efficient form of commerce, the perfect nexus of the supply-and-demand curves. But they have traditionally been expensive to hold and limited in reach. The Internet solves both of those problems: on line, bidders in Florida and California can view the same Civil War-era glass perfume bottle. They are also relieved of the social awkwardness and time-consuming nature of haggling face to face. Many simply automate their bidding, letting the computer take care of negotiation.
It is not all about market efficiency, however. Buyers and sellers might find themselves exchanging E-mail about the former teen-age idol Bobby Sherman, long after the transaction was over. On Ebay, the most popular site, etiquette dictates that buyers and sellers post feedback about each other as a guide to others.
And then there is the adrenaline rush of winning.
"You get the fun of outbidding someone; you get something glorious in the mail, and on top of that someone publicly praises you for doing it," said Robrt Pela, 37, a writer in Phoenix, who has acquired several Partridge Family albums via on-line auction in recent weeks. "It's become my favorite form of procrastination."
If Americans become hooked on cyberspace bargaining, the implications for the retail economy could be as wide reaching as the introduction of fixed pricing enabled by standardized production a century ago. While 1998 on-line auction sales were a relatively small $1.4 billion, some analysts see a future where everything is a negotiation, from heating oil to the chopped meat at the Internet grocery store. "There is a building mind-set of, 'Hey, I can bid for things,' " said Kate Delhagen, a senior analyst at Forrester Research. "All this has the net effect that people start thinking that they can name their price. This is going to cause a real change in how we do business."
In a report released last week, Forrester predicted that business-to-consumer interactions would account for 66 percent of a $19 billion on-line auction market by 2003. Already, several sites like Onsale and First Auction have created a hybrid format of auction retailer. They buy excess merchandise cheaply, particularly computer equipment, and resell it to the highest bidder.
Other unconventional on-line models for bringing buyers and sellers together are also flourishing on the Web. At Priceline.com, travelers name their price, and airlines and hotel chains meet it when they have spaces to spare. (The formula made an impression on Wall Street, where Priceline achieved the highest first-day value for any Internet company, $9.8 billion, when it went public two weeks ago.)
But for now, most Web transactions are person-to-person through third-party auction houses that connect interested parties. And the Web's central bazaar is Ebay, a San Jose, Calif., venture started in 1995, whose audience has recently surged to 6.5 million visitors a month and has a market capitalization of $23 billion (roughly three times that of Kmart). Ebay keeps no inventory and takes no responsibility for authenticity of the wares being showcased on its screens. It does take a variable percentage of each final bid, making it one of the few Internet ventures to be profitable.
Ebay's hands-off formula has raised concerns about fraud. There have been numerous instances where genuinely naive sellers have misrepresented their wares -- advertising an 18th-century British sea chest, for example, when they have a 19th-century traveling trunk. Instances of outright theft, where buyers send off their checks and never receive their booty, although far rarer, have also occurred. While the company insists that 99.9 percent of the transactions on its site go off without a complaint, the Federal Government is investigating individual allegations of fraud. And Ebay reached a settlement last month with the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs in which it agreed to take steps to weed out fraudulent sellers. The company also recently signed a deal with Collector's Universe, an authentification service to which sellers can pay a fee if they want their items evaluated and vouched for.
Still, consumers are voting with their modems, and as they continue to click on Ebay, competitors are trying to cut in. Last month, the on-line bookseller Amazon.com opened its own auction house. Sotheby's and Christie's, the gold standard of traditional practitioners, have said they will soon deign to peddle by modem. And a plethora of niche sites like gunbroker.com, planet bike and mobilia.com, for car buffs, are proliferating.
 
Seventh Heaven For Collectors
If Ebay's diverse population is any indication, the new sites may well find customers. A considerable part of the on-line auction crowd is made up of longtime collectors who buy and sell off line as well. But the Web seems to be igniting the collecting impulse among those who might otherwise have been content to buy retail or not at all.
Stephanie Cannode, 23, a nurse in Kenton, Ohio, for instance, recently began collecting My Little Ponies, which she remembers fondly from her not-so-distant youth. After showing off her on-line finds, Ms. Cannode must now contend for computer time with her father, who scours the auction boards for Zippo lighters; her mother, whose passion is Beanie Babies, and her brother, who recently went to a Nascar race with tickets he bought on Ebay.
Perhaps the most seductive aspect of the auction is the scent of a good bargain. Frequent bidders tend to develop elaborate strategies to outwit the competition, from listing a top bid at the outset and letting the computer take care of the rest, to swooping in during the final minutes after competing bidders have shown their hands.
Some, like Darren Jer of Manhattan, who bought a digital camera at a Cyberian Outpost auction last week for $620 plus $6 shipping, come away crowing. "When it comes to buying consumer electronics equipment on the Web, I'm pretty assiduous about finding the best price," said Mr. Jer, 25, who said he had never tried an auction before. "And I got this for $100 below market value. I'm a happy customer."
 
Logic and Reason Out the Window
Others are more familiar with the notorious "winner's curse."
"If you've got to have something, that will definitely push you over the edge," said Tony Porzio, 38, of Albuquerque, N.M., who concedes he may have overpaid just a tad for a 1964 World's Fair subway map. "But if you've got to have something, you'll pay what you have to pay. That's really the beauty of it."
The other half of the equation is a country full of entrepreneurs tickled to make a buck as they clean out their basements. Mark Siegel, a computer programmer in Miami, has taken to ransacking his closets for items to offer on Ebay. No wonder. So far he has sold a Tori Amos CD, the import version of "Upside Down," for $142, and a copy of the first American issue of Maxim, a men's magazine, that he describes as "basically worthless" for $71. "I personally get a thrill out of selling junk that I would have probably thrown out," he said.
Robert Lavallie, 28, of the Bronx started out as a buyer but quickly became a seller after hearing a friend's sheepish account of having paid $325 for some "Planet of the Apes" action figures that he could have bought at a toy store for $75.
"As a seller I just saw that people were insane enough to pay ridiculous prices for some items," Mr. Lavallie said. "It's not like you actually have your cash in your hand, so you don't realize what you're doing. You lose track of logic and reason."
In fact the barriers to selling on the Web through auction are so minimal that a small but significant group of people have quit their jobs to become full-time merchants. A much larger number sell as a hobby or to make petty cash.
Take Danny Friedman, a 12-year-old Manhattanite, who has discovered that he can make up to $125 a month buying Beanie Babies cheaply in New York City and reselling them to collectors in rural areas. Just recently, he bought Spooky the ghost for $5 and auctioned it off for $38.
While hobbyists rushed in, more established retailers (even pure Internet merchants) resisted the auction format, worried that a bad customer experience could damage name brand credibility. But that's changing. Deva Hazarika, founder of MOAI, a firm that designs auction software, has seen a surge of interest from professionals looking for tools to differentiate their sites from the crowd. "Companies selling directly to consumer see it as a way to create excitement," he said. It will not be long, he predicts, before retailers routinely offer on-line auctions as an alternative format for holding sales.
 
A Way to Dump Excess Inventory
Bruce Van Kleeck, spokesman for the National Retail Federation, also sees a future where traditional retailers use net auctions as a way to dump excess inventory. "Why not have a factory outlet on line where people bid for goods?" he asks. "Ultimately, it makes logical sense."
Of course, sellers of fixed-price goods face pitfalls in entering the auction venue. They must avoid, for example, the potentially ire-inspiring situation where consumers end up bidding more for merchandise than they would have paid in the store. The Web site for Lands' End has been experimenting with reverse auctions for almost two years. On Saturday it puts a limited quantity of some clothing item, like a denim dress, on sale for 25 percent off, but alerts customers that as the week progresses it will continue to mark down the goods. Customers then have to weigh the extent of the discount against the likelihood of the item selling out when deciding whether to bid, but they never risk being burned by paying more than an item's original listed worth.
But the spread of such clever efficiency could defeat the whole purpose. "It's spread the knowledge of what the market price is to every tiny little town in the world," said William Gibson, the science fiction author who coined the term "cyberspace," and who wrote about his Ebay addiction in a recent issue of Wired magazine. "Sometimes I worry there will be such a severe rationalization of the market that the fun will go out of the hunt."

HEADLINE: Saving New York's Shipping

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey and Gov. George Pataki of New York have long had profound differences over how to run the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. At the moment, they have an obligation to put those differences aside and conduct themselves like allies for the sake of the regional economy.
At issue is the need to hang onto the lucrative business generated by two major ocean cargo carriers, Sea-Land Service and Maersk, which Maryland and Baltimore are wooing.The two companies have set today as the deadline for receiving the authority's new lease arrangements. The carriers have asked for a refurbished terminal in New Jersey offering better berths, cranes to service huge cargo carriers, and deeper channels. While the Governors have been bickering, Maryland sweetened its offer. 
 Unless New York and New Jersey devise a creative counterproposal, the region could lose two anchors of its maritime economy that provide more than 80,000 jobs in cargo, freight handling, rail and other businesses in New Jersey and about the same number of east-of-Hudson jobs in freight forwarding, warehousing, trucking, banking and insurance.
Mr. Pataki has some legitimate gripes. The authority spends at least $200 million from profitable operations like Newark, Kennedy and La Guardia airports on subsidizing deficit operations like the PATH trains and the Port Authority bus terminal, which mainly serves New Jersey. Cross-subsidies are crucial to financing transit in both states. But those for PATH and the terminal are too high.
Mr. Pataki wants a pool of investment dollars for New York comparable to the value of the Sea-Land and Maersk improvements in New Jersey. He would also restructure the authority itself so that revenue and income from facilities in each state would be invested in that state. But talks on such issues should not disrupt the urgent business -- the possible loss of major shipping contracts.

HEADLINE: Showdown Ahead Over Political Agenda in Congress

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
As Congress returned today, House Democrats prepared an offensive against the House Republican leadership intended to force a vote to overhaul campaign finance laws. At the same time, House Republicans contemplated embracing an issue traditionally championed by Democrats: an increase in the minimum wage.
The jostling for position indicated that after the impeachment trial of President Clinton, followed by weeks of relative silence in Congress, the battle over which party controls the political agenda is about to intensify, particularly in the narrowly divided House. And as they struggle over a wide range of domestic concerns, including health-care policy, tax cuts, spending and the shape of the Social Security system, both parties face calculations about which issues they want to promote, which they want to neutralize and on which they want to campaign in 2000. 
 The Republicans are trying to keep attention on four main themes this spring: Social Security, tax cuts, education and national defense. Today they reconciled minor differences in House and Senate budget blueprints, and they planned to push through both houses this week a budget that they said would wall off Social Security payroll tax receipts so that they could not be diverted to other uses. The budget plan for the 2000 fiscal year would also make room for at least $15 billion in tax cuts next year, growing to as much as $800 billion in tax cuts over the next decade.
The budget is a policy blueprint that sets the guidelines for an array of spending bills and tax-cutting legislation and a monthslong struggle is expected with Mr. Clinton over the size of tax cuts and the shape of domestic spending programs.
Anticipating that battle, Congressional Republican leaders today sought to rally the public behind tax cuts at a town hall meeting in Fredericksburg, Va., alongside Gov. James S. Gilmore 3d, a Republican who won election in 1997 by pledging to eliminate the state's unpopular personal property tax on cars.
"Often in government there's competing philosophies," said Representative Thomas M. Davis 3d, the Virginia Republican who heads the House Republicans' re-election effort.
In a swipe at the Democrats, Mr. Davis said, "There's one group in government that seems to believe that if it moves, tax it; if it keeps moving, regulate it; and if it stops moving, subsidize it."
But the Republican plan to cut taxes, though walling off Social Security money, would require stiff spending cuts that even many of the Republicans charged with writing the spending bills have complained would prove too difficult.
Democrats are pushing their own agenda including an increase in the minimum wage, an array of education programs and an overhaul of the campaign finance system. They also want stricter controls on health maintenance organizations, and they are hoping to draw moderate Republicans to their side on some of these issues. Republicans are writing their own health care measures, but unlike the Democrats they do not want to give patients the right to sue H.M.O.'s.
"Obviously we're going to spend a lot of time getting a budget done," said Representative Martin T. Meehan, Democrat of Massachusetts. "But we've had nothing on health care, nothing on H.M.O. reform. Really, if the Speaker wanted to send a message that he was going to work in a bipartisan way, the first bill we would have considered would have been campaign finance reform."
Last year, a coalition of House Republicans and Democrats managed to overcome an array of obstacles put before them by the Republican leadership and pass by a vote of 252 to 179 a bipartisan campaign finance bill sponsored by Representative Christoper Shays, Republican of Connecticut, and Mr. Meehan. The measure, which died in the Senate, would ban the unregulated and unlimited donations to political parties that were at the heart of the campaign finance abuses in the 1996 Presidential campaign.
The new Speaker, J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, has indicated that although he will allow a campaign finance debate, he does not plan to take up the measure until all the spending bills are passed. But proponents of the Shays-Meehan bill want it passed quickly so there will be pressure on the Senate to act.
Seeking to force the issue to the House floor, Representative Jim Turner, Democrat of Texas, said a group of Democrats on Wednesday would begin to collect signatures on a petition demanding a vote on the measure. The signatures of 218 House members are required for such a petition effort to succeed. A crucial question will be how many Republicans join the Democrats.
"I don't know that I anticipate Republican members joining us immediately," Mr. Turner said. "But I think the pressure will increase as the days pass."
The House Republican leadership is showing more flexibility on another measure usually associated with Democrats, an increase in the minimum wage. The Republicans' traditional allies in business oppose the bill, but it is popular with the public and a number of Republican moderates like Representative Jack Quinn of New York favor the measure, which means it is likely to have the votes to pass.
Senior Republican strategists say they are considering moving to the floor this summer a bill to increase the minimum wage, depriving Democrats of the potent issue.
"You get it on the floor and get it off the floor as quickly possible," said a Republican House strategist. "Why drag it out and let them make a huge issue out of it given the vote margin we have?"
The Democrats want to raise the minimum wage to $6.15 from $5.15 an hour over two years. Mr. Quinn would raise it to $6.15 over three years and index it for inflation in future years. It was not clear what kind of increase the Republican leadership would allow to the floor.

HEADLINE: U.S. Hard Put to Find Proof Bin Laden Directed Attacks

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

 BODY:
American commandos are poised near the Afghan border, hoping to capture Osama bin Laden, the man charged with blowing up two American embassies in Africa eight months ago, senior American officials say.
But they still do not know how to find him. They are depending on his protectors in Afghanistan to betray him -- a slim reed of hope for one of the biggest and most complicated international criminal investigations in American history. 
 Capturing Mr. bin Laden alive could deepen the complications. American officials say that so far, firsthand evidence that could be used in court to prove that he commanded the bombings has proven difficult to obtain. According to the public record, none of the informants involved in the case have direct knowledge of Mr. bin Laden's involvement.
For now, officials say, Federal prosecutors appear to be building a case that his violent words and ideas, broadcast from an Afghan cave, incited terrorist acts thousands of miles away.
In their war against Mr. bin Laden, American officials portray him as the world's most dangerous terrorist. But reporters for The New York Times and the PBS program "Frontline," working in cooperation, have found him to be less a commander of terrorists than an inspiration for them.
Enemies and supporters, from members of the Saudi opposition to present and former American intelligence officials, say he may not be as globally powerful as some American officials have asserted. But his message and aims have more resonance among Muslims around the world than has been understood here.
"You can kill Osama bin Laden today or tomorrow; you can arrest him and put him on trial in New York or in Washington," said Ahmed Sattar, an aide to Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the blind Egyptian cleric convicted of inspiring the bombing of the World Trade Center in 1993. "If this will end the problem -- no. Tomorrow you will get somebody else."
Interviews with senior American officials and knowledgeable observers of Mr. bin Laden in Pakistan, Sudan and elsewhere suggest that there is widespread support among ordinary people in the Muslim world for his central political argument: that American troops should get out of Saudi Arabia. The embassy bombings, they note, took place eight years to the day after the G.I.'s were ordered onto Saudi soil.
The interviews also raise questions about key assertions that have been made by the Government about Mr. bin Laden. Senior intelligence officials concede that their knowledge of him is sketchy.
"We can't say for sure what was going on" with him from 1991 to 1996 -- most of the years covered in the indictment -- one senior official said.
 
His Affluence Seems Overstated
Present and former American officials and former business associates of Mr. bin Laden say he appears to control only a fraction of the $250 million fortune that the American Government says he possesses.
"Clearly, his money's running out," said Frank Anderson, a former senior Central Intelligence Agency official who maintains close Middle Eastern contacts.
Larry Johnson, the State Department deputy counterterrorism director from 1988 to 1993, said Administration officials had "tended to make Osama bin Laden sort of a Superman in Muslim garb -- he's 10 feet tall, he's everywhere, he knows everything, he's got lots of money and he can't be challenged."
Milton Bearden, a retired senior C.I.A. official who ran the agency's war in Afghanistan and retired in 1995, said the Government had "created a North Star" in Mr. bin Laden.
"He is public enemy No. 1," Mr. Bearden said. "We've got a $5 million reward out for his head. And now we have, with I'm not sure what evidence, linked him to all of the terrorist acts of this year -- of this decade, perhaps."
Political leaders in Sudan and Pakistan who have met Mr. bin Laden describe him as intelligent, soft-spoken, polite. They also say he is deadly serious about his violent brand of radical politics and capable of killing in God's name.
Mr. bin Laden was born into the ruling class of Saudi Arabia. His father was the favorite construction magnate of the Saudi royal family, who gave Mr. bin Laden's family huge contracts to renovate the holy cities of Mecca and Medina and build palaces for Saudi princes.
American officials calculated Mr. bin Laden's fortune by estimating the family fortune at $5 billion and dividing by 20, the number of male heirs. But business associates of Mr. bin Laden said his family cut him off years ago and are managing his share of his inheritance for him as long as he is disowned. Business associates say that Mr. bin Laden has been living on a generous allowance from his eldest brother and that his assets in Saudi Arabia are now frozen.
In 1980, at 22, Mr. bin Laden left Saudi Arabia and moved to the Afghan frontier. In Peshawar, Pakistan -- working alongside, but never directly allied with, the C.I.A. -- he used his money and his machines to help the Afghan rebels fight the Soviet Army invaders.
The Afghan war shaped Mr. bin Laden, those who know him say. "He is an ordinary person who is very religious," said President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan, who met Mr. bin Laden often from 1992 to 1996. "He believes in the rule of Islam and where possible the establishment of an Islamic state. The time that he spent in Afghanistan led him to believe that this might be achieved through military means."
Legend has it that Mr. bin Laden fought bravely against Soviet troops. But former C.I.A. officers say he was a financier, not a warrior -- "a philanthropist supporting a number of health care, widows-and-orphans charity operations in Peshawar for Afghan refugees," as Mr. Anderson put it.
He also helped create a headquarters called Al Qaeda, the Base. It was a way station in Peshawar where Egyptian and Saudi volunteers rested before setting off for battle in Afghanistan. Its name became a kind of flag uniting Mr. bin Laden's followers. American officials call it a global terrorist network.
When the Soviet forces left Afghanistan in 1989, Mr. bin Laden went home to Saudi Arabia. He soon set his sights on the last remaining superpower.
"He himself was very much wary about America," said Saad al-Faqih, a Saudi exile living in London, who worked as a surgeon for wounded Afghan fighters, "very skeptical about America and the Saudi regime."
He found a new enemy on Aug. 7, 1990, when the United States began sending half a million soldiers to Saudi Arabia, preparing for war against Iraq.
"One of the stories put out by bin Laden is that he went to King Fahd and promised that he would raise holy warriors who would protect Saudi Arabia," said Mr. Anderson, who was the chief of the C.I.A.'s Near East operations in the mid-1990's. "His violent opposition to the Saudi royal family began when King Fahd denied or rejected that offer."
 
Americans Painted As New Crusaders
To Mr. bin Laden the deployment of Americans in the land of Mecca and Medina smacked of the Crusades, the Christian religious wars against Islam that began nine centuries ago. His rage transformed him into a stateless outlaw.
In November 1991, Saudi intelligence officers caught Mr. bin Laden smuggling weapons from Yemen, his father's homeland. They withdrew his passport. Soon afterward he made his way to Sudan, which had decreed its borders open to all Muslims, with or without passports or visas.
Veterans of the Afghan jihad, or holy war, against Moscow followed Mr. bin Laden, under Al Qaeda's banner. But "when Al Qaeda was moved to Sudan, it lost around 70 percent of its members," Mamdouh Mahmud Salim, accused of being an associate of Mr. bin Laden, said during an interrogation by the German police after his arrest in September.
"This group didn't have a purpose except to carry out the jihad," Mr. Salim said, "and since nobody carried out the jihad, it lost a lot of its members."
 
He Lived As an Investor
There were three kinds of men in Al Qaeda, he said. First, "people who had no success in life, had nothing in their heads and wanted to join just to keep from falling on their noses." Second, "people who loved their religion but had no idea what their religion really meant." And third, "people who have nothing in their heads but to fight and solve all the problems in the world with battles."
Mr. bin Laden lived in Khartoum, the Sudanese capital, "as an investor," said President Bashir. "With his money, he was adventurous, and probably he gained this mentality by his experiences as a fighter."
The indictment against Mr. bin Laden says he provided training camps in Sudan where Afghan war veterans prepared for terrorist missions. But a senior American intelligence official contradicted that, saying, "There was never a bin Laden-financed training camp in Sudan."
The official added: "In 1993, '94, '95, he's managing and building up his legitimate business presence there in Sudan. I won't pretend we've got a good intelligence base on this period, but we think he was laying the groundwork for Al Qaeda."
In 1995 two C.I.A. officers were stalked by teen-age followers of Mr. bin Laden in the streets of Khartoum. "Bin Laden was approached by us and was told that this would not be tolerated," said Ghazi Salaheldin, the Sudanese Information Minister. Sudan expelled the teen-agers.
In the face of such perceived threats -- though some were mirages, based on a slew of false C.I.A. reports -- the United States withdrew from Sudan in late 1995. The absence of American diplomats and spies in the country diminished Washington's ability to know what Mr. bin Laden was doing at the very moment he stepped up his political war.
In 1995, after the Saudi Government rescinded his citizenship, he began sending scathing attacks on the royal family from Khartoum.
"Bin Laden took a chance and started doing some political activities," President Bashir said, "not terrorist activities, but he started issuing political bulletins and communiques and faxes" denouncing the Saudi Government as corrupt and repressive.
The United States took notice. "There had been confusion" after the World Trade Center bombing about the nature of radical Islamic threats to the United States, said Mr. Johnson, the former senior counterterrorism official.
 
No Evidence To Implicate Him
"There were lots of theories, not very good intelligence, and so the intelligence community actually started generating a picture that Osama bin Laden was, if you will, the new face of terrorism," he said.
On May 31, 1996, four Saudis were beheaded after confessing to bombing a Saudi National Guard post in Riyadh and killing five Americans. All told their interrogators that they had received Mr. bin Laden's communiques. Only 25 days later, a truck bomb tore through a military post in Dhahran, killing 19 American soldiers.
Mr. bin Laden was blamed by American officials for instigating the attacks. But no known evidence implicates him, and the Saudi Interior Minister, Prince Nayef ibn Abdel Aziz, has absolved him. "Maybe there are people who adopt his ideas," Prince Nayef said. "He does not constitute any security problem to us."
Shortly before the Dhahran attack, Mr. bin Laden and members of his entourage left Sudan in a C-130 military transport plane. The Sudanese had asked him to leave -- at the request of the United States. Mr. bin Laden landed at an American-built airport in Kandahar, Afghanistan. Three months later, on Aug. 23, 1996, he declared war on the United States.
"The situation in Saudi Arabia is like a great volcano about to erupt," his declaration stated. "Everyone talks openly about economic recession, high prices, debt" and "the filling up of the prisons."
 
How Did He Control the Bombers?
Mr. bin Laden's criticisms of Saudi repression and corruption closely corresponded with State Department reports and C.I.A. analyses. But Mr. bin Laden blamed the United States. "The root of the problem is the occupying American enemy," he proclaimed, "and all efforts should focus on killing, fighting and destroying it."
A second, more ominous warning from him came on Feb. 23, 1998: "To kill Americans and their allies, both civil and military, is an individual duty of every Muslim who is able, in any country where this is possible," until American armies, "shattered and broken-winged, depart from all the lands of Islam."
Then came the embassy bombings last August. American authorities say the men who attacked the embassies in Kenya and Tanzania were controlled by Mr. bin Laden. But they still have no clear idea how.
Despite efforts at the highest levels of the United States Government, Mr. bin Laden and his closest associates remain isolated in Afghanistan.
It is difficult to say precisely where the criminal case against Mr. bin Laden stands. Prosecutors have obtained unusually restrictive court orders that bar the defendants and their lawyers from communicating with virtually anyone.
 
The Case Runs Out of Steam
Publicly, at least, the case has lost momentum. While two men suspected of being bombers were quickly apprehended, many other suspects are still at large. The last arrest was more than six months ago. A spokesman for the United States Attorney in Manhattan declined comment.
Now the hunt for Mr. bin Laden depends on whether the Taliban, his radical hosts in Afghanistan, will betray him. The United States has little leverage with the Taliban, and little fresh intelligence on how to capture Mr. bin Laden. It has no spies in Afghanistan and little new information on precisely how he might have instigated the deadly bombings.
"I do not have a clear picture yet of what happened when," said Prudence Bushnell, the United States Ambassador to Kenya, who was wounded in the bomb blast, which killed 12 of her colleagues. "I may not ever have a clear picture of what happened when. None of us may."
 
A COLLABORATION
This article resulted from a collaboration between The New York Times and the PBS program "Frontline," which will broadcast a documentary tonight about Osama bin Laden that will run on most PBS stations at 9 o'clock. The "Frontline" program was based on the work of Lowell Bergman, correspondent, Martin Smith, producer, and Orianna Zill and Ivana Damjanov, associate producers.
