HEADLINE: Teacher Turned Playwright Is Among the Winners of 22 Pulitzer Prizes

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
An Atlanta kindergarten teacher, a biographer of Charles A. Lindbergh and a writer who spent 20 years researching the geologic history of North America were awarded Pulitzer Prizes yesterday.
The teacher, Margaret Edson, was awarded the prize for drama, for her intricately layered play, "Wit," which chronicles a college professor's death from cancer. 
 The Pulitzer Board gave the award for biography to A. Scott Berg's "Lindbergh," a book that examined the aviator's complex life, from his 1927 one-man flight from New York to Paris to his Nazi sympathies, a transformation one onlooker at the time described with the phrase "from Jesus to Judas."
John McPhee, a staff writer at The New Yorker for 34 years and a professor at Princeton University, won the general nonfiction award for "Annals of the Former World," a 696-page examination of the geologic life of North America. It was the 28th book by Mr. McPhee.
Two prizes were awarded to The New York Times. Maureen Dowd, an Op-Ed page columnist, won the award for commentary for a series of columns on the national impact of President Clinton's affair with Monica S. Lewinsky and his pursuit by Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel. The award for national reporting was given to the staff, with a special mention for Jeff Gerth, for a series of articles that reported that despite national security risks, two aerospace companies had improperly shared expertise with China with the approval of the United States Government.
The prize for editorial writing was awarded to the editorial board of The Daily News, for its campaign to rescue the Apollo Theater in Harlem from financial mismanagement. It was the newspaper's third Pulitzer in the last four years.
The Associated Press won the prize in feature photography for its collection of photographs of the major figures and events stemming from President Clinton's affair with Ms. Lewinsky.
The A.P. was also awarded the prize for spot news photography for its portfolio of images following the embassy bombings in Kenya and Tanzania.
The prize for investigative reporting went to the staff of The Miami Herald for revealing pervasive voter fraud in a city mayoral election. The results of the election were later overturned.
The award for beat reporting was given to Chuck Philips and Michael A. Hiltzik of The Los Angeles Times for their stories on corruption in the entertainment industry, including articles about a sham charity sponsored by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences and the resurgence of payola in the radio industry.
The award for international reporting was given to the staff of The Wall Street Journal for the newspaper's coverage of the Russian financial crisis.
The Hartford Courant staff was given the award for breaking news reporting, for its coverage of a shooting rampage in which a state lottery worker killed four supervisors and then committed suicide.
The staff of The Washington Post won the award for public service, for a series that identified and analyzed patterns of reckless gunplay by city police officers who were inadequately trained or supervised. The articles combined data with what Leonard Downie Jr., The Post's executive editor, called "old-fashioned shoe-leather reporting."
It was the first public service Pulitzer for The Post since 1973, when it won for its Watergate coverage.
The prizes are administered by the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism.
The Pulitzer administrator, Seymour Topping, said the singling out of Mr. Gerth from among six reporters was rare for a staff award, which is given to work produced by more than three reporters.
"When we see an instance where a reporter has done very outstanding work and carried a great deal of the burden of the story, we adjust the citation to take note of that," he said.
For more than two decades, Mr. Gerth has been at the forefront of the nation's investigative reporting. In 1992, he wrote the original story on the financial dealings of the President and Mrs. Clinton in the failed Arkansas real estate venture known as Whitewater.
The award for feature writing was given to Angelo B. Henderson of The Wall Street Journal. Richard Read of The Oregonian was awarded the prize for explanatory reporting.
In a year that was notable for long novels introduced with great public-relations fanfare -- like Tom Wolfe's "Man in Full" -- Michael Cunningham's book "The Hours," a slim novel that arrived quietly, won the fiction award for its retelling of Virginia Woolf's "Mrs. Dalloway" from three perspectives.
The prize for history went to "Gotham: A History of New York City to 1898" by Edwin G. Burrows and Mike Wallace.
Mark Strand won the award for poetry, for his volume of poems titled "Blizzard of One."
And a special posthumous citation was bestowed on Edward Kennedy Ellington, the jazz legend better known as Duke.
Ms. Edson, speaking from the office of the assistant principal at Centennial Place Elementary School in Atlanta, said she was told of the award as she was cleaning up after a class project about insects. She said that she would tell her kindergarten class about the prize today.
"I think, as much as they get the idea of the Pulitzers, they will be very pleased," she said, adding that she had no plans to quit her job as a kindergarten teacher.
 
DRAMA
MARGARET EDSON
"Wit"
It seemed somewhat unlikely dramatic fodder, but by weaving together the sonnets of John Donne with a literature professor's battle with ovarian cancer, Ms. Edson wrought a play which, Peter Marks's wrote in his New York Times review, "finds poetry in the reading of a sonogram and science in the deconstruction of a sonnet."
Ms. Edson, 37, is a first-time playwright and full-time kindergarten teacher in Atlanta. (She was called out of her classroom to the principal's office when the award was announced.) She said that the play, which played Off Off Broadway before moving to an Off Broadway theater, was inspired by her experiences working in a cancer and AIDS ward in a hospital in Washington.
"It's really about the relationship between love and knowledge," she said yesterday. "And in the end, about grace."
 
GENERAL NONFICTION
JOHN McPHEE
"Annals of the Former World"
Starting in 1978, Mr. McPhee crisscrossed the United States to gather information about the country's formation over billions of years. The book combines his four previously published volumes on American geology, including "Assembling California," and adds a fifth section on the American Midwest. It tells not only geological history but the history of geology and the stories of the scientists who have worked out the histories of rock and mountain from the plains of Brooklyn to the San Andreas fault.
 
POETRY
MARK STRAND
"Blizzard of One"
Mark Strand, who was born in Canada, is the author of nine books of poetry. He teaches in the Committee on Social Thought at the University of Chicago. Mr. Strand, 65, has been called a "Platonic" poet. His verse is spare, magisterial, his themes universal rather than particular. Thus, in the poem that provides the title for his prize-winning collection, a snowflake is not simply itself, but rather a focal point for Mr. Strand's meditation on absence and death.
From the shadow of domes in the city of domes,
A snowflake, a blizzard of one, weightless, entered your room
And made its way to the arm of the chair where you, looking up
From your book, saw it the moment it landed. That's all
There was to it. No more than a solemn waking
To brevity, to the lifting and falling away of attention, swiftly,
A time between times, a flowerless funeral. No more than that
Except for the feeling that this piece of the storm,
Which turned into nothing before your eyes, would come back,
That someone years hence, sitting as you are now, might say:
"It's time. The air is ready. The sky has an opening.
 
BIOGRAPHY
A. SCOTT BERG
"Lindbergh"
Mr. Berg has written three exhaustive biographies. The first two were of the editor Maxwell Perkins and the film producer Samuel Goldwyn. For "Lindbergh" (G. P. Putnam's Sons), Mr. Berg spent nine years researching the life of the pioneer aviator whose flight across the Atlantic in 1927 made him what Mr. Berg calls "the first modern media superstar." Mr. Berg, 49, who lives in Los Angeles, found Lindbergh an immensely complicated figure, cold and distant to his family and tainted by words of support for Adolf Hitler, but nonetheless a "solid-gold hero."
 
HISTORY
MIKE WALLACE and EDWIN G. BURROWS
"Gotham: A History of New York to 1898"
For two decades, Professors Wallace and Burrows labored in the shadows with "Gotham: A History of New York to 1898" (Oxford University Press). Their 1,383-page populist tale brings humor and narrative drive to the story of New York City. Mr. Wallace is a history professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice; Mr. Burrows is a history professor at Brooklyn College.
 
FICTION
MICHAEL CUNNINGHAM
"The Hours"
In "The Hours" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), Mr. Cunningham conjures a parallel between Virginia Woolf's "Mrs. Dalloway" and his own novel, moving from a fictionalized portrait of Woolf herself in London in the 1920's to Los Angeles in 1949 and New York in the 1990's. The theme of "The Hours," a reviewer wrote in The New York Times Book Review, is "the haunting of present lives by memories and books, by distant pasts and missed futures, by novels and poems to be read and written."
Mr. Cunningham, who was born in Cincinnati in 1952, graduated from Stanford University and the University of Iowa. He teaches writing at Columbia University.
"It had seemed like the beginning of happiness, and Clarissa is still sometimes shocked, more than 30 years later, to realize that it was happiness. . . . There is still that singular perfection, and it's perfect in part because it seemed, at the time, so clearly to promise more. Now she knows: That was the moment, right then. There has been no other."
 
MUSIC
MELINDA WAGNER
Concerto for Flute, Strings and Percussion
Ms. Wagner, a 42-year-old composer who was born in Philadelphia and lives in Ridgewood, N.J., is an imaginative musical fantasist who once described her accessible, inviting music as "not really about anything that could happen in the world, but about the exploration and potential of ideas concerning sound." In her three-movement concerto, considerable expressive variety is demanded of the solo flute line, which is set against a sparkling, tactile orchestral texture. The work was given its premiere by Paul Dunkel, the flutist, with the Westchester Philharmonic on May 31, 1998.
 
SPECIAL CITATION
DUKE ELLINGTON
On the centennial of his birth, the Pulitzer Prize Board cited Edward Kennedy (Duke) Ellington for his indelible contribution to art and culture through the medium of jazz.
Duke Ellington's protean career, lasting over 50 years, connected jazz's beginnings before the 1920's with its most modern aspects in the 1970's. From his earliest recordings until his death in 1974, he strengthened his command of jazz composition and arrangement. By the 1940's, at the helm of an 18-piece band, he was one of the most innovative and popular composers in America, bridging the realms of dance music and sophisticated art song.
Starting in 1943, Ellington composed a string of tone poems, suites and sacred music, including "Black, Brown and Beige" and "Such Sweet Thunder." His final extended pieces were the liturgical "Sacred Concerts."
 
PUBLIC SERVICE
THE WASHINGTON POST
In its series "Deadly Force," The Post concluded that District of Columbia officers shot and killed more people per resident than any other large city police force.
A Post reporter suspected that the Federal Bureau of Investigation collected but did not disclose police-shooting data. Through repeated requests under the Freedom of Information Act, The Post's computer-assisted reporting team got the data and then analyzed it. Then reporters reviewed previous homicides, talked to the police and prosecutors and at one point test-fired police handguns.
The Post concluded that shootings were so numerous because of poor police training, hair-trigger handguns and questionable tactics, like shooting at moving cars.
 
NATIONAL REPORTING
STAFF OF THE NEW YORK TIMES
The New York Times staff, notably Jeff Gerth, was honored for a series of articles disclosing the corporate sale of American technology to China, with the approval of the United States Government despite national security risks.
The Times reporters documented how the Democratic Party's newest financial backers, high-tech entrepreneurs, had lobbied the Clinton Administration to change the rules. The series prompted official investigations and major changes in policy.
 
BREAKING NEWS REPORTING
STAFF OF THE HARTFORD COURANT
The Courant was awarded the prize for its "clear and detailed coverage" of a shooting rampage in which a state lottery worker shot four supervisors before turning the gun on himself.
The day after the shooting, The Courant published some 13 stories accompanied by a map that traced the gunman's violent trek through the building and a detailed timeline of events.
Coverage also included a profile of the gunman, who had called a Courant reporter the day before the killings.
 
EDITORIAL WRITING
THE DAILY NEWS EDITORIAL BOARD
The Apollo Theater on 125th Street in Harlem may once have been "where stars are born and legends are made," as its motto avers. But more recently, the historic theater has been in decay, as editorial writers from The Daily News discovered during a visit in March 1998, said Michael Goodwin, editor of the editorial page.
The News's editorial board began a campaign to rescue the theater, which is now owned by the State of New York and is run by a foundation. A series of editorials exposing financial mismanagement at the foundation prompted the Attorney General to file a civil suit to try to remove the board of directors, and led state officials to take a more active role in revitalizing the landmark theater.
 
FEATURE WRITING
ANGELO B. HENDERSON
The Wall Street Journal
Mr. Henderson, The Journal's deputy bureau chief in Detroit, read an account of a pharmacist who shot and killed a would-be robber. He guessed it was a man he had interviewed years earlier.
Mr. Henderson contacted him, as well as the family of the victim. "Two lives came to a crossroads that day," he said. His story was honored for illustrating the lasting effects of crime.
Now a senior special writer, Mr. Henderson, 36, a native of Louisville, lives in Detroit, where is also a deacon of his Baptist Church.
 
BEAT REPORTING
CHUCK PHILIPS and MICHAEL A. HILTZIK
The Los Angeles Times
As business writers for The Los Angeles Times, Mr. Philips and Mr. Hiltzik examined corruption in the entertainment industry in three separate projects. They examined the music industry's richest awards program, the Grammys, and showed that its charities spend pennies on the dollar toward its stated goals of assisting unemployed and disabled musicians. Next, they looked into the epidemic of drug use among prominent entertainers and the detoxification programs illicitly run for them. Finally, the reporters explored a resurgence of radio payola -- illicit payments for radio airplay of new recordings.
 
INTERNATIONAL REPORTING
STAFF OF THE WALL STREET JOURNAL
The Journal staff won for its in-depth, analytical coverage of the Russian financial crisis.
Andrew T. Higgins, 41, the Moscow bureau chief, and a team of five reporters explained what propelled Russia's crisis in a series of front-page articles last year. Mr. Higgins has been assigned to the Moscow bureau since July 1998.
The stories were also written and researched by Bob Davis, 48, who covers the White House; Steve Liesman, 35, who covers international oil and gas industries in New York; Elizabeth W. McKay, 37, a reporter in Moscow; Carla Anne Robbins, 45, who covers national security issues and diplomacy, and Mark Philip Whitehouse, 32, a reporter in Moscow.
 
EXPLANATORY REPORTING
RICHARD READ
The Oregonian (Portland, Ore.)
Mr. Read, 41, who covers international business for The Oregonian, won for "The French Fry Connection," a series last fall that, by chronicling the journey of 20 tons of potatoes from Oregon to Southeast Asia, documented how the Asian financial crisis threatened the economy of the Pacific Northwest. "The fate of of one particular load of french fries," Mr. Read wrote, "and the lives and cultures of those who handled it, illuminates the causes and effects of Asia's anguish the way no economic treatise ever could."
 
INVESTIGATIVE REPORTING
STAFF OF THE MIAMI HERALD
A team of reporters on the staff of The Herald won for a series of six articles leading to a reversal of the 1997 election of Xavier Suarez as Mayor, a post he had held from 1985 to 1993. The reporters uncovered hundreds of fraudulent ballots including ones from voters outside the city, voters who claimed their signatures were forged on absentee ballots and voters who were paid $10 each. As a result, the election was nullified by a judge, and Joe Carolla, Mr. Suarez's opponent, was appointed Mayor.
 
COMMENTARY
MAUREEN DOWD
The New York Times
Maureen Dowd, a columnist for the New York Times Op-Ed page, was honored for the moral insight and wit she brought to bear on the combat between President Clinton and Kenneth W. Starr. When Mr. Starr's report came out in September, Ms. Dowd concluded: "These are not grounds for impeachment. These are grounds for divorce."
Ms. Dowd joined The Times as a metropolitan reporter in October 1983. She was appointed a columnist of The Times in January 1995 after serving as correspondent in its Washington bureau from August 1986.
 
CRITICISM
BLAIR KAMIN
The Chicago Tribune
Mr. Kamin said memories of body surfing as a boy in New Jersey inspired his six-part series on developing Chicago's lakefront. That series helped shape the city's thinking on the future of its lakefront parks.
"The edge where the land meets the water is a sacred place that everyone in a democracy deserves access to," Mr. Kamin said. Calling himself a practitioner of "activist criticism," Mr. Kamin, a graduate of Amherst College and the Yale Graduate School of Architecture, has also crusaded to improve public housing. In 1993, he spearheaded The Tribune's national design contest for public housing, and in 1995, he wrote a six-part series on how to create public housing that works.
 
FEATURE PHOTOGRAPHY
SUSAN WALSH
The Associated Press
 President Clinton, with the First Lady next to him, addresses House Democrats outside the White House after his impeachment. The picture, part of The Associated Press's coverage of the impeachment, was published on Dec. 19, 1998.

EDITORIAL CARTOONING
DAVID HORSEY
The Seattle Post-Intelligencer
 The Post-Intelligencer won its first Pulitzer Prize for the cartoons of David Horsey, 47, whose submissions focused on a tangled sexual abuse case in Wenatchee, Wash., and the turmoil in Washington.

PUB-DATE: April 13, 1999

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1828 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Diamonds in theCold;
New Canadian Mine Seeks Its Place in a DeBeers World

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: EKATI MINE, Northwest Territories

 BODY:
To dig rough diamonds out of the Canadian tundra, operators of the first major diamond mine in North America face some of the most hostile conditions on earth -- blinding snow, bitter temperatures and a desolation so complete that for all but two months of the year, when roads cross frozen lakes, no truck can get within 150 miles of the mine.
Formidable, but all that may be the easier part of working the Ekati mine. To sell the more than four million carats of diamonds they expect to painstakingly pick out of the ground each year, the Canadian miners have to deal with one of the most potent market forces in the world: the legendary De Beers diamond cartel. 
 Simply put, the Canadians need De Beers, a subsidiary of the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa. Without it, they risk disrupting the cartel's tight grip on the market -- a grip that keeps gem prices high for all. And last month, in fact, the mine's owners agreed to sell part of its production to De Beers. But that deal carries its own risks, for antitrust regulators in Washington take a dim view of De Beers, and if the owners get too cozy with the cartel, their American businesses could suffer.
For more than 65 years, De Beers has had a near monopoly on the world's supply of rough diamonds, in some years handling upward of 80 percent of the uncut stones sold to dealers and polishers around the world. Formed during the Depression, the cartel -- sometimes called the world's most successful monopoly -- controls or influences nearly every step of diamond production, from the pace of extraction in its own mines and those run by companies with which it contracts, to the distribution of rough diamonds. It routinely stockpiles supplies when prices drop, then restricts their release to help prices recover.
De Beers argues that this is a benign monopoly benefiting almost everyone, an argument similar to the one made now by Microsoft. But the United States sees it differently. More than five decades ago, in 1945, the Justice Department initiated antitrust proceedings in New York against diamond cartel members. De Beers pulled up stakes, never to return.
The closest it came to an actual run-in with the Justice Department was in 1994, when General Electric, one of the largest producers of industrial diamonds, was charged with colluding with De Beers to raise prices. G.E. was acquitted. But to this day, De Beers has no business interests in the United States.
Yet the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, the huge Australian mining company that owns 51 percent of the Ekati mine, does have businesses in the United States -- lots of them, in copper, coal and other minerals. And B.H.P., as it is known, does not want to jeopardize those operations.
B.H.P., with annual revenues of $22 billion, is new to the diamond industry, and is not used to dealing with anything like the De Beers marketing system. After spending years getting approvals from the government and local Indian communities, and 18 months of hectic construction, B.H.P. finally began production in October and is eager to earn back its $700 million investment.
But even B.H.P. acknowledged that the cartel system had kept diamond demand growing and prices continually rising even as most other commodities, like gold and silver, have been plagued by fluctuating conditions that undercut prices and forced mines to close.
"The important thing is that they want to market the stones in an orderly fashion," said John Lydall, a mining analyst at First Marathon Securities Ltd. in Toronto. "In the diamond industry, everybody benefits from prices being high."
De Beers says that includes the 70 percent of American women who own at least one piece of diamond jewelry and want to be assured of its value. The De Beers control of the market, and its relentless advertising -- through its 52-year-old "A Diamond Is Forever" campaign -- enhance the desirability of diamonds.
De Beers does not like to lose control over any source, especially not one with the potential of the Canadian find. In 1997, Tim Capon, a De Beers director and head of the Central Selling Organization, which since 1930 has been the De Beers diamond buying and selling arm, told miners in Toronto that too many independent producers would ruin the system that has helped the global diamond market grow from $20 billion in 1985 to $50 billion last year.
It all reached a crucial point early last month. B.H.P. and its Canadian partner, Dia Met Minerals Inc., based in Kelowna, British Columbia, agreed to sell 35 percent of Ekati production for the next three years to De Beers, while marketing the rest itself, but De Beers will have no control over Ekati's production.
The compromise seems to have satisfied almost everyone. The Ekati miners hope that if they sell less than 50 percent of production to De Beers, the Justice Department will ignore the joint venture. So far, Washington has been silent.
De Beers now has a foot in the door of what could in a few years be one of the world's top five diamond-producing regions.
And, finally, the global diamond industry seems pleased. Pleased to see mighty De Beers taken down a peg or two by B.H.P.'s independent stance. Yet pleased also to see the system that has protected prices for so long remain strong.
"To the extent that the Canadians were able to rattle De Beers's cage a bit, that's a healthy thing," said Martin Rapaport, publisher of the Rapaport Diamond Report, a New York industry newsletter and price service. "But De Beers is still pretty much the only game in town."
De Beers executives appear unconcerned.
"Of course, we're keen to encourage producers to use the centralized system we have," said George Burne, managing director of the De Beers Canada Corporation, which has opened an office in Vancouver. But he said that even though Ekati could produce up to four million carats a year, that would be just a small portion of the 120-million-carat global production.
"With that volume," he said of Ekati, "it's not going to bring the house down."
The existence of diamonds in Canada's rugged north had long been suspected but was hard to pin down. De Beers first prospected in Alberta 25 years ago, but did not find deposits rich enough to make mining feasible. Finally, a dogged Canadian geologist, Charles Fipke, in 1985 came upon telltale signs of diamonds in the Lac de Gras region of the Northwest Territories, 125 miles below the Arctic Circle.
Mr. Fipke's discoveries set off a diamond rush. What he found was that many small, shallow lakes in the area were actually the worn-down remnants of ancient volcanoes from more than 35 million years ago, when the area was a steamy tropic.
Deposits -- called pipes -- were widespread in Canada's north, but the secret was finding those likely to contain enough diamonds to make mining worthwhile. Over the 25-year life of the Ekati project, annual revenues are expected to average $400 million to $500 million, but that is just a small part of B.H.P.'s business.
The area may also soon get a second mine. Diavik, 60 percent owned by the mining giant Rio Tinto P.L.C. of Britain, could receive final government approval by the end of the year. And De Beers itself, through its wholly owned subsidiary Monopros, is in a joint venture with Mountain Province Mining Inc. that is doing bulk sampling on what could be Canada's third diamond mine at Kennady Lake, not far from the other two operations.
Limited diamond mining and prospecting are done in the United States, primarily in Colorado, Wyoming and Arkansas. Little of the output is gem quality, so nearly all the production is used in industry.
Ekati is now basically an open-pit operation, but first the lake above the pipe had to be fished out and drained. What used to be Panda Lake is now Panda Pit, said Brad Skeeles, mining manager at Ekati.
For 24 hours a day, seven days a week, through everything except blinding whiteout conditions, the surrounding granite rock is removed in layers to get at the diamond-bearing material called kimberlite. Once the kimberlite is out of the ground, the process is comparatively simple, said Michael G. Rylatt, manager of the processing plant, though made more complicated by the Arctic conditions.
Because of the relentless cold, processing takes place inside one huge building, three football fields long and more than six stories high. Outside temperatures can drop to 50 degrees below. Inside, Mr. Rylatt often works in short sleeves.
Essentially, Mr. Rylatt said, Ekati uses a process developed by De Beers. The ore rock is crushed into smaller and smaller pieces, then -- using natural properties of diamonds that make them heavier than other elements -- the ore is mixed into a slurry and the diamonds and other heavy minerals are separated from the rock by centrifugal force.
The remaining material is exposed to X-rays, which makes the diamonds luminescent. A light-detecting mechanism touches off powerful jets that eject the suspected diamonds.
Only then does a small group of sorters actually pick out the diamonds. For security reasons, this is the only part of the process when human hands touch the diamonds. The plant processes 9,000 tons of ore a day. The yield: roughly one coffee can full of rough diamonds.
The environmental review of the project was controversial and extensive, with the final agreement alone filling eight four-inch binders. The local government required that a high percentage of B.H.P.'s 500 employees come from northern Canada, including Indians and Eskimos. These jobs pay $40,000 to $50,000, on average.
And Ekati agreed to cover the costs of flying the 160 natives who work at the mine to and from their home communities at the beginning and end of every two-week shift.
The first Ekati diamonds offered for sale in Antwerp, Belgium, early this year brought about $125 to $130 a carat, excluding the largest stones, which will be sold later. The total came to $8.5 million, which Mr. Lydall, the First Marathon analyst, considered encouraging. But the world diamond industry is still recovering from the economic turmoil in Japan and the Far East; De Beers's earnings dropped 40 percent last year.
To avoid the enormous expense of building three processing plants so close to each other, Ekati and the other two prospective mines are expected to consolidate some work, said Vahid Fathi, a mining analyst with ABN Amro Inc., in Chicago. "There are a lot of economic and synergistic forces that are going to force a major consolidation sooner rather than later," Mr. Fathi said.
Mr. Burne of De Beers said the company had had no discussions with the other Canadian players. Even so, De Beers will not be content with its small percentage of the Canadian mines for long.
"Who knows what sort of relationship we can have with them in the future?" Mr. Burne said. "I can tell you, we're not going to go to sleep on it."

HEADLINE: From Steinbrenner, a Triple Play for Government Investment in New Stadium

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
After 13 years of agitating about a move to Manhattan or New Jersey, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the principal owner of the New York Yankees, has now publicly expressed interest in keeping the team in the Bronx but has also extended his requests for government investment in a new stadium to include not only the state and the city but the Federal Government as well.
In a brief comment in this week's issue of Crain's New York Business that was expanded upon yesterday by his spokesman, Mr. Steinbrenner suggested that city, state and Federal officials develop a comprehensive plan for revitalizing the area surrounding Yankee Stadium in the South Bronx, including improvements to schools and transportation. 
 Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who had strongly advocated building a stadium for the Yankees on the West Side of Manhattan, hailed Mr. Steinbrenner's interest in remaining in the Bronx. "If the end result is that the Yankees want to stay in the Bronx, that is the best possible result for me and for the city and for everyone else," Mr. Giuliani said yesterday.
The Mayor, who was at Shea Stadium for the Mets home opener against the Florida Marlins, portrayed Mr. Steinbrenner's new stance as a renewed interest in a plan by the administration to build a new stadium and baseball "village" in the South Bronx.
"The model that we are talking about is a model that we presented to him," said Mr. Giuliani, explaining that the city, the state and the Yankees had contributed equally to the model's costs.
The Mayor did not mention the political opposition that had grown around a West Side stadium from Republicans like Gov. George E. Pataki and Democrats like the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone.
Elaborating on Mr. Steinbrenner's comments, his spokesman, Howard J. Rubenstein, said: "George Steinbrenner most recently said if the Federal, state and city governments will come to him and the Yankees with a plan to revitalize that area in the Bronx and not just a new Yankee Stadium, he would seriously consider it. And when he talks about revitalization, he is talking about possible retail outlets, entertainment center, transportation, highway access, a vast variety of things that will impact favorably on that borough."
Such developments would most closely resemble a plan proposed by the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, who has long maintained that the Yankees should remain in their historic home. But meeting Mr. Steinbrenner's current requests would require substantially more planning, including the involvement of Federal agencies.
Some of that planning has already begun. Since the fall, Mr. Steinbrenner has been involved in discussions with Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Harlem Democrat, about the possibility of using Federal empowerment zone statutes to transform the area around 161st Street, where the stadium is situated.
Mr. Rubenstein said Mr. Steinbrenner was seeking not just government money but assurances that the project could be completed. "It has to be a plan that demonstrates where the financing would come from and who would be in charge of doing it," Mr. Rubenstein said. "He wants the government to be very specific on a wide-ranging basis about the Bronx. He wants to see not only what a plan would be but how it could and would be executed. He is concerned that if an election comes and goes, suddenly the plan doesn't materialize."
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Ferrer praised Mr. Steinbrenner's remarks. "I think it's a very positive first step," he said. "We are getting there. It is an acknowledgment, I think, that there isn't an economic rationale for being in New Jersey and there isn't any political support for a West Side stadium. The Mayor found that out very dramatically last year."
The team's lease at Yankee Stadium, which is owned by the city, expires in 2002. While Mr. Steinbrenner had long kept city and state officials guessing by threatening to move the team to New Jersey, that possibility was essentially squelched by a recent business agreement linking the Yankees to the New Jersey Nets basketball franchise, which is seeking money from New Jersey to build a new arena in Newark and would not want the Yankees lobbying for state money for a new stadium at the same time.
Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that a stadium project in the Bronx could end up costing more than a stadium on the West Side. "It makes the most sense for the Yankees to stay in the Bronx from an emotional standpoint, and because that's the house that Ruth built and it has tremendous history and that alone has tremendous value," he said. "It may end up costing more but it will end up having lots of benefits."

HEADLINE: Why the Chinese Are Fretting: Is Clinton Fickle?

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 12

 BODY:
When President Clinton visited China last summer, he and China's top leader, Jiang Zemin, held a news conference broadcast live around China in which they discussed every sensitive issue in their countries' relations, from Tibet to allegations of illegal Chinese donations to American political campaigns.
At the time, some other senior Chinese officials considered it possibly the biggest risk Mr. Jiang had taken in the decade since he had assumed China's top political titles -- an unprecedented concession to demands for more political openness. The Chinese public had never before seen live broadcasts of an American President, much less one debating head to head with his media-shy Chinese counterpart. The risk-taking paid off when Mr. Clinton's visit was judged a success by both sides. 
 Just 10 months later, Prime Minister Zhu Rongji has complained at every stop on his six-city tour of the United States that Mr. Clinton "does not dare" to take what he considers to be a much smaller political risk: allowing China to join the World Trade Organization under terms that even Mr. Clinton's own trade negotiators considered a slam dunk.
"We know our American counterparts very well," said a senior Chinese official traveling with Mr. Zhu. "We have been negotiating this agreement for 13 years. When you are doing these things for so long, you know when you have a deal. We had a deal."
Chinese officials accompanying Mr. Zhu pointed to this asymmetry -- Mr. Jiang taking the gamble of his political life, Mr. Clinton overruling some members of his own staff -- as an illustration of what they see as endless frustration in their dealings with the United States. Yes, they say, democracies work differently from dictatorships, but that does not justify what they perceive as Mr. Clinton's fickleness.
The frustration has built even as Chinese officials gush about Mr. Zhu's visit to the United States. The Prime Minister has shown, they say, that he can stand with the most skilled American politicians and argue persuasively for his views. He might even succeed in rallying public support for China's entry into the trade organization, they say, though some Chinese officials have been known to overestimate the political influence that American business leaders have.
That confidence was in evidence today when 1,500 business executives, including chief executives of Motorola, United Airlines, Bank One and a dozen other companies based in the Midwest, gathered at a Chicago banquet for Mr. Zhu. With the Prime Minister seated at the podium, several chief executives vowed their support for China's entry as Mr. Zhu nodded in appreciation. Commerce Secretary William Daley, in town for the occasion, also assured Mr. Zhu that China's admission "is not a question of if, but when."
Chinese officials also reacted favorably to word that some 100 business executives showed up today for a White House briefing on trade talks with China. Several executives who attended reportedly complained that the Clinton Administration misread both public and Congressional sentiment when it scuttled the deal with China.
Christopher Galvin, Motorola's chief executive, said that support for China's entry has gelled enough during Mr. Zhu's visit that he wishes the Prime Minister had visited Washington at the end of his nine-day stay instead of the beginning. "Then we might have a deal," Mr. Galvin said.
Despite such optimism, the damage from Mr. Clinton's wavering may run deep. One of Mr. Zhu's top aides, probably reflecting the views of other Chinese officials, said Mr. Clinton's role in the trade talks was not unlike his decision in 1995 to bow to Congressional pressure and allow President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan to visit the United States. Although Mr. Lee's visit to Cornell University, his alma mater, was billed as private, Beijing, which views Taiwan as a renegade province, saw it as an attempt to bolster the island's official status.
Then, as now, Congress appeared to make China policy instead of the White House, said this aide, who declined to be identified further. Then, as now, Mr. Clinton intervened at the last moment and overturned an approach that had the firm backing of his China experts. "Clinton's memory is short," this Chinese official said. "Our memory is longer."
Part of the problem is that while China's foreign policy puts relations with the United States at the top of its agenda, the United States juggles many international priorities. It is no coincidence, one Chinese official said, that Mr. Clinton rejected a trade deal while the United States was leading the NATO assault on Yugoslavia.
The Clinton Administration insists that China is a high priority. But Chinese officials doubt that. The Administration, for example, has so far failed to find a suitable successor for its current Ambassador to China, James Sasser, who has made his intention of leaving that post known for months.
The conflict in Yugoslavia is also a direct affront to the two stated pillars of China's foreign policy: peace and noninterference in the internal affairs of sovereign countries. Where the United States sees the persecution of an ethnic minority, China sees the threat of foreign intervention in Taiwan and Tibet, its own restive regions.
But perhaps the biggest worry is that the Clinton Administration did not appreciate the delicate nature of the process that produced China's revised bid to join the World Trade Organization.
China has sought entry to the trade body for 13 years, but it has really made only two strong pushes for membership. The first came in 1994, when the trade organization was born of its predecessor, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The application then came amid a rush of economic reforms. Chinese officials made GATT the symbol of its modernization drive, only to have the United States block entry.
China's interest in joining the trade body, which requires demolition of tariffs and trade barriers, faded in the intervening years. It was fully revived only late last year. Then, Mr. Zhu, newly appointed Prime Minister, made entry his personal mission.
Chinese trade officials said that never before had a senior Chinese leader taken an interest in the details of negotiations the way Mr. Zhu did.
"Without Zhu, it would never have been smooth," said a trade official.
Crucially, the push to join the trade body became the symbol of a new stage in China's reform program. Previously, economic reform focused on agriculture and manufacturing industries. But the new drive aimed at opening the country's undeveloped service sector -- telecommunications, banking, consulting, accounting, entertainment and many other areas -- to both domestic and foreign competition.
With the Asian financial crisis dragging down growth in China and the country flooded with over-investment in unproductive industries, the opening of services was seen as one of the few ways to promote quality economic growth. The trade organization offered a framework to change myriad internal Chinese rules and regulations that keep services off limits.
"Service sector reform and the W.T.O. are the same thing for China," said this trade official. "We won't get one without the other."
China could still get both if negotiations pick up where they left off last week. But the Chinese side, while publicly indicating continued support for a deal, privately frets that restoring momentum will be tricky.
There are no more scheduled visits of Chinese or American leaders. The Clinton Administration may see its remaining clout to push a trade deal through Congress only diminish as Mr. Clinton approaches the end of his term. And, perhaps most worrying for the Chinese, trade was supposed to be the unbreakable bond between the two countries that keeps them talking even when military, diplomatic, and human rights concerns strain ties.
"Trade is the one area where our two interests are really in line," the Chinese trade negotiator said. "So if we don't even agree on trade, the outlook is not so good."

HEADLINE: The Pulitzer Prizes

 BODY:

ARTS
 
FICTION -- "The Hours," by Michael Cunningham.
DRAMA -- "Wit," by Margaret Edson.
HISTORY -- "Gotham: A History of New York City to 1898," by Edwin G. Burrows and Mike Wallace.
BIOGRAPHY -- "Lindbergh," by A. Scott Berg.
GENERAL NONFICTION -- "Annals of the Former World," by John McPhee.
POETRY -- "Blizzard of One," by Mark Strand.
MUSIC -- Concerto for Flute, Strings and Percussion, by Melinda Wagner.
SPECIAL CITATION -- Duke Ellington. 

JOURNALISM
 The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Associated Press each won two Pulitzer Prizes yesterday.
 The Times staff received the prize in national reporting for a series of articles disclosing the corporate sale of American technology to China with Government approval, despite national security risks. Maureen Dowd of The Times won for commentary, for her columns on the ambitions and values reflected in President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.
 The Wall Street Journal won in international reporting for its coverage of the Russian financial crisis, and Angelo B. Henderson was awarded the prize in feature writing for his portrait of a druggist driven to violence by his encounters with armed robbery.
 The Associated Press was honored for both spot news photography and feature photography, for pictures of the United States Embassy bombings in Africa and for its images surrounding the Clinton impeachment scandal.
 The Public Service prize went to The Washington Post for articles identifying patterns of reckless gunplay by city police officers. The award for beat reporting went to Chuck Philips and Michael A. Hiltzik of The Los Angeles Times for articles on corruption in the entertainment industry. The Miami Herald won in investigative reporting for exposing voter fraud in a mayoral election that was later overturned.
 In the breaking-news category, The Hartford Courant won for reporting about a state lottery worker who killed four supervisors and then himself. Richard Read of The Oregonian, in Portland, won in explanatory reporting by featuring a local industry to illustrate the impact of Asia's economic crisis.
 Blair Kamin of The Chicago Tribune won for architecture criticism, and The Daily News of New York was honored for its editorial campaign to rescue the fiscally troubled Apollo Theater in Harlem.
 The complete list, page B9.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Union Ranks Rise 6% in Connecticut

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Union membership in Connecticut rose 6 percent in 1998, far outstripping the national average, a result of aggressive organizing campaigns, dissatisfaction among some workers and a hiring spurt sparked by a booming economy, labor leaders say.
The number of Connecticut residents in unions jumped to 263,000 in 1998 from 248,000 in 1997, according to data from the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. Nationally, union membership increased less than 1 percent, to 16.2 million in 1998 from 16.1 million in 1997. 
 The Federal data do not specify which unions had the largest increases in membership. It was collected through household surveys in which people were asked only whether they were a member of a union.
But John Olsen, president of the Connecticut A.F.L.-C.I.O., said last week that the health care, hotel, retail and public employee unions, among others, saw growth in 1998.
Mr. Olsen attributed much of the growth to intense organizing campaigns and a belief among some workers that they were being left out.
The New England Health Care Employees Union, District 1199, which represents public and private agency health workers, added more than 1,100 members in 1998. Its membership grew to 20,000.
A union spokeswoman, Deborah Chernoff, said most of the growth had been in nursing homes, where workers had complained about low wages and demanding jobs.
In February, a threatened strike by nearly 6,000 workers at 49 Connecticut nursing homes was averted when Gov. John G. Rowland offered to increase state payments by $200 million.
Larry Dorman, a spokesman for the Connecticut A.F.L.-C.I.O., said the robust economy meant that employers were hiring more workers and that some of those new employees were joining unions.
Membership in teachers' unions also swelled. The Connecticut Education Association, which represents 33,000 teachers, added about 1,000 members from September 1997 to September 1998.
The Connecticut Federation of Educational and Professional Employees, which represents about 22,000 teachers, state employees and health care professionals, added about 700 members in 1998.
About 500 municipal workers in Stamford joined the United Automobile Workers last year. David Exline, president of U.A.W. Local 2377, said the workers looked to the U.A.W. because they wanted a strong union. Previously, they were represented by the Municipal Employees Association.
Membership in the state's largest public employees union -- the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, Connecticut Council 4 -- held steady at 34,000. But the union has added 300 members since January, when it began an organizing campaign.

BABSON, ARTHUR CLIFFORD

HEADLINE: Can This Be Paris?;
The French Learn to Speak Fusion

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
THERE is a dessert in Paris called the wonton kumquat Nutella. It cannot be found in Escoffier, or anywhere else, for that matter.
Served at a new Right Bank restaurant called Cafe Mosaic, the kumquat surprise comes in a bamboo steamer that holds a very undessert-like display of three soft wonton envelopes, each containing a whole kumquat and a small puddle of molten Nutella, the commercial chocolate and hazelnut spread. The thing is awful. But in Paris, it may be the wave of the future. 
 In this city of bistros, brasseries and three-star shrines, a new type of restaurant seems to be taking hold: ultradesigned, up to the minute and emphatically un-French in style and culinary point of view. The spaces tend to be large and, by French standards, quite noisy. The waiters and waitresses, who are very young, ply their trade with an almost American casualness. The food is strange.
Fusion has come to France, and it feels funny. Influences from Asia, America and -- heaven help us -- even England have been creeping into one of the world's most rigidly codified cuisines. Like steam opening a mussel, the cultural pressures of the new global economy, and the internationalizing of taste, have forced the inward-looking French to look outward on a peculiar new world. Classically minded chefs are trying to assimilate concepts like Afro-Thai cuisine and to accept the idea that patrons care as much about the setting as they do about the food on the plate. The result is a new culinary moment in France, one that Gault-Millau magazine is calling "the new disorder."
All this and the euro, too -- it's a lot to swallow. But Paris seems titillated by the strange new dances that its chefs are trying out, and the theatrical spaces in which they perform them. They have mobbed the new Lo Sushi, designed by Andree Putman, where patrons pick up their sushi plates from a conveyer belt, and Man Ray, a hip-to-the-hilt Pacific Rim restaurant whose owners include Johnny Depp and Sean Penn. The new restaurant wave has attracted a group that Patrick Derderian, the owner of Zebra Square and Bermuda Onion, recently called "the happy few" -- about 5,000 young and restless diners who move from address to address, their ranks swelled by well-to-do young professionals who, like the scene makers, want more than food from a restaurant.
"It appears that the era of the brasserie is over," said Miguel Cancio, a restaurateur and the consultant behind Man Ray, Barfly and Buddha Bar. "People want more -- they want to be transported somewhere else, and to be entertained."
Asian, barely three weeks old, could stand as an archetype for the new fussy French fusion restaurant. It is enormous, a 400-seat, two-level affair that occupies about 16,000 square feet of prime real estate on the swank Avenue George V. The decor is high-tech teahouse, with an emphasis on dark, exotic woods that contrast sharply with the polished concrete floor and a Zen garden of dazzling white sand and bleached rocks that sends out vibrations conducive to spiritual peace. The sound system broadcasts a third-world mix of weird animal noises, rain-forest drips and tribal grunts and chants.
The menu makes more stops than a German tour bus. The dim-sum cart rolls by, followed by mixed plates of Japanese sushi, Vietnamese spring rolls and a green salad with sesame dressing. Dishes bear names like Ming beef, chicken Chitchat, Paradise Lost salad, and the intriguingly named "Delta Brochette Pff, Pff," which turns out to be chunks of chicken thigh on a stick.
It's a menu to read as much as to eat. Each dish is a statement, a little like the macaroni and cheese at Spoon, Alain Ducasse's new restaurant with the cheeky American accent. The dish itself is not as important as the fact that it's on the menu, like the fish and chips at Alcazar, Terence Conran's shiny new Left Bank brasserie on the Rue Mazarine.
Alcazar is nothing if not shrewd. Under the direction of Guillaume Lutard, formerly the senior sous-chef at Taillevent, the kitchen turns out a carefully calibrated mix of brasserie standards, seafood platters, pan-Mediterranean fare and the occasional English dish, like bread and butter pudding, or fish and chips. It's world food for young diners who move easily from Los Angeles to New York to Paris to London and who feel most comfortable in casual, sleekly designed restaurants that buzz and hum.
Alcazar's design is crisp and clean to the point of being antiseptic. The large open kitchen, with its gleaming white tiles and shiny stainless steel fixtures, is so pristine it could serve as a hospital operating theater, which is, in fact, what it looks like. On the blond-wood tables, the salt and the pepper, arranged in neat piles, come in a precision-tooled rectangular steel ashtray (available for about $15 on the way out), and the American-style selection of four rolls (plain sourdough, rye sourdough, black-olive and walnut) is served in what seems to be an oval Shaker box but on closer inspection turns out to be the lid to a container of cheese.
Alcazar is cute that way. Every touch has been thought through with one aim in mind: to make diners feel that they are the actors in a first-class production, with all the right props in place.
It's a set-design approach to dining that was perfected at Buddha Bar. Some of the heat has cooled at this first of the mega-restaurants, but when it opened in late 1996, it created a sensation. It was the Parisian equivalent of Balthazar or Asia de Cuba in Manhattan, a highly wrought stage set that allowed chic young Parisians to put on a show for themselves.
The scene has since shifted, but the decor remains. Buddha Bar is a fever dream of tropical elegance, its dense, opium-inspired interior rich with exotic woods, betasseled chandeliers and lush fabrics. Upstairs is a mile-long bar in the form of a dragon ship. Downstairs, there's the unignorable Buddha, a serene mass of beatitude seated on a square pedestal large enough to support a Cadillac. Rising nearly 60 feet to the ceiling, he has the air of a customer waiting patiently for a very big meal.
When it comes, he will want more spice. The lurid sensibility that went into the decor evaporated mysteriously at the kitchen door. The menu, a pan-Asian and French smorgasbord, skips blithely from Vietnamese spring rolls to Korean-style grilled steak to miso-glazed turbot, an Asian package tour for the timid. When it comes to the desserts, the exotic mask drops entirely. Except for a blancmange with coconut milk, the line-up is as French as a cancan. There's nothing wrong with any of the food, exactly, and the restaurant's excellent hot sauce, served on the side, works wonders on just about everything except the blancmange, but on the plate, Asia seems as remote as Buddha's smile.
In the United States, chefs have embraced the new ingredients and spices of Asia, Latin America and the Caribbean with a sometimes unseemly passion. They may not always love wisely, but shyness has not been a problem. In Paris, however, fusion resolutely refuses to fuse. When it comes to visual style, and atmosphere, the French cannot be beat. They seem to have no trouble with the theatrical elements of dining, or the international design idiom that goes with flashy fusion cuisine from Sydney to Miami. There are not many New York restaurants, for example, to equal the drop-dead elegant Telegraphe, recently redone in a blend of Viennese Secession and Art Nouveau by the design team behind the three-star Ambroisie.
But the intercultural mingling that energizes American chefs tends to stump the French, for reasons that are not that hard to figure out. A cooking tradition as ancient and deeply ingrained as France's presents every chef with a hundred reasons not to try anything funny. America, by contrast, has always been a "why not?" culture, and the national tendency toward experimentation has been powerfully reinforced by an unending influx of new immigrant groups and new cuisines.
The example of Jean-Georges Vongerichten shows that a French sensibility and Asian ingredients can produce spectacular results, but his brethren here in the old country appear to be struggling a bit with their spring rolls and their sesame vinaigrettes. They either pussyfoot or, like a teetotaler who falls off the wagon, go wild and shoot up the town.
Cafe Mosaic, the Mad Max of Paris restaurants, falls into the second category. Deceptively, the interior is cool and understated, with dark wood blinds covering the windows facing the busy Avenue George V, and a suave semicircular bar, decorated with a vase of white orchids, off to one side of the room. All the more shocking, then, to witness the parade of oddities streaming out of the kitchen. Anise-steamed crayfish whiz by in a mason jar. The "salade verte" turns out to be a half-head of iceberg lettuce, sitting on the plate like a stooge. Then come the kumquat wontons a la Nutella, or even better, the "orange a l'orange," a glistening orb of citrus fruit, preciously situated in a large gray bowl, that oozes an orange cream when pierced with a fork.
Some of this is thrilling, like the smoky roast pepper, with a sauce of anchovies, chickpeas and soy, or the ruby-colored pigeon breast mired in a gooey plum-peanut sauce and surrounded by kumquats. All of it is cartoonish. At table after table, French diners, after a scandalized intake of breath, were laughing as the plates arrived, and who could blame them? In retrospect, the two mini-baguettes placed on the table at the beginning of the meal seem like the last word in irony.
It's the kind of small gesture that conceals a big fact: French cuisine has entered the postmodern era.
 
Taste of the Future

HEADLINE: U.S. Retail Sales Continued to Rise in March

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Retailers rang up stronger sales for an eighth consecutive month during March as tame inflation helped foster a shoppers' paradise of high spending power in a robust economy.
The Commerce Department said today that total sales by retail businesses rose two-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $239.6 billion last month, maintaining momentum after upwardly revised jumps of 1.7 percent in February and 1.3 percent in January. 
 Previously, the Commerce Department said that February sales had risen by nine-tenths of 1 percent and January sales by 1 percent. The revised February sales increase was the strongest since a similar 1.7 percent rise in February 1994.
Separately, the Labor Department confirmed muted price rises as its Consumer Price Index edged up by a seasonally adjusted two-tenths of 1 percent after a rise in February of one-tenth of 1 percent.
The slim rise over all occurred despite spiraling energy prices stemming from an agreement among the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise oil prices. Gasoline costs alone surged 3.7 percent in March.
The core Consumer Price Index, which removes the costs of the volatile food and energy sectors, advanced only one-tenth of 1 percent, the same as in February.
"We have the best of both worlds, low inflation and sustained growth," said Gordon Richards, an economist with the National Association of Manufacturers.
Strong consumer demand and strong spending on everything from refrigerators to clothing have shielded the nation's economy from the recessions abroad, Mr. Richards said, while lower import prices have benefited shoppers.
The reports added to the impression that confident consumers, buoyed by a booming stock market and ample job opportunities, were the key force pushing the economy into its ninth year of unbroken expansion since the 1990-91 recession.
Ken Mayland, an economist with Keycorp in Cleveland, emphasized that even though there were pockets of softness in March consumer spending, "in no way, shape or form can the March advance be considered a soft number." He added, "Consumers extended a spending binge of mammoth proportions."
Sales by automobile dealers, which account for a quarter of monthly retail business, dropped a half-percent last month, to $60 billion, a reversal from February, when they had soared 3.1 percent. Excluding autos, overall retail sales in March were up a half-percent after a 1.3 percent rise in February.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Continues to Reach Highs, With Increase of 55.50

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average closed at a record high yesterday for the second consecutive day, but the rest of the stock market lagged as investors took profits, especially in technology shares.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 55.50 points, to 10,395.01, after having moved in and out of positive territory throughout the day. 
 The blue-chip index rose as high as 10,418.87, a gain of nearly 80 points, in early trading yesterday.
Investors bought the shares of economically sensitive companies such as basic materials processors and manufacturers, which sent the Dow higher. But they also shed technology shares, aside from Internet-related stocks, for a second day.
The drop in technology shares took both the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq composite index lower on heavy volume. The S.& P.-500 index fell 8.82 points, to 1,349.82, while the Nasdaq declined 15.31 points, to 2,583.50.
"This is a continuation of the last week or so's trend of market rotation out of tech stocks and into other sectors of the market," said Charles Crane, chief market strategist at Key Asset Management in New York. Investors bought "more cyclically sensitive stocks, which explains why the Dow is doing better than the other two indexes."
Investors sold technology stocks following Compaq Computer's announcement on Friday that its first-quarter profits would be lower than expected because of softer personal computer prices. Compaq shares, which fell nearly 7 points on Monday, were down another 1/4 at 23 13/16.
Larry Rice, chief investment officer at Josephthal & Company, said the market was in an expected pullback after Monday's strong performance.
"I think it's normal after a 165-point" gain in the Dow Monday, Mr. Rice said. "I don't think it's out of the ordinary here; in fact, it's doing as I expected."
Stocks were also hampered by lower bond prices. The 30-year Treasury bond was down 20/32, to 96 16/32. Its yield rose to 5.49 percent, from 5.45 percent Monday. Bond traders were bidding prices lower in anticipation of $10 billion in new corporate and government-agency debt to be issued soon. There was also concern that Japanese insurance companies, big buyers of United States bonds, might cut back their purchases.
Bond prices fell despite a Labor Department report that consumer prices edged up a manageable two-tenths of a percent in March, a sign that inflation is under control. The department also reported that retail sales rose a smaller-than-expected two-tenths of a percent in March.
The market was anxiously awaiting the release of Intel's results after the close of trading today. The microchip maker is seen as a bellwether for other high-tech companies. Intel shares were down 75 cents, to 60 1/2, and fell another 1 1/2 in after-hours trading. Intel reported first-quarter earnings slightly above Wall Street's expectations, but also said it expected second-quarter revenues to be flat to slightly lower than in the previous quarter.
Positive earnings reports lifted some stocks, particularly the financial services sector. Merrill Lynch retreated after an early gain tied a strong earnings report.
The brokerage firm Paine Webber also surged after releasing a strong earnings report.
Not only did the shares of large cyclical companies climb, but smaller-company stocks put in a good day as well, said Barry Hyman, senior equity analyst at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum.
"The secondary market is starting to show some life," Mr. Hyman said, and it has to participate in the rally in order for the market to go higher. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies rose 4.92 points to close at 417.24.

HEADLINE: A Land Of Reluctant Warriors

BYLINE: By Geoffrey Wheatcroft; Geoffrey Wheatcroft is the author of "The Controversy of Zion: Jewish Nationalism, the Jewish State and the Unresolved Jewish Dilemma."

DATELINE: BATH, England

 BODY:
The debate, in the White House and Congress, about the use of ground troops in Kosovo is becoming more serious. This is happening despite the belief, strongly held in Washington, that recent experience from Lebanon to Somalia has made Americans unwilling to risk the lives of soldiers.
But there is another truth, longer standing though little recognized. Americans have never liked fighting wars, and have comparatively little experience of warfare -- compared with Europe, that is, and in the matter of sustaining casualties. 
 Since 1900, more than 1 million British servicemen have been killed in war, 2 million Frenchmen, more than 5 million Germans, more than 10 million Russians. In that same period, in every war put together, two world wars, Korea, Vietnam and all others, fewer than half a million Americans died.
On the poignant Vietnam memorial in Washington, the names of almost 60,000 Americans are carved. But compare that number killed over more than a decade with the 20,000 British soldiers who died on July 1, 1916, the disastrous opening day of the Battle of the Somme in World War I. And how many battles have been fought on American soil this century? How many bombs have fallen on American cities?
This isn't a cause for resentment, disparagement or foolish European boastfulness. One can only envy the Americans their good fortune of geography and history. But that good fortune has had a greater effect on the American character than is commonly believed.
American forces in World War II did not lack fighting spirit or military effectiveness. The well-equipped, well-paid and well-trained United States Army fought admirably, and on at least two occasions, in Sicily in 1943 and Normandy in 1944, Gen. George Patton's Yanks outstripped Field Marshal Sir Bernard Montgomery's plodding British forces on their flank.
But American commanders recognized that their first priority was to minimize their own casualties. "Old Blood and Guts" Patton had his own brand of often-quoted gung-ho oratory: "Americans love to fight," he said. "All real Americans love the sting and clash of battle. . . . Americans love a winner and will not tolerate a loser. Americans despise cowards. Americans play to win -- all the time. . . . That's why Americans have never lost, not ever will lose a war."
Those words were all the same misleading. In that same speech, which was delivered to the Third Army based in Britain in 1944, Patton also went out his way to reassure them. "You are not all going to die," he said. "Only 2 percent of you here today would die in a major battle."
With all his bellicose language, Patton had grasped a crucial truth. The men he commanded would not fight -- or "be fought" -- like the armies on the Western Front 30 years before, on the Somme or at Verdun. The American Army wasn't only fighting for democracy. It was itself democratic in the sense that it had to be commanded by consent, and there were clear limits to what it could be expected to endure.
By contrast, the armies of the totalitarian powers were expected to endure anything, driven by a mixture of raw nationalism and sheer terror, as Saddam Hussein's and Slobodan Milosevic's armies still are.
When it's said that the Red Army fought heroically at Stalingrad, bear in mind that during that one battle alone more than 13,500 Russians were shot by their own side as a reminder that every soldier's life was cheap.
The American people did in fact fight one terrible war, the Civil War, with appalling casualties. The American Somme was Antietam, where more than 20,000 men died in little more than one day's fighting in September 1862. It was an experience Americans have seemed determined never to repeat.
Even now, and despite the latest opinion polls, many Americans wonder whether their Government should "make its citizens fight and kill and die in a war they may oppose, a war which even possibly may be wrong, a war which, in any case, does not involve immediately the peace and freedom of the nation," as the 23-year-old Bill Clinton wrote in 1969 in a letter explaining his own reluctance to serve in Vietnam.
In the American experience there are strong echoes of Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries. Then, we were the lone global superpower, combining hegemonic might with a sense of national destiny and righteous moralism in a way that other countries found hard to take.
More than that, as the historian Linda Colley has written, "Unlike most of their European neighbors, Britons at this time -- like Americans in the 20th century -- were able to savor military glory without ever having to pay the price in terms of civilian casualties and large-scale domestic destruction." She could have added "or military casualties," too.
Americans have always evinced a deeply rooted and understandable disinclination to fight other people's wars, particularly the wars so many immigrants had fled Europe to avoid. Today Americans wonder why they should pay for, let alone fight, those wars today.
 Even without ground troops in Kosovo, Americans are entitled to observe that their share of NATO's financial burden is ludicrously disproportionate. After all, the European Union is larger than the United States in terms of population and of economic product, and it's hard to see why the Americans should pay more than the rest of the member states put together.
In the "American century," the United States has played a role that the Founding Fathers did not intend and that went against the American grain. Is it really surprising that, as the century closes, Americans no longer feel like playing this role?

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Pearson Obtains Right To Rename a Building

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
The illuminated signs atop the 40-story office building on the east side of the Avenue of the Americas between 53d and 54th Streets shine the letters ITT across the New York skyline in four directions. But the signs are out of date.
They are to be succeeded by new letters in coming months, possibly FT, for The Financial Times. A deal has been completed that gives Pearson P.L.C., the British media conglomerate that owns the international financial daily, naming rights and the use of the signs at the ITT building, at 1330 Avenue of the Americas, across the street from the New York Hilton. 
 Whatever letters Pearson chooses, the change-over will also symbolize a broader transition under way in the building itself, the outgrowth of a long-term phase-out in the Manhattan operations of the ITT Corporation. The Pearson deal has completed the process of releasing the ITT space.
The corporation itself bowed out as an independent company only last year, when its primary assets -- the Sheraton hotel chain and Caesar's Palace in Las Vegas -- were acquired by Starwood Hotels and Resorts, based in White Plains.
Remaining ITT staff members then moved out of the Manhattan building. Three years earlier, the company's manufacturing arm split off, becoming the independent ITT Industries, based in White Plains.
Starwood has continued the subleasing campaign that ITT began in 1995, when it occupied 175,000 square feet in the building, about 40 percent of the total space. Cushman & Wakefield has been in charge of leasing the space.
Pearson, the London-based international media company, has signed on for 75,000 square feet on a sublease that runs to 2006. The sublease then transforms into a primary lease for seven more years from the building's owner, the Shuwa Corporation, based in Tokyo.
What its sign will read is not entirely settled, said Philip J. Hoffman, president of Pearson's North American arm, in an interview last week. But the North American office of The Financial Times, now at 14 East 60th Street, will be one of the Pearson businesses going there, making "FT" a strong possibility.
Pearson has hired Chermayeff & Geismar Inc. of Manhattan to design the sign. The company also designed the Met Life logo that replaced Pan Am atop 200 Park Avenue, which was born as the Pan Am building in 1963.
"You would really like one big letter," said Jonathan Alger, a designer at Chermayeff & Geismar. For Pearson, "FT is probably best, technically speaking."
Brokers estimated that the leasing deal was worth about $60 million over 15 years, but they did not disclose a figure that would represent the value of the right to name or sign the building.
"Usually you have to lease at least 25 percent of a building to get the naming rights," said George H. Keller 4th, the Cushman & Wakefield broker who represents Starwood in the disposition of the ITT space, working with Albert Cleary and Robert F. Sheehy. "But they really wanted their own name on a building and they are getting it here though they're taking only about 17 percent."
Richard Berzine & Company represented Pearson.
Pearson has a substantial and far-flung presence in the city: Penguin Putnam is at 375 Hudson Street; Macmillan Publishing is at 1633 Broadway; Pearson Education is at 1185 Avenue of the Americas; the Economist magazine is at 111 West 57th Street; Pearson Television is at 1325 Avenue of the Americas, and the Interactive Data Corporation is at 100 William Street.
But only the television operation, The Financial Times and the New York headquarters and a small Penguin Putnam office are moving to 1330 Avenue of the Americas. "We wanted a single location for Pearson businesses in Manhattan that don't have their own mass," Mr. Hoffman said.
The original holder of the signage right was ABC. Capital Cities/ABC moved its headquarters to the Upper West Side in the 1980's, and sold its building to Shuwa.
ITT's ability to inherit the signing right played no small part in its decision to move to 1330 Avenue of the Americas when it was shrinking its Manhattan operations, said Mr. Sheehy of Cushman & Wakefield, who was then the company's real estate director.
Under a 1965 zoning amendment, new illuminated signs are not permitted at heights above 40 feet in most high-density office districts, with the exception of the Times Square district. (The bright-red umbrella emblem of Citigroup on the north facade of 388 Greenwich Street does not count; it snuck in on a Buildings Department interpretation concerning building logos that has since been rescinded. Citigroup adopted the Travelers emblem when it was formed through the merger of Citicorp and Travelers Group last year.)
Among the other tenants who have leased parts of the former ITT space in 1330 Avenue of the Americas are First Dominion Capital, a financial subsidiary of Dominion Resources and Paxson Communications, a television company based in Boca Raton, Fla.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Best Western is expanding its share of corporate travelers by aiming at those on a tight budget.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
PROBABLY few people think of Pokhara, Nepal, and business travel in the same breath. But Best Western recently opened its newest hotel there, the New Hotel Crystal, about 90 miles west of Katmandu. Along with 40 air-conditioned rooms, satellite television and currency exchange facilities, it has a business center with fax, E-mail and copy services.
That brings to 185 the number of international hotels that Best Western has added during the last year, along with 171 domestic properties. Altogether, there are about 3,800 Best Westerns in 76 countries and territories, and next Jan. 1 it will top the 4,200 mark when almost 400 Consort Hotels in Britain will also carry the Best Western logo. 
 Best Western is not only the world's biggest lodging brand; all of its properties are independently owned and operated. They are gathered under the Best Western banner not as franchises but in an association whose members pay for marketing, national advertising, the toll-free reservations number and similar expenses.
While still heavily patronized by leisure travelers, Best Western's share of business travelers has been inching up. Three months ago it started Business Plus, a program designed to appeal to those who are self-employed or on a tight corporate budget. Some 350 hotels participate in the program, which requires that at least 10 rooms or 10 percent of the property's total rooms meet standards that include king-size or queen-size beds, desks, phone lines for computers, lounge armchairs, clock radios, coffee makers and free access to toll-free numbers.
 
Heading Off Scandal
Hoping to be host to the Summer Olympic Games in 2012, and determined to avoid a replay of the tawdry details surrounding Salt Lake City's winning bid for next year, Cincinnati has established an ethics panel. In addition to developing a code of conduct, the committee will also consider opening the Games' financial arrangements to public scrutiny. But the competition to land the Games is likely to be as fierce as the competition in the athletic events, because a dozen other cities have also expressed interest in winning the 2012 Games.
 
Discounts in the Wings
When normal air service resumes to such cities as Sofia, Bulgaria; Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina; Skopje, Macedonia, and Tirana, Albania, passengers wanting to fly there from Kennedy International Airport in New York will be able to do so for about $550, round trip, on Austrian Airlines. In addition to what amounts to a 40 percent discount, they will also be allowed three pieces of baggage, instead of two, up to a total of 200 pounds.

Data on Hotels
Health and fitness centers are in 48 percent of hotels in the United States, compared with 43.7 percent in 1996 and 36.4 percent in 1994. Voice mail was in 52 percent of hotel rooms in 1998, compared with 22 percent two years earlier. And the percentage of hotels offering rentals of videocassette recorders has remained at about 25 percent since 1996.
Those percentages do not include all hotels, but were compiled from replies from more than 9,400 of the nearly 40,000 hotels surveyed for the American Hotel and Motel Association. It is, the association said, the most comprehensive such study ever conducted under its auspices.
Business travelers are not likely to be surprised that more than 35 percent of the luxury hotels provide rooms with safes. Or that one-third of the luxury properties sampled offer cell phone rental. It is also no big surprise that a smaller percentage of such hotels now offer free local calls than in the recent past. What is surprising is that the percentage plummeted to 34 last year from 48 just two years earlier, while 60 percent of economy hotels and 46 percent of budget hotels still throw in free local calls.
 
One-Upmanship
You know those apples many hotels keep at the check-in desk, presumably for ravenous guests? Not to be outdone, the Premier Hotel in Times Square in New York gives away popsicles. But, as befits a hotel whose posted room rates start at $395 a night, these are champagne popsicles. Enclosed in wrappers and presented on ice in a champagne bucket, they are served in the lounge during cocktail hour.
