HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries' Prices Fall, With Big Debt Sales Planned

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices sagged yesterday under the weight of the large calendar of corporate and agency borrowers planning to sell their debt over the next few days.
Corporate bonds give investors an attractive alternative to Treasuries because the yields are higher, so the rates on Government paper have to rise to stay competitive. Securities firms arranging the corporate sales often sell Treasuries ahead of the offering, and that also tends to raise yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price. They do that as a precaution against rates rising before the corporate deals are done, replacing the Government securities when the sales are complete. 
 Among the corporate borrowers expected to sell about $9 billion soon, are the Inter-American Development Bank, Freddie Mac , and the Associates Corp of North America. Inter-American priced a $1 billion global bond issue yesterday through Lehman Brothers and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. The 10-year bond was priced to yield 5.755 percent. That is about 65 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, above a Treasury security with a comparable yield.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond dropped 20/32, to 96 16/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.49 percent, from 5.45 percent on Monday,
Reports on consumer prices and retail sales left market expectations of continued economic growth with little inflation unchanged and raised the likelihood that the Fed will not push up interest rates soon.
"This is the world we said we always wanted," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, "strong economic growth with low inflation. The stock market continues to rise, and people are having trouble finding things to get upset about. The bond market, in turn, is expected to stay within its current range as a by product of an unchanged F.O.M.C. stance, with the long bond centered at 5.50 percent."
The Consumer Price Index rose only two-tenths of 1 percent in March, a smaller-than-expected increase. Mr. Fine said that along with a minimal one-tenth of 1 percent rise in the core rate, the inflation statistics continued to impress market participants. But he said the relatively benign lift in gasoline prices may be masking a much larger jump in the April data to be released next month, as pump prices around the country have surged since the March data were compiled. The key issue, he added, is whether fuel price increases will continue, because if they do, the indirect effects on transportation and other components of inflation could be considerable.
"At first glance," Mr. Fine said, "the 0.2 percent increase in retail sales seemed to suggest a noticeable slowing in the growth of consumer spending, but in light of past data revisions and giddiness in the stock market, this conclusion would undoubtedly be premature."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Kvaerner to Sell Its Shipyards and Cut About 25,000 Jobs

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, April 13

 BODY:
The reorganization of European industry reached into the heartland of Norway today, when the Continent's biggest shipbuilder announced plans to sell all its shipyards and other money-losing businesses.
The announcement by Kvaerner S.A., an engineering conglomerate troubled by poor management and bad acquisitions, is the latest example of a revolution in European corporate culture. 
 After snubbing shareholders for years by pursuing murky strategies and producing mediocre profits, many of Europe's biggest industrial companies are now slashing costs and getting rid of businesses that do not measure up.
Last November, Siemens A.G. of Germany disclosed plans to jumpstart profits by selling off businesses with sales of $10 billion. Alcatel S.A., the huge French manufacturer of telecommunications equipment, announced plans last month to eliminate 12,000 jobs by the end of the year 2000. ABB Asea Brown Boveri A.G., the Swiss-Swedish engineering concern, eliminated more than 12,000 jobs last year.
But the shake-up at Kvaerner is one of the most drastic. If carried out in full, the company would abandon a business that had also been a bedrock of Norwegian industry. It would shrink itself to about one-third of its current size, shedding 25,000 of its 80,000 workers. The moves are likely to lead to job cuts at shipyards around Europe and possibly in the United States as well. Kvaerner, which builds everything from offshore oil rigs to cruise ships, had been planning to build ships at the old Philadelphia Naval Shipyard and employ about 1,000 people there.
Those plans could change abruptly, depending on what the shipbuilder's new owners decide to do. Kvaerner executives said they had not decided whether to simply sell the shipyards, spin the business off as a separate entity to shareholders or retreat more gradually by putting them into a joint venture with some other shipbuilder.
Whichever course prevails, the changes will be drastic. Kjell E. Almskog, who took over as chief executive last December, said the company had set aside 4 billion kroner, or about $500 million, to cover reorganization costs.
In addition to unloading the shipyards, which employ about 10,000 workers, the company plans to sell businesses with another 11,500 workers in areas like metal equipment, mechanical engineering, pulp and paper products and a real estate development. Several thousand other jobs would be eliminated in the companies that remain.
"Keep in mind that this is an old, traditional Norwegian company," said Ottar Haugerud, an analyst at Orkla Securities in Oslo. "They have turned the company upside down. It is a completely different company today than it was yesterday."
Almost any change would be an improvement. Under Kvaerner's previous chief executive, Erik Tonseth, the company's 1998 losses totaled 1.4 billion kroner, or $290 million. The company's stock plunged nearly 80 percent last year, though it had partly recovered since Mr. Almskog took over and made it clear he would shift course.
Many of the problems can be traced to Mr. Tonseth's disastrous purchase of Trafalgar House, a sprawling British engineering company that also owned the Cunard Line of cruise ships, for $1.38 billion in 1996. Trafalgar was loaded with debt and problems, which drained capital at a time when the shipbuilding industry was in a recession.
Though Kvaerner sold off numerous chunks of Trafalgar, including Cunard Line and the Queen Elizabeth 2 cruise ship, it still ran up big losses last year and was plagued by high costs and its disjointed mish-mash of companies.
Mr. Almskog, a former top executive at ABB Asea Brown Boveri, is now trying to refocus the company and return it to profitability.
"If we want to be a world champion, or in the world class anyway, we need to scale back," he told a news conference in London today. "The plan for this 'new Kvaerner' is to create a group that is significantly smaller and much leaner, but infinitely stronger."
Though investors had been expecting a fairly broad reorganization plan, most were surprised by the decision to abandon shipbuilding. In Oslo, Kvaerner stock dropped 3 kroner, or 2.2 percent, to 136 kroner today.
Analysts said it might be difficult to find buyers for Kvaerner's 12 European shipyards. Beyond that, Mr. Almskog's description of the problems at other businesses was bleaker than some analysts had expected.
"My gut feeling is positive, but the state of the company was worse than expected," said Mr. Haugerud of Orkla Securities.
Nonetheless, most said the plan was a step in the right direction.
"It is hard to get rid of shipbuilding yards in Europe these days, but in the long run this is the right decision," said Olof Jonasson, an industry analyst at Handelsbanken Markets in Oslo.

HEADLINE: Transit Officials Respond to Complaints of Metrocard Flaws

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
As if to prove that nothing is perfect, New York City Transit's hugely popular Metrocard came under fire yesterday, with members of the City Council and transit advocates pointing to flaws that cause some customers to pay twice for the same ride or to be denied entry to subways and buses.
The technical glitches, which have provoked sporadic complaints from riders since the Metrocards went on sale in 1993, have done little to dampen the enthusiasm of most riders. New York City Transit data show that bus and subway ridership rose by 9 percent, or by more than 10 million people, in 1998, an increase attributed to the city's strong economy and to the convenience of the electronic cards. 
 But while no one suggested yesterday that the Metrocard system be abandoned, executives of New York City Transit found themselves called to account in a series of angry complaints at a City Council hearing and a news conference.
Foremost among the problems cited was a tendency of the subway system's electronic turnstiles to misread the cards, forcing people to swipe them repeatedly. In some cases, the machines reject the cards but still deduct the fee as if the passenger had been admitted through the turnstile.
And for those holding cards good for an unlimited number of rides, the glitch can create aggravating delays, since those cards, once registered electronically, cannot be used again anywhere in the system for 18 minutes. A transit executive said later that the agency was preparing a partial solution to that problem.
The most spirited criticism came from members of the public and the City Council at a hearing of the City Council's Transportation Committee. The council released the results of its own survey of 1,002 riders in February and March, which found that 92 percent had been forced on some occasions to swipe the Metrocard more than once before it was accepted, and more than 50 percent had had the card "double deducted" or rejected entirely.
One rider, Mira Mignon, an executive assistant from Brooklyn, provided vivid testimony of how a Metrocard glitch can snowball, in her case resulting in a $60 fine.
Ms. Mignon said that she had tried to use a valid Metrocard in a station in SoHo after midnight one night, but that the card was rejected by the turnstile. She said she had no money to pay an additional fare, and was afraid to leave the station at that hour to find an automated teller machine. After a tollbooth attendant refused to help, she said, she jumped the turnstile, and was arrested.
"I am a captive rider and I am being punished unfairly for the failures of the transit system," Ms. Mignon said.
Noach Dear, the chairman of the transportation committee and a persistent critic of the transit agency, said, "New York City Transit is treating people like cattle."
Transit agency executives, called before Mr. Dear's committee to defend their system, said the glitches in the system were far outweighed by the convenience and savings it had provided. The problems "are minuscule" said Gary G. Caplan, the budget director for New York City Transit's parent agency, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
He said the agency's own data show that 95 percent of Metrocard users are passing through turnstiles on the first or second swipe of their cards, and that most of those who do not are rejected because their cards are not valid or are inserted into the turnstiles incorrectly.
Mr. Caplan said that New York City Transit would alter its system of rejecting unlimited-ride Metrocards for 18 minutes after they are used. The time lapse was intended to discourage scam artists who might sell rides repeatedly off the Metrocards.
To ward off fraud -- and to deny people the ability to offer free rides to their companions -- he said, the 18-minute lapse will still be imposed for those using the same card in the same station. But there will be no time constraints on using a card in different stations.
Mr. Caplan and other New York City Transit officials declined, however, to say when the change would take place, again citing worries over security. "We are not going to announce it in advance," said Al O'Leary, the agency's spokesman. "People will just realize at some point that a problem has gone away, and they will be happy."

HEADLINE: Whitman Signs Bills Cutting Property Taxes

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: BELLEVILLE, N.J., April 13

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a bipartisan package of bills today giving New Jersey residents the first installment of promised property tax relief and giving herself a powerful new talking point in her race for the Senate.
"Today is about helping local officials across the state find efficiencies; it's also about honoring a promise I made to the taxpayers of the state of New Jersey to relieve them from higher property taxes," Mrs. Whitman said at a bill-signing ceremony at a public library here. 
 The four bills she signed into law today amount to a modest $35 million in spending and are intended to encourage the 1,600 local governments in the state to consolidate services like schools and fire protection in order to save money and hold down property tax increases. That legislation is likely to help her senatorial prospects, as is a bill giving residents $1 billion in direct property tax relief, the installments timed to arrive within weeks before Election Day for the next five years. The Governor intends to sign that bill on Thursday, the deadline to file tax returns.
But Mrs. Whitman tried to play down, at least for the day, any political advantage she might gain from the property tax cuts, which took seven months from the time they were proposed to reach her desk.
"For government work, it's not bad to take ideas from a commission and get them into legislation that is actually signed within seven months," she told reporters.
Stephanie Bell, a spokeswoman for the Governor, said that Belleville -- a small blue-collar community just north of Newark and about 60 miles from Trenton -- had been chosen for the bill signing because the Governor had canceled a previous appearance here. But it also put Mrs. Whitman away from the State House on the day when the Legislature's Black and Latino Caucus was holding a hearing in Trenton about allegations of racial profiling by the state police. The administration, especially Attorney General Peter G. Verniero, has come under increased criticism over the issue.
In her first term as Governor, Mrs. Whitman delivered on a campaign pledge to cut the state income tax by 30 percent for most middle- and low-income taxpayers. But in November 1997 the notoriously restive New Jersey electorate came close to turning her out of office in favor of a long-shot Democratic candidate, Mayor James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge, and much of that voter anger was over paying some of the highest property taxes and automobile insurance rates in the nation.
But in the first three months of this year, with the help of a Legislature controlled by her fellow Republicans, Mrs. Whitman has moved swiftly to shield her political weak spot on property taxes as she turns her attention toward a race for the Senate seat being vacated next year by Frank R. Lautenberg, a Democrat who is retiring after three terms.
Late last year, Mrs. Whitman established a property tax commission to provide her with ideas for controlling property taxes.
"The debate shouldn't be about relief versus reform," Mrs. Whitman said today. "I believe anything that we can do to help ease the property burden is worth doing, and we can do all these things."
Democrats in Trenton, who have received their own share of electoral grief over taxes, have not made the property tax cuts a partisan issue, and some of them were co-sponsors of the legislation that the Governor signed today.
One bill will create a $10 million pool for grants and loans to finance studies or start-up costs for new shared service agreements among communities. The other part of the legislation allocates $25 million for tax credits for taxpayers in communities that now have combined services.
The bill that Mrs. Whitman intends to sign on Thursday -- a week after she announced that she was forming a fund-raising committee for a Senate race -- is clearly the highest-profile piece of legislation. It will provide $1 billion over five years for property tax relief, eventually giving homeowners, regardless of income, an average annual rebate check of $600.
"The tax reduction to individuals is simultaneously a tax bill and a statement of political philosophy," said Joseph J. Seneca, the chairman of the New Jersey Council of Economic Advisers, a five-member panel that analyzes economic conditions and forecasts trends. "It's a response to the perceived request of homeowners for direct property tax relief. That concern has been expressed for many years, especially at the ballot box on many Novembers."

HEADLINE: Push to Turn Diallo Rally Into a Broader Movement

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN 

 BODY:
Terence Tolbert answered one of the room's eight phones with a one-word salutation: "Coalition."
Mr. Tolbert normally works as chief of staff for State Assemblyman Keith L. Wright, a Democrat from Harlem. But yesterday he shared office space with aides to the Manhattan Borough President, C. Virginia Fields, City Councilwoman Christine Quinn of Manhattan's West Side and Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, along with a former Black Panther and an organizer from 1199, the 150,000-member National Health and Human Service Employees Union. 
 They were seated in 1199's midtown headquarters around a conference table in what they call the "Peace Room," the planning center for tomorrow's rally in memory of Amadou Diallo. On one wall was a gallery of news clippings about the fatal police shooting of Mr. Diallo on Feb. 4; on the other were lists of who was responsible for handing out leaflets in 49 subway stations around the city.
After two months of protests inspired by the Diallo shooting, tomorrow's is expected to be the largest, with demonstrators gathering at Cadman Plaza in downtown Brooklyn, then marching over the Brooklyn Bridge to a rally outside 26 Federal Plaza in lower Manhattan. It is intended, the organizers said, as a showcase for a new civil rights movement, a multiracial coalition organized mainly around police brutality, but it is expected to attract all manner of citizens who have complaints about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
"This is not like a structured, well-oiled machine that every detail is being carefully thought out and established," said Ken Sunshine, a political consultant who is chief spokesman for the rally organizers. "It's a broad range of people who are volunteering and building something."
Organizers do not yet have permits for the sites, but they have had several meetings with the Police Department and said there is an oral agreement allowing the rally. Inspector Michael Collins, a department spokesman, said, "We don't expect any problems."
From the Peace Room on the seventh floor of 1199's headquarters, where "two days and counting" was scrawled on a wipe-off board, to the paid television and radio advertisements that have been broadcast in recent days, the preparations for the rally have had the feel of the final days of a political campaign. The operation also has the hallmarks of grass-roots union organizing, with a sophisticated phone bank that started April 8 and "literature drops" planned for today in housing projects throughout the city.
For the organizers, led by 1199's president, Dennis Rivera, the rally will test whether they can turn the outrage over Mr. Diallo's death into a broad-based movement whose first goals are in a 10-point plan on police reform. For Mr. Giuliani, it is likely to be another dose of negative publicity.
"What we may be seeing is the minority groups coming of age as a coalition force, being the dog rather than the tail," said Norman Adler, a political consultant who has worked for both Democrats and Republicans. "The question is whether you can turn a rally into a movement."
With a $300,000 budget from union political action funds, minority business leaders and elected officials, and with a cadre of professional organizers on loan from their jobs, the rally's organizers are under pressure to draw crowds significantly larger than those at the daily demonstrations last month in front of Police Headquarters that often attracted more than 1,000 people. There has been talk that as many as 25,000 might attend, but rally organizers have been loath to predict a turnout. They have also refused to say who will speak.
The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson cannot make the rally but is to speak at a luncheon for 100 organizers today as a kind of pep rally. There is also a candlelight vigil scheduled for tonight at the Brooklyn Bridge.
Beyond numbers, which experts say Mr. Rivera is a genius at attracting, there is also the perennial political problem of staying on message. The 10-point police reform plan includes complicated legislative proposals for the city, state and Federal level, on corruption, police brutality, affirmative action, residency requirements and firearms training. But the Diallo rallies increasingly attract Giuliani opponents of all stripes, including veterans of battles over issues like street vending and community gardens.
"The arrests and the rallies have mobilized public attention; the purpose of mobilizing public attention is to then move an agenda," said Mitchell Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University. "The agenda is still ethereal. No one knows what the agenda is. The question is, can the agenda move to the front page instead of the rally?"
At City Hall, aides to the Mayor have been murmuring about the motivations behind the rally, suggesting that ambitious politicians with their eye on the mayoralty, or on the United States Senate seat Mr. Giuliani may seek in 2000, are exploiting a tragic death for personal gain. Polls have shown that the Mayor's popularity is slipping, and every day he is forced to respond to a rally is a day he cannot tout the city's booming economy and dwindling crime rate.
While upstate voters seem unmoved by the Diallo case, analysts believe Mr. Giuliani would need strong support in the city to win the Senate seat. "He's had a run of bad publicity," Mr. Adler said, "and this doesn't help."
In the Peace Room yesterday, the official line was that tomorrow's rally is not about the Mayor. There were no anti-Giuliani signs on the walls. The red T-shirts for the rally's marshals bear the slogan, "Justice for Amadou Diallo."
So how is this rally different from all other rallies? "In some ways it is a culmination, in other ways it is the beginning of the next chapter," said the Rev. Al Sharpton, who led the Diallo rallies of the last two months. "It's like farming. You go out every day planting the seeds and everybody says, there's that crazy farmer. The farmer says, one day these seeds are going to grow."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Economists Starting to See A Payoff From Technology
For more than a decade, most of the nation's leading economists have questioned the economic payoff from information technology -- the billions upon billions spent each year by companies and households on everything from computers to software to cellular phones.
But now economists are wondering whether higher productivity growth -- averaging about 2 percent in the last three years, roughly double the pace from 1973 to 1995 -- is the long-awaited confirmation that the nation's steadily rising investment in computers and communications is finally paying off. Page A1. 

Several Companies in Phone Deals
Cisco Systems, the maker of data-networking equipment, announced a $2 billion acquisition of Geotel Communications, expanding into telephone software, while two of the biggest makers of traditional phone systems, Ericsson and Northern Telecom, said they would acquire private data-networking companies. Shares of Geotel Communications rose $11.6875, to $55.9375. C2.
 
Motorola's Profit Increases 20%
Motorola said that its first-quarter profit rose 20 percent, helped by cost cuts and improved sales of mobile phones and chips. C2.
 
Bell Atlantic Says Market Is Open
Bell Atlantic, in a meticulous march toward the $80 billion long-distance market, told New York State regulators that it had fully opened its network to competition, as required. C11.
 
Dow Gains, but Other Averages Fall
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 55.5 points, to 10,395.01, another record, but other gauges slipped as investors took profits, especially in technology issues. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 8.82 points, to 1,349.82, while the Nasdaq composite index declined 15.31 points, to 2,583.50. C15.
 
A Proposal to Cut Auto Pollution
The Clinton Administration is preparing to announce as early as next week that it will require cleaner gasoline and tougher pollution standards for autos, including forcing large sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks to meet the same emission standards as cars. A22.
 
Inquiry of America Online Sought
At least seven former volunteers who helped maintain America Online's virtual community have asked the Labor Department to look into whether the on-line service's use of unpaid labor violates Federal law. A18.
 
Barclays Chief Quits, Citing Health
Barclays, Britain's second-largest bank, is looking for its fourth chief executive in six months after Michael O'Neill resigned because of ill health, touching off speculation that the bank may be vulnerable to a takeover. Mr. O'Neill, 53, fainted twice last week and was found to have an irregular heartbeat that could be aggravated by stress, a bank spokesman said. C10.
 
Korean Bank Sale Is in Trouble
An agreement by the South Korean Government to sell Korea First Bank to a consortium led by Newbridge Capital has foundered over a disagreement about how to value the bank's assets and establish a sale price. C4.
 
Study on Fast Data Connections
The battle over access to high-speed Internet connections moved to the Senate Commerce Committee, whose chairman, John McCain, said he would seek a study on how to make the technology more widely available. C26.
 
In another move aimed at providing music over the Internet, Real Networks agreed to buy a software company, Xing Technology, for up to $75 million in stock. C8.
 
Milberg Weiss to Pay $50 Million
Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, a New York law firm that has grown rich by suing corporations, agreed to pay $50 million to Lexecon, a consulting firm that often testifies for corporations. Lexecon had accused the law firm of trying to destroy its reputation. C2.

HEADLINE: Los Angeles's Chance to Recover Its Fumbles

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 13

 BODY:
This metropolis unblushingly bills itself as the entertainment capital of the world, and from Hollywood studios to thrill-ride theme parks, oxygen bars and big Pacific rollers, it can back up the boast. But when it comes to professional football, the most popular sport in the country, Los Angeles has been stuck in its own end zone.
Now that is about to change. Maybe. 
 Last month, the National Football League announced that Los Angeles was its first choice to receive the league's as yet unnamed 32d franchise, bypassing a firm bid of $200 million in public financing from Houston in favor of Los Angeles's lucrative television market, which is bigger than that of many states and could help the league's slipping television ratings.
But there's a catch: Los Angeles, the town that couldn't keep a team, now has not one but two competing proposed stadiums and owner groups, each of them featuring "guys with egos the size of Montana," in the words of one City Hall aide. The league gave Los Angeles until September to meet a variety of demands, including a strong show of support from the local business community, or lose the franchise to Houston.
Los Angeles's quest says much about the difficulty of uniting this disparate region of semi-connected suburbs around any idea and about its boosters' determination not to accept any status that could be seen as second-class. It also bespeaks the tremendous economic power of professional sports teams and their attraction for wealthy owners, if not for municipalities.
"Football is the No. 1 sport in America," said Michael Ovitz, the onetime Hollywood super-agent and current entertainment manager who is leading a bid to build a new Spanish-style stadium and shopping complex called the Hacienda on a vacant site in the suburb of Carson, just north of Long Beach, with towering mission bells that would ring on a home-team touchdown. "No. 1. There's not even anything else close, and how do you not have football in this city? It doesn't make any sense."
The other proposal is led by the billionaire insurance and construction executive Eli Broad and Edward P. Roski Jr., a real estate developer who co-owns the Kings hockey team and the Lakers basketball team and helped develop the new Staples Arena where those teams will play downtown. Their plan would dramatically revamp the Coliseum into a state-of-the-art stadium, topping its famed peristyle facade with bat-wing canopies and luxury suites.
So far, neither side has moved to compromise, though the city establishment has shown a clear preference for reviving the Coliseum as part of its efforts to revitalize the greater downtown area.
And the N.F.L., in a move to make the Coliseum more attractive to any of its wavering owners -- who have the final vote -- has tentatively approached the Fox Group about moving the Los Angeles Dodgers from their longtime home in Chavez Ravine to a new baseball stadium that could be built next to the Coliseum, creating a kind of multiplex, officials said today, confirming a report in The Los Angeles Times.
But unlike Houston, or Hartford, which recently lured the New England Patriots with a pledge to build a $375 million stadium, Los Angeles has shown no willingness to spend direct public money on a new stadium, except for tax breaks on the revenue a team might generate and freeway improvements already completed near the Coliseum. Carson has offered a $150 million bond issue, plus $30 million in cash to build the stadium and adjoining mall, but that site is a former dump that would have to be cleaned up.
League officials make it quietly clear that their preference would be for a unified proposal from the two groups. But both sides here, while pledging cooperation, are waiting for the next move by the league.
"I think there's still a bit of confusion owing to the lack of specifics from the league, in terms of a concrete choice," said City Councilman Mark Ridley-Thomas, whose district surrounds the Coliseum site and who has spent three years promoting it. "The league will have to make the next step."
Los Angeles's relationship with football has not been easy. First the Rams, which arrived from Cleveland in 1946, decamped to Anaheim in nearby Orange County after the 1979 season, and then, in 1995, to St. Louis. That same year, the Raiders abandoned a star-crossed 12-year sojourn at the Coliseum and returned to Oakland, leaving the nation's second-largest city outclassed by the likes of Charlotte, N.C., Green Bay, Wis., and Jacksonville, Fla.
Angelenos did not care about football, the argument went. The Coliseum, on the edge of the South-Central neighborhood torn by the 1992 riots, was not safe, the skeptics said. Too much traffic, too little parking, too little vacant land and lack of public investment seemed to doom the city's hopes of attracting another team.
As the would-be owners jockey for advantage, plenty of skeptics remain unconvinced of the need for a team. A Los Angeles Times poll last year found that only 38 percent of respondents considered it at least "somewhat important" to have a team in Los Angeles.
"I don't think they're economic boons for the region," Joel Kotkin, a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute of Public Policy in Malibu said of sports franchises. "They may be economic boons for people who have downtown real estate. Something like a Staples Arena, which will be full a great deal of the time, and bring in groups, yes. But football teams? They play seven times a year and basically a bunch of rich white guys go to the games. I can't figure out how that makes much of a difference."
John Macks, a former political consultant who now writes for "The Tonight Show," said: "I grew up in Philadelphia and worked in Washington. There it was the Eagles and the Redskins and it defined your existence. Here nobody cares. First of all, it's not raining and snowing on a Sunday in November. There are other things to do.
"And to us, driving is a contact sport. If we want to get out our aggression, we can go for a Sunday drive. As everyone in Hollywood knows, the sequel is never as good. Why have another bad one?"
Mr. Roski acknowledged that rampant rowdyism at Raiders' games at the Coliseum had left him unable to persuade his wife to go to games there, adding: "I could get my son-in-law; he had no choice." But Mr. Roski said that since the Raiders left, the University of Southern California has continued to play at the Coliseum without incident.
The N.F.L. has made it clear that it does not want the choice of a site to dictate a choice of owners. Because Mr. Roski holds the exclusive rights for the state-owned Coliseum site, that could be a stumbling block, and he has offered to give up those rights if necessary. Similarly, Mr. Ovitz said that if his rival bid at Carson, which is backed by the billionaire grocery magnate Ron Burkle and a bevy of movie stars like Tom Cruise and Kevin Costner, is seen as an impediment to returning a franchise to Los Angeles, he would step aside.
When the league made its announcement last month, civic leaders were quick to float a scenario in which Mr. Ovitz would give up his bid, and join Mr. Roski's group as a minority owner. But so far, neither side is giving up, and league officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, suggest the league may simply select a site, then auction ownership rights to the highest bidder.

HEADLINE: The Twisting Hunt for an Officer's Killer

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
The pursuit of the killer of an Orange, N.J., police officer, a case that at first seemed so linear and logical, has evolved into a perplexing tangle of events that are billowing to transform the matter into something well beyond the death of an officer in a city where police officers do not get killed.
Rather than resolution, three arrests have produced riddles and unanswered questions, charges and countercharges. Even some of the police officers immersed in the case are wondering: Do they have the right man? How many men are they really after? 
 So many questions lingered yesterday because officials involved in the investigation were not willing to provide even some of the most rudimentary answers about what happened when and why.
What is clear is that three men were brought into custody over the weekend, either directly or indirectly because of the quest for the killer. One of the men died an hour after being arrested. Law enforcement officials, who said the man was not a suspect in the killing, suggested yesterday that he suffered an asthma attack. His father contended that he was beaten to death by the police, even though an initial examination by the Medical Examiner's office found no evidence of a beating.
Another man, the only one of the three who has been charged with the crime, showed up in court with a bruised eye. No officials would comment on how it happened. The third man was charged with drug possession, but some police officers said he may have been involved in the shooting.
The series of events unfolded quickly. Officer Joyce Anne Carnegie, 38, of the 113-member Orange police force, was shot to death last Thursday evening when she got out of her squad car to question a man who fit the description of someone who committed armed robbery nearby. One Orange police officer said that Officer Carnegie was first shot in the stomach and, while on the ground clutching the gunman's foot, was shot a second time point-blank in the head.
She was the first officer killed in the line of duty in 33 years in Orange, a pinpoint of a town of 29,000 people just northwest of Newark.
Officer Carnegie's death prompted a manhunt by dozens of investigators from the Orange police, the Essex County Prosecutor's office and the Newark police, and it produced quick results.
On Saturday night, the police found Terrance Everett, 24, at a well-kept white stucco house he shares with his mother in East Orange. There was a late-model pearl-colored Cadillac El Dorado parked in front of an old sedan in the driveway. Two girls who lived nearby said that Mr. Everett drove a red two-door car of a make they could not identify. Authorities said that Officer Carnegie's killer fled in a 1986 blue Honda Accord.
The authorities have not said why they homed in on Mr. Everett. He was charged with robbery and weapons possession in addition to the murder charge.
Raids as part of the hunt for Officer Carnegie's killer continued on Sunday, though it was unclear why, if investigators believed that they had found the killer.
Two more men were arrested Sunday night. James (Malik) Coker, 29, of Newark, was taken into custody at the Douglass-Harrison Homes, where he was visiting his aunt. The police charged him with possession of crack and with trying to swallow the drugs when officers came to the apartment. It is not known what led investigators to Mr. Coker, and he has not been formally linked to the shooting.
But one Orange police officer said that he and some colleagues were unconvinced that Mr. Everett was the killer and were looking hard at Mr. Coker. Patricia Hurt, the Essex County Prosecutor, refused to answer questions about the case yesterday.
The most bizarre twist in the case involved Earl Faison. According to investigators, the 27-year-old Mr. Faison inadvertently came to their attention Sunday night when he was hailing a cab at South Day Street and Freeway Drive West, a block from where Officer Carnegie was shot. Feeling he bore a resemblance to a composite police sketch of the killer, authorities said, officers working the area approached him. A police officer said Mr. Faison ran and was chased for three blocks before he was caught. When he was frisked, officials said, they found a semiautomatic gun, and they arrested him on gun possession charges.
According to the Essex County Prosecutor's office, Mr. Faison collapsed and died an hour later as he walked into the warrant room at Orange Police Headquarters. The Prosecutor's office said yesterday that the Medical Examiner's office had been unable to determine the cause of death and was doing further testing. But officials said the medical examiner ruled out blunt force trauma as a possible cause and found no evidence of kicking, beating or strangulation.
A law enforcement official said that Mr. Faison had an asthma attack at the police station, which can be fatal if not treated quickly. Earl Williams, Mr. Faison's father, confirmed his son had asthma but said he had never suffered a seizure and the condition was under control. Mr. Faison's girlfriend, who did not want to give her name, said he did not have a regular doctor but took medication and occasionally went to the emergency room.
Mr. Williams said that he went to the morgue Monday but was not allowed to see his son's body. Instead, he was shown a picture of him. "From the moment I saw the picture, I knew he was beaten to death," he said. "He was beaten very badly. It looked like he was dragged by a truck." Mr. Williams said there were multiple cuts and bruises on his face, and his face was swollen.
Ray Weiss, a spokesman for Ms. Hurt, would not comment on the case beyond saying that the investigation is continuing. Patrick Toscano, the first assistant Essex County prosecutor, said, "It is my understanding that the Orange police officers did nothing wrong in this situation."
According to his girlfriend, Mr. Faison was on probation and had served 10 months in jail before being released in June. She said she did not know why he had gone to jail or whether he owned a gun. She said he was with her on the night the officer was killed.
Mr. Faison was an aspiring rap singer, according to his sister, Kytria Faison. And over the weekend, relatives said, he took a bus to Virginia with another rap group, Naughty By Nature. He returned Sunday afternoon, they said, and spent the rest of the day moving his studio equipment from his aunt's house in Newark to his girlfriend's house in Orange. He was leaving his girlfriend's house, getting into a cab, she said, when the police approached him.
Little was immediately known about Mr. Coker. Ursula Scott, 37, the aunt he was visiting when he was arrested, said he was unemployed, but she did not know where he was living or much else about him. She said he did look like the sketch of the killer. "He did say, because he had a bald head and some weight, he was afraid to go out on the street," Ms. Scott said.
When Mr. Everett, the man charged in the killing, appeared in court on Monday and pleaded not guilty, he had a blackened left eye. Raymond Hamlin, his lawyer, told the judge that his client had incurred facial bruises since he was arrested, though he did not accuse the police of inflicting them. Later, he told reporters that he could establish that Mr. Everett was elsewhere at the time Officer Carnegie was killed.
Ms. Hurt has indicated that she had four people who have identified Mr. Everett. Like so many other things in this twisting case, it is not known who they are and what they identified him for -- robbing someone or killing a police officer.

HEADLINE: Computer Age Gains Respect of Economists

BYLINE: By By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
In a nation of technophiles, where Internet millionaires are minted daily, it seems heresy to question the economic payoff from information technology -- the billions upon billions spent each year by companies and households on everything from computers to software to cell phones.
But for more than a decade, most of the nation's leading economists have been heretics. 
 "You can see the computer age everywhere but in the productivity statistics," Robert M. Solow, a Nobel Prize winner from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, once said.
For years, even as the computer revolutionized the workplace, "measured productivity" -- the output of goods and services per worker -- stagnated, barely advancing 1 percent a year. So it is easy to see how Mr. Solow's pithy comment became the favorite punch line of the economic naysayers.
Yet today, even renowned skeptics on the subject of technology's contribution to the economy, like Mr. Solow, are having second thoughts. Productivity growth has picked up, starting in 1996, capped by a surge in the second half of last year, after eight years of economic expansion. That has drawn attention because past upward swings in productivity typically occurred early in a recovery as economic activity rebounded. Once companies increased hiring, it slowed again.
But something seems fundamentally different this time. It apparently relates to the increased speed and efficiency that information technology advances -- including the Internet -- is finally bringing to the mundane day-to-day tasks of millions of businesses.
The question, posed by economists, is whether the higher productivity growth averaging about 2 percent in the last three years, roughly double the pace from 1973 to 1995, is the long-awaited confirmation that the nation's steadily rising investment in computers and communications is finally paying off. The evidence is starting to point in that direction.
"My beliefs are shifting on this subject," Mr. Solow said. "I am still far from certain. But the story always was that it took a long time for people to use information technology and truly become more efficient. That story sounds a lot more convincing today than it did a year or two ago."
Another pillar in the pessimist camp was Daniel E. Sichel, an economist at the Federal Reserve. His work, along with another Fed economist, Stephen D. Oliner, in 1994, and on his own in 1997, found that computers contributed little to economic growth. But recently, Mr. Sichel ran similar calculations for the last few years and came to a different conclusion.
In a paper that has just been published in the quarterly Business Economics, he wrote that his new work points to "a striking step up in the contribution of computers to output growth." And the nation's improved productivity performance, he noted, is "raising the possibility that businesses are finally reaping the benefits of information technology."
 
Wanted: New Way To Measure Economy
The impact of information technology on the economy is more than an academic debate. If, as some experts assert, the technology dividend is a key reason for the nation's extraordinary run of high growth, rising wages and low inflation, there are significant policy implications. If the recent gains are not just a temporary blip, it suggests that the Federal Reserve can be less fearful of inflation and keep interest rates stable rather than be forced to raise them to cool off what would otherwise be considered an overheated economy. The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, and the other Fed governors are scheduled to hear presentations on information technology's effect on the economy from several academics during a private meeting in Washington tomorrow.
Mr. Greenspan, for one, seems to believe a fundamental change is under way in the economy. He told Congress in January that the economy is enjoying "higher, technology-driven productivity growth."
The Fed governors will hear a forceful case for technological optimism from Erik Brynjolfsson, an associate professor at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management.
Mr. Brynjolfsson asserts that the economic value of speed, quality improvements, customer service and new products are often not captured by Government statistics. "These are the competitive advantages of information technology," he said. "We need a broader definition of output in this new economy, which goes beyond the industrial-era concept of widgets coming off the assembly line."
The Government, after years of defending its figures, conceded two weeks ago that productivity growth may be understated. The core of the problem, Government economists say, is the increasingly complex challenge of defining and measuring output in much of the economy's fast-growing service sector, which includes the vast reaches of banking, finance, health care and education.
According to the official statistics, for instance, a bank today is no more productive than a bank was two decades ago. Yet that seems to take scant account of, say, 24-hour automated teller machines, which clearly benefit customers who no longer have to wait in lines to be served by human tellers during regular "bankers' hours."
Edwin R. Dean, chief of the productivity division of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, wrote in a recent research paper that the agency is increasingly concerned that its measurements do not "fully reflect changes in the quality of goods and services" or "capture the full impact of new technology on economic performance."
Still, the Government's methods of measurement will not be overhauled anytime soon. "These are tough, tough questions and we are not going to get instant solutions," Mr. Dean said in an interview.
 
Revolution Unfolds In the Back Offices
American corporations long ago made up their minds, voting for technology with their dollars. Investment in information technology -- computing and telecommunications gear -- has quadrupled over the last decade, rising as a share of all business spending on equipment to 53 percent from 29 percent, according to the Commerce Department. And that is only the hardware. There have been surges in corporate spending on software, consulting, technical support and training related to the field.
"The payoff from information technology is unquestionably there with individual companies and we're seeing it over and over again," said Chuck Rieger, a senior consultant at I.B.M.'s services division.
Of course, anecdotal evidence from individual companies is no proof of broad-based benefits in an $8.5 trillion economy. But what many experts find encouraging is that the rapid introduction of low-cost Internet technology means most companies can now afford to set up electronic links with customers and suppliers. For example, a recent survey of 2,500 manufacturing companies, conducted by PricewaterhouseCoopers, found that the number of factories with Internet links to customers and suppliers doubled last year.
At more and more companies, these Internet-based networks are already streamlining the mundane chores of business life like invoicing, purchasing and inventory control. This is not the glamorous side of Internet commerce, occupied by Amazon.com and others selling consumer products. Yet if a technology dividend in productivity is at hand, the place to look is in the back offices of business. "That is where it will be," Mr. Solow, the M.I.T economist, said, "in the wholesale automation of corporate transactions."
This business-to-business commerce over the Internet is projected to jump from $48 billion in 1998 to $1.5 trillion by 2003, according to Forrester Research Inc. During the same period, the research firm estimates that consumer sales over the Internet will rise from $3.9 billion to $108 billion.
 
Looking for Clues In the Service Sector
The service sector of the economy is where productivity gains appear to have been especially sluggish and where experts are looking most closely for evidence of an efficiency payoff from technology.
In Chicago, Michael Rushmore, a banker, said Internet computing has "fundamentally changed the way we do business" over the last three or four years. An example of this is the way corporate loans are syndicated among many banks, said Mr. Rushmore, who is a managing director of Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities, the securities arm of the BankAmerica Corporation.
Until about two years ago, syndicating a large corporate bank loan meant distributing a lengthy offering document, often running more than 200 pages, to 50 to 100 banks. It was, Mr. Rushmore recalled, a nightmarish, inefficient process that involved waves of overnight mail, constant faxing and armies of messengers.
Today, much of that process is handled over the Internet on bank Web sites that other banks tap into to read and download the offering document, ask questions and exchange views. Mr. Rushmore estimates that the Internet-based system trims 25 percent from the time it takes to close a deal, not just improving the ease of the transaction but also saving an immense amount of work.
The rapid spread of Internet-based computing, experts say, promises to compress the time it takes for any new technology to enhance economic welfare in general. The classic study of the phenomenon, "The Dynamo and the Computer: An Historical Perspective on the Modern Productivity Paradox," by Paul David, an economic historian at Stanford University, was published in 1990.
The electric motor, Mr. David noted, was introduced in the early 1880's but did not generate discernible productivity gains until the 1920's. It took that long, he wrote, not only for the technology to be widely diffused but also for businesses to reorganize work around the industrial production line, the efficiency breakthrough of its day.
"The process takes longer than people think, but I still believe that we will get a revival of productivity growth led by the spread of computing," Mr. David said.
 
Techno-Pessimists See an 'Arms Race'
His is a misplaced faith, according to the dwindling band of techno-pessimists whose own beliefs remain unshaken. Sure, they concede, there has been surprisingly strong productivity growth for the last three years. Could this represent a break in the trend? Possibly, they grudgingly admit, but only a tiny shift at best.
The real problem, they say, lies in the composition of the nation's vast service economy. More than half of all white-collar workers are what they term "knowledge workers" -- managers, executives and professionals like doctors, lawyers, teachers, even economists.
"The work they do does not lend itself to technology-driven improvements in productivity, and any gains are really difficult to eke out and are glacial," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "Paul David's electrical motor has nothing to do with the knowledge-intensive process of work in a service economy."
A leading technology cynic at the Fed meeting tomorrow will be Paul Strassmann, a former chief information officer of Xerox and the Pentagon. Mr. Strassmann, author of "The Squandered Computer," published in 1997, believes that much of corporate America's spending spree on information technology amounts to an "economic arms race," fueled by misguided management theories.
The recent improvement in productivity, according to Mr. Strassmann, is mainly attributable to the lower cost of capital because of low interest rates. His summary view, though at odds with those of technology optimists like Mr. Brynjolfsson of M.I.T., may also be received warmly by the Fed.
"The explanation for the productivity improvement is interest rates, not information technology," Mr. Strassmann said. "The hero here is not Bill Gates. It's Alan Greenspan."
Yet even Mr. Strassmann finds the technology undeniably useful, if not a productivity elixir. When asked a detailed question, he replied: "Just look it up on my Web site. It's a lot more efficient that way."

HEADLINE: Aiming for Greener Pastures;
Farm-Equipment Makers Step Up Efforts to Diversify

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 8

 BODY:
The name John Deere conjures up tractors, farm equipment, big green machines lingering in the distance, on a huge corn field somewhere in the Midwest.
While it receives most of its revenues from the farm, Deere & Company, the world's largest maker of agricultural machinery, also peddles lawn and turf products. The Case Corporation, a rival in farm machinery, has broadened its reach as well, financing dump trucks and marine equipment. And Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest maker of earthmoving equipment and a major agricultural supplier, is selling truck engines while leveraging its vast distribution network to move Chrysler auto parts and Puma sneakers. 
 All three heavy-equipment makers -- the biggest names in farm and construction equipment -- are moving into new fields in an effort to buffer themselves from the wrenching up-and-down cycle of their core businesses. At the moment, they are trying to break out of a nasty slowdown that in the last few quarters has sapped the profits of virtually every maker of farm equipment. When the farm economy here in the Midwest sagged with the Asian economic crisis and the construction business showed signs of slowing late last year, the big-equipment makers stepped up their efforts to diversify in hopes of maintaining profitability, even in a down cycle.
The sector has been upgraded recently by some Wall Street analysts who believe that the heavy-machinery cycle is likely to start moving upward, but most analysts are unimpressed by the steps toward diversification. Fundamentally, the companies are defined by their core businesses -- and so are still captives of the business cycle.
"I know what they're trying to do, but it's just not showing up in the numbers," Tobias M. Levkovich, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said about Case. "They've gotten reamed by the cycle, and that's with the U.S. construction business doing very well."
Still, the most recent downturn has been a big impetus in a trend that has been in place for some time.
Case, for instance, now receives about a third of its revenue from sales of construction equipment. Deere receives nearly one-fifth of its revenues from lawn and consumer products. Caterpillar, which originated in 1925 with the merger of two farm tractor companies, is dominant in excavating and earthmoving machines, but now receives a third of its revenues from engine sales and about 5 percent from financial services.
The three companies say they are also outsourcing more operations to cut fixed costs and venturing further afield into unrelated businesses, such as health care, distribution management, toys and clothing. Caterpillar has a new line of "Cat" boots, caps and jeans. Deere likewise has a major licensing deal involving toys and clothing.
Caterpillar executives are hammering away at a consistent message. "If the U.S. construction market slows down we've been telling people, 'Look, we are not a U.S. construction industry business,' " said F. Lynn McPheeters, chief financial officer at Caterpillar. "This is a global, multifaceted company that has taken a lot of the cyclicality out of the company."
Wall Street remains skeptical, however. Despite diversification, when the farm and construction economies weakened last year, particularly in Asia, so did the profits of these companies.
At Case, earnings dropped 80 percent in 1998. Deere, which has laid off at least 300 workers in the last six months, saw profits decline 75 percent last quarter.
Caterpillar, by contrast, had a year of record revenues, $21 billion. But profits are expected to slip 50 percent when it reports quarterly results this week compared with the similar quarter a year earlier because of weaker sales of agriculture and mining products and a slump in Latin America.
Investors had been dumping the Big Three stocks until recently, when the shares began to recover somewhat on hopes that the cycle might be on the verge of an upturn. But it was a long plunge downward: Case stock, for example, fell below the price of its 1994 initial public offering.
Case says it has drastically changed its operations since it was spun off from Tenneco that year. Now, the company says, it is quicker to react to downturns. Executives also say the company has cut fixed costs in recent years and moved rapidly to idle plants. And it has counted on geographical diversification and benefited from stronger sales of construction equipment and growth in its financing of marine and commercial vehicles, such as municipal garbage trucks.
"I'm absolutely convinced we're a dramatically different company than we were in the last down cycle," said Steven G. Lamb, president and chief operating officer. "In the last downturn we weren't profitable. But since then we've grown our construction, credit and international businesses."
Many Wall Street analysts, however, are far from convinced that Case or its competitors have fundamentally changed their reliance on cyclical businesses. When Lisa Shalett, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, raised doubts about the new efforts, executives at Case summoned her to their offices in Racine, Wis., for a review of the numbers.
"At the end of the day, it's great these companies have attempted to diversify," Ms. Shalett said. "But the key struggle for investors is that they don't make tons of money outside of the core business."
When the farm equipment market turned down in the early 1990's, Case lost more than $2 billion, including restructuring charges; Deere lost $920 million in 1993 alone. Caterpillar was also hemorrhaging. Though the farm slump could deepen in 1999, Mr. Lamb says Case executives are comfortable with Wall Street projections that Case will be "solidly profitable" in 1999, despite a slowdown in earnings growth over the last two years.
Jean-Pierre Rosso, the chief executive at Case, says his company's stock has fallen far too sharply. "At $25 it's still undervalued," Mr. Rosso said a few weeks ago, just days after shares of Case bounced back from their low of $18. "At $20 it was so grossly undervalued for a company with $6 billion in sales and excellent assets." On Tuesday the shares closed at $28.75.
Deere is more diversified. Its commercial-equipment division, which includes lawn and turf products, saw an 88 percent jump in operating profits in 1998. Its diesel engine business is also strong, and its managed health care operation improved greatly in 1998, after a large loss in 1997.
Caterpillar is the most diverse of the three, but falling demand in Asia has hurt crucial sales of earthmoving equipment, used for construction projects like the Hong Kong airport. The company is expanding its agriculture business, making a run at Deere in the sale of giant combines, but the biggest growth area for Caterpillar may be engines.
With its acquisition last year of Perkins Engines, the former subsidiary of Lucas Varity P.L.C., Caterpillar is now one of the world's largest makers of diesels for construction. Caterpillar engines are under the hood of about one-third of all big trucks in the United States.
Caterpillar is also promoting mobile electric generators, which are in high demand in the developing world. And it has leveraged its distribution network, called the Caterpillar Logistics Services, founded in 1986. The division now has 2,600 employees and handles, warehouses and distributes more than $4 billion worth of products each year, including parts for Sun Microsystems and Land Rovers.
Profit margins are much richer in farm vehicles than in the affiliated businesses, analysts say, and that means profit downturns in that business can be disproportionately sharp.
"The highest margins business at cyclical peaks is farm equipment," said Mr. Levkovich of Salomon Smith Barney. "They're trying to grow all those other things, but the buck still stops in farm."
The last big pure farm-equipment maker in the United States is the Agco Corporation of Duluth, Ga., which had $2.9 billion in sales in 1998. The company says that because it outsources most of its business and focuses primarily on assembly, it is less susceptible sharp downturns. Nonetheless, for the fiscal year ended Dec. 31, Agco's revenues fell 9 percent, to $2.94 billion, and the company announced that it was cutting 1,400 jobs. Its shares are now trading at $6.9375, down from $27 a year ago.
"Agriculture is cyclical, and since that is our primary industry, so are we," said Robert J. Ratliff, the company's chief executive. But Agco, which has grown in recent years by acquiring companies like Massey-Ferguson, said it would continue to seek acquisitions and would diversify to mitigate downturns.
In diversifying, however, Case, Deere and Caterpillar are poaching in one another's backyard. Construction companies and farm companies are now construction-farm companies with a growing interest in peripherals, like forestry equipment. Caterpillar and Deere are both selling diesel engines, in the hope that they will be a cyclical antidote.
Analysts who follow the industry talk about Caterpillar taking on Deere with big combines; Deere and Caterpillar taking on Ingersoll-Rand in a mechanism called the skid-steer loader, a small and easily adaptable multipurpose construction vehicle.
These searches for a cure, some analysts say, involve considerable risk.
"Everyone wants to diversify their exposure so they're not dependent on the farmer," said David Bluestein, an analyst at Paine Webber. "But these guys are all diversifying into other companies' core markets and that's going to lead to overcapacity, which causes pricing pressure."

Graph: "Taming the Cycles?"
The three big heavy-equipment makers -- trying to buffer the sharp ups and downs of their core farm and construction equipment businesses -- are increasingly trying to diversify. But Wall Street still sees them as cyclical stocks.
 
CATERPILLAR

HEADLINE: After Criticisms, Clinton Moves To Restart Talks With Chinese

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Facing sharp criticism over his failure last week to reach a trade deal with China, President Clinton telephoned China's Prime Minister this afternoon to restart the negotiations in Beijing this month.
The White House announced the effort as Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, who has complained repeatedly about the failure to reach a deal during his tour of the United States, was visiting New York before heading to Canada. Mr. Zhu had spent much of his day lobbying business executives about the benefits of an accord on trade. Page A12. 
 At a dinner in New York tonight sponsored by the Economic Club, Mr. Zhu said he had told Mr. Clinton during their phone conversation that he felt "very confident that in the near future we will see the successful conclusion of negotiations that are favorable to both sides -- but especially to the U.S."
Mr. Clinton's phone call to the Chinese leader followed a gathering on Monday in which nearly two dozen business executives met at the White House and sharply criticized the Administration for failing to seal the deal, which would give American companies access to the world's largest market.
"They were happy with the progress we made but were worried that the deal would not come to fruition," an Administration official said. The official said Mr. Clinton's phone call, which lasted about 20 minutes, was intended to send a signal to business leaders that the White House was doing all it could to seal the deal and that it intended to lock China into concessions it had made on numerous trade issues.
In a joint statement, the two countries said they would "move intensively" to resolve the remaining issues that blocked them from reaching a deal last week while Mr. Zhu met with President Clinton in Washington.
After he left Washington last week, Mr. Zhu began a surprisingly political campaign across the United States to pressure the Administration to work harder to complete the negotiations. Officials said Mr. Zhu was worried that he had not received enough of a commitment from the United States. The Administration, perceiving Mr. Zhu as a leading force for reform in China, wanted to allow him to return home and claim that he had made substantial progress.
Time may have been running out for Mr. Clinton too; if he did not catch Mr. Zhu before he left the country, some officials feared, the momentum for an agreement might have been lost for the rest of Mr. Clinton's second term as the Presidential elections heat up and Mr. Clinton's China policy comes under increasing fire.
China's entry into the World Trade Organization, the group that determines the rules for global commerce, was the prize that Mr. Zhu came seeking but was denied as talks collapsed at the last minute. Some Administration officials said that anti-China sentiment on Capitol Hill was so intense that they thought they could not get any deal through. At the same time, officials said, President Clinton was distracted by the Kosovo conflict and had not fully conveyed to his negotiators how much he wanted to complete the deal himself.
President Clinton still faces a tough sell on any agreement in Congress. Some Democrats in Congress were leery of an accord with China, predicting it would set off a divisive battle in their party, particularly with labor unions, which are concerned about protecting American jobs.
Mr. Zhu said during his visit here that he believed the deal fell through because of domestic American politics and that Washington had politicized what was essentially an economic issue. Republicans on Capitol Hill have been furious over Mr. Clinton's policy of engagement with China at a time when China is accused of stealing military secrets from the United States, cracking down on political dissidents and making illegal financial contributions to Mr. Clinton's 1996 re-election campaign.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, said last week during Mr. Zhu's visit that he strongly opposed a deal and was suspicious of whether China would commit to fair trade practices. The United States has a $57 billion trade imbalance with China.
China made several broad concessions last week in order to gain entry to the trade organization, a step it has been working toward for 13 years. Entry would require China to demolish its tariffs and trade barriers but would give it broad access to the markets of many other nations.
The Chinese concessions included allowing foreign companies to sell their products directly to consumers, an enormous opportunity in a land of 1.2 billion people. China also agreed to allow foreign companies to invest as much as 49 percent in telecommunications industries and to give greater access to foreign-owned insurance companies. In a separate civil aviation deal, it agreed to allow more flights from the United States. And it signed an accord to lift restrictions on the import of American wheat, citrus fruits and meat.
But still outstanding were areas like trade in financial services and assurances that the United States could enforce agreements with China.
After Mr. Zhu left Washington on Saturday, he criticized Mr. Clinton, saying in cities across the country that the President "does not dare" take a political risk in allowing China to join the trade organization. A senior official traveling with the Prime Minister said, "We had a deal."
Before Mr. Clinton called Mr. Zhu, Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, said on Capitol Hill today that the President was committed to seeing that negotiations would be finished in time for China to join the World Trade Organization this year.
"We will re-engage with the Chinese shortly," she said in testimony before the Senate Finance Committee, promising to "work on each of the issues that are open to bring this full agreement to closure."
While some Senators were hostile, others said they were worried that the deal would unravel and that China would withdraw the concessions it made last week. Mr. Zhu himself complained that the Administration had "made public many documents and said we had agreed to them, but in fact we have not agreed."
Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, accused the Administration of "raw, rotten protectionism" at the behest of American textile and steel companies, worried about the low price of Chinese imports.
He said the Administration was trying to force China to keep limits on textile exports for five years longer than currently allowed under the trade organization's rules. And he said that America's high barriers in this area had already cost the average family of four $700 more in clothing bills each year.
Administration officials said the talks in Beijing would be at the "expert" level between an assistant trade representative, Robert Cassidy, and China's vice minister for trade and economy, Long Yongtu. "Any higher-level talks will depend on progress that the experts make," one American official said.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
State Jobless Rate Rises For First Time in 2 Years

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The state's unemployment rate went up last month for the first time in nearly two years.
The rate was 4.5 percent in March, up from 4.1 percent in February. In March, the rate was again higher than the national rate, which fell to a 29-year low of 4.2 percent. 
 The numbers show about 20,000 fewer New Jerseyans held jobs during the month, but many economists consider a 4.5 percent unemployment rate to be close to full employment. New Jersey companies increased their payrolls by 6,400 during the month. The added jobs were held by state residents as well as out-of-state commuters.
The last time the unemployment rate went up was in June 1997, when the 5.2 percent rate was slightly higher than the preceding month's 5.1 percent rate.

HEADLINE: 'Saving' Social Security as a Guise to Raise Taxes

 BODY:

To the Editor:
According to Robert D. Reischauer (Op-Ed, April 9), fixing Social Security requires nothing more than higher payroll taxes and lower benefits. But in focusing on how to keep the trust fund solvent for longer, he ignores that the program is a bad deal for the average worker. 
 A 30-year-old married couple, who each earn an average wage of about $26,000, can expect to earn a paltry 1.2 percent return on their Social Security taxes. The most conservative private investment averages more than five times that. If this couple were allowed to invest the money themselves, they would have about $525,000 more for retirement than Social Security will provide.
Congress should allow workers to invest a portion of their Social Security taxes in personal retirement accounts.
 
WILLIAM BEACH
Washington, April 9, 1999
 
The writer is a senior fellow in economics at the Heritage Foundation.

HEADLINE: In School;
Bucking imposing odds, P.S. 115 turns around from failing statewide tests to winning honors

BYLINE: By Randal C. Archibold 

 BODY:
Carmen Serrano, to put it modestly, loves cats.
This is obvious from the cat posters, done by her pupils and their parents, dangling from the ceiling and clinging to the walls outside her classroom, and from the little cat dance she does as she sings a tune from "The Aristocats," shaking an imaginary tale for emphasis. 
 Behind the fun, however, lie serious lessons. The cat motif hooks students into subjects from reading (children write their own "cat tales") to science (stuffed-animal cats are used as props in lessons on weights and measures).
"We're not restricted here," said Ms. Serrano, who teaches first grade. "If you want to be innovative, then fine, if it works."
"Works" is understood to mean students doing well in mathematics and, especially, reading. And Public School 115 has improved enough on both in the last decade to rebound from officially failing to the Schools Chancellor's honor roll.
This accomplishment came about despite what might seem to be challenging odds: The school sits in a rough neighborhood near the corner of West 177th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue in Washington Heights. Nearly all the school's 1,300 children are poor enough to qualify for free lunch. Most come from immigrant families, mainly from the Dominican Republic. About half do not speak English fluently, and many of their parents, like Luisa Cabrera, the P.T.A. president, are taking classes at the school to learn it.
But on New York State's new school report cards, P.S. 115 is rated "far above average" in comparison to others with similar demographics. On citywide examinations last spring, 50.6 percent of third graders were reading at or above grade level, an improvement from 37.3 percent three years before and a hair below the city average of 51.3 percent.
On last year's statewide test, 60.9 percent of its third graders could understand typical reading matter for that grade, well above 23.5 percent for demographically similar schools and 33.2 percent city average.
That was a sharp contrast to 10 years ago, when the school made the state's first roster of academically troubled schools, known as Schools Under Registration Review, primarily because of chronically subpar reading scores.
The school took a multipronged approach toward reform, lifting itself off the list after three years.
A leadership committee was formed to involve parents and teachers in the direction of the school, advising the principal on everything from curriculum and staff training to whether pupils should be dismissed from one exit or two.
Parents were taught to use the public library so they could encourage their children to read, and the school enacted a 90-minute "Golden Hour" every morning during which the entire school reads intensively. Some students get another hour in the afternoon, and in advance of standardized tests, they pore over preparation materials.
Teachers have also raised their expectations, said Mayra Cruz, a fifth-grade special education teacher and the teachers' union representative for the school. (Some teachers were encouraged to take early retirement after the school landed on the failing schools list.) "They used to say, 'Oh, Johnny so-and-so can't learn,' " Ms. Cruz said. "No more. Now it's, 'Every child can learn.' "
Help also came from outside, with state, Federal and community financial assistance that has allowed for such occasional extras as class trips to Philadelphia and even Phoenix as part of an exchange program with an elementary school there. A local bank set up a "branch" in the school that every other week collects deposits from fifth graders, who in turn learn firsthand about economics.
The British Government donated $2,500 for library books a few years ago after an official from the British Embassy visited as part of a "principal for the day" program. "It's a true story, and funny in a way, but it is the sad reality," said George Tomka, the school's principal for 14 years. "The British Government had to give us library books."
New schools built in the area have eased the overcrowding cited by Mr. Tomka as a significant detriment to learning, and a few years ago, workers patched over long-neglected holes in ceilings and crumbling walls that had cast a pall over the five-story Gothic marvel, built in 1913.
The school is far from perfect. Steven Rothschild, a former teacher who now coordinates an absentee prevention program and arranges links to local businesses, said he lamented the fiscal shortfalls that wiped out most after-school sports over the years -- a basketball team remains -- and the craze over standardized tests that he believes can stifle teachers' creativity.
"I would go crazy if I were in the classroom now," he said.
Mr. Tomka, who once was the school's gym teacher, also wishes for more extracurricular activities, but he is convinced that the school is on the right track, waving off suggestions that test preparation is overemphasized.
"When I went to elementary school, we had the same thing," said Mr. Tomka, who attended public schools in the Bronx. "We had structured time for reading. I don't think it hurt anybody. And everybody could read and write."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 16, 1999, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about students' gains at Public School 115 in Washington Heights misstated the source of its "far above average" ranking for academic performance. Such rankings are issued by the New York City Board of Education on the basis of scores on citywide reading tests; they do not appear on New York State school report cards.
