HEADLINE: Alta Vista Invites Advertisers to Pay forTop Ranking

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Alta Vista, one of the leading services that search for information on the World Wide Web, is inviting advertisers to pay for the right to be listed atop its search results.
Even though advertising, both explicit and hidden, permeates most Web sites, the major search services have until now insisted that the search rankings themselves are produced objectively according to computer formulas and are not for sale. 
 The move comes as more and more Internet services, struggling to increase revenue and justify their fantastic stock market valuations, are selling advertising in forms that could well be confused for objective information. For example, Amazon.com, the bookstore, has started selling publishers the right to prominent reviews by Amazon's editors.
Alta Vista is owned by the Compaq Computer Corporation, which wants to build up its revenue quickly in order to sell a portion of Alta Vista in an initial public stock offering later this year. In February, Alta Vista was the 13th most popular site on the Internet, according to Media Metrix, which measures Web traffic.
The Alta Vista search result program was reported Tuesday by Wired News, an on-line news service. Doubleclick, the company that sells advertising for Alta Vista, promoted the program in a recent E-mail message to potential customers.
"When users perform keyword searches on Alta Vista, what is the first listing they see?" the message said. "Now it can be your company's listing." The message said Alta Vista was auctioning off the right to be listed in the first two positions to the highest bidders.
Kurt Lozert, the general manager of Alta Vista's search service, argues that when the program is disclosed it will not be confusing.
"We want to make it clear that we haven't changed our core index, but we want to offer additional ways for users to find some results that are interesting," he said. "We've tested a number of concepts so it will be very clear to users this is not the index results. These will be boxed, say, or there will be a red thing that says this is an advertisement."
Experts on on-line publishing say that the details of these graphic devices will determine whether the program is in fact misleading.
"It's largely a design issue of how they present the paid for selections," said Larry Pryor, the director of the on-line journalism program at the University of Southern California. "If they try to be subtle about it and slide it by so people can't tell, it's a terrible problem."
After a flurry of E-mail from customers criticizing its paid placement of reviews, Amazon decided to identify which reviews are subsidized, although this disclosure is not adjacent to the actual reviews.
Alta Vista's plan has also raised worries among small businesses that have come to rely on free listing on search engines to bring business to their Web sites.
"Search engines are one of the great equalizers of the Web," said John Heard, the president of Beyond Engineering, a consulting concern in Laharpe, Kan. "It lets a mom-and-pop business selling flowers compete with 1-800-Flowers. If everything is converted to paid advertising, then all the business will go to those with the deepest pockets."
Alta Vista is partly copying the business model of Goto.com, an Internet search site that consists entirely of paid listings. But in Goto's search results, each listing is explicitly accompanied by the amount that the advertiser will pay the site if a user clicks on the link. "We have confidence that advertising adds value to results, just like the Yellow Pages," Jeffrey Brewer, the company's chief executive, said.
Search engines are especially potent advertising vehicles because so many people use them when they are researching products to buy. But other than Goto, none of the sites have sold positions in their search results.
"I have tried to get each of the search engines to alter their search results to put my clients on top," said Michael Golden, the head of the New York office of Organic Online, an agency that represents many on-line stores. "They won't do it, and frankly that's a good thing."
And most of them said they remained committed to that policy. "We don't sell our search results -- never have, never will," said Melissa Walia, public relations manager for Excite, another search engine.
What Excite and most of the other search services have done, however, is to sell advertisements of all shapes and sizes that are placed above and to the side of search results.
Type "Viagra" into Lycos, for example, and the screen shows a graphical advertisement for an on-line clinic that proscribes sells Viagra. Below that is a text link, with the ambiguous marking "Bullseye" that in fact is an ad for another clinic. And to the side is an ad for a book on Viagra from Barnes & Noble. A user would have to move to the second page of the results to find the actual list of Web pages about Viagra.
The search services argue that all this advertising actually benefits users, because it is often more likely to be relevant to users than their other search results.
"If you type in 'computer,' are you looking to buy a computer, fix a computer, or research the history of computers?" said Celia Francis, the director of search marketing for Alta Vista. The paid placements, she argued, are more likely to be useful to users than a list of pages on which the word "computer" appears.
But Evan Thornley, the chief executive of LookSmart, a small Internet search and directory service, contends that consumers are starting to rebel against many of these ads.
"The short-term economics are in favor of flogging every piece of real estate that you have," he said. "But the long-term economics say that you also want to have a business at the end of the day."

HEADLINE: Showing Good Form at I.R.S.;
New Commissioner Has Agency Minding Its Manners

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
He gets up before dawn every day and runs five miles, then heads for his Government job without eating breakfast. He does not need the work -- after all, he's sitting on a $40 million fortune he made running his own business -- but this may be his biggest challenge yet.
Charles O. Rossotti, the first Commissioner of Internal Revenue who is not a tax lawyer, is pursuing a technological and cultural revolution with the improbable goal of both making the Internal Revenue Service more efficient at collecting taxes and making Americans happier about paying them. 
 Since arriving 18 months ago, Mr. Rossotti has instituted a 24-hour hot line for taxpayers, with an emphasis on reliable, courteous service. Many of those now fielding calls are longtime auditors whose old jobs were hunting for errors and searching for cheating on tax returns filed years earlier. To improve the accuracy of their responses, the commissioner has undertaken a seemingly obvious step that somehow eluded his predecessors: giving I.R.S. employees ready access to the Internal Revenue Code.
He is also having those unfathomable audit notices rewritten in plain English, with help from focus groups of taxpayers.
The task before him is enormous. Not only must the I.R.S. collect $1.7 trillion this year, more than the gross domestic product of Britain, it must also transfer billions of taxpayer records from computer systems that date to the Eisenhower Administration to modern disk storage and data base systems that have not yet been designed.
Mr. Rossotti has little room to stumble. Before he arrived, the agency wasted $4 billion on computer systems that proved to be unworkable. And Congress, unlikely to tolerate a repeat of that fiasco, is keeping a closer eye on the I.R.S. than ever before.
Last year, after two years of inquiries that stirred widespread outrage over mismanagement and abuse of taxpayers, lawmakers approved a major overhaul of the agency. They created a board with authority to oversee I.R.S. management and policies, set a five-year term for the commissioner and expanded protections against abusive tax agents.
On top of everything else, Mr. Rossotti must win over many senior executives and middle managers -- or replace them -- if his plans are not to get lost in the bureaucracy.
His admirers describe Mr. Rossotti, 58, as an organizational wizard with the uncanny ability to see both the forest and the trees and then decide which leaves need trimming and which need more sunlight. Among his priorities is upgrading I.R.S. laptop computers so old that they still run on the outmoded MS-DOS operating system.
And he has recruited his own team of senior executives from business and state government, teaming them with career I.R.S. executives whom he chose for their track record in getting things done.
His biggest problem, Mr. Rossotti said in a recent interview, is putting his vision of a customer service agency into focus for 98,000 I.R.S. employees, many of whom have become jaded at the spectacle of commissioners' coming and going without leaving a noticeable mark.
"There is so much change going on that it appears bewildering to our people, and they don't understand why we are doing what we are doing," he said.
So Mr. Rossotti did something almost unheard of in the top ranks of Government. Instead of assigning subordinates and consultants to churn up a new organizational table and write a report, he did the job himself.
On vacation with his wife in Naples, Fla., over the Christmas holiday, Mr. Rossotti wrote down his vision for the I.R.S. on his laptop computer -- an exercise that led to a 68-page booklet, "Modernizing America's Tax Agency."
It begins with a new mission statement that takes a revolutionary attitude toward taxpayers. The statement makes no mention either of the I.R.S.'s enforcement powers that have been the terror of generations of Americans or of the pressing need to raise revenue for the Federal Government. Rather, it emphasizes the importance of putting on a friendly face for the agency's "customers."
The old mission statement -- "to collect the proper amount of tax" -- was replaced by this: to "provide America's taxpayers top-quality service by helping them understand and meet their tax responsibilities and by applying the tax law with integrity and fairness to all."
Mr. Rossotti also crammed the statement with practical details on running the I.R.S., such as the need to install ergonomic work stations for employees. "I wanted to explain how all the different parts fit together and not just move boxes around on the organization table," he said.
In contrast to former commissioners, who often wrung more money from Congress with promises that a dollar spent on enforcement would generate several dollars in extra taxes, Mr. Rossotti wrote that "enforcement revenue is not a good measure of success in achieving the strategic goal of service to all taxpayers."
Audits, collections and criminal investigations currently consume 40 percent of the I.R.S. budget. And while Mr. Rossotti acknowledged that such enforcement actions were needed, he suggested that the carrot would be more effective than the stick in persuading people to pay what they owed. (Even before he came aboard, the I.R.S. was shifting its emphasis to voluntary compliance, reducing the audits of high-income returns to 1 in 60 last year from 1 in 9 a decade earlier.)
"Since 98 percent of the revenue comes in without enforcement action," he wrote, "a 1 percent increase in voluntary compliance would be roughly equivalent to a 50 percent increase in enforcement revenue."
Fred Goldberg, the Bush Administration tax commissioner who was one of a handful of I.R.S. critics sent a copy of the booklet with a hand- signed note by Mr. Rossotti, said he was impressed by its content.
"All of this ultimately is in the execution, but the vision hangs together as a coherent theory of management," Mr. Goldberg said. He said Mr. Rossotti was attacking a culture in place since the enactment of Federal legislation in 1952 that replaced politically appointed -- and often corrupt -- tax collectors with civil servants.
While reform ended most abuses, it also fostered a climate of secrecy and suspicion that is at the root of much of the I.R.S.'s recent malaise. Now, Mr. Goldberg said, Mr. Rossotti has laid out "a system designed to respond to taxpayers' expectations with an explicit discussion that the notion is not to squeeze the last dollar from the stone, that service to taxpayers is important."
Even longtime critics of the agency are impressed. "At this point, Rossotti is right on the mark," said Jeff Trinca, former chief of staff of the National Commission on Restructuring the I.R.S., a Congressional commission. "He is doing all the right things; he understands the management, technology and training issues better than anyone who has sat in that seat."
Given Mr. Rossotti's background, that is perhaps not surprising. He earned a master's degree in business administration from the Harvard Business School in 1964 and went on to become one of the Pentagon whiz kids under former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara, spending five years as Assistant Secretary of Defense for Systems Analysis. He left the Government in 1970 to co-found American Management Systems in Fairfax, Va., a computer consulting company that specializes in showing businesses how to integrate technology into their operations.
Mr. Rossotti has also banned dollar quotas as a measurement of tax collectors' performance. Many of his predecessors tried and failed to put that change into effect, but unlike them, he has created an alternative monitoring system that relies, in part, on taxpayers' assessments. Moreover, he plans to base senior I.R.S. executives' pay partly on such issues as their success in resolving taxpayer complaints.
Mr. Rossotti says his efforts to overhaul the I.R.S. could take up to nine years -- or could flop quickly. "I'm no fool," he said. "There's no guarantee that this will be successful. We could crash and burn in any number of ways, but I think it's worth it, and I think I can do it."
He took on the task almost by accident. Two years ago, he got an unsolicited call from an executive recruiter asking if he could recommend someone with strong organizational skills and an understanding of technology to head the agency.
At the time, Mr. Rossotti was chairman of American Management Systems. "I thought, now that would be an interesting job," Mr. Rossotti said, a smile lighting up his face. He said that his wife, Barbara Margulies Rossotti, a corporate lawyer, told him he was crazy.
Crazy or not, he sure is busy. He has become so absorbed in his new responsibilities, he says, that he rarely allows himself to indulge in two of his favorite pastimes, playing his baby grand piano or hitting the tennis courts. In his year and a half on the job, he says, he has found time to have lunch with his wife during the workweek exactly twice.
He has even become a little careless in his usually impeccable attire. The other day, he sported one of his custom-made British suits, which matched his gray hair perfectly, a rich yellow necktie and a natty pocket handkerchief. But his wing-tip shoes were dull and scratched.
"They're not polished?" Mr. Rossotti asked in surprise before gazing down at the offending footwear. Well, he added in his defense, "I just haven't had time."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Investors Take Profits, With the Dow Gaining by 16.65

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
In a session showing exceptional shifts in focus, investors cashed in profits in high-flying technology and consumer stocks and switched their money into neglected issues that would benefit from revived world economic growth.
When the churning ended, seven of the 30 components of the Dow Jones industrial average had surged more than 3 points, with Alcoa jumping 6 9/16, to 53 1/4, and six Dow stocks had fallen more than 3 points, with Wal-Mart down 5 15/16, to 98 5/8. 
 The blue-chip gauge eked out a 16.65-point advance, to 10,411.66, its third straight record but well off its day's high. It was ahead by 131 points at midday. The Nasdaq composite index, however, dropped 76.22 points, or 2.95 percent, to 2,507.28, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 21.38 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,328.44.
"There's definitely the beginning of a sector rotation going on that could become violent, given the relative valuations," said Rosanne M. Cahn, equity economist at Credit Suisse First Boston. "All the stuff that's cast a pall over the industrial cyclicals is starting to turn around."
Over the last few sessions investors have started to gravitate toward such economically sensitive industries as paper, chemicals, metals and machinery on the belief that foreign economic crises are abating and that world economic growth will pick up, aided by last week's European interest-rate cuts.
At the same time, a select handful of favorite big-name stocks have vaulted ever higher. "Investors are taking another look at price-to-book and price-to-earnings ratios," said Daniel B. Eagan, a portfolio manager at Black Rock in Philadelphia. "The high valuations are causing them to look for other opportunities."
Among the winners were Dow Chemical, up 8, to 109 1/2; Georgia Pacific 6 5/8, to 91 1/4; Caterpillar 5 15/16, to 60 11/16, and Nucor, a steel company, 3 1/2, to 55 13/16.
"We have a market that's moving away from the defensive names, with people attracted to cyclicals," said Gary Dickinson, portfolio manager at Columbia Partners in Washington, "Most of the problems of the global economy may be behind us."
Investors' interest in smaller stocks has also picked up in recent sessions. The Russell 2000 index pushed up yesterday morning, briefly moving into plus territory for the year before its substantial gain largely evaporated during the afternoon. The Standard & Poor's index of small-capitalization stocks posted a 1.15 percent gain yesterday, trimming its decline so far this year to 7.37 percent.
J. P. Morgan & Company, which reported a much bigger earnings increase than Wall Street expected, soared as high as 140 1/16 before succumbing to profit taking to close at 132 7/8, leaving it a gain of 3 9/16. Boeing rose 3 3/8, the biggest gain in five months, to 38, on optimism about its earnings report today. Time Warner beat earnings expectations but fell 3 1/2, to 73 1/2, although it traded after-hours as high as 78 5/8.
TRW, which warned of lower profits, fell 1 1/16, to 41 15/16, after hitting a 52-week low.
Brokerage houses joined technology and drugs among the weakest sectors. Charles Schwab tumbled 12 1/4, to 138 1/4; Merrill Lynch 5 5/16, to 92 1/16, and Knight/Trimark 17 7/16, to 100 1/16.
Intel slumped 3 1/2, to 57; America Online 8 7/16, to 150 7/8; Dell 2 5/16, to 38 1/8; Microsoft 4 1/4, to 85 7/8; Amazon.com 10 3/8, to 168, and Ebay 10, to 162 7/8.
Merck, Pfizer, Schering Plough and American Home Products each fell more than 4 points, while Eli Lilly and Warner-Lambert fell more than 3.
On the New York Stock Exchange, volume climbed to a hefty 952 million shares, with advancing issues outnumbering declining ones by 1,766 to 1,285. A total of 113 issues hit new 52-week highs while 63 made new lows.
The Wilshire 5000 index, which includes nearly all American stocks, fell 1.43 percent to pare its gain so far this year to 7.01 percent.

Treasury Issues Drop
By Dow Jones
Prices of Treasury securities drifted lower in thin trading yesterday as weakness in the dollar, stock gains and a big supply of higher-yielding corporate debt securities weighed on the market.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond was at 96 10/32, down 6/32 from Tuesday. That pushed the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, up to 5.50 percent, from 5.49 percent on Tuesday.
Treasury prices sank late in the session as the dollar dropped to its lowest level against the Japanese yen since April 1, ending at 118.68 yen in New York, down from 119.83 on Tuesday. A weak dollar makes American holdings less attractive to foreign investors. Also, the Dow Jones industrial average climbed more than 120 points in afternoon trading before erasing most of those gains heading into the close.
"It looks like the dollar is coming under some pressure and stocks continue to do well," said Scott Graham, co-head government trader at Prudential Securities in New York. Those factors, as well as the heavy corporate calendar and continuing signs of improvement in the global economy "just slowly weighed on the market through the course of the day," he said.
A large sale of 2,000 June bond futures contracts late in the day also helped send the market lower.
Among yesterday's corporate issues were Freddie Mac's $3 billion reopening of its five-year reference note and the Associates First Capital Corporation's $1.5 billion five-year note offering. Flows related to those deals were mixed as underwriters bought Treasuries to cover hedge sales while investors sold Treasuries to make room for the new supply.
The market is also awaiting several other large deals, including Conoco Inc.'s $3 billion, three-part offering of 5- , 10- and 30-year debt, which is expected to be priced today. Also, the Korea Development Bank is expected to price a $1 billion global bond offering in the coming days.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: IN RUSSIA;
Yeltsin Chooses Former Premier As Envoy to Balkan War Talks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 14

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin today chose his former Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, as his personal envoy in talks to settle the Yugoslav conflict. More than a few outsiders said the appointment was driven as much by domestic as foreign necessity.
In particular, they see Mr. Chernomyrdin, a bland but respected middle-of-the-road politician, as Mr. Yeltsin's counterweight to Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov, who has until now led Russian efforts to find a solution to the Yugoslav crisis. 
 Mr. Chernomyrdin, 61, affable and politically astute, has the background to bargain with the West. A Communist Party member for 30 years, many of them as a senior policy maker, he seamlessly moved to capitalism in 1989 as chairman of the world's largest gas company, Gazprom, first under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet leader, and later Mr. Yeltsin.
Mr. Yeltsin made him Prime Minister in 1992 and he kept the job until 1998, when Russia's growing economic problems led to his dismissal.
Mr. Chernomyrdin was never known as an ardent capitalist or reformer. But he was a reliably pro-Western and pragmatic Prime Minister, and developed a close relationship with Vice President Al Gore, with whom he shared the leadership of a commission formed to address joint United States-Soviet economic and military issues.
Mr. Yeltsin asked Mr. Chernomyrdin to return to the Prime Minister's job last September, after the country's economic crash. But Communists and nationalists in Parliament blocked the move. And despite Mr. Chernomyrdin's open ambition to run for President in the 2000 elections, many Russian analysts have written him off as a political force.
A spokesman said Mr. Chernomyrdin would soon be meeting with parties to the conflict "at the highest levels," but offered no further hints as to what tacks he would take.
Today Mr. Chernomyrdin suggested that his ties to Mr. Gore could prove useful in finding a way out of the Yugoslav conflict. "We must persuade the Americans, including the Democratic Party which is preparing for a Presidential election in 2000, that it is in their interest to end the strikes," he was quoted as saying by the Russian news service Itar-Tass.
Mr. Chernomyrdin clearly would be a more acceptable representative to Western officials than would be Mr. Primakov, who spent most of his career needling the West in Soviet and Russian foreign-policy jobs and as Mr. Yeltsin's head of Russian intelligence.
Mr. Yeltsin also has an interest, some political analysts say, in reclaiming some of the policy turf that Mr. Primakov began to occupy during the extended period last fall and winter when Mr. Yeltsin was ill.

HEADLINE: Clinton Proposes New Grants As Way to Encourage Savings

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
President Clinton today proposed giving low- and middle-income taxpayers up to $300 a year as seed money for a new type of retirement account intended to create powerful incentives for increased savings.
Laying out the details of an idea he first raised in sketchy form in his State of the Union Message, Mr. Clinton said the plan would offer something to couples with incomes of up to $100,000 and individuals with incomes up to $50,000. The benefits would be greatest for couples with incomes up to $40,000 and individuals with incomes up to $20,000. 
 In addition to $300 in the form of a tax credit, the Government would match deposits made by participants, up to a certain level, much like 401(k) programs that are popular with employers and employees.
The complex plan is structured as a tax cut, and is the White House's main entry in the debate over what kind of tax relief Washington should provide the country now that the Government is moving into an era of potentially huge budget surpluses.
Because it would introduce a new, investment-oriented way of helping workers prepare for retirement, the proposal could play a critical role in the faltering effort to find some bipartisan compromise on how to shore up the Social Security system.
But it is also an attempt by the Administration to address one of the nation's most pressing long-term economic problems, the decline in the personal savings rate, which late last year dipped to zero.
"I believe Americans who work hard their entire lives and raise their children should not have to have their retirement poised precariously on the edge of poverty," Mr. Clinton said at a news conference in the White House Rose Garden. "I believe that Americans, however, have to do more to save for their own future, but that Americans deserve the chance to do that."
The proposal's political prospects are uncertain. While tax incentives for savings are generally popular in both parties, Republicans are pressing for a much broader package of tax cuts.
White House officials said the plan would cost about $38 billion a year at first, and perhaps $50 billion a year in a decade. They said that while the sums involved are large, they are less than a third of what Republicans in Congress have proposed in their tax-cutting plans, and are therefore more prudent given the other demands on future surpluses and the possibility that the surplus might not be as big as expected.
But if the two parties agree to a compromise on taxes, the budget and Social Security later in the year, some form of Mr. Clinton's idea could well be included. Although the accounts proposed by Mr. Clinton would be set up independent of Social Security, they are similar in concept to Republican proposals for creating private investment accounts within the Social Security system.
"The President's proposal is a good starting point for further discussions on personal retirement accounts, and I look forward to working with him," said Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who heads the Senate Finance Committee.
The plan's benefits to individuals would vary widely based on their economic situation. The basic idea is to help low- and middle-income workers capitalize on the power of the stock market to create wealth and prepare themselves for retirement. The plan would offer them a choice of perhaps three investment options with varying levels of risk, including stocks and Government bonds.
A couple earning up to $40,000 a year would receive $600 in grants, $300 per taxpayer. The couple could then deposit up to $700 in their accounts -- $350 each -- with every dollar deposited matched by an additional dollar from the Government.
In that way, the couple would end the year with $2,000 in the account. Of that, $700 would be their own contribution, and $1,300 would be provided by the Government -- $600 would from the grant and $700 from the Government's matching funds.
A single taxpayer with up to $20,000 in income would receive the $300 grant, and could deposit $350 more into the account. The deposit would be matched dollar for dollar. In this way, the total deposit into the account each year could be as much as $1,000.
The Government benefits would be reduced for couples with incomes above $40,000 and for individuals with incomes above $20,000.
A couple with income of $60,000, for example, would be entitled to a grant of $300, $150 each, while couples earning $80,000 or more would not be entitled to any grant.
Similarly, the amount of the matching deposit would decline for higher income taxpayers. While couples with incomes of $40,000 or less would have their deposits matched on a dollar for dollar basis, couples earning $60,000 would receive 75 cents in matching funds for each dollar deposited. Couples with income of $80,000 to $100,000 would receive 50 cents in matching funds for each dollar deposited.
Most couples with incomes of $100,000 or more would be ineligible, except for those who do not have an employer-sponsored pension. They could receive matching funds of 50 cents on the dollar for all of their deposits up to the annual maximum of $1,000 per person, which for people at lower income levels includes the grant.
Investment gains in the account would accumulate tax free, and would only be taxed when withdrawn after retirement. Neither the grants nor any of the deposits or matching funds could be withdrawn for any purpose other than retirement.
In economic terms, the main question is whether the plan, which the White House named the Universal Savings Account, would lead people to save more, or whether it would simply reward people for doing what they already do.
On the one hand, the White House sought to provide as much financial incentive as possible to stimulate higher levels of individual savings. On the other hand, it could not make the incentives so appealing that the new accounts would lead people to divert savings from existing 401(k) accounts and other plans.

HEADLINE: Off Screen, a Union Divided;
It's Actor Against Actor as Guild Election Turns Bitter

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Riding around Manhattan on her bright blue bicycle, Kelly Craig resembles a lot of other young actresses in New York, with her klieg-light smile, her willowy figure and her cheerful willingness to live on a shoestring while working to make it big.
But recently, Ms. Craig has discovered some qualities she did not know she had: leadership ability, organization skills and plain old grit. Plus, she now has a good lawyer. 
 That is because Ms. Craig is the challenger in a bitter runoff election for a seat on the New York board of the Screen Actors Guild, which represents her and every other actor in the city who appears on film (including a lot of television shows and commercials). Ballots are now arriving in the mailboxes of 24,000 New York guild members, who have until May 3 to vote.
Film work is flourishing in the city these days, as is obvious to every resident whose even semi-scenic neighborhood was infested with movie crews last summer. It is probably the fastest-growing industry in New York in terms of jobs, according to state figures, and spent more than $2.5 billion in the city last year.
Thus, it may seem odd that the actors union is now undergoing a sort of civil war over what are fundamentally economic issues. The guild's incumbent leaders say that concessions the union has made to producers in recent years have helped lure the film industry back to New York City, which was shunned by Hollywood in the early 90's.
"By giving a little, we have gained a lot," said Jordan Derwin, the longtime board member who is running against Ms. Craig.
But Ms. Craig and her supporters argue that those concessions came at the expense of the members who struggle the most, and that the union is not doing enough to help them. They complain that the union is still fighting the last battle, rather than working on new challenges like improving payments for actors' work that appears on cable television and the Internet.
"There's a stubbornness to change, perhaps," Ms. Craig said. "I believe I do have fresh ideas and a different perspective."
There are plenty of ways to describe this election, including as a contest between youth and energy on the one hand, and age and experience on the other. Ms. Craig is in her 20's (like many actors, she's coy about her age) and a neophyte in union politics; Mr. Derwin is a lawyer turned actor who has been serving on the union's board for more than 16 years (and who also declines to say how old he is).
Neither has ever had a major role in a blockbuster, but then, few people who serve on the board are household names. Probably the most famous is Sam Waterston, who stars on NBC's "Law and Order," which is shot in New York.
Despite the uptick in film production, there is not enough steady work here, Mr. Waterston said. But he stays because "the possibility of working regularly in film and television while at the same time continuing in the theater is the closest thing to heaven."
But well-to-do actors like Mr. Waterston are a rarity, and not just on the guild's board. "I'm Jason, and I'll be your waiter tonight" is only the tip of the struggling actor iceberg. On any given day, according to Jayne Wallace, a union spokeswoman, 85 percent of the membership is not working.
About 900 of the 25,300 New York members in 1997 made more than $100,000 from guild-covered work in 1997, according to the union's data. Meanwhile, more than 6,000 made less than $1,000, and about 8,300 made nothing (though they are probably working in a non-film job).
Even excluding those who made no money, about 67 percent of the 17,000 working members did not make the $7,500 they need to qualify for health insurance under the union plan. Trying to help these people is one of Ms. Craig's priorities, she said; she would like the union to explore creating a "Health Fund Bank" to which members could make voluntary contributions that could keep their insurance going if they do not earn the annual minimum.
Does she qualify for health insurance? "I think I'll make it this year," she said, "I think I will, I hope I will. I had a pretty okay year." She will not disclose how much money she makes from all of her jobs -- she says she has not yet done her taxes -- but it is enough so that she no longer has any roommate but her cat, Ketzel.
She takes every acting-related job she can get, including stunt work, dancing and serving as a stand-in. She models clothes and appears in filmed commercials (New York Lotto) and print advertisements (her work for a vitamin company brought not just cash, but a free supply of ginko). She acts in and produces plays in a small theater on the Lower East Side.
Both Ms. Craig and Mr. Derwin describe themselves as principal actors -- meaning those who speak lines -- who sometimes do background work to keep body and soul together. Such extras in and around New York get paid $102 a day.
The issue of extras is highly emotional among union members, as became clear during the original election last fall, when eight independents ran for board seats. The winners were mostly incumbents, but one challenger, Avis Boone, won; Ms. Craig and Mr. Derwin tied.
During that campaign, fliers for the union-backed group branded the independents as extras, who are the lowest in the acting caste system (or "walking lampposts," as one actor puts it). In New York, a lot of actors occasionally work as extras, but there is still something of a stigma attached. In California, extras are seldom professional actors, but might be teachers or firefighters or just full-time extras.
But it is not just snobbery that causes friction between the guild's haves and have-nots, or, more accurately, have-littles and have-lesses. Midrange performers have seen their pay squeezed in the last few years, as producers try to cut costs while paying stars millions of dollars. They are outnumbered by the extras, and they worry.
"Guys like me, most years I break $50,000, but I haven't yet gotten above $100,00," said Michael Arkin, who has played a doorman on "Law and Order" and was a state trooper in the recent movie "Rounders." "We're the bread and butter of the union. The demands that some people in the background community are making, they might be good, but they cost money."
Mr. Derwin is head of the committee that advises the guild on extra performers, and he concedes that he has irked some colleagues by, for example, working on a contract to equalize the pay that extras get across the country (New Yorkers still get more than Californians, but the rates will be the same in a couple of years). He said producers had been avoiding New York because the extras earned more here.
Ms. Craig is careful not to criticize Mr. Derwin personally -- and is anxious not to be seen as a troublemaker. But some dissidents complain about his travel expenses, which topped $26,000 over two years, according to documents the union files with the Federal Government.
On sets, some are quick to point out that while they share apartments with roommates in Queens or Jersey City, he lives in a building with a doorman on the Upper East Side (Mr. Derwin says his wife is a schoolteacher whose income helps support his acting career).
Lisa Scarola, a dissident board member, blames Mr. Derwin for the loss of thousands of jobs because, she says, he has approved contracts that let producers hire fewer guild members or at reduced wages, and approved contract waivers for producers who pleaded hardship.
And she does not buy the argument that concessions are necessary to lure productions to the city. "The Statue of Liberty is in the script, 42d Street is in the script, the star lives in New York and her kids go to school in New York -- they're going to shoot in New York," she said.
Such talk infuriates Mr. Derwin's supporters, like Leslie Shreve, a board member who specializes in one of the guild's more lucrative sectors, voice-overs for commercials. She credits Mr. Derwin with maintaining protection for New York background actors after a union for California extras was crushed by producers in the late 1980's.
"That he is now being vilified is very shortsighted, very mean-spirited, and, I think, gross," Ms. Shreve said.
Mr. Derwin clearly has the support of the union's staff; he conducted a telephone interview from the guild office in Times Square, as Ms. Wallace, the union's publicist, listened in.
And Ms. Craig had to take the union to court, after it refused for three months to set a date for the runoff election -- and continued to let Mr. Derwin serve on the board. The union said at first that it wanted to wait until after members had voted on a proposed merger with another union, and then said it wanted to wait until the Federal Labor Department ruled on challenges to the election.
But in a ruling last month, Lewis A. Kapan, a Federal District Court judge in Manhattan, wrote that it was "more than probable" that the union "has not acted in good faith." He ordered the election be held no later than Monday, which is when the ballots were mailed.
Arthur Z. Schwartz, a prominent labor lawyer who represented Ms. Craig -- and whom she says she may have to pay by doing his office filing -- said that while Ms. Craig is younger than most of his clients, in some ways her case is typical. "I work a lot with insurgent groups," he said, "and nobody achieves any level of success unless there is economic unhappiness among the members."
Both Ms. Craig and Mr. Derwin say they will continue to be active in the union, even if they lose the election. And Ms. Craig said she will continue to try for her dream role in a movie. "A lawyer or district attorney part would be right up my alley," she said. "Strong women roles, not victims."

HEADLINE: As More Prisons Go Private, States Seek Tighter Controls

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio

 BODY:
The trouble started soon after the prison opened two years ago.
First there was violence. In the first 10 months, 20 inmates at the prison, the Northeast Ohio Correctional Center, were stabbed, two of them fatally. The prison, it turned out, was taking in maximum-security inmates when it was supposed to be medium-security. 
 Then, after management said it was solving the problems, six inmates, four of them murderers, escaped by cutting through two razor-wire fences in the middle of the afternoon. The inmates were eventually recaptured.
It was an alarming record for any prison, but just as troubling to state and city officials here was that they had no way of monitoring or controlling what was happening there: Northeast Ohio was a private prison, the first in the state.
As the private prison industry booms across the country, growing to 163 institutions now from one or two in 1984, the lessons of Youngstown have hit hard. Ohio, Texas, Tennessee and several other states have enacted or are considering legislation to control private prisons, some responding to lapses in these prisons in their own states.
At the Federal level, a bipartisan group of members of Congress from Ohio and New York introduced a bill in March to prohibit Federal inmates from being housed in private prisons. And a number of cities and states are taking less formal approaches in an effort to build tighter controls into contracts with private prison companies.
It is not, they say, that private prisons have more problems than public ones. The difference is that the the private prisons may not be subject to the same regulations and oversight.
In one way or another, the private prison industry now touches almost every state in the country. As tough sentencing laws have swelled prison populations, some 26 states have private companies operating or building prisons, which can often be built faster than public prisons. And states that do not have private prisons often send their inmates to states that do.
Corrections experts and state legislators are most concerned about the relatively small but growing number of prisons like the one in Youngstown, in which a company arranges to build a prison and promises to fill it with inmates, instead of contracting in advance with the state for a prison that state officials have decided they want.
In Youngstown, the Corrections Corporation of America, the nation's largest operator of private prisons, made a deal with the economically depressed former steel town: Youngstown gave the prison the land for a dollar and the corporation promised to create 450 jobs and find the inmates. It found them in the troubled Lorton prison in the District of Columbia.
But while the company had a contract with Washington, there was no contract giving Ohio or Youngstown officials any oversight of the prison.
Some small towns and cities "have nothing and so they're lured by this idea of this prison coming in and bringing this employment," said Marlene Beckman, special counsel to the Assistant Attorney General in the Justice Department who organized a conference on these issues in March.
In cases like Youngstown, sometimes called speculative or negotiated prisons, the company usually negotiates directly with a town or city, often one desperate for jobs and corporate taxpayers because its factories or mines have dried up. (In one Minnesota town the mayor even took a job with the private prison.) There is often no contract outlining the prison's responsibilities to that city or its state; the prison's only contract is with the supplier of the inmates.
And if there are not enough inmates in the state to fill up the prison, the company may bring in out-of-state inmates, who might misbehave because they are unhappy about being away from home. Some states exporting inmates, including Idaho and Montana, have been so dissatisfied after violence and escapes that they canceled contracts with private prisons in Louisiana and Texas.
When a prison operates without state oversight or takes in out-of-state inmates, rules can get muddy. And even if such prisons are not the majority, regulation proponents say they starkly reveal the need for laws that regulate all private prisons and answer certain questions: What are the rights and responsibilities of local law enforcement? Which definition of maximum security applies? Who is responsible in an escape? How much training should prison staff have?
"It's sort of like hazardous waste," Ms. Beckman said. "When you bring in something that is potentially dangerous, which inmates are, what, if any, obligations do states have to regulate them?"
In Youngstown, investigations faulted the District of Columbia for sending violent inmates to Ohio when it was not supposed to. But they also found that the prison's operator, the Corrections Corporation, did not follow its obligation under its agreement with Washington to obtain and scrutinize the files of prospective inmates and reject unsuitable ones. Typically, medium-security inmates have sentences of 10 years or less.
The Corrections Corporation was also criticized for filling up the 1,700-bed prison too fast, and for not separating inmates known to have been violent or threatening to each other.
"When I first walked into the prison there were over 250 inmates who had separation orders who were in the same facility," said Jimmy L. Turner, the warden who was brought in last March, after the stabbings. "Most prisons don't operate with known enemies in the same facility."
The problems leading to the escape included failures to monitor the recreation yard, Mr. Turner said.
Susan Hart, a spokeswoman for the Corrections Corporation, which operates 74 institutions in this country, said problems were partly due to the prison's desire to be "user friendly" and to accept the Washington inmates. "If we had to do it all over again, we would certainly do some things differently," Ms. Hart said.
City and state officials were determined to insure that changes would be made.
"The Youngstown example, almost in any aspect, says, 'Here's how not to do it,' " said Peter Davis, director of the Ohio Correctional Institution Inspection Committee, a watchdog group. "It was the quantity and the breadth of violent things that were occurring in such a short time frame that made it the horror that it was."
Youngstown officials sued the Corrections Corporation of America, forming an unusual alliance with another set of plaintiffs, inmates complaining about safety and prison conditions.
Significant improvements were made, hundreds of potentially dangerous inmates were transferred, and in a settlement, the company agreed to pay inmates $1.7 million, meet rigorous standards and pay for a Youngstown employee to monitor the prison.
State legislators, who passed modest legislation last year after the stabbings, are now proposing tougher bills that would forbid private prisons to accept out-of-state prisoners above the level of medium security.
In Ohio and other states, private prison companies have lobbied against some proposed regulations, especially ones that restrict the types of inmates they can house.
On the other side, unions of public corrections officers have pushed for strong limits on private prisons, which tend to hire nonunionized workers. These unions are strong in states like New York and New Jersey, which have one privatized immigration detention center apiece.
Proponents of private prisons say they cut costs by ordering supplies efficiently and paying workers less. Studies about whether they save money have yielded mixed results. Historically, private prisons have not taken in the most serious offenders. But they are expanding to take more complicated inmates -- those classified as maximum security, mentally ill, juvenile offenders.
Wayne Calabrese, president of the second-largest private prison company, Wackenhut Corrections, says his company usually operates through state contracts that do not involve out-of-state prisoners.
As for other regulations, Mr. Calabrese said, he would find some acceptable, but objects to those that would bar private prisons from taking certain kinds of inmates or that would try to legislate staffing ratios.
Ms. Hart declined to specify which regulations her company would oppose. But some industry analysts said restrictions on out-of-state inmates or speculative prisons would hurt Corrections Corporation more than some other companies.
In Tennessee, proposed laws would levy hefty taxes on private prisons and would bar them from bringing in out-of-state inmates. A bill backed by the state's Governor, Don Sundquist, would ban only out-of-state inmates convicted of crimes like murder and rape.
Two incidents in Tennessee have troubled supporters of the bills, both in prisons run by the Corrections Corporation, which is based in Nashville. In one episode, two inmates were transferred out of Youngstown to a prison in Mason, Tenn., where, the authorities said, one stabbed and killed the other. The other incident involved accusations that members of the staff at a prison in Whiteville used excessive force in subduing an attack on a guard by inmates from Wisconsin.
Texas passed a law requiring private prisons to meet the requirements of public ones after an escape of two sex offenders from Oregon from a Corrections Corporation institution in 1996. The institution was intended to house illegal immigrants and the corporation never told Texas officials that more than 200 Oregon sex offenders were held there.
Similar concerns have arisen in New Mexico, where last year, at a Wackenhut prison, two inmates were fatally stabbed and guards beat one inmate and kicked another handcuffed inmate in the groin. The New Mexico Legislature passed a modest private prison regulatory bill, but after a riot at the Wackenhut prison in March, some lawmakers called for tougher measures.
Spokesmen for the prison companies said that their staff members had either acted appropriately or had been disciplined.
At Youngstown recently, Mr. Turner, the warden, was eager to show the improvements, including the addition of gun towers, extra fencing and razor wire, and drug-sniffing dogs. State and local officials give Mr. Turner high marks for addressing the problems.
But the whole experience has been sobering, said Mayor George McKelvey.
"They surely gave us good reason not to trust them," Mr. McKelvey said. "We know we have to monitor everything they do."

HEADLINE: Elizabeth Dole Questions Clinton's Policies on Iraq and Serbia

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 14

 BODY:
Elizabeth Dole accused the Clinton Administration tonight of conducting a Balkan policy that "encourages adversaries to shift strategies, wait it out, or attempt to break our alliances." She called on President Clinton to "build up and deploy the forces necessary to win the war" in Kosovo, including sending ground troops if necessary.
In a speech to midshipmen at the United States Naval Academy that her campaign billed as a major foreign policy address, Mrs. Dole, a Republican Presidential contender and the only woman in the race, also sharply criticized Mr. Clinton's credibility and steadfastness of purpose in his approach to both Iraq and Serbian aggression. 
 "Credibility counts," she said. "And if you have any questions about that, look at the U.N. weapons inspections mess in Iraq or today's tragedy in Kosovo. When tough deadlines are set and then repeatedly postponed, when the other side appears to break its agreements with impunity, when we accept half promises, we send the wrong signal about our values and our will."
Mrs. Dole's speech placed her firmly in the internationalist wing of her divided party and allowed her to show that a woman can talk tough on military matters. Unlike the growing number of Republicans in Congress who disdain international organizations, she emphasized the importance of NATO as well as world financial institutions.
"Our leadership in international trade and monetary organizations is essential for upholding our core economic interests and promoting worldwide economic growth," she said. For Mrs. Dole, the speech served several particular purposes. She has lagged toward the back of the Republican field in fund-raising and could benefit from respectful notices in the foreign policy arena.
"There is a circle in politics," acknowledged one of her advisers. "Good poll numbers raise money. Good press gets you good poll numbers. Good press gets you money."
Some political commentators, particularly at this moment of crisis overseas, have questioned whether Mrs. Dole had the experience to master military matters.
Time and again tonight she sought to show that she does have international experience. She spoke of visiting the borders of Rwanda and Bosnia as the president of the American Red Cross and of meeting with Solidarity leaders in Poland as Labor Secretary. And she mentioned her role as a negotiator with China as Transportation Secretary.
To bolster that experience, she announced tonight, she will leave on Thursday for Macedonia and Albania to visit camps of Albanian refugees from Kosovo and meet with local leaders. Her husband, former Senator Bob Dole, met with Albanian leaders in Kosovo last month as an envoy for the Administration.
Without mentioning President Clinton by name, Mrs. Dole deplored American commitments "caged in hesitation" and said, "Long experience teaches that when we've committed military forces to a rightful goal, we should use all the power necessary to achieve it." She said she would endorse the use of ground forces if NATO commanders and the Joint Chiefs of Staff said they were necessary. Mrs. Dole also embraced the kinds of refugee relief operations that NATO troops are carrying out near Kosovo.
She recalled flying to Zaire (now Congo) to see camps for the those fleeing massacres in Rwanda.
"From the plane's window I saw a huge mass of people in the choking dust and heat," she said. "I also saw jeeps and trucks with our beautiful red-on-white cross -- and an enormous C-141 military aircraft, unloading critical supplies. To those who criticize the military's role in such rescue efforts, I'll just say there are simply times when nobody else can do the job."
Mrs. Dole noted that some people ask why the United Nations and regional bodies cannot take care of regional problems. "The answer is simple," she said. "Wherever America's national interests and our national values intersect, this nation must lead. That includes using military force when necessary."
But sometimes she sidestepped hard questions. She failed to say whether she thought the United States forces should have intervened to stop the Rwanda conflict.
On China, she endorsed engagement, but called simultaneously for Beijing to be pressed harder on human rights and in trade negotiations.
At the same time she said the United States should "stand by our friends in Taiwan." But when someone from the audience questioned her on how far the United States would go to defend Taiwan against China, she replied: "I think there are some things that I want to look at very, very carefully before I can give you a definitive answer. I am not yet an announced candidate, much less an elected nominee of the party."
When a midshipman asked if she would be willing to send her own "sons and daughters to bleed in Kosovo" she replied, "Yes," and repeated her stand on intervening in Kosovo. She did not mention that she has no children.

HEADLINE: Former Union Head Indicted In Scheme to Defraud Local

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The former president of a union local that represents New York City municipal janitors was indicted yesterday on charges of stealing more than $110,000 through various schemes, including submitting fake bills for sandwiches for Labor Day picnics, prosecutors announced.
The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said the official, Lola McBryde, used several schemes with other union leaders at District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the giant municipal union, to embezzle money from her local's treasury. 
 The indictment charged Ms. McBryde with stealing more than $50,000 by having Local 1597 pay large sums for food for Labor Day parades and picnics, while only a small number of sandwiches were provided.
Prosecutors said that Ms. McBryde then got back some of the inflated payments in a kickback scheme and shared them with two leaders from District Council 37 who previously pleaded guilty: Mark Shaplo, formerly one of the council's top officials, and Joseph DeCanio, the former president of a local representing highway repair workers.
Ms. McBryde, who retired last month from the local's presidency, pleaded not guilty at an arraignment in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. She has until Monday to post $10,000 bond.
Ms. McBryde is charged with second-degree grand larceny, punishable by up to 15 years in prison, and falsifying business records, punishable by up to four years.
Her lawyer, Richard Harvey, declined to comment on the indictment.
Mr. Morgenthau said Ms. McBryde also stole $16,000 by intentionally overpaying a travel agency for conferences and conventions attended by her local's members. When the travel agency refunded the overpayments, she kept the extra money for herself, the indictment charges.
On one occasion, the indictment said, she used that money to travel to Greece with another person.
The indictment also accused Ms. McBryde of obtaining $33,000 when her local paid inflated prices for Thanksgiving turkeys and hams for her local's members.
Michael Bixon, an assistant district attorney, said that in an elaborate web of schemes, presidents of several locals in District Council 37 usually kept half of the embezzled money while Mr. Shaplo and Mr. DeCanio each received 25 percent. Lawyers knowledgeable about the investigation said Mr. Shaplo and Mr. DeCanio are cooperating with prosecutors after having pleaded guilty to embezzlement and to engaging in vote fraud. Mr. Morgenthau said there would soon be more indictments.
Yesterday's charges were the latest development in a corruption scandal at District Council 37, which represents 120,000 municipal workers.
Three officials have already pleaded guilty, two others have been indicted, and the parent union has forced out at least a dozen others after finding evidence of financial improprieties.
Mr. Morgenthau announced yesterday that on Monday a travel agency in Westbury, N.Y., Tina Vacations, and the agency's general manager, Peter Mantikas, pleaded guilty to inflating the cost of several conferences and trips taken by members of two union locals.
The agency and Mr. Mantikas admitted to receiving payments for the true cost of the trips and then kicking back the inflated amount to Mr. Shaplo, Mr. DeCanio, Bessie Jamison, former president of a local representing clerical workers at the Board of Education, and Gloria Whittle, a former president of a local representing Housing Authority clerical workers. Ms. Jamison pleaded guilty to embezzlement last month, and Ms. Whittle died in 1997.
Mr. Mantikas said he paid the kickbacks to secure the union's business in the future. He was charged with falsifying business records and faces probation. He and the travel agency agreed to repay the union locals $15,000.
Yesterday's indictment portrayed union officials as trying to exploit every angle to pocket extra money. Ms. McBryde is charged with stealing nearly $4,300 by making the local pay for a cruise that she and a companion took to Alaska.
Mr. Morgenthau said, "McBryde falsely represented that the expenses were related to food and beverages purchased for the local."
In the sandwich scheme, prosecutors said, Ms. McBryde pretended that her local was paying tens of thousands of dollars for sandwiches for Labor Day parades and picnics. She had a bakery run by a nephew of Mr. DeCanio provide her with inflated invoices, while Mr. DeCanio provided her with a handful of sandwiches, the prosecutors charged.
The indictment said Ms. McBryde approved the fake invoices and had the local make checks payable to Mr. DeCanio, who then shared the proceeds with her and Mr. Shaplo.
Mr. Morgenthau said the presidents of other locals participated in similar sandwich schemes.
The indictment said Ms. McBryde embezzled $33,000 by receiving fake invoices for holiday turkeys and hams. The indictment said John Economos, the owner of the Coffee Mug, a restaurant near City Hall , provided the fake invoices. She used some of her local's money to purchase the turkeys and hams at normal price, and she shared the inflated invoice amount with Mr. Economos, the indictment charged.
Mr. Morgenthau said Mr. Economos was charged with third degree grand larceny, punishable by up to seven years in prison, and falsifying business records. Mr. Economos pleaded not guilty.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
The Teetering Balkans

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, April 14

 BODY:
NATO's bombing of Yugoslavia is destabilizing neighboring regions in which the United States and Europe have stationed tens of thousands of troops, spent billions of dollars and invested years of work in trying to secure peace, build democracy and improve moribund economies.
Since the bombing started on March 24, the 32,000 NATO-led troops who keep Bosnia's shaky peace have faced numerous attacks from Serbs and are on high alert in the worst tension since the end of war in 1995. The Government put in place by the West is frozen and inactive. In Montenegro, a President who has won backing from Washington and other foreign capitals is devoting all his energies to averting a coup backed by the army of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic. 
 Macedonia, already coping with hundreds of thousands of Kosovo refugees, is worried about tens of thousands more arriving, and Croatia's tourist-dependent economy faces a bleak summer of empty hotels and beaches.
For involved foreigners and locals, the real fear is that prolonged NATO bombing of the Serbs will reopen all the wounds still festering from the Balkan wars of this past decade.
"The security situation is stable, but the longer the bombing goes on the more difficult it will be to control the situation," said Lieut. Gen. Mike Wilcocks, a British officer who is the deputy commander of the Stabilization Force in Bosnia, the NATO-led peacekeepers known here by the acronym SFOR. "We are watching the situation like a hawk."
In Bosnia and Montenegro, the best face that diplomats or military officials have put on the Serbian fury stoked by three weeks of bombing is that they should be able to contain it until Mr. Milosevic is defeated. At that point, they suggest, prospects for democratic development in the region will soar.
"If getting rid of Milosevic fails, then everything else fails," said Carlos Westendorp, the top international official charged with keeping peace in Bosnia. "That is the condition we need for full development of the region, respect of borders and democracy."
He and other Western officials concur, however, that the longer the bombing campaign continues, the more difficult it will be for peacekeeping forces in Bosnia to hold back Serbian radicals and for the elected government in Montenegro to escape a coup that could spark a civil war.
The bombing has halted efforts to rebuild infrastructure or return Bosnians who fled the war to their old homes. Hundreds of Westerners have evacuated what is called Republika Srpska, as the Bosnian Serbs' 49 percent of Bosnia is known. Mr. Westendorp has ordered the elected Serb assembly not to hold any sessions until the Kosovo war is over.
"What I am doing is freezing the situation," Mr. Westendorp, the high representative enforcing the 1995 Dayton peace accords, said here today. "The hard-liners are constantly harassing the moderates. It would do a lot of harm to have the assembly meet."
Next door, fears of a coup in Montenegro, a Yugoslav republic where the American Government is making significant diplomatic and financial investments, have paralyzed the economy while backing elected leaders into a corner. They are struggling to stop the Yugoslav Army from taking over the news media, conscripting senior officials in the republic and fomenting street violence.
The bombing also scuttled a bid to improve relations between Montenegro and its neighbor, Croatia.
According to a Western diplomat, Montenegro had been planning before the bombing to apologize to Croatia for Montenegrin forces that in 1991 and 1992 shelled the historic coastal city of Dubrovnik, the jewel of Croatia's Adriatic coastline and once a major tourist draw.
While Croatia has supported the bombing of its old foe Serbia, the assaults appear to have shattered prospects for the country's tourist industry this year. Most summer hotel bookings up and down the Adriatic coast have been canceled, hotel owners said.
In the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia, too, there is widespread concern that the flood of refugees from Kosovo could destabilize a government that has been receptive to Western influence.
The West has the most control where it has the most military muscle. That is in Bosnia, where peacekeepers from 37 countries, including 6,200 American troops, are heavily armed and have more than three years' experience dealing with the terrain and managing the anger of local Serbs.
After the bombing began on March 24, General Wilcocks said he ordered a ban on the training and movement of local armies across Bosnia. SFOR troops have been ordered to wear body armor in the field at all times and not to travel in groups of less than three.
In the week after the bombings began, there was a sharp increase in Serbian attacks on SFOR troops, including several incidents when hand grenades were thrown at soldiers from moving cars. General Wilcocks said no troops have been injured in the attacks.
The general said in an interview that forces in Bosnia "have nothing to do with NATO." But the credibility of that distinction, if it ever held much weight among Bosnian Serbs, took a severe blow on April 3, when SFOR troops, acting on orders from Washington, blew up a stretch of railroad that connects Belgrade with Montenegro.
The tracks were destroyed in a stretch of the railroad that cuts across a tip of Bosnia. Western diplomats here said SFOR troops were ordered to take immediate action because of information that a trainload of armed Serbian paramilitary forces was headed to Montenegro to make trouble for the pro-Western government there.
The destruction of the tracks, during which SFOR troops killed a local watchman who fired at them, gave Serbian nationalists in Bosnia a reason to argue that their country was being occupied by the same forces that are bombing Serbia.
The NATO bombing, moreover, exacerbated an already severe political crisis in Republika Srpska.
Earlier in March, Mr. Westendorp in effect fired the elected President of the Serbian republic, Nikola Poplasen, a radical Serbian nationalist who had refused for months to work with the government's moderate prime minister.
On that same day, an arbitrator in Vienna denied the Serbs exclusive control of a city, Brcko, that connects two parts of their territory. Many Serbs regard the city as an essential link for the survival of their government inside Bosnia, a loosely federated country they share with the Muslim-Croat Federation that covers 51 percent of Bosnian territory.
The bombing, then, was perceived as part of a triple whammy by the West against Serbs and has sharply raised the risks of violence, said Bryan Hopkinson, director of the Sarajevo-based Bosnia project of the International Crisis Group, a think tank financed by European governments and Western foundations.
"At worst, the capacity might soon exist to mount an armed secessionist movement, at least for that part of Republika Srpska east of Brcko, perhaps using paramilitaries so that the political instigators would not be directly implicated," Mr. Hopkinson, a former British Ambassador to Bosnia, wrote in a report last week. "The public, in its present baffled and enraged state, would probably not be hostile."
Mr. Hopkinson said in an interview that any move by the Bosnian Serbs to secede would be easily handled by peacekeepers.
"They might lose a few men, but if SFOR is determined to resist an insurrection, they could," Mr. Hopkinson said.
In neighboring Montenegro, however, Western diplomats are not at all certain that the elected government could resist an army coup. The army has tanks and artillery, while the republic's police, although well trained and believed to be highly motivated, do not.
The President of Montenegro, Milo Djukanovic, has told American diplomats that he was confident that he could avoid bloodshed in Montenegro while challenging Mr. Milosevic's authority, but only if the West refrained from bombing.
Since the bombs started to fall, Mr. Djukanovic has said in interviews that his police would prevail in a fight against the army, but he and other officials have conceded that such a fight could ignite a civil war among his heavily armed population.

HEADLINE: NATO Must Be Clear About Kosovo's Future

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re Caspar W. Weinberger's "Losing Track of the Main Objective of War" (Op-Ed, April 12): I find it fascinating that Republicans from the Reagan and Bush Administrations feel comfortable chastizing the Clinton Administration for its policy in the Balkans. They are the same people who declared victory in the Persian Gulf without ousting Saddam Hussein, a failed policy that has left us with nearly 10 years of continued headaches in Iraq. 
 Try substituting Iraq for Kosovo and then read Mr. Weinberger's statement that "victory in this war must mean . . . the elimination of Mr. Milosevic." Clearly, the United States must learn more effective ways to wage economic and military war against renegade countries.
More important, we and others need to understand what "winning" a war really means in the new world order.
 
NICHOLAS H. HEINTZ
Jericho, Vt., April 12, 1999

HEADLINE: Political Briefing;
California's Governor Is Facing Quandary

BYLINE: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:
Gov. Gray Davis of California is in a political quandary.
A Democrat elected last fall with heavy Hispanic support, he must decide within the next few days whether to appeal a Federal court decision that declared Proposition 187 unconstitutional. That proposition, enacted in 1994 at the strong urging of Gov. Pete Wilson, Mr. Davis's Republican predecessor, shut off benefits to illegal immigrants. 
 In California, most illegal immigrants are Hispanic. They saw the measure as unusually harsh -- as did most other Hispanic residents in the state, not the least being those able to vote.
For years, many Hispanic-Americans voted Republican. But last fall, they voted heavily Democratic, contributing significantly to the defeat of Dan Lungren, Mr. Davis's Republican opponent. That vengeful switch has not been lost on Mr. Davis, who knows as well as anyone that Hispanic residents make up more than a third of California's population, with the percentage growing daily.
The other important figure that he must keep in mind is that Proposition 187 did not pass with just Republican backing. It also had heavy Democratic support.
Mr. Gray also must consider whether pressing an appeal might damage California's ties with Mexico. Trade with Mexico has become a major factor in the state's economic well being.
Finally, there is the question of whether Mr. Davis is duty-bound as Governor to appeal a Federal court ruling that struck down a state law. If legal experts conclude that he must, he just might find political refuge in that conclusion.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Foreign Desk
