HEADLINE: Film Sales Lift Kodak Profit, Sending Stock Up Sharply

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
The Eastman Kodak Company, buoyed by six months of steady growth in film sales, announced yesterday that its net profit in the first quarter, excluding one-time charges, rose 9.3 percent, to $259 million, or 80 cents a diluted share, from $237 million, or 73 cents. Sales rose 6.5 percent, to $3.1 billion from $2.91 billion. The company also said it would buy back $2 billion in stock over the next four years.
Investors reacted positively to the news, sending shares of Kodak soaring $6.4375, or 9.67 percent, to $73. 
 The delighted reaction was a bit startling, in that as recently as February analysts had been predicting that Kodak would earn 89 cents a share. In fact, the stubbornly high expectations worried Kodak so much that on March 29 it warned investors that its earnings for the quarter would not top 80 cents. It indicated that the earnings might even drop as low as 73 cents. But most analysts figured that was a low estimate, and the consensus settled at 76 cents.
Now analysts say it was not the earnings numbers, or even the promise of a stock buyback, that drove the share price up. Rather, they say, it was the indication that Kodak's sales were finally growing again.
"The key is that the revenues were stellar," Jonathan Rosenzweig, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, said.
That the stock has long traded at less than 15 times earnings helped as well, added B. Alexander Henderson, an analyst with Prudential Securities. "You put together a cheap stock with significant improvement in revenues, and you're going to get this kind of movement," he said.
Kodak's sales growth came from various places. Film sales in China, Brazil and a few other economically troubled markets were surprisingly strong, as were sales of low-end digital cameras in the United States.
But film sales in America provided the happiest surprise. The nation's entire consumer film market was up 10 percent this quarter from the first quarter of 1998, after rising 9 percent in the last quarter. Kodak did even better, with the number of rolls of film sold rising by 17 percent.
"Sales were a lot stronger than even we had expected," said Harry L. Kavetas, Kodak's chief financial officer.
Moreover, unit sales were up even though neither Kodak nor its archrival, Fuji Photo Film, slashed prices this year. "They're all finally realizing that it is marketing, not price, that makes the difference," Ulysses Yannas, an analyst with Mercer, Bokert, Buckman & Reid, said.
Of course, no one expects film sales to keep growing at a double-digit clip. "It seems unlikely that the very strong growth in consumer markets that's been observed in the fourth and first quarters will persist," Michael Ellmann, an analyst with Schroder & Company, warned.
Indeed, even Kodak's president, Daniel A. Carp, tempered his glee. "It's been quite a while since I've seen two back-to-back quarters of such strong industry growth," he said. "But industry numbers do bounce around a lot as the year goes on."
And pricing may yet put a damper on profits. Kodak promised its retailers aggressive price cuts on films and single-use cameras in May and June, the time when film sales normally start to heat up. "They sell the most film in the second and third quarters, which means they've yet to establish what the really important prices for the year will be," Jack L. Kelly, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company, said.
Moreover, Kodak's sales of consumer digital cameras keep growing, which may not be such a blessing. Kodak still loses money on every unit it sells. And if enough consumers embrace digital cameras, it could be bad news for films. "Digital sales aren't negatively impacting film sales yet, but that will be a front-and-center issue by Christmas 2000," Mr. Henderson of Prudential Securities, said.
There were more immediate tarnishes on the quarter's shine as well. Kodak brought its costs down by only $80 million, possibly jeopardizing its chances to deliver the $470 million in cuts it had promised for the year. Kodak executives, however, insisted the company was on target.
It has delayed its much-anticipated project to electronically deliver processed photos to America Online's 17 million customers. Its sales of motion picture film, long a steady growth area for the company, were sluggish at best.
The company's Eastman Software subsidiary, which lost $65 million last year, continued to lose money. And Kodak wrote off losing bets on some inkjet technologies and retail photo kiosks. Those three troubled areas resulted in a combined charge of $68 million against the latest quarter's earnings.
Still, for the first time since June, the good news in a Kodak quarter handily outweighed the bad. "I know that one quarter does not make a year," Mr. Carp said. "But we are very pleased with where we are right now."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 28; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1002 words

HEADLINE: Crime

BYLINE: By Marilyn Stasio 

 BODY:
Storytellers are always digging up the past, but few bring to that melancholy task the exquisite delicacy achieved by Peter Robinson in his new police procedural, IN A DRY SEASON (Avon Twilight, $24). When a drought dries up a reservoir in the Yorkshire dales and uncovers the ruined village of Hobb's End, Inspector Alan Banks of the North Yorkshire Police is given the punishing assignment of identifying the human skeleton that also emerges from the mud.
In a tricky feat of parallel narration, Robinson juxtaposes Banks's attempts to reconstruct the history of Hobb's End with the efforts of a former resident to keep its secrets buried. As Banks pieces together the bare outline of a young war bride who deserted her shellshocked husband after V-E Day, she springs to full life in the memoirs of Gwen Shackleton, her sister-in-law and closest friend. In journal entries that provide a moving portrait of rural England during wartime, Gwen re-creates the daily life of a village by writing about all the things that are missing from it: the fuel and the foodstuffs, the local boy killed at Dunkirk. Remembering a wedding with no confetti, no church bells and no icing on the cake, Gwen feels a great sadness that communicates itself over the years to Banks, who is a sensitive man, and to readers who appreciate a mystery that must be unfolded gently, like an old letter. 
 The wise children and prescient animals that always manage to find their way into Martha Grimes's Inspector Jury mysteries have a book of their own in BITING THE MOON (Holt, $25), which sends two brave girls on a hair-raising road trip from Santa Fe, N.M., to Salmon, Idaho, in pursuit of a child molester and animal abuser. Although this villain is described as "a charming cuss," he seems a pretty straightforward creep, as do the other unfeeling brutes who trap coyotes, stage savage dogfights and slaughter endangered animals in "canned hunts."
The girls are quite another matter. At 14, smart, shy Mary Dark Hope needs to come out of her shell, which she does on this coming-of-age odyssey with the big-eyed wonder of a true explorer. The young amnesiac who calls herself Andi Olivier and feels an affinity with the coyotes she frees from traps is more complicated. Too wise for her years, she's a sober realist with a romantic imagination that makes reality bearable. In Mary's shrewd assessment, "it was as if part of her were weaving a fabric that the other part kept unraveling." Although their "vision quest" bogs down in bumpy scenes and skimpy characters, it crests in a white-water raft trip down the Salmon River (they don't call it "the River of No Return" for nothing) that tests the girls' mettle and inspires some grand nature writing from Grimes.
Maureen O'Donnell, the protagonist of Denise Mina's shattering first novel, GARNETHILL (Carroll & Graf, $24), lives at the top of the highest hill in Glasgow. From this vantage she broods on her homeland, a nation lashed by "drizzling rain and a 50-year recession," its social fabric strained by "endemic domestic violence and armies of drunk men shouting about football."
If Maureen sounds glum, consider her situation: haunted by recurring flashbacks of her father's sexual abuse and still shaky from a breakdown that landed her in a psychiatric hospital, she has just got word that her boyfriend is married. Being a gritty sort of girl, she gets blasted with a friend and wakes up the next morning to find her rotten boyfriend tied to a kitchen chair, his throat cut from ear to ear. With her mental history, Maureen is a natural suspect. But even though her own mother thinks she's guilty, she manages to expose an old, ugly pattern of abuse that has been the ruination of women who lack her resilience -- and her cleansing anger.
The writing isn't pretty, but you can't look away from it. When Maureen visits her former psychiatrist and watches another patient flaunt the scars on her wrists, she makes the wry observation that "visible scars are a good way to stop casual approaches from the happy and content."
Lev Raphael sets his campus mysteries at a factory-like state university in fictitious Michiganapolis, Mich., and populates them with the kind of stupid students and pretentious faculty members who blacken the eye of academia. Happily, he also gives his narrator, a lowly English professor named Nick Hoffman, license to mow down these intellectual pretenders with his scathing wit. In THE DEATH OF A CONSTANT LOVER (Walker, $23.95), Nick risks life, limb and tenure to investigate the disappearance of one student and the violent death of another, while regaling us with nasty digs at "cruel-eyed" administrators, "subliterate and maladjusted" students and department colleagues who treat one another with "all the charm and dignity of snarling terrorists." Although Nick can be a sweetheart when he's with his live-in lover, Stefan, and a smart guy in the company of genuine scholars, the idiocies of academe always bring out the caustic humor that is the best part of him.
Just when you despair of ever finding one of those devious puzzle mysteries that no one seems to write anymore, along comes Robert Barnard with a crafty whodunit like THE CORPSE AT THE HAWORTH TANDOORI (Scribner, $22). Although not much is made of the fact that the story is seated in Bront country, Barnard works some clever variations on the governess-in-peril theme of Romantic literature with a confounding plot that hinges on the fate of an amiable Irish lad who wanders into an enclave of artists and becomes the manservant of a once famous painter, now grown old and living in seclusion on his estate. The whole setup is sinister, but the Gothic atmosphere really thickens when Charlie Peace and Mike Oddie, the likable Yorkshire coppers in this series, confront the "ruthless, egotistical, amoral" genius who lives in the big house surrounded by his adoring disciples -- only to find themselves in the dark heart of a colony of lost souls.

HEADLINE: A Century Of Art: Just How American Was It?

BYLINE: BY MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
ARTWISE, was this really the American century? We take the cliche for granted because, well, because we are so arrogant. Never mind that it's just a catch phrase cooked up in 1941 by Henry Luce, the most thoroughly unreconstructed of American chauvinists, partly out of missionary zeal and partly to sell his magazine.
We accept it because, let's admit it, we're proud to have taken over the planet. We only feign embarrassment that people living in remotest Borneo drink Coke and like Mike. Better us, we think, than, say, the French, heaven forbid, because then we would all have to speak their language and eat their food and have shorter work weeks and maybe even live in Paris for a while, and wouldn't that be awful? 
 The American Century is the title of what looks to be an immense two-part survey at the Whitney Museum of American Art, the first part of which, covering the years 1900 to 1950, will open Friday. It's one of several century-ending extravaganzas (the Modern is planning another). And no doubt they all, to some degree, will confront the cliche of American predominance in visual art, deciding what it means and whether it really makes sense.
Why doubt it? For starters, of course, because during half the century not even most Americans cared about American art. Artists like Hartley, O'Keeffe, Weston, Dove, Demuth, Davis, Lawrence, Benton and Marin made little impact here or elsewhere. Their profiles have gone up considerably in the United States as we've had more chances to see their work, but they're undervalued and still hardly ever exhibited elsewhere. People abroad mostly regard them as provincials, the way we regard artists like Ben Nicholson and Stanley Spencer as provincial British painters. It may be unfair but it's the case. John Marin was perhaps the most admired American artist in the United States at midcentury. I'd wager that Marin today is no more familiar even to an art-savvy European than Francis Gruber and Cornelis Corneille are to us.
So when we boast about the American century in art, we really mean the American half-century. Then we must figure out what, if anything, is specifically American about American art during the last 50 years, because otherwise we easily make the mistake of confusing the quality of American art with the impact of the American dollar: to acknowledge that we have dominated the marketplace and the media since World War II is not to say that the visual art that we have produced has been truly distinctive and, more than anyone else's art, has shaped worldwide taste. There's no question about the influence everywhere of jazz and rock and Hollywood films. But we're talking here about painting and sculpture.
And from the beginning, as Robert Hughes has written, American art has oscillated between dependence and invention. Another way of putting it is that American art, for much of this century, couldn't decide how American it ought to be. On the one hand were the regionalists (John Sloan, George Luks, George Bellows, Grant Wood, John Steuart Curry and so on). And on the other hand were the modernists, who, whether they were pure abstractionists or Surrealists, pursued a European model of what you might call pan-nationalism or universalism (Burgoyne Diller, Ilya Bolotowsky, Peter Blume, O. Louis Guglielmi). We devalued them both: American art seemed to us either too derivative of Europe or too local, a contradiction that we never quite resolved.
Then Abstract Expressionism came along, and it was soon touted as the first distinctly American brand of modernism. America, it was said, had finally invented an abstract art that owed nothing to Europe. The American century had begun.
Or at least, that's the standard account. Politically minded art historians during recent decades have added to it the notion, which has become fashionable, that artists like Pollock and de Kooning were then aggressively exported to further an American agenda during the cold war. Abstract Expressionism, according to these historians, became a form of propaganda. The idea was that the Abstract Expressionists enjoyed a freedom of expression that was not possible in the Soviet Union. So the United States Government and the Museum of Modern Art conspired to promote them abroad, in exhibitions like the Venice Biennale and the Sao Paulo Bienal, and pretty soon American art had insinuated itself around the globe along with other American products.
Is it true? Looking back, the Abstract Expressionists don't seem quite so all-American. We can see, for example, how much de Kooning, the Dutchman who sneaked into the United States as a stowaway in 1926 and changed the course of art here, continued to owe to previous Dutch painters like Hals. And there's not much strong evidence that the Abstract Expressionists were ever embraced by the Government during the early 50's; nor were they extensively pushed elsewhere until they had already begun to be supplanted here by a new generation that included Johns, Rauschenberg, Lichtenstein and Warhol. The first Pollock retrospective to tour Europe was in 1958. By then he was already dead. No one abroad seemed terribly impressed, anyway. Shows in Europe of new American art were panned throughout the 50's.
The first Americans to achieve global fame were probably the Pop artists during the 1960's, whose success was obviously linked to the ascendance of American pop culture generally. But it's useful to recall that British artists like Richard Hamilton, Malcolm Morley and Eduardo Paolozzi, and Germans like Sigmar Polke and Gerhard Richter, at the same time and for different reasons, were also using pop images in their work.
So you could say that cutting-edge American art during the early 60's did not so much dominate or shape world taste as dovetail with it, or with a part of it. Meanwhile, America, having developed an inflated ego, no longer seemed to feel it had to pay the same close attention to what was going on elsewhere, and it wasn't until the 1980's, when a booming art market buoyed interest in almost everything, that many myopic Americans finally noticed what Polke and Richter (and also Beuys and Kiefer and various others) had been up to.
Looking back on the generation that emerged during the late 50's and early 60's, it's a guess that internationally speaking, Polke and Richter will be remembered with Rauschenberg, Warhol and Johns among the major figures, and that American art will seem neither as distinct nor as dominant as we tend to think it was.
Prognosticating, of course, is a risky enterprise, but while we're at it, let me also suggest that the most singular agglomeration of Americans in the century may turn out to be the ones who came next: the Conceptualists, Minimalists and Post-Minimalists, among them Donald Judd, Bruce Nauman, Eva Hesse, Richard Tuttle, Ana Mendieta, Robert Irwin, Richard Serra and the artists of diverse stripes who went to work on a vast scale in the American West: Walter De Maria, Robert Smithson, James Turrell and Michael Heizer.
I might add the exceptional case of Philip Guston, an Abstract Expressionist in the 50's, who in the 70's, ignoring almost everyone's advice, remade himself, until he died in 1980 producing what the artist Elizabeth Murray has called sad, nutty songs: wild, angry, cartoonish pictures that caused many people to say he'd lost his mind. Today, when there's so much new art that involves cartooning and surrealism, his weird late works seem astonishingly prescient and moving. Guston has turned out to be one of the most influential American painters at the end of the century.
I don't mean by all this to say that the artists to emerge in the late 60's and 70's are necessarily the best ones we've ever produced. I mean they belong to the first American generation in this century that depends principally on what, by now, had become a modern American tradition: they built on works by Pollock, Rauschenberg, Johns, David Smith, Ad Reinhardt and others who were not even strictly visual artists, like John Cage.
What they produced, moreover, bespoke a specifically American context. Artists like Smithson were working in the American landscape, and Minimalists and Post-Minimalists like Judd and Serra were exploiting a vocabulary of industrial forms that grew out of the American cityscape. Their art actually resembled the streets of SoHo, then still an industrial neighborhood only beginning to be taken over by artists. Earlier Americans like Demuth and Sheeler had painted pictures of industrial buildings in a streamlined style. But the sculptures by artists of the late 60's and early 70's consisted of steel and tar, their stripped-down esthetic evoking not only an urban present but also a Puritan past.
Now we're at the end of the century, and the American paradigm, it seems, has gradually shifted. No doubt all the big century-ending exhibitions will have to confront this fact. Throughout our history, the notion has prevailed that there could be a distinctly American art, as if a particular form or style might encapsulate the nation's identity. Assimilation was an underlying assumption.
But there really has been no national art. It's curious but true that we do not, as a nation, identify with specific American paintings, or at least not with any paintings of serious quality, as Mexicans identify with the works of Rivera and Italians identify with the works of Raphael or Titian. I put it this way to exclude the work of an illustrator like Norman Rockwell.
Can you name any American picture, which, if it were to be sold and end up in another country, would provoke anything like the national heritage debate that surrounds the Greeks and the Elgin marbles? Certainly not a Pollock or a Warhol. And if you cite "Washington Crossing the Delaware" then consider the fact that not more than a handful of Americans have even heard of the man who painted it (Emanuel Leutze).
We're so enamored of the free market that we don't think of American art in terms of national treasure. But more to the point, we're so diverse culturally: the goal of a synthetic American art remains illusory because the idea of an American identity is, in the end, an illusion. If we cling to the melting pot idea, we have also become increasingly alert to its inadequacies.
This is why the paradigm has begun to change. The 90's are a pluralist decade in art, the legacy of multiculturalism, economics and technological change. The breakdown of old borders, thanks to the end of the cold war and the burgeoning of the Internet, has hastened American awareness of culture globally, and vice versa: we see more new art from around the world, and people elsewhere see more easily the art we make.
If, consequently, art around the world today isn't actually more varied than it used to be, we have become more respectful of a wider range of it. We're regularly given chances to view contemporary work from Japan, Korea, India, Africa and Central America, not to mention Europe, and emigre artists here trumpet their roots.
Diversity is now regarded as an asset. That is a prevailing theme in American art at this moment. And America, particularly New York City, as the world's economic epicenter, remains the crossroads for new art, so by extension, diversity is a message being spread around the world. We may be leaving the American century without having produced an American art that speaks for us collectively as a nation, but as a nation we have developed into the nexus for world art.
And who knows? In the future, the American century, if it's still called that, may be defined, paradoxically, not by the art we began to invent at midcentury but by the global culture we helped to disseminate at century's end.

HEADLINE: DANCE;
A Performer of Many Faces, All Brazilian

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO; Diana Jean Schemo, a correspondent for The Times, has just completed an assignment as Brazil bureau chief.

 BODY:
ANTONIO NOBREGA, a Brazilian performer who will be making his United States debut at the Kennedy Center's American Dance Festival April 27 through 29, trots out a variety of characters in "Figural," the one-man show he will use to greet North American audiences. The figures he conjures, through mime, dance, music and acrobatics, are not simply creatures of the artist's fancy but a string of types meant as a showcase for Brazil's culturally rich northeast.
That is because Mr. Nobrega, more than most performers these days, feels himself on a mission greater than exploring his own emotions. In his case, he has set out to do no less than preserve Brazilian culture, both inside and out of the country. 
 To Brazilians, Mr. Nobrega is perhaps the most popular performer of music and dance from the northeast, which serves as an artistic wellspring for the rest of the country. In recent years, Brazil's northeast has undergone a cultural resurgence, with the release of films, books, music and dance from the area. The region's music, from the spirited forro to the fusion of choro to the African drums of groups like Olodum, is now a staple of the Rio de Janeiro club scene, and Mr. Nobrega himself typically sells out the Canecao, one of the top concert halls for popular music in Rio.
In a recent telephone interview from his home in Sao Paulo, Mr. Nobrega said he considered Brazil's northeast "the most representative area of Brazil, if you talk about anything cultural at all." Salvador of Bahia was the first capital of Brazil, in the early 1500's. And from Recife, in the neighboring state of Pernambuco, came the country's first export, the sugar cane produced by African slaves. It was here that the cultures that form Brazil -- Indian, African and European -- first mingled and made music.
One of Mr. Nobrega's recent shows in Rio, "Wood That the Termites Don't Chew," recreated the traditions of traveling minstrels of the arid northeast, performers who visit towns and play for the spare change tossed from windows. Mr. Nobrega credits some lyrics and music to texts and traditions more than a century old. True to the minstrel shows of the northeast, Mr. Nobrega's wife and children took part in the show, swirling around the shacks and clotheslines on stage for the exuberant umbrella dances of frevo.
In Washington, audiences will see Mr. Nobrega alone, performing one of the first pieces he choreographed and wrote for his repertory. In "Figural," he dons the brilliant costumes and masks by Romero Andrade Lima, among Brazil's most talented costume designers, to portray a scoundrel, a saint, a beggar woman in rags and Casanova, who dances with a doll. He portrays a clown, Tonheta, to tie the images together in the second part of the show, using humor and music to comment on life's sad parade. Tonheta, who plays several instruments at once, is the only character not to wear a mask.
"What most distinguishes the work of Antonio Nobrega," wrote Barbara Heliodora, dance critic for the Rio daily O Globo, "is his total delivery of himself as an instrument of creation."
Throughout the character changes of "Figural," "there is not one gesture, not one look, that calls attention to Nobrega's person or personality," wrote Ms. Heliodora, who has called the performer's talent and technique "exceptional."
Mr. Nobrega, 46, came to dance only as an adult. He originally trained in classical music, encouraged by his father, a doctor in a sanitarium. In the late 1960's, he played violin with two orchestras, the Chamber of Paraiba and the Recife Symphony. He then joined the Armorial Quintet, a group of classically trained musicians who sought to promote Brazil's native, as against strictly European culture. It was with the Armorial that Mr. Nobrega picked up the rabeca, a four-string instrument of country music similar to the violin. The move would redirect the artist in him utterly.
In the following years, Mr. Nobrega gave himself over to researching Pernambuco, his native state. Economically, the northeast is the poorest piece of Brazil. If Brazil is sometimes nicknamed Belindia -- part first world like Belgium and part third world like India -- Pernambuco belongs firmly in that second end of the definition. But culturally, the northeast is Brazil's richest area, Mr. Nobrega realized. Most of the art with a distinctly Brazilian flavor, from the books of Jorge Amado to capoeira, a form of martial arts borne of slavery and balletic in its symmetry, came from the northeast.
"The roots of Brazil are there," said Roberto da Matta, a Brazilian anthropologist at the University of Notre Dame in Indiana. He noted that the music of the Bahian composer and singer Dorival Caymmi opened the way for bossa nova, while Olodum has played with Paul Simon. "Music in Brazil is an essential element: it's considered the equivalent of money here," Mr. da Matta said. "You have three forro disks, some local food -- which is really national food -- and it's like having a bank account."
Mr. Nobrega studied Brazilian modern dance with Klauss Vianna, and learned pantomime, mimicry and acrobatics at the Dmitri School of Theater in Switzerland. Later, he went to the Advanced School of Circus Art at Chalons-sur-Marne in France.
He calls "Figural" a "synthesis" of archetypes from the northeast, "little choreographic designs that spring form the Brazilian imagination, adding, "The figures represent a Brazilian mythology."
THOUGH Brazil's population, at 163 million, and its Portuguese language provide an instant market for everything home-grown, from computers to line dances, as an artist Mr. Nobrega decries the dominance of United States pop culture.
"I think the health of the world, culturally speaking, lies in what is a part of your soul," he said. "If you cut out that soul, you leave a sad people." On the Rio radio dial, a listener is as likely to pick up American as Brazilian music. If it is Brazilian, it often sounds like American music that just happens to be sung in Portuguese.
"The concept of globalization will be true only on the day that it creates genuine contact," he said. "I'm speaking about my country, which is completely colonized by your country, and by the worst elements. The music of yours that makes it here is not the best of your music, it's the junk. The same with the television and movies. It's a kind of cultural imperialism."
On a more selective level, Charles and Stephanie Reinhart see Brazil exerting an important influence on American culture. The couple, artistic advisers for dance at the Kennedy Center, invited Mr. Nobrega as the only foreign performer in a series about American dance.
"If you look at the history of dance in the United States, a major part of the fusion that's happened has come from Latin America," said Mr. Reinhart. "In the early years of modern dance, you have Catherine Dunham drawing on Caribbean and Brazilian movements. It's part of our heritage in that it's part of what's formed us."
Mr. Reinhart said he had seen Mr. Nobrega rehearse "Figural" at his Sao Paulo studio several years ago and thought his work a good panorama of Brazilian movement. "I think that what he's done, he's done in a new way, even though it's old," he said. "It's like Picasso and the African sculptures: what's modern and what's not modern? It was innovative and yet based on his interpretation of tradition."

COMPANY: JOHN F KENNEDY CENTER FOR THE PERFORMING ARTS (84%); 

ORGANIZATION: JOHN F KENNEDY CENTER FOR THE PERFORMING ARTS (84%);

PUB-DATE: April 18, 1999

SECTION: Section 2; Page 13; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2008 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
Seeing the 60's Through a 90's Corrective Lens

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
A WHIFF of incense mixed with marijuana smoke drifts through two recent movies, "Hideous Kinky" and "A Walk on the Moon," both of which conjure an era that Hollywood, in its devotion to snugly happy endings, has largely avoided. In the countercultural dream that has so intimidated Hollywood, a hippie Pied Piper with stringy shoulder-length hair, a fringed jacket and reeking of patchouli oil is banging a tambourine on his knee with one hand and flashing a peace sign with the other. Beside him are a trio of spaced-out go-go girls shimmying and gazing groggily into the purple haze.
Although that signature scent, blown across three decades of shifting winds, isn't overpowering in these films, it is just pungent enough to suggest that what we think of as "the 60's" -- the years (1964-72) bracketed musically by Beatlemania and "American Pie" -- were not a hallucination but a messy, uncomfortable reality. In their hesitantly nostalgic ways, both films remind us that in the days of turning on, tuning in and dropping out, people actually followed Timothy Leary's notorious prescription for personal enlightenment. 
 But in remaining true to Hollywood's tidy, late-90's formulas, they also suggest that dropping back in was just as easy and that all that dope smoking, acid tripping, searching, protesting and free love was an adolescent prank, a temporary lapse of judgment.
The notion that this heady ethos was really just an episode in a cultural mini-series whose happy ending finds the Dow Jones industrials hovering around 10,000 and garish $1 million houses sprouting all over the American landscape is a quintessential revisionist view of what the 60's were about. These films insinuate that thousands of ex-hippies, now in their late 40's and 50's and presiding in executive suites, emulated Bill Clinton's experiment with marijuana and never inhaled. And if they did inhale, God forbid their children should follow suit.
Both films focus on young, attractive women who break the rules to pursue sexual and spiritual transcendence, then return to the middle-class lives they renounced. In the smart, beautifully acted "Hideous Kinky," set in Morocco in 1972, Kate Winslet is Julia, a young Englishwoman drifting around North Africa with two young daughters in tow and no money. In Marrakech she meets a Moroccan street acrobat (Said Taghmaoui) who is also penniless. The two make love, smoke hashish and drag the girls along on a risky trek into the Moroccan countryside. Now and then, Julia, who aspires to learn Sufi dancing, makes noises about wanting to experience pure joy by obliterating her ego.
In reimagining an era of hippies, dropouts and seekers after a higher consciousness, "Hideous Kinky" is accurate as far as it goes. But that isn't very far. The movie conveys only the flavor of the time. Julia's quest is portrayed as muddled and vague, and the movie nudges us again and again to recognize what a terrible, irresponsible parent she is. When one daughter insists she wants to return to England and have a proper education, her mother is dumbfounded. True, Julia radiates a certain defiant charm. But in the film's overall judgment, she is also a silly spaced-out fool who must come to her senses. And in the end she does.
"A Walk on the Moon" follows its protagonist Pearl Kantrowitz (Diane Lane) to a working-class Jewish resort in the Catskills in the summer of 1969. Pearl, who married her husband, Marty (Liev Schreiber), when she became pregnant at 17, is now the mother of a 14-year-old daughter, Alison (Anna Paquin), who is just entering adolescence. On weekdays, while Marty is back in New York City repairing televisions, Pearl plunges into an affair with Walker (Viggo Mortensen), a smolderingly handsome peddler of blouses that he sells to the summer colony out of his van.
Pearl momentarily loses her head and slips off with Walker to the nearby Woodstock festival, where her daughter accidentally witnesses Pearl, body-painted and ecstatic, being whirled in her lover's arms. Alison is understandably upset. When Pearl finally must choose between Marty and Walker, the small, finely acted film caves in to 90's movie values. In the final scene, Pearl and her husband begin a tentative slow dance to music on the radio: a soupy version of Dean Martin's "When You're Smiling." Marty, realizing that his wife has almost left him behind in the 50's, switches to a station playing Jimi Hendrix's "Purple Haze." Signaling that he'll try to get with the times, he relaxes and swings out.
"A Walk on the Moon" is a decent little film, but in reducing a wrenching life decision to a matter of switching radio stations, it blithely denies the enormous power of the forces that have tugged Pearl into an affair. An earlier scene in the film juxtaposes images of Pearl and Walker making love at the exact moment Neil Armstrong first sets foot on the moon. The implication is clear. For Pearl, this is not just a dalliance but an earthshaking, life-changing sexual awakening. Had "A Walk on the Moon" been made in the 70's, there is little doubt that the character would have forsaken her family to go on the road with her sexual savior. Today, that's just not permitted.
IN what they show and don't show of the 60's, both films raise disturbing questions: When did it become embarrassing for the mass media to portray the counterculture as a movement driven by passionate idealism and a reckless insistence on crashing through barriers? Could it be that the movies are too scared of the era and the freedoms it represented to confront it head-on?
Every now and then, Hollywood has tried. "Easy Rider," which came out of left field in 1969 and was made for a dime, proved to be a one-of-a-kind, a fluke. While other films of the period, like "Midnight Cowboy" and "Five Easy Pieces," and later, "Shampoo" and "Coming Home," expressed a combative, rebellious spirit, they didn't dive in to the thick of things. Hollywood was very late in addressing the Vietnam War. It had to be safely behind us before we could begin to watch movies about it. Among Hollywood's leading filmmakers, only Oliver Stone, in films like "Born on the Fourth of July," "Platoon" and "The Doors," has taken the passions of the 60's seriously enough to portray the full impact of the generational and political fissures that ripped open the American psyche.
Outside of Mr. Stone's films, vintage rock music and rock documentaries, from "Monterey Pop" to "Gimme Shelter," seem to do a much better job than most feature films of capturing the era.
One could list a hundred reasons why Hollywood has never given the 60's their due. High on that list would be the problem of 60's fashions. Even at the time, the hordes who donned the more extravagant hippie regalia often looked ridiculous. How could anyone take such weirdly dressed characters seriously? Another problem is the stoned-out argot adopted by millions of young people in the late 60's and early 70's (with its "right ons";"like, mans" and "heavies"). Today it sounds quaint and surprisingly conformist.
Post baby-boomers may find it hard to envision block after city block of shaggy-haired youth clad in exotic robes and finery milling in the streets. But such scenes were commonplace in San Francisco, in college communities and in the East Village of New York City in the late 60's. On Sunday afternoons, the area around the Bethesda Fountain in Central Park became a stoned soul picnic in which hundreds of artists, pot-smoking hippies, drug dealers and musicians congregated for fragrant, dreamy communal love-ins.
As one who embarked on the same pharmaceutical, sexual and political consciousness-raising adventures that millions of others did, I can remember a day when I was so convinced that the world had changed forever that I tossed all my neckties into the trash. In the antimaterialistic spirit of the times, I gave away treasured possessions, which amounted to almost nothing in those days: a collection of cherished 45 rpm records donated to a friend's jukebox. Determined to "rip off" the system, one day I bravely pilfered a can of tuna fish from a supermarket shelf.
Visiting some friends in Key West, Fla., in the spring of 1969, I descended on a town crawling with drugged-out hippies, including a self-proclaimed white-robed Jesus. During that sojourn, I met a skinny, acid-tripping girl who solemnly informed me that "Any Day Now," the title of Joan Baez's new album of Bob Dylan songs, referred to Mr. Dylan's imminent suicide. "He's just going to trip right out," she said with that special hushed "Wow!" in her voice that seriously hip people attached to all things mystical.
As much as that counterculture was mobilized by antiwar sentiment, its driving force was really drugs, and not only psychedelics. In the quest to "break on through to the other side," as Jim Morrison bellowed, any and every stimulant was enlisted for the cause. Amphetamines, which were widely available back then and carried little stigma, contributed immeasurably to the collective paranoia that was rapidly building up. And, of course, there was always booze to smooth the transitions.
Two other random flashbacks. In one, I am hounded out of a Chinese restaurant by a radical feminist and her poet husband after I describe my extremely liberal political views. But they and their revolutionary comrades have big plans to sabotage the 1968 Presidential elections by, among other tactics, vomiting on the voting machines. Liberals were their worst enemies. "When the revolution comes, you'll be one of the first to go!" they scream, and I'm out of there. Fast.
In the other, I am living in New York and supplying lyrics for a revolutionary rock band no one has ever heard of in another city. Asked to donate $300 -- a third of my life savings at the time -- for sound equipment, I gladly obliged, only to discover that the money has gone up the leader's nose in crystal methedrine. So much for the new Beatles!
Recalling such crazy 60's moments, I wonder if what we call the 60's was a mass psychosis that is either best forgotten or swept under the rug. But I don't think so. For all the smashed lives and insanity that such excesses brought, the root of that frenzied exploration still strikes me as an honest, if naive, effort to improve the human condition by storming the barricades of consciousness. That idealism is distilled in the best music of the era, which combines a majestic rage with an exhilarating eroticism.
Today's social climate is in many ways antithetical to that of 30 years ago when the notion of capitalism itself was under siege. The power of today's American economy combined with the country's conservative, comformist values, make joining the system irresistible to all but a few. Rebellion is reduced to a matter of fashion statement.
IF the AIDS epidemic ended the sexual revolution, sexual allure has increasingly become the major marketing tool fueling the economy. Rock may have been superseded by rap, but the history of rock-and-roll is probably the one with which more Americans are familiar than any other. As for drugs, the new miracle elixirs, Prozac and the other serotonin boosters are tools to help people become happier, more efficient producers in the great American money machine.
Movies may never get the 60's right. For one thing, those days are fading fast, and many of the Hollywood studio executives calling the shots are Wunderkinds in their 20's and 30's whose closest contact with the 60's are VH1 flashbacks or their parents' (censored) anecdotes.
In his sweetly prescient 60's ballad, "Younger Generation," John Sebastian, a quintessential Woodstock-era songwriter, contemplated impending fatherhood and the raising of an adolescent son. "And then I'll know that all I've learned my kid assumes/ And all my deepest worries must be his cartoons," he mused.
In a way he was right. But the lessons taught by the 60's are not the ones that those who lived through them imagined they would be.

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM/NEW HAVEN;
Afraid of Shakespeare? Not These Students

BYLINE: By PEGGY McCARTHY 

 BODY:
JAMES ANDREASSI JR. loves to tell about a tough-talking teen-ager with an arrest record who was a reluctant student in his Shakespeare program.
"At first, he was less than enthusiastic about participating. Little by little, we were able to draw him into our evil Shakespeare web," Mr. Andreassi said. He said he assigned the boy a speech from Hamlet and "to say he was having difficulty with the text, would be an understatement. But, by the end, he was performing it with a great deal of panache and aplomb." 
 At the cast party, the boy grabbed Mr. Andreassi. "Thanks man," he said. "I ain't never done nothing before."
Mr. Andreassi, artistic director of The Elm Shakespeare Company in New Haven, said the boy's ultimate response symbolizes the transformation that can occur when students are taught Shakespeare in a stimulating and encouraging way.
"Every kid wants to be validated. Every kid wants success," he said. "There's something about paricipating in a project where Shakespeare is the focus that's intimidating to kids. When they succeed in that forum, it really is significant to them."
The Elm Shakespeare Company includes Equity actors, and in the summer performs Shakespearean plays, with no admission charge, in Edgarton Park in New Haven. During the academic year the company works with students and teachers from the High School in the Community in New Haven, a magnet school with students from New Haven and surrounding towns.
As part of an English class, the students read and analyze Shakespearean plays, and write papers, much like students in any Shakespeare class. In the course, however, they also work with members of the Shakespeare Company. They perform a play, learning skills as varied as fight choreography for battle scenes to stage managing.
In the process, they usually develop self-esteem, self-confidence, and a love for something they would never have expected to enjoy, according to teachers and Elm Shakespeare staff.
Charlene Andrade, director of "Julius Caesar," which the students performed last month, explained that "we start by telling them, 'you cannot fail. You have permission to be as wonderful as you are.' When they're given that kind of permission, they're not afraid."
At a rehearsal, Ms. Andrade pointed out a dark-haired girl who was too shy to say one word on stage, so was working as stage manager. But, like others without speaking parts, she was expected to appear in crowd scenes. In a run-through of a battle scene, Richard Squeri, the fight choreographer, made a point of singling out the girl, saying that she was desparately needed in that scene. "I love what you're doing," Mr. Squeri told the girl. Then he called to Ms. Andrade who sat in the audience: "She can't be the stage manager for this scene because she's in the battle."
Ms. Andrade, who teaches theater in the New Haven school system, said "I want these kids to leave with a sense of success." She said "they will shine" whether they have only one line or, in the case of the shy girl, "she will shine in the battle."
High School in the Community is an alternative magnet school which has classes in 3 1/2-hour blocks, which makes it suitable for the sizeable task of putting on a Shakespearean play. And, as the play's performance date nears, students put in some six-hour days just for this class, learning lines and rehearsing.
The school attracts a diverse population of students, racially, ethnically and economically, Ms. Andrade said, adding their success at working as a cohesive group in the Shakespeare class "is a microcosm of what is possible" in society.
Student participants, taking a break from a rehearsal to study their lines, said the class is far from typical. Dante Freeman, a 17-year-old junior from New Haven, had never been in a play before he was given the lead role in "Julius Caesar."
"I thought I was going to have a small part. When I found out I was Caesar, I said, 'You're kidding.' Now, I'm at home every night rehearsing my lines.
"I finally get to find out what I can really do," Mr. Freeman added. "I can reach out and grab the part.
On the other hand, Nicole Avellani, an 18-year-old senior from Hamden has taken theater workshops in the past, prompted by her mother who was a theater major in college. But, the student who played Portia and the narrator said before she took this class, "I never really had as much passion for it."
On the stage, the atmosphere is professional. The students are expected to meet high standards and be attentive, but are also lavished with praise.
"It's something you actually have to put your mind to," said Shantell Darden, 16, a sophomore from Hamden. She added that she particularly enjoys the cooperative aspect of it. She said she has been in plays since the fourth grade and she's "not used to working with everybody helping each other with lines."
The Elm Shakespeare Company was established in 1995. The relationship with the High School in the community began the same year. Ellen Dion, an English teacher who conducted the class this year, said when former students are asked what they remember most about high school, they point to this class.
Mr. Andreassi said the school doesn't have sports or an identifiable "school spirit" activity. "We help with that," he said.
Company staff also conducts workshops and two-week seminars in other schools around the state. The group, a non-profit organization, is a member of "Young Audiences of Connecticut," which coordinates arts education activities for schools.
Next summer, 10 students will receive internships to Elm Shakespeare and become part of the crew that works on the production that is performed for the public.
This year, "Henry IV, Part I," will be performed Aug. 18-22, Aug. 25 through 29, and Sept. 1-5, all at 8 p.m. The company's goal is to attract 30,000 people, who are encouraged to bring their families and picnics. For information: (203) 772-1474.

HEADLINE: Q & A/Mary Travers;
When Life Is a Song, and Also a Cause

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
MARY TRAVERS, folk music icon, mother, grandmother and idealist, lives quietly with her husband, Ethan Robbins, two cats and a dog named Peaches in an exquisitely restored 250-year-old Redding farmhouse. The house is filled with books, antiques and memorabilia from worldwide touring as part of the group called Peter, Paul and Mary.
An enormous painting of the singer topless dominates one wall of the living room. Another wall holds a picture of Ms. Travers at 19 playing her guitar. Photos of her mother, her two daughters, Erika and Alicia, and her two grandchildren crowd the top of the piano. "We are four generations of strong women," she said. 
 Her 1960's principles have not faded with time but she says, "I'm not an ideologue," then adding, "except when I was a parent. Parents are not democratic. We need democracy in the big picture. As a parent, it's 'Go to your room.' "
After almost 40 years of performing, Peter Yarrow, Noel Paul Stookey and Mary Travers have hardly slowed down. She said they have no plans to retire, as she got ready to fly to Minneapolis, Toronto and Chicago for a week of performances. Every year the group prepares new material. They add six new songs and remove six. They rehearse in Manhattan at the home of Peter Yarrow.
The one aspect of her performing life she dislikes getting to the performances. "What isn't fun is getting on and off airplanes," she said.
Recently the group released a new compact disk called "Songs of Conscience and Concern," a collection of lesser known folk songs with social and political messages.
Ms. Travers's farmhouse is a retreat between performances. It is a place where she indulges her passions: cooking and gardening. She also reads and writes poetry and says "From time to time I fix lyrics." One of her poems has been set to music by Noel Paul Stookey. It was written about Ms. Travers's mother, who died last year of Alzheimer's disease.
Recently Ms. Travers shared some of her memories and plans. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. Why do you credit your mother with influencing your life the most?
A. My mother was a marvelous woman: bright, beautiful, dry wit. She was the head of public relations at Danbury Hospital for years. She wrote a couple of books. One was on Margaret Sanger for children, a cookbook, one about the children's crusades.
She used to say to me "be careful of compromise, Mary. There's a very thin line between compromise and accomplice." So that was Mom. I think I grew up at a time with mentors. I think it's very hard for young people today because there isn't really a whole lot of good mentor material out there. I had Pete Seeger, I had my mother and my father, although my mother and father were divorced. My father was a very ethical person.
I was surrounded by a very committed community growing up in Greenwich Village. Most of my mother's friends were writers and artists, people who by nature are committed and, also many of them were committed in what I call the ethical-political sense. So I grew up listening to Paul Robeson and Pete Seeger, believing that inequality was an evil, that women had the right to be anything they want to be and should work.
Feminism wasn't something I discovered in the 60's. It was something I had generational input into. The women who had been the most vibrant in my life all worked. And were responsible for themselves as well as for and to other people.
Q. How did you begin your singing career?
A. Singing was a very social thing in the Village. Every Sunday you met up with friends and sat in the park and sang. You went from one group to another. One minute you were singing blues with somebody. Then you went to another group filled with banjoes and did something like the "Rocky Mountain Rundown." There were lots of different groups.
Q. Is that how you met Peter Yarrow and Noel Paul Stookey?
A. I was living on MacDougal Street and Noel Paul Stookey was working across the street at the Gaslight Cafe. He was working as a half singer, half comedian, half master of ceremonies. I realize that's three halves. I didn't pass math.
Peter had just graduated Cornell and was going to take off for a year bumming around. He had a manager named Albert Grossman who wanted to form a group with Peter and some other people. There was a store called Izzy Young's Folklore Center. It had pictures all over the wall of folk singers, everybody who had opened their mouth. There was a picture of me. Peter is purported to have asked Albert "Gee who's that?" and Albert said "That's Mary Travers. She'd be great if you could get her to work." He's been trying to get me to work for years, almost 40 of them.
We've fought. We've cried. We've made up. We tried never to say the thing you can't take back while dancing as close to that line as you can.
Q. How did you raise two children and perform?
A. Dancing very fast! I remember when Erika got the mumps. I forget whether it was Peter or Paul who'd never had the mumps, but we had a dicey moment there hoping that they wouldn't catch it.
It wasn't totally easy, but on some levels in retrospect, it was great to have children. When I started singing at the very beginning with Peter and Paul, Erika was 9 months old. So I always did it with kids. I had never wanted to be famous. It never occurred to me. It never occurred to be that I was going to be a singer. I sang as a hobby, something I did for fun. It was really a surprise to me that I ended up doing this professionally. Fame hit rather quickly. Erika was in many ways my sea anchor. She was my reality base. "The baby has to go to the doctor." "The baby needs new shoes." "I can't do that because I can't find a baby-sitter." There was always that reality. I think it saved me from a lot of trouble or what would have become trouble. Fame be can a very destructive force on somebody's life if they are an unformed human being. I was just 23 at that time.
Q. Where does the political activism come from?
A. There are moments in our lives that are pivotal. I think the March on Washington in 1963 with Dr. King was such a moment.
I've always been the ravenous reader in the group and I had read about having a moment where you have a kind of revelation, usually in a religious context. I never understood what words like epiphany meant. They are great words but what do they mean? At the March on Washington I had both an epiphany and a revelation. I felt like I was three feet off the ground and I saw the truth.
The truth was that people of good will could effect, nonviolently, a moment of social change. Up until then I think the only time I saw large crowds functioning was on newsreels and they weren't functioning for good reasons.
Q. Does society still need changing?
A. We need to have a change. The change that I'm looking for has to do with a realization things have gone too far. For instance, this latest shooting in New York and the coincidental firing of a New Jersey police officer over the issue of racial profiling. All of a sudden the issue of racial profiling is popping up everywhere. This could be a very good thing because it may just wake up some folks to the fact that racial inequality still exists. We have not finished this job.
Q. How is life different today from your youth?
A. What we have in common with the 50's at the moment is a strong economy. I have the Mary Travers theory of social change. That is, when the economy is really good people tend to be more generous about social issues, so I'm hopeful. We need to get on with the business of being a more integrated society.
We make a mistake expecting that everyone is going to have the time now. One of the wonderful things about the 60's was college kids could take a year off and work on voter registration for example. You can't do that now. It's so damn competitive out there and everyone is worried about money. Lots of those activists from the 60's got married, had children, sent them to college. I think when college costs $33,000 a year, more than a lot of people earn in a year, we have to ask what's wrong with this picture?
Q. Why do Peter, Paul and Mary do so many benefits?
A. I was raised to believe that everybody has a responsibility to their community and I use the word very loosely. It's a big community. If I get recognized in the middle of the Sinai Desert I have a big community.
Q. Has folk music lost its appeal?
A. Folk music can be found at folk festivals like the one in Curryville, Texas or Philadelphia and also at lots of little clubs. Folk music is alive and well and so is Mary!

SECTION: Section 11; Page 2; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1373 words

HEADLINE: Habitats /Sutton Place;
For a Designer, the Agony Of Renovation Is a Joy

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL 

 BODY:
EVERYONE talks about how difficult it is to renovate: the time, the energy, the angst. Potentially wonderful apartments sit on the market for months, even in this economy, because they require extensive work, and nobody has the nerve to take them on.
Joann Brancato, however, loves to renovate. A designer who does a lot of residential work in Manhattan, she talks about the thrill of renovating the way other people talk about a vacation in Paris or a great score in the stock market. She feels ecstatic when a space is being gutted, when there is an opportunity to create something new. "I love the disruption of it all," she says. 
 So when a broker showed her a particularly infamous apartment on Sutton Place a year ago, she didn't flee they way other people had. In the world of disaster apartments, it ranked among the worst. It hadn't been occupied in three or four years. It had an overpowering stench of mothballs and mold. When the curtains were pulled back to let in a bit of sunlight, the fabric disintegrated. Thick dust covered everything.
On the other hand, the co-op apartment was 2,700 square feet, not including the wrap-around terrace, for $800,000, with a maintenance of $3,300 a month in a doorman building. She had just given birth to her second child, and she and her husband, David Wirtz, a lawyer, really wanted to move out of their small two-bedroom apartment on Fifth Avenue near 86th Street.
They didn't want to leave their neighborhood, because Central Park is a paradise for parents whose children grow up knowing every inch of the terrain, every bump on the playground slides. But when Ms. Brancato told real estate brokers what she and her husband could pay, and that they wanted 2,000 square feet on the Upper East Side near the park, "all of them laughed at me," she says. They would have liked a loft downtown, in TriBeCa, but they couldn't find one they could afford with a doorman.
And so they ended up looking at the apartment on Sutton Place. Her husband liked it immediately. He is 6 feet, 4 inches tall, and although the 8-foot, 6-inch ceilings were not unusually high, the large space felt comfortable, especially compared to the boxy apartments they had been looking at. . The price was right. And he trusted that his wife, something of a miracle worker, could fix it up.
Ms. Brancato, however, had the opposite reaction. "I hated it," she says. She knew the L-shaped apartment had a southern exposure, but the draperies were so massive and heavy that the presence of light was a theoretical concept. The apartment was even more chaotic than most because it had been assembled from three units and never completely integrated. Vinyl and pink carpeting covered the floors, and there were gates everywhere that had been used to restrict the movement of dogs. "It was really hideous," she says.
She disliked it so much that she didn't want to spend much time there considering the design possibilities. "It stunk," she says. She knew she had to see a floor plan before its potential would be clear. And she agreed to do that only to please her husband. She had absolutely no interest in living on Sutton Place.
"I didn't want to be on the East River," she says. "I didn't like the lobby. I didn't like the hallway." And she didn't know anyone in the neighborhood. She had never even thought of looking in Sutton Place, an area that to her seemed filled with old people, with no potential playmates for her children.
But when she saw the floor plan, she knew she could give it the open, easy, loftlike feeling that she likes, because the structure, and the light, were there. "I knew I could eliminate walls," she says. She didn't know, though, whether she could overcome her negative feelings about the neighborhood. But she decided she had to try. Moving to the suburbs was impossible, in her mind.
"I grew up on Long Island," she says. "Everybody was the same. I didn't know anybody black, or with an accent, or anybody very rich or poor." Besides, the suburbs are clearly too quiet for a woman who likes to watch walls fall. "I need my adrenaline pumping all the time," she says.
AND so they began. Fast. The day after they closed on the apartment last May, they moved in, because they couldn't afford to rent another place while renovating the new one. She and her husband, as well as their daughter, Meghan, who is soon to be 4, and their year-old son, Michael, lived in a section of the apartment that had been a studio. "Once they started ripping things out of here, it was such a high," she says. "It took a lot of Dumpsters." Although she does the same thing for a living, she says, "it's also my obsession; the transformation of space to me is very exciting."
Last October, they moved into the finished section while work proceeded in other areas. But construction never progresses seamlessly. "It was a nightmare for me," she says. "The night the cabinet guy was installing the kitchen cabinets, my daughter is in there playing with dolls, and I'm cooking, and my son is eating nails off the floor. And that was typical." Her son never did swallow a nail, she says, but "he tried very hard."
The finished space is clean, spare and serene, but also warm and inviting. There are no messy piles around. "For fun, I clean closets," Ms. Brancato says. But she also designed the space to hold the clutter that multiplies in families with children. Near the entry is her "stroller closet," an urban version of a country mud room.
The lighting is subtle and multifaceted. In the hallway are tiny halogen lights, and over the dining room table one small tightly focused light shines down on a box of grass. The windows, of course, have been stripped of the light-deadening fabric, and the apartment now has the airiness it should have on the eastern edge of Manhattan. She reconfigured the space to create three bedrooms, as well as a dining room, den, living room and kitchen, and an office for her business. Through the door of her daughter's room she cut a square; through her son's, a circle. It gives them a place to have fun, and throw balls, and allows her to peek in.
AMAZINGLY, she did all the work for about $220,000, which was possible, she says, because "I don't like to spend money foolishly." Her knowledge of materials and their prices helped her make choices that kept costs down.
She used simple tiles in the bathrooms, not marble. In the kitchen she used slate, not granite. Rather than putting down new flooring to replace the flawed parquet, she had it painted with Benjamin Moore China White and stenciled in a checkerboard pattern. All the walls are painted a shade of gray, or purple gray. "If you have wonderful lighting, a good paint job, and good floors, you don't need anything else," she says.
She is happy with her new place, but naturally, would move tomorrow, to have the chance to gut something again. "I would do it in a heartbeat, but my husband would have a nervous breakdown," she says. "It's not his temperament."
She has even begun to like the neighborhood, At first, she says, "I was nervous because it felt like midtown." But now she appreciates the fact that she can walk to designer showrooms, and that First Avenue is filled with services. "There's a wonderful fish market, and you can get your nails done," she says. "Not that I get my nails done."
She has discovered some small, pleasant parks nearby, and even some children. She credits her broker, Cristina Marzullo of Douglas Elliman, with convincing her that the neighborhood was being unjustly overlooked by people like her. And indeed, Ms. Marzullo says, while apartments there are one-third less than they would be in SoHo or TriBeCa, prices are rising as young families realize it's not as staid as they feared.
While Ms. Marzullo has sold about 20 apartments in the area in the last few years, the sale to Ms. Brancato and Mr. Wirtz stands out, she says -- in part because even her mentor said that she would be crazy to take the listing, that she would never be able to sell it.
After the sale, Ms. Marzullo was one of the brokers nominated by Douglas Elliman for "the deal of the year." Based, of course, not on the price, but on the challenge.

HEADLINE: In the Region /New Jersey;
Builders Rush to Meet Call for Flexible Structures

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
MOVING to capitalize on what they say is an increasing demand from tenants to combine several different operations under one roof, developers are constructing a spate of buildings that can accommodate uses from office to distribution and from research and development to light manufacturing and storage space.
Some 1.1 million square feet of space in a collection of such new and renovated one-story structures, called flex buildings, are nearing completion, under way or planned throughout the state, according to Grubb & Ellis, the national commercial brokerage. Most of the buildings are being developed on speculation, including projects in Roxbury, Plainsboro, Franklin Township and East Brunswick. 
 Others are being constructed as build-to-suit deals for specific tenants. An example is the 160,000-square-foot building that Prologis, an industrial real estate investment trust based in Aurora, Colo., with offices in Cranbury, is developing on 22 acres at Darlington Avenue and MacArthur Boulevard in Mahwah for Konica Photo Imaging. Konica will be consolidating its Englewood Cliffs offices and its warehouse in Wayne into larger space in the $15 million Mahwah building when it is completed in September, said Michael Nachamkin, vice president at Prologis.
Much of the demand for flex space, commercial brokers agree, is coming from small companies that are expanding and larger firms that are consolidating. Tenants in the market include telecommunications, pharmaceutical, biotech and computer companies as well as Internet-related concerns. Internet-related tenants may also begin to filter over from Manhattan, brokers say.
"Because of the explosive growth of Internet and new media firms in Manhattan and the tightness of the market there, you may see tenants look at New Jersey as a less costly alternative, just as financial institutions and more traditional corporations did in the past," said Mark Mandell, an associate director at Cushman & Wakefield, another national brokerage firm.
The appeal of such space is its flexibility. The structures, which generally have 30,000 to 130,000 square feet and ceilings just under 20 feet high, can be carved into individual units as small as 3,000 square feet, each with its own entrance and utilities.
"Today, tenants are leaving old space for new," said Arthur Della Salla, regional research manager at Grubb & Ellis. But that flight to quality has not left an unmanageable amount of space available for the market to absorb, given that much of it is in older buildings that, like those in the state's manufacturing sector, may never get leased, he added.
His company put the vacancy rate for flex space in the state's 11-county northern and central New Jersey market, which comprises 25.6 million square feet, at 17.5 percent, up from 14.2 percent the same period last year. At the same time, average annual square-foot rental rates, combining office space with space for other uses, have fallen to $8.35 a square foot from $8.74 a year earlier. Tenants pay their own utility costs. Rents for newly constructed space are higher, about $10 to $11 a square foot on average.
DESPITE the vacancy rate, Mr. Della Salla said, developers are taking a "calculated risk that the strength of the state's economy will continue to fuel the demand for modern and efficient space, particularly in central New Jersey, where many small businesses in emerging industries are located."
Eric Witmondt, president of Associated Realty, a Parsippany commercial brokerage, added that many concerns see flex buildings "as a way to control their work environment and as a less costly and more efficient alternative to pure office space."
In turn, an increasing number of tenants are interested in using up to half of the space in a building, and sometimes more, for offices, he said, noting, however, that for these projects to be successful they must provide "a higher ratio of parking for the increased office usage."
That is the case at the Roxbury Business Park, a single 61,000-square-foot brick flex building on nine acres at Route 46 and Interstate 80 in the Morris County township of Roxbury.
The building, developed by Roxbury Associates, a local development company, was completed in January. It is fully leased to four tenants, each of which is using half its space for offices and the other half for storage, said Mr. Witmondt, whose brokerage handled the marketing and leasing for the project. Annual rents are $6.50 to $7 a square foot for nonoffice space and $13.50 to $14 for office space. Traditional office space in the area rents for $22 to $24 a square foot, Mr. Witmondt said.
He added that his company was also handling the marketing for a 53,000-square-foot structure in which he expects tenants to use 80 percent of the space for offices.
The structure, which the Roseland Property Company of Roseland will start building this summer, will be the final building at the Enterprise Business Center along Route 1 in Plainsboro. The park already has six flex buildings, each with 30,000 to 60,000 square feet, and two 50,000-square-foot office buildings. Annual rents at the new flex building, to be completed by the first quarter of next year, are expected to be $16 for office space and $7 for other space, Mr. Witmondt said.
At the World's Fair Corporate Center at Exit 10 of Interstate 287 in Franklin Township in Somerset County, First Industrial Realty Trust, a real estate investment trust based in Chicago with offices in Livingston, is nearing completion on two speculative buildings. One has 30,000 square feet and the other, 46,000 square feet.
In July 1997, First Industrial took over the 150-acre business park as part of its purchase of 1.8 million square feet of commercial space from the Punia Company, an industrial developer. Some 800,000 square feet of flex space had already been built at the park, which is 97 percent leased, said Hayden Tiger, a regional director of the New Jersey office of First Industrial.
Mr. Tiger said his company pressed ahead with development because of the high occupancy rate and the fact that there had been no new construction of flex space in the immediate area in a decade. The park is also one block from three million square feet of office space, and many of the businesses that moved into the park "to service the corporate users are expanding," he said, adding, "There is a demand for newer upscale flex space." Tenants have already leased 10,000 square feet in each of the two new brick and glass buildings. Rents are $14 a square foot for office space and half that for other space.
In East Brunwick, Denholtz Associates, a commercial development concern based in Rahway, in a joint venture with Praedium Fund, an affiliate of Credit Suisse First Boston, is converting the former Interstate Bakery on Tice's Lane, where Twinkies were once made, into the Tice's Lane Corporate Center. It will contain 283,046 square feet of flex space in three single-story buildings.
Denholtz bought the empty complex, set on 34 acres just off Route 18, last fall for $6 million, or $20 a square foot. "We saw it as a value-added opportunity to take a single-user factory that could be reconfigured and redesigned for multiple users," said Steven J. Denholtz, the developer's president. Even after investing more than $3 million on renovations, he said, the cost to buy and convert an existing building was still lower than the $60 to $65 a square foot it would cost to build a new one.
Mr. Denholtz said he was also encouraged to proceed with the Tice's Lane project because his company has an 84,000-square-foot flex complex nearby that is fully leased. "We are seeing our existing tenants expand and in a good economy tenants are looking for better space," he said.
The old bakery buildings will be converted into blocks of 3,000 to 25,000 square feet each to accommodate up to 22 tenants. Additional windows will also be carved from the exteriors of the structures, which will be given new glass and stucco facades. In addition, truck loading docks will be added, as will landscaping and additional parking.
Rents at the complex, where occupancy will start this summer, will be $10.50 a square foot for office space and $5 a square foot for other space. Mr. Denholtz said there was room on the site for 84,000 more square feet of flex space, which he will build once two-thirds to three-fourths of the space in the larger complex is leased. "Almost every company has an application for flex space," he said.
