HEADLINE: In the Region /Long Island;
Commercial Builders Are Stepping Up Landscaping

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
FROM his fourth-floor office at 7600 Jericho Turnpike in Woodbury, Peter Tilles, one of the principals of the Tilles Companies, can look down on a three-acre spring-fed pond that his late father, Gilbert, donated 38 years ago to the Town of Oyster Bay for a town park.
Now he and his brother, Roger, the other principal, are using an ongoing landscaping program to turn their 137-acre, 1.5 million-square-foot Nassau Crossways International Plaza into a parklike setting as well. 
 When Gilbert Tilles and partners began developing the property in 1961, most of the surrounding area, including his acreage, was farmland. Now much of the area bordering Jericho Turnpike has become a dreary string of car dealerships and shopping strips, while Nassau Crossways offers a different environment.
The landscaping program has already cost more than $1 million, as the Tilles brothers turn what was once flat farmland into a rolling terrain of berms landscaped with shrubs, flowers and trees. At their adjoining 87-acre Gateways Executive Mall, they will spend $250,000 on landscaping.
Recently, magnolia trees, daffodils and forsythia trees were blooming and the town-owned pond at the northeast corner of Nassau Crossways was alive with Canada geese and other water birds.
"An office complex should not just be a workplace, but also a park where people can walk and relax," said Peter Tilles, who is also president of the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay. "And because of the environment we've created we've never had vacancies even in the bad times, and have attracted some of the top companies in the country."
Although most towns and incorporated villages have a site plan review process that includes requiring developers to submit a landscaping plan, much of the commercial and retail development in Nassau County in the planning stages or under way is going well beyond the basic municipal requirements. Providing curb appeal has become an important marketing tool. "To me, the environment sets the atmosphere for attracting tenants," Peter Tilles said. "Everyone can build an office building, but how do you get people to come?"
A 520,000-square-foot office project being planned by the Tilles Companies for a 52-acre tract near Route 110 in Melville will cost an estimated $125 million, $1 million of which will be budgeted for landscaping, Mr. Tilles said.
The project, to be called Expressway Corporate Plaza, still needs several approvals from the Town of Huntington before it can proceed, but construction could start by the end of the year, with an opening in 2001. The project's three buildings -- one of 100,000 square feet and the others of 200,000 square feet each -- will be built in phases.
"In our work, the landscape is just as important as the exterior design because it is of the essence, in our opinion, to provide the corporate world we work in with a sense of dignity, energy and letting one feel it's their home away from home," said Michael H. Spector, a principal in charge of the Spector Group of North Hills, the architects of Expressway Corporate Plaza.
The Tilles Companies has retained Oehme, van Sweden & Associates of Washington, D.C., as its landscape architect.
Although the landscape design is in the preliminary stages and still needs town approvals, proposals will likely include a series of decorative ponds in front of the three buildings and a natural amphitheater where concerts and other events can be held, with rock outcroppings providing the seating for up to 300 people.
"Landscaping gives a project a panache that nothing else can," said James A. van Sweden, president of Oehme, van Sweden. The Washington firm is also the landscape architect for the Americana shopping center in Manhasset, which has become well known on Long Island for its seasonal displays of flowers, ornamental trees and grasses.
"The first impression is so important," Mr. van Sweden said. "If a shopping center doesn't wow you, you may not even drive in."
THE Americana, which has about 200,000 square feet of shopping with such high-end retailers as Brooks Brothers, Emporio Armani, Tiffany and Polo Ralph Lauren, opened in 1956 "and we have virtually no vacancies," said Frank Castagna, a partner in Castagna Realty, which owns the complex.
"The North Shore has always been a highly landscaped area, so we felt that landscaping our front yard, which happens to be 1,500 feet long and 15 feet wide; our parking lot, and a 20-foot-wide strip in the back established our credibility and was a good business judgment," Mr. Castagna said.
Maintaining the landscaping costs $300,000 a year, added Mr. Castagna, who also owns Wheatley Plaza on Northern Boulevard in Greenvale. The 122,000-square-foot Greenvale shopping center, completed in 1980, reflects the philosophy "that pride of place should not only be reflected in your home but also in the streets you drive along and by public buildings," Mr. Castagna said.
Now Castagna Realty, in conjunction with Stephen Hess of Manhasset among other partners, is planning a 200,000-square-foot office project for an eight-acre site on New Hyde Park Road in North Hills, for which Oehme, van Sweden is also the landscape architect. The five-story precast concrete and glass building is being designed by the Spector Group.
The landscaping, on which the developers intend to spend almost $2 million, will include a reflecting pond, fountains and terraces. Construction will start when rents, now averaging about $28 a square foot, reach the $31 a square foot level needed to justify the $23-million building, Mr. Castagna said.
In Hauppauge, a 408,000-square-foot office complex to rise on 19.6 acres by the Tritec Real Estate Company of East Setauket will include a landscaped plaza between the two buildings, with outdoor seating for office workers. The landscape architect is Richard B. Ignatow of Huntington.
"Architects in general have always tried to include a good deal of vegetation and green area, but unfortunately many times landscaping is the first to go if there are budget constraints," said Charles Baldassano, president of the Baldassano Architectural Group of Ronkonkoma, the architect along with Mojo Stumer Associates of Roslyn, of the Tritec project.
Landscaping usually represents 10 percent to 12 percent of total costs, Mr. Baldassano said, and with the economy doing so well, "developers are more likely to do that today," he said.
Commercial brokers say that buildings that offer an inviting environment have a strong competitive edge, even though landlords may charge somewhat higher rents.
"A top-end company that competes for high-level people wants to offer them as good and as friendly an environment as possible," said Theodore P. Sasso, senior managing director at the Syosset office of Insignia/ESG, which is handling the leasing at the Tritec property, which is known as 100 Motor Parkway.
Starwood Ceruzzi of Fairfield, Conn., which is upgrading a 510,000-square-foot shopping center in Bay Shore called Gardiner Manor Center, is investing $200,000 in landscaping to enhance the redesign of what had been an aging mall.
"A high level of curb appeal makes a difference to shoppers and in turn to the level of sales, and that's what determines whether you attract tenants and whether they exercise the option to renew their leases," said Louis L. Ceruzzi, the president of Starwood Ceruzzi, which is spending $50 million on its project.
The center, still under construction, is already fully leased. New retailers include a Target department store that has taken 135,000 square feet, a Barnes & Noble that will be in 25,000 square feet and a Nobody Beats the Wiz electronics store that will occupy 30,000 square feet. An existing 150,000-square-foot Stern's department store will continue to be the anchor.
Town officials say that the growing emphasis on the environment is all about retaining Long Island's suburban character.
"People move here wanting to get a little patch of green in their lives and it is important that we make every effort to maintain that," said Anthony J. Santino, a Town of Hempstead council member. "Creeping urbanization is always around the corner if we let our guard down."
Oyster Bay adopted a site plan review ordinance in 1996. It requires developers not only to meet setback and parking requirements but also to plant shade trees in parking lots and to use landscaping to shield the view of cars.
"The rationale is to make development more esthetically pleasing and in turn more acceptable to the community," said John Venditto, the Town Supervisor.
"Residents always fear developers will ravage the land, and developers think residents will say no to everything," he added. "Now we have a process that brings all the varied interests together so that they can constructively exchange ideas on the best way to develop property."

HEADLINE: In the Region /Connecticut;
Drug Maker Buys Vacant GTE Building in Stamford

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
PURDUE PHARMA, a division of Purdue Frederick, a 100-year-old pharmaceutical company that relocated from New York City to Norwalk a quarter-century ago, bought the vacant GTE building in Stamford on March 27 for $77 million.
In doing so it will eventually take some 513,000 square feet of first-class office space off the market in a city where the vacancy rate for such space is at a 10-year low of about 6 percent. 
 The glass-sheathed GTE building, resembling an inverted ziggurat, has stood at 201 Tresser Boulevard as an icon of the city's rebirth since it was completed in 1973. It was the first owner-occupied corporate headquarters to be built in downtown Stamford during the urban renewal period.
Newmark & Company Real Estate of Manhattan represented the seller, the Zurich Reinsurance Company, in the sale and in the purchase of the building from GTE in January of this year. Zurich Reinsurance had contracted to buy the building in 1997, planning to occupy it after the last of GTE's employees left last fall. But late last year, Zurich Reinsurance changed its mind and never moved in.
The company's decision to abandon its plans and sell was based on "a gradual shift in our business to complex financially driven products that we expect to accelerate; we thought it advisable to stay close to the financial community in Manhattan," John Cross, its chief financial officer, said from its Manhattan headquarters.
Stephen Banker, executive managing director for Newmark's Fairfield County operations, said: "This is a milestone for Stamford. The city was at a point where no new construction projects could go forward until GTE was spoken for. Now developers-in-waiting can more aggressively formulate plans to go into the ground."
According to Robin Stein, a land use planner for the city, "there is nothing else like GTE left in the city, not even 100,000 square feet available for any user looking for a large space."
But because Purdue Pharma will not initially occupy the entire GTE building, 70,000 to 100,000 square feet of space will go back on the market, with Newmark as the leasing agent.
Without substantial preleases in hand, lenders are still extremely cautious about making financial commitments for speculative office buildings, but it now appears likely that one of three potential projects will proceed first -- a 480,000-square-foot tower that was approved by the city's zoning board in 1997 for Hines Interests L.P.
The site, at 425 Atlantic Street, within walking distance of the Metro North-Amtrak railroad station and one block north of the new Warburg Dillon Read building, is viewed as "an exceptional setting," said Kenneth W. Hubbard, executive vice president at Hines. At present, he said, "we are very concentrated on preleasing to two financial services tenants who would fill half the building and could assure financing."
A second entry, the Louis Dreyfus Property Group, based in Manhattan, expects to submit an application for a 508,000-square-foot building on Washington Boulevard this month, said David Friedman, a vice president in the developer's Stamford office. The site is across the boulevard from the Warburg Dillon Read property.
A third project, by the Toombs Development Company of New Canaan in partnership with Howard Milstein, a New York developer, "is the quietest," Mr. Stein said. It involves a vacant, excavated parcel that the partners have owned for two years. It lies behind the Town Center mall at Greyrock Place. Scott Toombs, president of the company, said, "we have been talking to prospective tenants on a regular basis and remain optimistic."
Reactions to the Purdue Pharma purchase among Stamford's real estate professionals have been mixed. "We could have had a scenario where Zurich sold it to a less-than-full-building user and more space would have hit the market," said Ed Tonnessen, an executive vice president at Albert B. Ashforth, real estate brokers in Stamford. "With space so tight, we need a new building, something to set the musical chairs in play again. Nobody significant is moving out -- there is no juggling for space. New construction will give us some backfill operations."
O N a more conservative note, Owen J. Brown 3d, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield, said: "One new building would lease in a heartbeat in the mid-$30's a square foot. The need and demand are there. But not all three buildings. They are all about the same size and tenants requiring 100,000 to 200,000 square feet are few and far between these days."
That may be changing. The number of companies in the area that are expanding, like Purdue Pharma, is growing. The Thomson Corporation, for example, an international publisher of newspapers and educational and technical publications based in Stamford, now occupies more than 175,000 square feet of space spread over five locations in Fairfield County. "We are exploring alternative space opportunities," said Ray Meglio, vice president for real estate, indicating that a consolidation might be coming.
Purdue Pharma now owns or leases 240,000 square feet of space in five Norwalk locations, and in the last three years it added 200 of the 600 people that make up its current headquarters staff, all of whom will be transferred to Stamford. In addition, it has manufacturing and chemical research facilities in Totowa, N.J., and in Ardsley in Westchester County.
Strong growth in the last three to five years was attributed by Howard R. Udell, vice president and general counsel for the company, to the introduction of two highly successful products: OxyContin for the relief of chronic pain and MS Contin, a morphine-based, controlled-release substance, to relieve cancer pain.
"Starting in the spring of next year we will move in in phases," Mr. Udell said, "after facade repairs, some reconfiguration of office space, and upgrading of the mechanical systems and windows are completed." He gave the building high marks for being well maintained, for the beauty of its terrace and ground level gardens, and the elegance of its cafeteria and other interior spaces.
"We've been looking for new quarters for several years," he said. "We had a building designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill to be constructed on our present site at 100 Connecticut Avenue in Norwalk, but shortly before we were to break ground last year we realized that we had outgrown it."
After dropping construction plans, Purdue bought a 10,000-square-foot building at 200 Connecticut Avenue from the Davis Companies of Boston and Wilton, a company that has been providing Purdue with an overall program of asset management. "Now we are negotiating to buy the building back," said David Fiore, a Davis senior vice president in Wilton. As part of its service, Davis made Purdue aware of the availability of the GTE building last December. Purdue bought it without a broker.
Jeffrey Dunne, a senior vice president at CB Richard Ellis in Stamford, has been hired by Purdue Pharma to sell both of its Connecticut Avenue buildings. Regarding the GTE sale, he said: "It takes away potential competition for developers who want to do spec projects, but the problem is that rental rates are still not quite high enough at the low- to mid-$30's. You need mid- to high-$30's, and I don't think rentals will rise quickly. There are still more than three and a half million out of a total of 14 million square feet of office space available, including older buildings around the city that are very hard to lease."
Purdue Frederick was founded in 1892 by John Purdue Gray, a doctor, and W. W. Frederick. By 1952, it had become a small pharmaceutical manufacturer in Greenwich Village that was in serious financial difficulty.
It was bought by two doctors, Mortimer and Raymond Sackler, brothers who had a psychiatric practice on Manhattan's Upper East Side. The company was expanded through acquisitions and the development of new products, eventually moving to Yonkers and then to Norwalk in 1973, where the headquarters was built. The company is still owned privately by the the Sackler family of Greenwich.
Its relocation to Stamford may have some beneficial tax consequences. Connecticut gives companies that move their headquarters to municipalities with state-designated enterprise zones a five-year 80 percent abatement on real estate and personal property taxes, plus a 10-year 25 percent credit against state corporate income taxes. Personal property is made up of office, manufacturing and other business equipment.
If the company goes into a vacant or underutilized building outside the enterprise zone, the benefits are somewhat reduced. Stamford's enterprise zone was established in 1994 south of Interstate 95 and the railroad tracks to bring new business and industry into that depressed area. GTE is north of the highway, outside the enterprise zone but still eligible for the lesser benefits, according to James Heckman, a spokesman for the state's Department of Economic Development.
"We've had discussions with the state that are not yet resolved," Mr. Udell said.

HEADLINE: Should Artists Give Way to Parking Space?

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
THE twin brothers Enzo and Germano Russo arrived in the United States three decades ago, after graduating from the School of Fine Arts at the University of Florence in Italy.
But the portrait and landscape artists say it was not until 1993 that they finally found a home after stumbling on an old factory building in South Norwalk. 
 Along with dozens of other artists, artisans and a few merchants, they turned a cavernous structure made of red brick -- where workers made locks for more than a century -- into an artists' colony that has been at the center of an economic renewal in the South Norwalk, or SoNo, section of the city.
Now the building is also at the center of a growing battle over the city's plans to tear it down and replace it with a 600-space parking garage as part of a $250 million project called Reed-Putnam, after two streets in the historic district. The plan would include a hotel, restaurants, shops and pubs as well as studios and lofts for artists along what is described as "70 strategically placed acres."
"We have lived and worked in many places, including New York City, but this is the best space we have ever had, the people in this building are our family," said Germano Russo, who compares the four-block South Norwalk area to the SoHo section of Manhattan. "Like SoHo," he said, "this is a true community of artists who thrive and inspire each other to create many different forms of art."
But the city, following the advice of its planners and development agency, would tear down the building and replace it with a six-level parking garage for the expanding Maritime Aquarium, which is considered the area's economic anchor.
"Of course we would like to see the artists stay," said a spokesman for the Aquarium, Dave Sigworth, "but we need more parking and it has to be in close proximity to our building. The artists are great for the community, but accessible parking is our top priority."
That angers the artists who say they are particularly upset by what they view as the "pave paradise, put up a parking lot" stance being taken by the aquarium and city planners.
"I think I could accept just about anything else," said Mary Kenely, an artist, "but to even think about tearing down such an historic building for the proverbial parking garage would actually be funny if it weren't so sad and pathetic." Ms. Kenely draws and paints and shares a loft and studio in the building with her husband, Richard Klein, a sculptor and museum curator who is vice-president of the Historic Lock Building Association, which has organized a campaign to save the building.
To wage that battle, the artists -- who say the city's plan would punish the very people who have helped revitalize the area and even helped make fashionable its SoNo nickname -- have enlisted the help of a national group, Artspace Projects Inc., a Minneapolis-based nonprofit group that specializes in saving historic buildings and transforming them into space for artists to live and work.
An official with Artspace, Chris Velasco, recently spoke to more than 300 people at Norwalk City Hall who had come to protest the city's plans to raze the building. "This is a story we hear all over the country," said Mr. Velasco, artists coming into a downtrodden neighborhood and helping to bring about an economic rebirth, and then it becomes so upscale the very artists who helped bring the area back can't afford to live there anymore."
Norwalk officials, including city council members, who attended the meeting say they are having second thoughts about whether to move ahead with the plan that many believe made more sense when it was first proposed in 1983 than when it was updated two years ago. (It was delayed for more than a decade because of an economic downturn and sagging real estate prices.)
Those doubts were only reenforced recently with an apparent 11th-hour disclosure of the redevelopment agency's plans to include a $3.4 million subsidy and $2 million parcel of land for the developer -- Stamford-based Spinnaker Industries -- as part of its contract to raze the Lock Building and construct a multi-use structure and parking garage.
Said the city council's president, Peter Nolin: "There are so many questions about whether this is the most economically viable plan for the city, and now that we find out so late in the process about what amounts to a $5.5 million subsidy for the developer, I think it's even more important to slow down and reevaluate the entire proposal. We were told there might be some kind of subsidy, but nobody thought it would be anywhere near the figure that is being mentioned."
But the need for more parking at the Maritime Aquarium, across the street from the Lock Building and at the heart of the area's decade-long revitalization with more than 600,000 visitors a year -- is forcing the city's hand and limiting its options, city planners say.
The executive director of the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency, Edward Musante, said he still prefers the Reed-Putnam plan. "I like historic buildings," he said, "I consider myself a preservationist, but the problem is, we desperately need more parking and there just aren't a lot of places to put it."
Mr. Musante insisted the council had been made aware of the $3.4 million in money and $2 million in land that would go to the developer -- and denied that the $3.4 million is a subsidy, explaining, "That money will not be going into the developer's pockets, it will be used to insure that parking fees are kept reasonable so that people will be able to afford to park down there. He added that "the problem with this situation is there are so many competing interests involved here it would be very difficult, if not impossible, to satisfy everyone."
But Artspace, which has helped preserve and develop 75 artists' communities around the country, is trying. The group is working on a proposal it plans to present within the next few weeks that some artists and Artspace officials estimate will cost at least $11 million. Mr. Velasco said that they were trying to blend the best elements of the Reed-Putnam plan with one that would save the building and continue providing affordable space for the artists.
Mr. Velasco coninued, saying that, "It would mean a lot of hard work and we would have to raise a great deal of money, probably from a variety of private, philanthropic and government sources, and a lot of things still have to fall in place. But it can be done, and the turnout in Connecticut was the best I have ever seen."
While the building has been in bankruptcy for several years, it is still being used for studios and lofts by about 40 artists, arts exhibitions, and a few businesses. The owners, two families that constitute Maritime Square, Inc., say they believe the artists contribute greatly to the fabric of the city, but aren't sure if the building is worth saving.
"We love the artists and what they have brought to the community," said an owner, Michael DiScala. "I'm just not sure they have to be in that particular building."
But the artists say they are committed to saving the building for its historic significance and for the sprawling space that is perfect for studios.
The structure, built in 1856 at the height of the industrial revolution, has been declared a state historic landmark. It may not look like much from the outside, but its 112,000 square feet include hardwood floors, 25-foot-high ceilings, and wide, wood-framed windows with beaming light.
With its view of the Long Island Sound and its site near the Metro-North railroad station, the Lock Building has become the hub of an artistic renaissance in the South Norwalk neighborhood where a micro-brewery, historic museum and new restaurants are chasing away the last vestiges of decay that once threatened to make the area a slum.
Planners for the city say they are interested only in what is best for the city and community, and that with more than $30 million invested in the Aquarium and with the real estate market booming again, the redevelopment plans need to move ahead soon. "We can't sit on this forever," said Mayor Frank Esposito, a supporter of the current plan who said he was now willing, however, to consider alternatives after the recent outpouring of support to save the Lock Building.
City planners say they are keeping an open mind too, but still believe the current plan has the most benefits.
The city's assistant director of redevelopment, John Burritt, said, "We're not opposed to taking another look at this, and I don't know that anything is ever cast in concrete until a final contract has been signed, but frankly we think the original plan is still the best one for the community. The aquarium is expanding and parking is shrinking."
But city council leaders say the artists make a strong case.
"It is indeed rare to see this vigorous a display of public support for any project," said Mr. Nolin, "and there is no question we may be able to find a better plan that could include saving the building."
Tom Becker, a president of the SoNo Business Association Inc., which represents more than 200 businesses in South Norwalk, said his group's board voted recently to ask the city to review the entire redevelopment plan. "We're not convinced this building has to be torn down," said Mr. Becker.
"That plan may have made sense years ago when it was originally designed, but we don't know if it's the best way to go anymore -- even for the business community."

HEADLINE: Grumman Retirees Win but Don't Rejoice

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
IN its glory years, the Grumman Corporation built planes that helped win World War II, and its lunar module won the space race by landing the first man on the moon.
The company propelled Long Island's economy for decades as its leading private employer, peaking in 1986 with a work force of 25,000. And in the hearts of the thousands of workers who benefited from its model paternalism, Grumman felt more like a family than a corporation. 
 But all that changed in 1994 when the ailing company was taken over by the Northrop Corporation. Employees were forced out of their jobs by the thousands, and benefits were slashed for the few who remained.
The involuntary retirees fought back. Claiming they had lost hundreds of millions of dollars, they filed a class action suit against the newly merged Northrop Grumman. They sought restitution of pension and severance benefits, reinstatement in their jobs and back pay. About 16,000 retirees and employees were notified of the suit; about 11,000 joined it.
Now their battle of nearly five years has reached a bittersweet conclusion.
Judge Thomas C. Platt of Federal District Court in Uniondale issued an order on March 24 approving a settlement under which Northrop Grumman will pay $6 million -- a fraction of what the retirees claimed they had lost. With up to a third of that amount reserved for legal fees, the individual payments would average a few hundred dollars apiece.
"Our settlement is totally, totally inadequate, by any standard," said one retiree, Pericles C. Tsombanis of Huntington Station. A 31-year veteran of Grumman, he was an electronics engineering supervisor earning "in the high 60's plus overtime" when he was forced out. Based on a preliminary formula, he estimates that individual payments will range from $83 to $2,400, and he expects to get about $1,400. "It is no way fair. It hurts. You gave all these years, and this is what their thanks is. It's an absolute horror. The plaintiffs were basically exploited for a legal fee."
Even the lead plaintiff named in the suit, Bob Walsh, said he felt betrayed. An engineer living in Melbourne, Fla., he estimated that he lost $70,000 in the Northrop takeover.
Although the opposition is vocal, it is relatively small, according to a lawyer for the retirees, Karl J. Stoecker. "Relatively few have that view," he said. "Most people seem to view it favorably." About 400 of the 11,000 lodged objections, most of them on two petitions, he said.
Northrop Grumman admitted no wrongdoing, a routine disclaimer in out-of-court settlements. The company, in a press release, said it settled "to avoid further cost of litigation and disruption to the company." The company declined to further discuss the case.
The judge's order started the clock running on a 30-day period for parties to file notice of appeal, but the legal fees in such a complex case and the possibility of years of litigation are daunting. Mr. Stoecker said of an appeal's chances, "I think it would be a long shot."
Litigants looking for their payments will have to wait. "There's a lot that still has to be done," Mr. Stoecker said. "The distribution is pretty complicated. It will take several months to compute the final figures and send out the checks."
Judge Platt presided over an 18-day trial of the case, with 20 witnesses and 140 exhibits, which ended early last year. He reserved decision and urged the two sides to compromise, saying a settlement would spare them further litigation and avoid the risk of their losing in court. They eventually agreed in December and submitted their proposal for his approval.
"It is clear that the proposed settlement is both fair and reasonable in view of the significant obstacles each side would have to overcome to succeed on the merits," Judge Platt ruled.
The decision offered consolation to both sides. Referring to the company, the judge wrote: "While the defendants claim no wrongdoing and apparently are not happy with this negotiated settlement, they recognize the extensive problems, expense and delay associated with further litigation."
Sympathizing with the workers, the judge also said: "A significant number of plaintiffs, on the other hand, claim that they are outraged at their treatment by, and claimed wrongdoing of, defendants and assert the settlement is grossly inadequate, particularly when it is divided among the thousands of claimants. While this court recognizes the legitimacy of plaintiffs' claims that they fell victim to defendants' perceived wrongdoings, proof of legal liability and proximately caused damage in excess of the $6 million amount is another matter."
Without a settlement, the judge wrote, the retirees "would still face the possibility of hundreds of trials to establish damages for a great many if not all of the class members" in the case.
The suit was partly based on a Grumman severance policy adopted in 1990 to protect employees and fend off a takeover. It guaranteed a week's pay for every year worked to employees who lost their jobs in the first 30 months of a new ownership. Grumman changed the policy in 1993 to apply only to hostile takeovers.
The next year, the Martin Marietta Corporation and Northrop competed to buy Grumman. Nearly a third of its stock was held by the Grumman Employee Investment Plan on behalf of workers and retirees. The plan's three trustees joined Grumman's other major stockholders in accepting Northrop's offer of $62 a share, $22 above the market price at the time.
The new management announced in September 1994 that it was abolishing severance pay at the end of that year and reducing future pension benefits. But it offered severance to anyone who quit the company by Dec. 8. Those who stayed faced an uncertain tenure with no severance and smaller pensions.
"It wasn't a good deal for employees," said Mr. Stoecker. Many workers felt forced out, and they filed suit that November.
Among their arguments was that the takeover was hostile. They also contended that the investment trustees breached their fiduciary duty in a conflict of interest because as executives they benefited from "golden parachutes" in the takeover. The suit said they should have deferred to an impartial trustee or left the decision to a vote of the employees and retirees. The critics also questioned whether the trustees got the best stock price. And they challenged the changes in pensions and severance.
The defense contended that Northrop Grumman, Grumman officials and the investment trustees had all acted within the law. Company officials testified that severance and pensions were subject to revision, and they doubted that the old policy could have been imposed on a new owner. Any losses suffered by retirees were offset by the $250 million paid to the investment plan for the stock, the company said, and the plan's trustees had no obligation to pursue the severance issue.
"Defendants made a strong argument that Grumman retained the ability to terminate the severance plan with impunity, or without liability to anyone," Judge Platt wrote. "When one adds to all of the above uncertainties of the innumerable appeals on the various disputed issues of fact and law, and the expense and time thereof, the proposed settlement, while not very appealing to any of the parties, appears to be eminently fair and reasonable."
Life was much simpler when Leroy R. Grumman and his partners started their tiny plane-repair company in 1930. Defying the Depression, their plucky enterprise blossomed into a giant Navy contractor that built fighter, bomber, reconnaissance and cargo planes used in every major conflict from World War II through the fighting now in Yugoslavia.
Although Grumman's sales topped out at $4 billion in 1990, its demise started earlier with the fall of Communism and the other dominoes that followed: the end of the Cold War, the slashing of military and space budgets and the collapse of the aerospace industry.
Today, 2,500 Northrop Grumman workers are left on Long Island, said the company's spokesman, Richard C. Dunne. The company's former 3,000-acre site at Calverton is being redeveloped, and 450 of its 600 acres in Bethpage are being converted to various office and industrial uses, a police helicopter hangar and 500 homes for the elderly.
One intangible casualty of all the changes was the intense loyalty that the old Grumman fostered. Each employee had a number, and a low one proudly signified long seniority. People with difficult illnesses were sent to the Mayo Clinic at company expense. There were birthday cards, Christmas turkeys, bouquets for spouses, scholarships for children, the "green car service" for flat tires and the world's biggest company picnic, according to the Guinness Book of Records.
"It felt good to work for them, very, very satisfying, a great sense of pride," recalled Mr. Tsombanis, who never found another steady job and still attends annual Grumman reunions. "There was a great sense of caring and security." Returning to the present, he said: "This is so counter to the Grumman reputation, to come down to this. Well, this is the new look. It's happening to everyone, it seems."

HEADLINE: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

BYLINE: By MAUREEN C. MUENSTER

 BODY:

PARK SLOPE
Music Is Bach and African: The Rest Is All Brooklyn
Multiethnic and multigenerational (with performers from age 3 to 73), Spoke the Hub Dancing will begin its 20th anniversary season this weekend and next with old and new theater works by Elise Long, the artistic director, in the "Local Produce Festival of the Performing Arts." 
 All performers are artists and teachers from Brooklyn. Ms. Long will present the premiere of her new dance production, "Balsamic Brooklyn," set to music of Bach and West Africa. At right is a scene from "Balsamic Brooklyn," in which, Ms. Long says, the young girl shown is "projecting the daily life lessons learned from her parents onto her doll."
"Local Produce Festival of the Performing Arts," performed by Spoke the Hub Dancing; Old First Reformed Church, Seventh Avenue and Carroll Street, Park Slope; two different programs, Friday through Sunday and April 30 through May 2; Fridays and Saturdays at 7:30 P.M., Sundays at 5 P.M.; $12 for adults, $5 for children 12 and under and people 60 and older; a complete schedule is available by calling (718) 857-5158.
 
UPPER EAST SIDE
Solving Family Problems At a Hotel in the 1830's
Next Sunday, visitors to the Abigail Adams Smith Museum and Gardens can take part in a musical play set in 1830, "Fare for All," and meet these characters: James Woodhull, keeper of the Mount Vernon Hotel; his daughter, Sarah, and son, George; Flora, a freed slave who worked at the hotel, and James Stuart, a visitor from Scotland.
The characters are based on historical fact and the musical deals with social, economic and cultural transitions of that period. Geared for children, the play will invite audience members to help the characters solve their problems.
"Fare for All," next Sunday at 1:30 P.M. and 3:30 P.M.; Abigail Adams Smith Museum and Gardens, 421 East 61st Street, between First and York Avenues; $5, $3 for children under 12 (price includes museum tour); reservations recommended; (212) 838-6878.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Starting the Rehabilitation Journey at Parkchester

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
AT the annual meeting of the South condominium of the sprawling Parkchester housing complex in the Bronx last January, Howard Hall made a vehement speech. He said he bought an apartment last November and was deeply dissatisfied with the conditions he found when he moved in. "If I have to pay a few more dollars to fix the place up, I'm for it!" he declared.
Half an hour later the balloting closed on the issue that brought him to his feet: whether to accept a far-reaching rehabilitation proposal by the Parkchester Preservation Company L.L.C. Last year the partnership bought the Parkchester holdings of the late Harry B. Helmsley, who sponsored its conversion from a rental into the North condominium in 1974 and the South condominium in 1986. Approval required a two-thirds vote. 
 The final count showed that 73 percent of the ownership interest had voted for the plan. Most of the affirmative vote came from Parkchester Preservation itself, which holds a 62 percent stake in the South condominium, mainly in apartments, but also including stores. But even among the nonsponsor residential owners who voted, the margin was 3 to 1 in favor -- 12 percent to 4 percent. There was no vote from owners representing a 22 percent stake.
In the South condominium there are 8,286 apartments, of which Parkchester Preservation owns 4,781. The voting is not one-apartment, one-vote, however. As in a co-op, the apartments' vote shares are based on their size and other factors.
Now, three weeks after Supreme Court Justice Anne E. Targum dismissed a challenge to the vote by a minority faction of unit owners, a $123 million rehabilitation program is getting under way. It will go on for two to three years. If in coming months the North condominium decides to embrace the program, construction work at Parkchester will be in progress for four years.
A plumbing and electrical upgrade, plus new windows, are the key parts of the program. It is perhaps the most ambitious and complex community preservation effort ever undertaken in New York City -- new financing for systems replacements in a large-scale, moderate-income condominium, and one with limited ability to borrow on its own in the private financial market.
Parkchester apartments had been failing to maintain their value, buyer and lender interest was diminishing and residents were plagued by plumbing and electrical failures. Most owners in the South condominium agreed with Mr. Hall that an infusion of capital and management capability was required. In fact, Parkchester board members said at the annual meeting that the condominium could not on its own have attracted the private-sector financing that was needed.
Parkchester Preservation owns 500,000 square feet of retail space, four parking garages and -- above all -- 6,391 never-sold apartments in the two condominiums, which have a total of 12,271 apartments.
"The rental market has already improved since the vote, because people know that renovations will take place," said Kumar Kancherla, president of the South condominium. "The sales market has also improved." Mr. Kancherla is an electrical engineer with New York City Transit who lives near Parkchester and owns or manages about 150 apartments there. He said that market prices were currently about half what they were 10 years ago when outsiders were paying $55,000 for one-bedroom units.
Parkchester Preservation Company is a partnership of two real-estate investors, Morton L. Olshan and Jeremiah W. O'Connor Jr., and CPC Resources, the for-profit subsidiary of the Community Preservation Corporation. The corporation is a lending consortium that specializes in rehabilitation-oriented multifamily housing in moderate-income neighborhoods.
"We felt there was a need for an entity to assume ownership when a major property is going downhill and there is no appropriate ownership to take hold," said Michael D. Lappin, president of the preservation corporation. CPC Resources was created to pursue such ventures. Because of the size and scope of the Parkchester undertaking two experienced partners were found to come aboard.
THE partnership has established another entity, Parkchester Preservation Management, as a joint venture with Ashton Management L.L.C., to lease and manage its apartments. The principals in Ashton Management are Linda Field and Stephen Warren. Ms. Field is also the principal in a separate company, Ashton Management, which owns or manages 1,700 apartments in the Bronx. Mall Properties, in which Mr. Olshan is the principal, is handling the commercial leasing.
Parkchester Management is now in the process of improving and renting out those of its vacancies that are in buildings not involved in the early phases of renovation work, Ms. Field said. Over the next year about 750 vacancies will be filled, she said. No immediate sales program is planned.
On Parkchester Preservation's recommendation the South condominium selected Wagman Construction Company of Valley Stream, N.Y., as the construction manager. Moving two buildings at a time and beginning with window replacement, Mr. Wagman said, workers will wend their way through Parkchester's housing clusters, starting at the Unionport Road entrance off Westchester Avenue.
The new casement windows have been designed and manufactured by Efco Corporation of Monett, Mo.
"All the plumbing lines will be replaced and we'll upgrade the electrical service with new risers," Mr. Wagman said. The new wiring will increase residents' electrical capacity fourfold, he said. During construction residents will not have to move out but they must be prepared for two weeks of domestic inconvenience, he said.
The apartments will get individual electric meters, and unit owners will be able to install air-conditioning. Individual metering will assure that those who use most electricity will pay for it, while those who use less will get the benefit of thriftiness, said Kathleen A. Dunn, project director for the Parkchester Preservation Corporation.
Ms. Dunn, former development director of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, noted that legislation enacted last year would enable the city to prorate the contemplated J-51 tax benefit for all apartments in advance of completion, essential in a project of this scope. The tax abatement lets the condominium handle renovation costs without excessive increases in monthly charges.
Negotiations are under way for Consolidated Edison to take over responsibility for maintaining the subsurface electrical lines, Ms. Dunn said. The condominiums inherited a situation in which they have that responsibility, and must contract out the work. This has led both to burdensome costs and undermaintenance, Ms. Dunn said.
With electricity excluded, residents' net housing costs are expected to rise on average $30 to $35 a month. This takes into account increases attributable to the improvements, and decreases attributable to the J-51 tax abatement. Con Ed has told the sponsor that the average cost per apartment for those with air-conditioning, based on the utility's experience in similar housing, is about $44 a month, Ms. Dunn said.
UNIT owners will also be able to refinance their mortgages -- a prospect that has been difficult for many years -- through arrangements made by the Community Preservation Corporation. With banks making new mortgages and refinancing old ones, many resident owners will probably be able to improve their financial situation significantly, Ms. Dunn said. There are an estimated 3,000 resident owners in Parkchester's two condominiums.
To soften the impact on older residents, a subsidy fund will be established by the sponsor for resident owners who were 62 or older as of July 1, 1998. If the income of these owners is, or ever becomes, less than $25,000 a year (plus an inflation factor calculated from last July), the sponsor may pay a portion of their maintenance costs.
The subsidy will be based on the net increase in maintenance costs attributable to the rehabilitation, plus an allowance for utility usage. The expectation is that a substantial proportion of the older owners in the South condominium will qualify, Ms. Dunn said, and get financial aid of anywhere from $45 to $100 a month.
Some time this year the North condominium is expected to vote on the rehabilitation plan. In the North condominium, the Parkchester Preservation Corporation owns only a 40 percent interest (and 1,610 out of 3,985 apartments). A positive vote by 45 percent of the nonsponsor ownership would provide a two-thirds majority.
A committee is currently evaluating the proposal, said Harry L. Brown, the retired postmaster of Hartsdale, N.Y., and a 25-year Parkchester resident who was elected board president of the North condominium last year. But he himself already supports it. "We're in bad shape right now," Mr. Brown said. "We need to accept this plan."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In / Prospect Heights, Brooklyn;
A Diverse Neighborhood Spruces Up in a Turnaround

BYLINE: By ROBERT WALZER 

 BODY:
IN the eyes of many Prospect Heights residents, the Alcazar is a metaphor for the change the neighborhood is undergoing.
Four years ago the prewar rental building at 347-365 Lincoln Place was a dilapidated, half-vacant eyesore with broken windows, fire damage and erratic hot water service. 
 The Chase Manhattan Bank foreclosed on the building and sold it to the BFC Construction Corporation of Manhattan for $540,000 in 1995. A year later the five-story, 54-unit building was renovated, its red brick gleaming alongside the restored stone portico and marble entrance. It is now fully occupied with a three-year waiting list.
"It used to be a drug-infested nightmare," said Joseph Ferrara, BFC's vice president. "Now the whole block has had an amazing turnaround."
Two decades after an economic downturn left Prospect Heights spotted with shuttered and abandoned buildings, the neighborhood is undergoing a revival. Newcomers are renovating long-neglected brownstones and Vanderbilt Avenue, a main commercial streets, new tenants trickle in as existing merchants spruce up their facades.
Prospect Heights has always lived in the shadow of the renowned Park Slope. But with Slope prices surpassing $1 million for the most desirable buildings, more buyers are looking at Prospect Heights, where prices for comparable buildings are 20 to 40 percent less, brokers said.
"We get a lot of the spillover from Park Slope, that is, people who can't afford the Slope but want a nearby neighborhood with similar amenities," said Karin A. Haerter, who manages the Park Sterling Brokerage Ltd. in Prospect Heights.
Yet Prospect Heights's ambiance is decidedly different from its wealthier neighbor. Nearly a quarter of households report under $15,000 in annual income, and another quarter earn $50,000 to $99,000. Culturally and racially, Prospect Heights is more diverse, with Caribbean immigrants and their descendants forming its backbone.
About 14 block-, merchant and residents' associations help "make it feel like a close little community," said John Policastro, who owns the Garden Cafe on Vanderbilt Avenue and Prospect Place. The Vanderbilt Avenue Merchants Association last year reinstated an annual block party after 15 years, said Duke Saunders, one of its organizers. Other organizations clean up graffiti, put fencing around tree bases and raise money for after-school programs.
Brokers say newcomers -- many of them professionals from Manhattan in their 20's and 30's -- tend to buy a building, rent out part of it and live in the rest.
Natasha Sweeten, an artist, and her husband, John Haskell, a freelance editor, bought a three-story brownstone in Prospect Heights late last year. The recently married couple needed more space, but the area they most wanted, Carroll Gardens, was too costly. So they bought a deteriorated building on Carleton Avenue for $220,000 and are spending $80,000 more to renovate it, while renting out part of it. "It was nice to come here and feel you're living in a neighborhood and not a mall," said Ms. Sweeten, who had rented a studio in SoHo before moving to Brooklyn.
Besides its brownstones and limestone and brick town houses, there is also a smattering of carriage houses and freestanding mansions, as well as about 9,000 apartments, many former rentals converted in the 80's to co-ops, and a handful of condominiums.
CO-OP units in less desirable buildings and blocks still sell for below the peak reached in the 1980's, brokers said.
But co-ops on the prime residential blocks -- such as those along Eastern Parkway, Plaza Street and Park and St. Johns Place -- are selling briskly. Brokers said two-bedroom co-ops on those streets go for $150,000 to $280,000.
Annie Rose, a broker with Joseph Berman Realty in Park Slope, said a two-bedroom apartment she sold in 1997 on Eastern Parkway for $124,000 just resold for $180,000. And James Cornell, a broker with Warren Lewis Realty Associates, said that five years ago he was "pulling teeth" to sell a co-ops in a building on Plaza Street for $115,000. Yet some months ago he sold a unit there for $215,000 the same day it went on the market after it received four offers above the asking price.
 The prices of brownstones are also spiraling upward. In what amounts to an apparent record for Prospect Heights, one four-story home went into contract this month at "a little higher than $750,000," said Mary Ann Albano, sales manager of the William B. May Company in Park Slope. And, she added, at least two other building sales surpassed $600,000 in the last year.
Residents value the easily accessible subway, bus and rail links and the neighborhood's proximity to major cultural institutions: the Brooklyn Museum of Art, the main branch of the Brooklyn Public Library, the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Also at its border is the 526-acre Prospect Park, where a lively food market takes place on Saturdays.
In addition to Flatbush and Vanderbilt Avenue's stores, residents shop at the Atlantic Center, whose developer, Forest City Ratner, has received approval to build a $180 million shopping center alongside that Atlantic Avenue site.
The neighborhood's eating establishments include the Dean Street Garden Cafe, which serves light American fare and has live music and outdoor seating in the summer. Residents have also enjoyed an old-fashioned diner, Tom's Restaurant, since 1936.
Education options within the neighborhood are limited. Elementary school pupils are zoned for one public school, P.S. 9, where only 37.5 percent of children through sixth grade read at or above grade level last year. That placed it 500th of 674 city elementary schools in ranking, said Arthur Nieves, an assistant to the superintendent of Community School District 13.
Middle-school opportunities are somewhat better. The Park Place Community Middle School, formerly the St. Augustine Catholic School, opened in September after a remodeling that left its stained-glass windows intact. The well-regarded school with 200 students has a waiting list to enter. "It has a very small, intimate environment which some people like," said Yvette Douglass, deputy superintendent of District 13.
OF the four other middle schools zoned for Prospect Heights children, reading achievement is highest in I.S. 113, where 61.7 percent of its students read at or above their grade levels last year, ranking 51st of 235 middle schools citywide.
Prospect Heights students are served by five high schools, including Prospect Heights High School, which has a prelaw program. Clara Barton High School, another nearby option, specializes in nursing careers.
Last June, 83.4 percent of Prospect Heights High School's 283 seniors and 92.5 percent of Clara Barton's 398-student graduating class went on to higher education.
The neighborhood got a smear of notoriety last March because of the slaying of Amy Watkins, a 26-year-old student studying social work at Hunter College. But Hubie Raton, community affairs officer with the 77th Police Precinct, called the neighborhood safer than most and characterized the murder as "a pretty isolated incident."
Prospect Heights was initially part of the Revolutionary War neighborhood known as Crow Hill, which was inhabited by freed slaves. Development gained ground in the 1870's, after Prospect Park was completed, and the area was first called Prospect Heights in 1892. Unlike Park Slope, which developers built cohesively, Prospect Heights "mushroomed in a mishmash of styles and locations," said Ronald A. McLaren, a local broker and architect.
UNTIL World War II, Prospect Heights's Italian and Irish residents were mainly middle class, with wealthier Jews living along Eastern Parkway. As those groups filtered out to suburbia, American blacks and, later, West Indians replaced them, at first occupying Prospect Heights's rooming houses.
The neighborhood underwent a depressed period in the 60's and 70's, when the Federal Housing Administration foreclosed on some residential buildings, and many merchants along Washington Avenue shuttered their stores. In the last two decades, most of the neglected structures in central Prospect Heights have been renovated and in a border area along Pacific and Dean Streets developers are starting to gobble up empty industrial buildings.
In one project, the New York City Housing Partnership is leading the development of a $12 million complex that includes 30 new three-family homes on Bergen Street. The partnership is getting financing from New York City and State as well as private funds, said a spokesman, Justin Blake.
In another transaction, investors including Manhattan-based Shaya B. Developers Inc. bought the former Daily News printing plant on an industrial strip of Pacific Street between Carlton Avenue and Sixth Avenue and are planning a commercial development, possibly with a theater complex, and including apartments above if the proper zoning can be obtained.
Speaking of the industrial buildings in the border area on Dean and Pacific Streets Mr. McLaren said: "It's the last large concentrated amount of square footage in brownstone Brooklyn. These are no handyman specials. You need to have sophistication in navigating city bureaucracy to make them work."

Duncan, the architect of Grant's Tomb, and sculptures were later added by the Brooklyn-born sculptor Frederick MacMonnies. The sculptures are of Lincoln and Grant, along with allegorical figures representing soldiers and sailors. LENGTH: 788 words

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Managing When Profit Isn't the Goal

BYLINE: By TODD COHEN 

 BODY:
NONPROFIT organizations, long known as an invisible sector in the economy, have grown rapidly over the last two decades, now accounting for 8 percent of the gross domestic product.
To meet the rising demand for trained leaders for these groups, a number of universities are offering graduate programs in nonprofit management. 
 "It's not enough to only want to do good; you have to do good well," said Michael Seltzer, acting chairman of the master's program in nonprofit management at the New School University in Manhattan.
The number of charitable nonprofit groups grew from 82,000 in 1975 to 181,000 in 1995, the most recent data available, according to the Internal Revenue Service. And in the last decade, the number of American universities offering three or more graduate courses in nonprofit management has grown from 17 to 82, say researchers at Seton Hall University, which offers a program of its own. Other universities with big nonprofit programs include Auburn, Boston University, De Paul and Notre Dame.
The programs do have their critics, who contend, among other things, that they have too narrow a focus for students who may switch fields later.
Still, the surge in degree programs reflects rising competition for support from foundations, corporations and government, which increasingly expect nonprofits to be more professional, said Alan J. Abramson, director of the Nonprofit Sector Research Fund of the Aspen Institute in Washington.
People who move to nonprofit work from business or government jobs may have leadership experience, Mr. Abramson said, but they may want more training in nonprofit issues.
Consider Jeff Aulenbach. Two years ago, he worked for the mental health department in New York City, managing contracts with nonprofit groups. He wanted to work for a nonprofit, but lacked the skills he thought necessary. So he enrolled part-time in the master's program at the New School.
A year later, while still taking classes, he landed a job as executive director of the Variety Boys and Girls Club of Queens. "I could not have gotten the job without the program," Mr. Aulenbach said.
Last month, he moved to a larger organization, as assistant executive director of the Gloria Wise Boys and Girls Club in the Bronx. He expects to finish the New School program next year.
Mr. Aulenbach said classes on topics like financial planning and marketing taught him "every issue that an executive director needs to deal with." At Gloria Wise, he applies lessons of his leadership class to help program directors work together after a string of mergers.
Many of the students are nonprofit managers who take classes part-time, with assignments often focusing on their real jobs.
"Because I was in classes with nonprofit managers all the time, I understood what the day-to-day challenges of working in a nonprofit were like," said Armanda Famiglietti, a 1993 New School graduate who manages grants for the Carnegie Corporation.
 NOT everyone is impressed with a nonprofit-management degree. Peter Dobkin Hall, director of Yale Divinity School's program on nonprofit organizations, called the credential "a degree of unproven and dubious value," explaining, "there is no such thing as generic nonprofit management." His program focuses on research rather than on teaching management skills.
To accommodate job-switching, he said, "you want to give people portable skills, skills that are as applicable to the public sector as to the business sector or the nonprofit sector."
Pablo Eisenberg, senior fellow at the Georgetown University Public Policy Institute, said nonprofit graduate programs tend to focus on internal issues like fund-raising and accounting, not on external issues like collaboration with business and government. "Most of them are really creating technicians, " Mr. Eisenberg said. The programs do not address a "crisis of leadership," he added.
Proponents like Mr. Seltzer of the New School say the curriculum is guided by student demand. This semester, he is teaching a course in advocacy, public policy and social change. This fall, he plans to begin training nonprofit managers to make better use of computers and the Internet.
The field of nonprofit studies is still relatively young. But some pioneers who have built their careers on such training now recommend it to others.
Dale Needles, now vice president for finance and administration at the Hispanic Scholarship Fund, has used the skills he learned at the University of San Francisco to manage organizations in the arts, international development and education. "Having that degree definitely helps in opening doors," he said. "Going through a program like that gave me a sound footing."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 2; Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
It's the Sprawl, Stupid. The Economy's Always Good.

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson reports from New Jersey for The New York Times.

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
The governor is running for the United States Senate, and in her campaign she will remind voters how much the state's economy has improved since she took office in 1994. Quite a change from her early days in State House, when she frequently worried aloud about the New Jersey's competitiveness with the Carolinas and points south.
The Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, meanwhile, will inherit the governorship, on an acting basis at least, if Mrs. Whitman wins in November, and he, too, makes note of the fine state of the economy in his publicity material. 
 Benefiting from a strong economy seems to be a perk of office when times are good, just as paying for a slump is a cost of incumbency in hard times. And now that things have been good for so long, we may see school board candidates -- don't forget to vote on Tuesday -- campaigning on their abilities as educators and for keeping mortgage rates low. But will voters always reward state candidates for a sound economy?
New Jersey is now in the 83d consecutive month of economic expansion since the last recession ended in May 1992, which means that this month, the state has matched in length the boom of the 1980's, which ran from 1982 to 1989. But while the 80's boom was fading as Gov. Thomas H. Kean was approaching the end of his second term, the roaring 90's show no sign of diminishing, and economists from the Federal Reserve to James H. Hughes, dean of the Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers, are starting to talk about the advent of a new economic paradigm, one where the efficiency of computer-driven global markets have ironed the cyclical wrinkles out of the economy.
So the question arises: Who gets credit when prosperity is permanent? Clearly the Whitman administration's corporate tax cuts and regulatory reforms deserve prominent mention in the record of job expansion in New Jersey, with 400,000 new jobs in the state since 1992 easily making up for the 262,000 jobs lost in the recession of 1989 to 1992.
And here's another factoid from Mr. Hughes that describes the growth of the new information-based employment boom in New Jersey: 80 percent of all the office space ever built in the state went up in the 1980's, and when the additional 110 million square feet were added to that base in the current boom, New Jersey's 11 northern counties, from Mercer and Monmouth north, have between them erected as much office space as all of metropolitan Houston.
Clearly there is a general sense in which a good economy helps incumbents, or, as Maurice Carroll, director of the Quinnipiace Poll put it, "Good economic numbers are good news for people in power."
But that is not the same thing as giving an office-holder the kind of specific credit that candidates seem to want, which is the kind of credit that can be applied against negative effects of other problems.
That, at least, is what Cliff Zukin, director of the Star-Ledger/Eagleton Poll, discovered when he tried to find out why the governor, with universal name recognition and the benefits of both the incumbency and a strong economy, nearly lost to Jim McGreevey in 1997.
"We devoted nearly five minutes to questions about perceptions of the governor in our February 1998 poll," Mr. Zukin said, "and the bottom line is that she does not get much credit for what's going right in the state because what's going right tends to be seen as Federal issues, but she does get blamed for what's going wrong."
So only 23 percent of Mr. Zukin's respondents gave the governor credit for the healthy state economy, but 49 percent blamed her for high automobile insurance rates, and only 19 percent gave her credit for low unemployment, but 42 percent blamed her for high property taxes.
Add one other intangible: in the 1980's, when Governor Keane was winning 80 percent approval ratings, New Jersey's real estate values jumped by 150 percent, and people felt rich. The new boom has not brought the same housing feeding frenzy, and many homeowners who bought at the peak may still owe more on their houses than the houses are worth. "Negative equity," as this situation is called, can have a depressing effect on any homeowner's political outlook.
Mr. Hughes suggests that with the economy effectively off the table as a campaign slogan, the voters start to look around at other measures of political success. When New Jerseyans do that, they see traffic congestion -- 400,000 new jobs equals 400,000 more cars -- less open space, less sense of community -- all items that show up as sources of voter dissatisfaction.
"In 1982 the Clinton campaign was famous for saying, "It's the economy, stupid," Mr. Hughes remarked. "But with the economy doing so well, the next campaign slogan might better be, "It's the sprawl, stupid."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 717 words

HEADLINE: THE RIGHT THING;
When Fear Of Firing Deters Hiring

BYLINE: By JEFFREY L. SEGLIN; Jeffrey L. Seglin is a visiting fellow at Harvard University's Center for the Study of Values in Public Life. His column on business ethics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to: righthng@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
OVER the last few years, several people have spoken to me about their reluctance to hire people whose race, color, creed or national origin -- or age, disability or sex -- put them in protected classes under anti-discrimination law.
The reasoning goes this way: You have to be absolutely sure that someone in a protected class is the best possible candidate, because people in these categories can make your life miserable with litigation if you ever have to dismiss them. 
 "It's a dirty little secret" that people are thinking this way, said Tama Starr, president of Artkraft Strauss, a sign-making company in New York, and one of the few business people who has spoken out on the subject. Those who subscribe to these ideas "have to choose between different protected classes and weigh the risk of hiring them," she said, adding, "This is a very obnoxious way to think."
Managers tread on swampy ethical terrain when they allow fear of possible problems to deter them from hiring apparently capable minority applicants -- or to hesitate so long over a decision that a candidate loses interest or gives up in frustration.
The fear of discrimination suits is not wholly groundless. A 1997 survey conducted by the Society for Human Resource Management found that of 616 personnel executives who responded, 53 percent said their organizations had been sued at least once by former employees in the last five years; nearly half the 611 suits they reported involved claims of discrimination.
But Martha R. A. Fields, chief executive of Fields Associates, a management consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., says the risk of a suit is often an excuse that masks a deeper motive for not hiring people in protected classes. It is more likely, Ms. Fields said, that managers really just feel safer hiring people like themselves.
Some people, she said, find it easy to think to themselves: "If I know people who are like me, I know the good, bad, and the ugly about them. If I don't know them and I see images of them in the media, I'm, like, 'Oh man, those black people, they might be welfare-dependent, or criminals, or crime victims. I don't know if I really want to bring that into my organization.' "
Increasingly, such bias is economically irrational as well as unethical. "The demographics of this country are shifting in major ways," Ms. Fields noted, as minority groups, especially Hispanic people, account for a rapidly growing share of the population and its purchasing power. "Consumers want to see people like themselves in organizations," Ms. Fields said.
Another underlying problem is managers who are poor at managing. Some who speak these fears are simply afraid to fire anyone -- not just someone in a protected class -- and shy away from situations they perceive as requiring them to take a chance.
To avoid hiring problem employees from any group, managers just "need to do a good job of checking resumes, identifying the time gaps and verifying simple facts," said Mary C. Dollarhide, an employment lawyer with Paul, Hastings, Janofsky & Walker in Stamford, Conn. For $200 to $300, a manager can also get a criminal background check on a candidate and a docket search to see if he or she often files lawsuits. "If you do your due diligence, you're going to stand a much better chance of not bringing in the gripers, complainers, bad actors and poor performers," Ms. Dollarhide said.
BUT a thorough screening does not absolve managers of having to manage. "If you get somebody in your midst whom you fail to discipline because you're afraid you're going to get slammed for having reprimanded someone in a protected class, well, guess what: The failure to do that is going to land you in exactly the same spot," Ms. Dollarhide said. "If the employee is terminated, he can sue and you're left with no records to support your case."
Much sound management translates into ethical behavior. Employees who are treated fairly, honestly and directly are both less likely to require dismissal and less likely to sue over it later.
That frees everyone to concentrate on the business they enjoy. "I still believe that people are good and honest and they want to do a nice job," said Ms. Starr of Artkraft. "Having to fight through more stupidity just hampers everybody's humanity."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Nancy Doniger)

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
Stepping Back, to Go Forward

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY 

DATELINE: STOUGHTON, Mass.

 BODY:
IN 1998, the National Basketball Association players were locked out and buyers of athletic shoes went on strike. Hurt by changing fashions, foreign recessions and the job dispute that gave the league's shoe spokesmen a collective bad name, shoemakers saw their earnings plunge. As a result, Reebok, for one, lost more than half its stock market value last year.
So in December, Reebok called in its ace: Angel Martinez. He had pulled Reebok out from Nike's shadow in the 1980's, when he created the aerobic-workout shoe. And as chief executive of Rockport, Reebok's street shoe subsidiary, the last four years, he even managed to convince younger shoppers that their grandfathers' clunky brown shoes could be sexy. 
 Now Reebok is waiting to see what magic Mr. Martinez, as its new marketing director, can create for its flagship brand. Should he do well, he could eventually succeed Paul Fireman as chief executive.
Mr. Martinez says he wants to put the humanity back into Reebok and its products. Instead of sitting grimly at computers, he says, employees should spend more time jamming, both on the company basketball court and in a company jazz band he hopes to revive.
He talks of making customers feel good not only about their shoes, but also about the benevolent athletes who promote the products and the workers who made them under what he calls more humane conditions than past industry practice. While some analysts say Reebok's foreign factories treat workers better than most in those countries, some human-rights groups call for far higher wages.
Mr. Martinez, from Reebok's headquarters in this suburb south of Boston, announces the end of the hype. "Yes, we did go through that period where you had to have the athlete with the giant contract slam-dunking in the N.B.A. or doing incredible things in the Olympics to sell any shoes," he said. "And that's not who we were. All we're doing now is going back to our roots."
Way back. It is hard to remember when this corporate giant was not spending more than $140 million a year on advertising, promoting gimmicks like shoes that inflated. But if there's a model for the down-to-earth company that Reebok now strives to be, it is Mr. Martinez.
A 43-year-old with close-cropped dark brown hair and a goatee, he wears a collarless dress shirt and a pair of the black Rockports he helped glamorize. He spoke frankly about the mind-set that brought Reebok to its present state.
"We've had an industry on steroids," he said. "It's been an industry that convinced itself that the average consumer out there was going to go from nine pairs a year of $100 shoes to 12 pairs a year of $100 shoes. And the consumer decided that no, maybe two pair a year was all they need."
No longer a strong challenger to Nike -- which has about 45 percent of the athletic footwear market to Reebok's 10 percent -- the company is depending on its new chunky DMX design for serious runners, a strong seller since it was introduced last year. But even as he discusses its virtues, Mr. Martinez freely acknowledges that the garish blue-and-chartreuse DMX in his hand is no thing of beauty.
"My first reaction was: 'Boy, that is ugly,' " he said. "But you know what happened? It happened for the Volkswagen Beetle, right? People buy it despite it being ugly. It feels so good that they buy it anyway."
Wall Street remains skeptical. John Shanley, an analyst with First Security Van Kasper, doubts that customers are looking for the softer side of Reebok. "We're talking about teen-age males, who have almost no sense of humanity," Mr. Shanley said. "They are basically looking for whatever is new, whatever is hottest."
Style was crucial when Mr. Martinez was a Reebok marketer in the 1980's. It was the start of the aerobics craze, and he saw that his wife, Frankie, would rather go barefoot to class than wear sneakers. "She didn't want to wear bulky, ugly-looking running shoes," he said. He convinced Mr. Fireman to promote a sleeker, yet very comfortable shoe just for women, and sales took off.
After marketing Reeboks for 14 years, he was sent by Mr. Fireman to head up the stagnant, tradition-bound Rockport in 1994. Linda Lewi, now Rockport's senior vice president for marketing, said Mr. Martinez had encouraged his workers to "get the hairballs out of the plumbing." Whether it was coming up with new styles or using less expensive materials, "he would be the evangelist for that idea, and really, people would want to suspend their disbelief and join him."
Mr. Fireman, 55, confirmed that the Rockport success had helped groom Mr. Martinez as his possible successor. Only one thing has changed about Mr. Martinez in 20 years, he said: "He gained weight. I knew him when he was running track and field and he was skinny. Now he's normal."
Mr. Martinez came to America from Cuba when he was 3, to live with his grandmother's sister in the Bronx. He remembers saving nickels to buy a $5.95 pair of Converse Chuck Taylors and walking home on the sides of his feet to keep the soles from getting dirty. Now he can afford toys like a Harley-Davidson and the Fender Stratocaster he might play in that company band.
But getting employees to loosen up at a headquarters where 100 colleagues were laid off last year is another matter. Mr. Martinez says he's not kidding when he tells them to shun E-mail in favor of real chat. "People weren't talking to each other; nobody was picking up the phone," he said. Pointing to his computer, he added, "I almost threw this thing out the window."
