HEADLINE: PRELUDES;
Temporarily Yours

BYLINE: By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money will appear the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
TEN years ago, I took a job stuffing envelopes. It was a necessity: I had just graduated from college and had no idea what I wanted to do with my life, but the lenders who had financed my college education weren't sympathetic to my existential crisis.
The job came through a temporary-employment agency, which paid me $7.25 an hour to cram manila envelopes with a company's pap. I lasted one day. 
 Since then, the temp world has changed dramatically. According to the National Association of Temporary and Staffing Services, there are nearly three million temporary employees in the United States, up from 500,000 in 1983. Today's temps are younger (50 percent are 20 to 34 years old) and smarter (30 percent have an associate or bachelor's degree). And the Bureau of Labor Statistics says they make an average of $10.62 an hour. Experts expect the $57 billion temp industry to nearly double its annual revenue by 2006.
Temporary employment has grown in part because employers are more cautious about committing themselves. "They want to try people out before hiring them," said James Essey, president of the Tempositions Group of Companies in Manhattan.
Many companies also prefer temps because they may not have to give them full benefits, or any benefits at all.
BUT it is not only employers who are fickle. Many young people engage in serial workplace monogamy, refusing to enter into serious relationships until they have sowed their corporate oats.
"You test each other out, like a trial marriage," said Georgia Ellis, a vice president at Fifth Avenue Temporary Services in Manhattan. "And it doesn't look bad on your resume, because it doesn't look like you've jumped from place to place. You have an excuse. You're a temp."
Kristin Robinson, 29, has morphed into what is known as a "permanent temp" -- one with a long-term assignment. For the last two years, Ms. Robinson, who is also an actress, has had a continuing temporary position as a graphics artist, three days a week, at Andersen Consulting in Manhattan. She freelances the other two days from connections made at other temp jobs. The freedom, she said, is invaluable: "I try to be respectful and give notice, but if I need to leave I leave. And I don't take work home."
Most young corporate nomads, some of whom are actors, musicians and writers, want to focus on their "real" careers without having to ask, "Do you want fries with that?" They thrive on the flexibility and often use their day jobs as floating office spaces for managing the rest of their lives.
In a full-employment economy, the competition among temp agencies has intensified. Many offer benefits to attract workers; employees staying six months may be eligible for vacation pay, child-care reimbursement and the purchase of medical coverage at group rates.
But the life of a temp isn't all free Krispy Kremes. Stories abound of demeaning treatment from employers and permanent workers. For details, check Tempslave, a magazine, or the Temp24-7 Web site (www.temp24-7.com), where temps can vent. Temp24-7 includes "Temps vs. Suits," a game in which temps can attack a virtual boss.
A recent "gripe of the week" on the Web site told of how a group of temps were all called "Jane" by colleagues who didn't feel like learning their names. Elsewhere on the site, temps posted stories of endless dry spells with nary a job proposition.
Cyberwrath aside, most of today's temps have strong bonds with bosses and agencies. Some employers are so fond of their longer-term temps that, when they take time off, other temps are hired to stand in.
Once displeased, temps can also request transfers. Or walk away. Suzanne Lynn, 27, said she left a Greenville, S.C., law firm for lunch and, angry about being yelled at, didn't come back. Her agency understood and handed her another assignment.
With that kind of freedom and unconditional love, temporary work might be the wave of the future. And even envelope stuffing, now paying $10 an hour in New York City, might be a slightly more profitable, if not enviable, experience.

HEADLINE: CALLINGS;
A Manager Who Moved From Innings To Arias

BYLINE: By LAURA PEDERSEN-PIETERSEN; Laura Pedersen-Pietersen is a Manhattan author and public speaker. Her column profiling people whose work is their passion appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: yourmind@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
WHEN a headhunter called him in 1986 to ask if he wanted to become house manager for the Met, James H. Naples Jr. immediately thought of shortstops at Shea Stadium, not coloraturas at Lincoln Center. At the time, Mr. Naples, then 35, was in charge of a staff of 900 as manager of Yankee Stadium.
If the offer was out of left field, the destination wasn't. The recruiter told him that the Metropolitan Opera House had gone through 22 house managers in 20 years and that "anyone who can last 10 years with George Steinbrenner can do this job." 
 Mr. Naples accepted the offer and, like legions of other workers in an age of ever-changing career paths, demonstrated that his skills were indeed portable. Economists note that despite low unemployment today, the labor force is still churning with workers losing, changing and gaining jobs.
"Skills are becoming increasingly transferable from job to job and industry to industry," said Paul Saffo, a director of the Institute for the Future, a forecasting and research firm in Menlo Park, Calif. "While expertise may be limited, an individual's skills may be very transferable."
Mr. Naples developed many skills in his Yankee Stadium job. In addition to overseeing all home games, he was in charge of high-pressure events like four World Series, the 1976 championship fight between Muhammad Ali and Ken Norton and a Mass celebrated by Pope John Paul II in 1979. For that one, Mr. Naples remembers praying for a logistical miracle; he had to coordinate communion logistics for 80,000 people -- 23,000 more than the stadium usually holds.
The job, of course, had rewards. At the Mass, he escorted the Pope onto the field as they chatted. After-hours during baseball season, he passed the time with the likes of Billy Martin, the often fired and rehired manager. The most memorable night was at Jimmy Weston's restaurant in Manhattan, talking baseball with Frank Sinatra.
Despite his love of the game, Mr. Naples eventually heeded the recruiter. Managing Yankee Stadium required up to 100 hours a week. Having married two years earlier, he had a 1-year-old daughter whom he hardly had time to see. Working for the Yankees was "a dream job for someone who's single," he said.
Offered a better compensation package and a more sensible schedule, Mr. Naples traded himself to the Met, where he has stayed 13 years. He manages 13 departments and 250 people, who work under several labor contracts he helps to negotiate. He is in charge of the building, security, the box office, the cleaning crews and the ushers. And not just during the opera season, since the Met plays host to groups including the American Ballet Theater and the Kirov Ballet.
"It's actually not that different from my old job," he said. "There we were presenting baseball and here we're presenting opera." His workweek, however, is more manageable; he works about 50 hours.
But how does a guy who was a pre-law student at Canisius College in Buffalo -- and who never took a business class -- become a businessman, manager and negotiator? "I learned about people from my father," he said. "He owned a bar in Buffalo where I worked as a kid, and you figure out pretty quick who is real and who you want to emulate and, conversely, whom you don't want to be like."
THAT'S how Mr. Naples got to know Mr. Steinbrenner, who was a frequent patron of the bar in the late 1960's, when he traveled to Buffalo on business for his family's shipping companies.
Mr. Steinbrenner later took control of the Yankees. In 1976, after the renovation of Yankee Stadium, he asked Mr. Naples, then 25, to oversee the ball park's concessions and luxury suites at a starting salary of $16,000. After a year, Mr. Naples became assistant stadium manager; in 1980, he became manager and in 1984 he received the additional title of vice president.
Mr. Naples also relied on lessons learned from watching an uncle, Max Margulis, a Buffalo nightclub impresario, handle not only his staff but also stars like Mel Torme and Aretha Franklin.
What about his own management techniques? "I'm in touch with all department heads almost daily and my door is always open," Mr. Naples said. "The minute I get to work there are eight people with eight problems. Solving them is like winning, and I love winning."
He has learned his negotiating skills on the job. Mr. Steinbrenner and Joseph Volpe, general manager of the Met, "are not only visionaries in their respective fields but sagacious negotiators," Mr. Naples said. "I've learned from them how to make both sides feel like they've accomplished something."
A recent surge in matters operatic has not hurt Mr. Naples's career. The Met has added performances, television broadcasts and recordings; attendance has risen and deficits have vanished. A survey by the National Endowment for the Arts shows that opera attendance rose 12.5 percent nationwide between 1992 and 1997.
And in saying goodbye to World Series rings and hello to Wagner's, Mr. Naples has found more time to spend with his wife, Nancy, and their children, Nicole, 14; Jimmy, 11, and Gavin, 5. Though he hasn't chatted with the Pope recently, Mr. Naples talked with President Clinton at opening night last fall.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
In Asian Markets, Some Signs of Spring

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
ECONOMICS is not accounting, but the sense seems to be spreading that Asia may be the FIFO region of the developing world: First in, first out of recession.
It has been nearly two years since bad times swept first through Thailand and then the rest of East Asia. But now there are some signs of life. 
 Growth estimates in countries like South Korea, Malaysia and India are being raised. Risk premiums on corporate and sovereign -- or government -- debt are shrinking. And equity markets are starting to recover.
In the last two quarters, Morgan Stanley's EMF Asia index, which covers nine markets, has risen 48 percent. But it still has much ground to make up, as do all emerging markets.
Robert J. Pelosky Jr., global emerging markets strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, took some time last week to discuss signs of spring in Asia, as well as other exotic precincts of the world.
 
Q. Some specialists in the emerging markets look at the recovery in certain stock markets and see a dead-cat bounce. Is that what you see?
 
A. Our feeling is that emerging markets in general are turning and that we are at the beginning of a new cycle for these markets -- one that has three stages. The value stage, which is where we are today and have been for some time, is first.
Then there is a growth phase, in terms of improved economic activity and corporate profitability. The third stage is momentum, which takes place as perceptions of risk decline, multiples improve and a broader spectrum of investors return to the investment class.
Asia had its dead-cat bounce a year ago, in the first quarter of 1998, when markets had a powerful rally and then petered out. The big question we have about Asia now is if the region can stage a broad-based recovery without a recovering Japan. We are increasingly of the opinion that Japan is recovering.
 
Q. Aren't economic conditions improving in some countries without a vibrant Japan?
 
A. It does seem that some parts of the region have started to recover. We recently have raised our 1999 growth forecasts for South Korea, Malaysia and India. And in terms of financial market performance, South Korea, Taiwan and India have been doing well.
 
Q. What is the risk if Japan doesn't come back as strongly as you hope?
 
A. In the late 1980's, Asia was a leveraged play on developed-country growth because these countries were basically export platforms to Europe and the United States.
Since then, there has been an increase in inter-Asian trade, which is where Japan comes in. If a Japanese recovery is generated by an aggressive monetary policy, then the risk is the yen will weaken. The question then will be if financial markets look through the negative implications of a weak yen to the positives of a Japanese economic recovery, one that would lead to greater demand for Asian exports.
 
Q. A year ago, many were worried that China would do further damage to the overall economic picture by devaluing the yuan. At this point, how much harm would it do?
 
A. The possibility of a devaluation has already been discounted by financial markets. But we feel the case for a significant Chinese devaluation is just not that strong.
Chinese exports are more demand-dependent than price-dependent. Last year, the Chinese didn't lose a lot of market share even though the currencies of their competitors in Asia fell sharply. If the United States is going to continue to have growth of around 4 percent, if Europe is bottoming and if emerging markets are bottoming, then demand for Chinese exports will pick up.
 
Q. It would seem that Latin America, which felt the impact of the world financial crisis well after Asia, would take longer to recover. Is that how it will play out?
 
A. We are starting to make the case that Latin America will recover more quickly than people think because the shock there was a secondary shock and because a lot of restructuring in that part of the world has been going on since 1994, when the region was also gripped with a financial crisis.
The fact that the American economy remains vibrant is a big positive for Mexico. And the Brazilian devaluation, when it came, was not a huge surprise. If interest rates in Brazil continue to decline, then the region can recover more quickly than people think.
 
Q. You mentioned the cycle that emerging markets are entering. How long will it take?
 
A. I would prefer to see a steady recovery rather than a big spike upwards because volatility in these markets has been what has kept most investors away.
I think this is a one-to-three-year kind of cycle. I think the growth stage will play out in 2000 and 2001, with the momentum stage following after that.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Is Mr. Gates Pouring Fuel On His Rivals' Fire?

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
THE worthies of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology had just finished thanking William H. Gates profusely for paying for a planned new computer science building with a handwritten personal check for $20 million. No sooner had Mr. Gates walked out the door last week than a procession of leading researchers at the university's renowned Laboratory for Computer Science sketched out projects and visions of the technological future that all headed in one direction: away from the personal computer.
In a talk called "The Post PC Internet," David Clark, an M.I.T. computer scientist, described a world in which the personal computer is less important because everything -- TV, wristwatch, eyeglasses, toaster -- has a computer-on-a-chip and "everything is going to be connected to the Internet." For example, a watch face might temporarily become a tiny screen displaying your appointments for the day, information sent wirelessly to the watch from its storage folder on the Internet. 
 "The future of computing is inevitably heterogeneous," Mr. Clark asserted. "Get used to it." He means technologically heterogeneous, not ruled, as PC's are, by a dominant technology standard like Microsoft's Windows operating system.
Shrink-wrapped software will go the way of the buggy whip, according to the M.I.T. computer experts. Consumers will be given computers -- "information appliances" in the new world -- free, or more accurately, bundled into a monthly service charge, on the model of cellular phones.
Much of corporate computing, predicts Hal Abelson, an M.I.T. professor, will shift to the service model as well. The large computer installations at companies that run their own Web sites will be replaced by centralized hosting services. The analogy is with electricity: in the 19th century, factories had their own generators, but with the rise of electric utilities, manufacturers left power generation to the specialists.
Mr. Abelson expects that even storage of corporate data, from procurement orders to customer records, will be handled by outside service suppliers. "You'll see the market for disks being replaced by storage services," he said.
Mr. Clark summarized with this forecast: "What does the future look like? Well, it's a network full of services."
So is Mr. Gates supporting a computer lab dedicated to the destruction of Microsoft's world? After all, many of the pronouncements heard last week at the conference marking the 35th anniversary of the M.I.T. computer lab -- an incubator for pioneering work ranging from word processing and spreadsheet software to PC networking and E-mail -- sound strikingly like the marketing slogans of Microsoft's rivals.
The network is king? The mantra of Sun Microsystems is "The network is the computer." Big iron at the hub of hosting operations and Internet services as the business of the future? Key chapters in the I.B.M. playbook of Louis V. Gerstner Jr.
Microsoft, of course, resists the notion of the post-PC era. An unrivaled marketer, Microsoft knows the opinion-shaping power of a deftly phrased concept, and buying patterns tend to follow ideas. But mostly, the company seems to object to the term post-PC; failing to counterattack when the demise of your lifeblood business is heralded would be a strategic mistake.
BUT Microsoft itself is moving toward the future foreseen at M.I.T. Steven Ballmer, Microsoft's president, described a reorganization last month as the "renewal of our vision" to put a "PC on every desk and in every home." But now, Mr. Ballmer says: "We want to extend that notion. While the PC will stay central, we realize there is demand for computing on non-PC devices." Translation: The only religion at Microsoft is winning. And the Windows CE operating system is its bid to get its software into these non-PC devices.
If the lucrative commodity of the future is Internet services sold by subscription, that is fine with Mr. Gates. He just calls it by a different name: software. In a question-and-answer session in Technology Review with Michael Dertouzos, director of the M.I.T. computer lab, Mr. Gates said, "Software will evolve into even more of a service business than it already is, and in the long term there will probably be a move toward a subscription-style model."
The stakes are high in the future shape of the information economy, and not just for Microsoft. That makes some people suspicious that Mr. Gates is trying to buy the future, by using big donations to computer science departments at M.I.T., Stanford, Harvard and Cambridge to bend academic research in Microsoft-friendly directions.
But Mr. Dertouzos, at least, has demonstrated independence of mind. He was briefly on the list of witnesses Microsoft planned to call in its antitrust trial, but according to colleagues, he agreed to testify as an expert witness on one condition: no coaching from the Microsoft legal staff. He was soon dropped as a witness when his deposition testimony did not echo Microsoft's defense.
A towering man, Mr. Dertouzos issues an emphatic declaration of academic independence. "Nobody has bought me yet," he said, "and I'll cripple anyone who claims they have."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
How Too Much Purple Could Mean Less Green

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

DATELINE: CONCORD, Mass.

 BODY:
AT first glance it seems pretty simple. A food processing company with a strong brand in a relatively narrow niche finds the competition toughening and the niche's sales trend flattening. To grow, it needs to extend its brand to new product categories, to make acquisitions, or both. That calls for a big financial commitment, which most companies can raise by tapping capital markets.
But Welch Foods isn't most companies: it is owned by a farmers' cooperative, the National Grape Cooperative Association. And that makes meeting its competitive challenges anything but straightforward. 
 With roots in 19th century agrarian socialism, co-ops can seem a quaint counterpoint to the unbridled capitalism energizing most of the economy. But they play a huge role in American agriculture. And the value-added co-ops -- the ones like National Grape that process members' produce into consumer products rather than just handling bulk commodities -- own more well-known supermarket brands than many consumers realize.
Co-ops help farmers by assuring that each year's harvest will be bought at predictable prices and by sharing profits, expertise and purchasing muscle. But the ownership structure can also be a significant competitive handicap.
By definition, a co-op cannot sell stock or use it to pay for acquisitions, or even build a war chest of cash from retained earnings; profits must be distributed to the members each year. So co-ops often have a difficult time financing major expansion, unless they borrow or merge with other co-ops, as many dairy co-ops have been doing.
In recent years, National Grape has managed to find steady if unspectacular growth by aggressively marketing the Welch's line of juices, jellies and related products, whose sales topped $600 million in 1998. But against increased competition from publicly traded companies with formidable marketing and financial strengths, Welch's now needs to look further afield.
"They have the capability to get beyond the billion-dollar mark in sales," said Ted Dardani, a principal with BT Capital Partners, a unit of Bankers Trust, who has worked with Welch's on acquisition and joint venture ideas. "They have done a very good job of building their brands back. The point now is, how can Welch's take all that brand equity and expertise and do some other product lines that make sense?"
Welch's now finds its longtime strength, an undistracted focus on jelly and juice, turning into a shortcoming, as ever more rushed Americans skip eating a traditional breakfast and demand sags.
For decades after the co-op acquired it in 1945, Welch's did well by remaining steadfastly grape-centric and conservative. It shunned new product development and avoided advertising spending like a bad grape disease. But by 1983, that strategy was flagging, and the co-op was in danger of reneging on its promise to buy 70 percent of its members' ever-growing harvests, according to Daniel P. Dillon, the president of Welch's, who joined the company around that time as a vice president.
Welch's management overcame initial resistance from the growers and shifted gears, stepping up marketing to rebuild demand through new TV advertising and a revival of the cartoon-character jelly glasses that were a 1960's hit.
The company paid for and trumpeted a study that concluded, somewhat controversially, that white grape juice is better than apple juice for babies and toddlers suffering from diarrhea because it is lower in sorbitol. It seized on studies in France finding that red wine helps control cholesterol, hoping that they would rub off on grape juice.
And it stretched the juice line any way it could, with new blends like pineapple-banana, frozen smoothies, concentrates that don't require refrigeration and, briefly, kosher grape juice. A new research center tests innovations like a plastic can for frozen juice that can be thawed in a microwave. And there are plans for more single-serving items, an area where Ocean Spray (another co-op) has made great strides.
"To really push ahead in the juice business, you have to deliver more than one kind of juice," said Kevin Murphy, chief operating officer of Ocean Spray, which recently bought a big stake in Nantucket Nectars. "I don't think Welch has been aggressive in that regard. They've really tried to stretch grape juice out." Mr. Murphy questioned whether Welch's should use scarce resources to chase growth in a shrinking category like frozen concentrate.
But moving beyond grape juices means tangling with the likes of Pepsico's Tropicana, Coca-Cola and Cadbury-Schweppes, a league in which Welch's is at a distinct disadvantage. "My competition isn't the local cooperative down the road," said Joe Falcone, a National Grape board member and fourth-generation grape farmer. "It's Nestle, and Pepsi, and big companies like that," which can raise capital faster and more flexibly. Still, co-ops can take advantage of low-interest loans from the National Cooperative Bank, a $19 billion entity that lends only to them.
Much of what has kept Welch's intact can also hold it back. With grape farmers for owners, "it's a conservative environment," said Rex Green, a managing director at Advest, a Boston investment bank that has advised Welch's. "These are men and women of the soil, rather than day traders. They look at their company and their stewardship of Welch's in the long term."
The next step for Welch's seems to be acquiring or pursuing joint ventures with companies that make other kinds of consumer packaged foods. Executives were quiet about specific plans.
Approaching such ventures slowly works in Welch's favor, Mr. Green said. "They have an excellent record of not launching failed products," he said. "They can't afford to invest the capital, and then not have it work. That absolutely reflects being in the environment of a co-op."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
9 Groups Join in a Marriage of Art and Cultural Institutions

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
The gathering at the National Black Theater on East 125th Street Tuesday morning had the trappings of a wedding ceremony, with catered hors d'oeuvres and waiters in tuxedos. There was even a performance by a gospel choir.
The event, billed as a news conference, was actually a marriage of sorts, joining together nine of Harlem's most prominent cultural institutions. The nine -- Aaron Davis Hall, the Apollo Theater Foundation, the Boys Choir of Harlem, the Dance Theater of Harlem, the Harlem School of the Arts, Jazzmobile, the National Black Theater, the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture and the Studio Museum in Harlem -- now make up the Harlem Strategic Cultural Collaborative, a coalition to market and promote the neighborhood's rich tradition of culture and arts. 
 "This coalition has been a dream of the Department of Cultural Affairs for a long time," said Schuyler G. Chapin, the Commissioner.
The actor Ossie Davis, who introduced a representative from each group, was equally effusive.
"The excitement that I feel comes from an understanding of the implications of what's happening here," he said. "Our history is one in which we have had to prove that we are even human beings. And the struggle has been led all these years, and is still being led, by people in the arts."
The collaborative was forged in several meetings that began this winter, when the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone organized a series of focus groups on improving Harlem's economy, said Howard Dodson, director of the Schomburg Center.
The organizations hope to share audiences by promoting one another's events, distributing brochures and creating special deals for people to attend programs at various spaces.
The first collaborative effort is a discount card, which will be issued automatically to subscribers and members of each of the nine groups, offering a 10 percent discount on various products and programs.
The coalition plans to try collective marketing strategies, like a cooperative Web site promoting all of Harlem's arts.
Patricia Cruz, director of Aaron Davis Hall, said she hoped the collaborative could build on the growth in economic development and rebirth of night life that are already taking place in Harlem to build audiences for all the neighborhood's cultural institutions.
"We have been programmed to be rugged individualists, to think we're all competing for the same pot of money," said Barbara Ann Teer, founder and chief executive of the National Black Theater.
"This whole paradigm has been one of scarcity. That has been a barrier, so we have to re-educate ourselves."
 NINA SIEGAL

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
A Search For Growth On the Vine

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
LAST year was a good one for plenty of newly released wines, from Oregon pinot noirs to Napa chardonnays. For investors in wine-company stocks, however, 1998 left a generally unpleasant aftertaste.
The Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities Wine Index, which tracks three wine-related stocks -- Robert Mondavi Winery, Beringer Wine Estates, and Canandaigua Brands -- rose just 4.9 percent last year, compared with a 26.7 percent gain for the Standard & Poor's 500. And the wine index has tumbled 13.5 percent so far this year through Friday. 
 But David Goldman, a Montgomery analyst, says winery stocks have been held down by fears, some of them unfounded.
Some investors feared a grape shortage from heavy rains in 1998, while others feared a glut as large amounts of vineyard acreage entered production during the year; neither came to pass. More broadly, worries about an imminent recession have also been discounted. Worries remain, however, that a new excise tax could be placed on alcohol. And small- to mid-cap stocks of all types continue to languish.
"These things won't always be true," Mr. Goldman said. He predicted 9 to 12 percent growth in sales volume, with higher growth in revenues as consumption continues to shift to better, pricier wines. "Bottom-line earnings growth looks like it will be 15 to 20 percent for the next few years," he said. "Lastly, there is a certain sex appeal."
The latter factor has long been the main reason to like the Chalone Wine Group, a maker of many high-end wines. The company went public in 1984 at $9 a share; 15 years later it is trading at $8.375, despite sales growth that has been in the double digits throughout the 1990's. (Investors who hold at least 100 shares, however, enjoy a 25 percent discount on Chalone wines.)
Mondavi went public in 1993 at $13.50 a share; it closed on Friday at $32.25 but has traded as high as $42.75 in the last 52 weeks. Beringer went public in 1997 at $26; it is now at $38.375, down from a 52-week high of $54.75. Two smaller wineries, R. H. Phillips and Willamette Valley Vineyard, are also publicly traded, as is Golden State Vintners, which makes wines sold under various labels. Canandaigua, a huge producer of lower-priced wines, made news this month by agreeing to buy the premium Simi Winery of California from LVMH Moet-Hennessey Louis Vuitton.
Mr. Goldman is especially bullish on Mondavi and Beringer, which he expects to hit $47 and $55, respectively, over the next 12 months. He is cautious about Ravenswood Winery, which sold one million shares at $10.50 each over the World Wide Web on April 9, through W. R. Hambrecht & Company, in an on-line auction without traditional underwriters. "I love the company -- they have a real success story," Mr. Goldman said. "My only concern is that Ravenswood will end up on the dark side of the moon in terms of analyst coverage."
Mr. Goldman has much company in recommending Mondavi and Beringer. Both have known brands and prime, extensive acreage in California. Mondavi had some earnings shortfalls last year, which it attributed to a shortage of grapes for its low-end Woodbridge chardonnay. Beringer has enjoyed steady sales and earnings growth.
John O'Neill, an analyst at BT Alex. Brown upgraded Mondavi to a buy in January, after the company announced a restructuring that trimmed the work force by 4 percent and refocused attention on core brands. "The structural change indicated the company will be more profit-focused," Mr. O'Neill said.
At Beringer, he said, a new line of $8 to $10 wines, Beringer Founders Estate, should increase sales volumes.
Bernice S. Behar, manager of the John Hancock Emerging Growth fund, said of Beringer: "The growth rate is there, and the demand is still pretty high. We continue to believe Beringer is the best-managed company in the business."
Among the doubters of Mondavi and Beringer is Tom Pirko, president of Bevmark Inc., a beverage industry consulting firm based in New York. He likes Beringer's management and the Mondavi family, but he does not believe either company should be public. "All these projects are the province of private equity deals," he said. "I don't know of any that really qualifies for a public offering."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Value Is Suddenly Looking Nifty

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
For years, stock market investors have resembled the fellow Oscar Wilde once described as knowing the price of everything and the value of nothing.
Last week, value suddenly mattered again to investors. 
 For anyone in value stocks, a rally has been a long time in coming. These companies have severely underperformed compared with their growth-stock brethren since the middle of 1994.
On Monday, however, the trend turned. Assets flew out of stock market darlings like Pfizer, Wal-Mart and Dell Computer and headed directly for former duds like Caterpillar, DuPont, even Eastman Kodak.
After peaking on Monday, the Standard & Poor's Barra Growth index lost 6.2 percent by week's end. But the S. & P. Barra Value index gained 1.9 percent for the week.
The about-face was all the more remarkable in that it was not caused by a market correction. Byron R. Wien, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, says it usually takes a market fall to shock investors into value havens.
So what scared investors out of growth stocks? Mr. Wien cites two events: the European central bank's interest-rate cut on April 8 and Compaq Computer's warning last Monday that its first-quarter earnings would be half what analysts were expecting. "Compaq's announcement reminded people that there can be disappointments even in technology," Mr. Wien said. "And the E.C.B. cutting interest rates reminded people that policy makers are determined to keep the world on a growth path."
Before they celebrate, value investors may be wondering whether the sudden shift is just a cruel head fake to an already beleaguered bunch.
Douglas R. Cliggott, United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, thinks the value story has staying power. One reason is an upswing in global earnings that he expects during the next 6 to 12 months as economies around the world emerge from the doldrums.
That, he said, will help value stocks stay strong. When world economic growth is falling, Mr. Cliggott noted, growth stocks win. "In periods of slow economic growth, earnings growth is scarce, so those companies that can demonstrate growth tend to get very high multiples put on those earnings," he explained. As growth accelerates, paying up for earnings makes less sense, and value shares typically rally.
It is perhaps not surprising that the value rebound is happening now. Such sentiment shifts often occur after the last diehard investor -- in this case a value type -- has thrown in the towel. This year, 98 percent of net inflows into equity mutual funds have gone to growth managers.
To investors who think that growth stocks always bounce back, Alan F. Skrainka, chief market strategist at Edward D. Jones in St. Louis, says history shows the perils of such faith.
Harkening back to 1972, the last time that a small group of growth stocks -- the Nifty 50 -- so dominated the investment scene, Mr. Skrainka looked at the performance of that era's four top technology stocks: Texas Instruments, I.B.M., Xerox and Polaroid. The shares, he found, fetched 40 to 95 times earnings in 1972.
But then the bear market of 1974 hammered them. And by 1982, the former leaders had not yet recovered; their average annualized returns for the 10-year period ending in 1982 were well below that of the S.& P. 500.
Market leadership, once it has been unseated, can take a long time to return.

HEADLINE: War and Analogy

 BODY:
Every war is conducted in the shadow of its predecessors, and the conflict in Kosovo is no exception. The nation is haunted by memories of the Second World War and Vietnam as it considers how intensely to prosecute the war in the Balkans. That is entirely appropriate, for the history of those struggles is relevant to this one. But neither analogy exactly fits Kosovo, and seeing beyond them is essential if the country is to make a searching examination of the proper course to follow in Yugoslavia. 
 Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and other proponents of American military involvement in Kosovo cast the conflict as a test of American and European willingness to confront aggression and homicidal ethnic hatred before they spread. They argue that in dealing with Slobodan Milosevic, the West must not repeat the appeasement at Munich in 1938 and other mistakes that initially allowed Hitler to move unimpeded against his neighbors and led him to conclude that Nazi policies would go unopposed. Because of the unimaginable devastation of World War II and the Holocaust, this view has great moral resonance today.
Opponents of American military action in Kosovo fear that, as in Vietnam, the country is being drawn deeply into a conflict where the national interest is unclear or concocted, the sacrifices may be dear and the outcome is uncertain. They see another protracted, unpopular war that ends with an imperfect settlement that might have been reached before fighting escalated. The echoes of Vietnam are understandably -- and properly -- strong in a White House and Pentagon populated with men and women who saw the lives of their peers wasted by Lyndon Baines Johnson.
For every American generation of this century, the power of war analogies has been undeniable, and they have framed debate about every recent American military venture abroad. George Bush, who was probably the last of the World War II veterans to occupy the White House, took America to war in the Persian Gulf not only to protect the flow of oil, but also to defeat Saddam Hussein, a tyrant whom he equated with Hitler. Ronald Reagan maintained that his invasion of Grenada broke the paralyzing spell of Vietnam.
In fact, both analogies contain enduring truths. World War II did show that maniacal dictators are best crushed early. Vietnam taught us that it can be a criminal act to send troops into combat without the support of the American people and Congress. But historical contexts change, and that affects the fit of old analogies to new circumstances. The bipolar world of the cold war no longer exists. Does that mean that the remaining superpower has unavoidable responsibilities to function as a humanitarian police force? Or does it mean that America should intervene in genocidal conflicts that would undermine the stability of an important region or ally and ignore more isolated bloodlettings?
President Clinton began to grope toward an answer to these difficult questions last week when he told a gathering of newspaper editors, "At the end of the 20th century, we face a great battle between the forces of integration and the forces of disintegration, the forces of globalism versus tribalism, of oppression against empowerment."
In this new world, the savage assault on Kosovo demands a response, and one that proceeds from a clearer policy than has yet been defined by Mr. Clinton or the foreign-policy leaders in Congress. Advancing the economic, political and ethnic integration of Europe is hard enough without a bomb-thrower like Mr. Milosevic. His actions present an intertwined humanitarian and diplomatic test to Europe and the United States. By forcing hundreds of thousands of ethnic Albanians to flee, Mr. Milosevic is using refugees to destabilize neighboring areas that he is unwilling to attack with his army. The sudden, explosive movement of peoples across Europe is a new form of aggression.
In the days ahead, Americans must ponder how vital these interests are to the United States. For the time being, NATO air strikes are the right way to attack the Serbian military and may weaken Mr. Milosevic's resistance. But the hour has come for a national conversation about how deeply the country is willing to be engaged in the defense of Kosovo.
Senator John McCain, directly tackling the Vietnam analogy, predicts that a NATO ground force operating with advanced American weapons would quickly overcome Serbian troops. Even if that is not the case, Americans outraged by the Serbian brutality in Kosovo may be willing to risk the casualties that could come with an invasion. To make that judgment, Americans need to learn more about the conflict and its potential consequences.
Mr. Clinton is the only person who can lead a national seminar on Kosovo, and he made a good start last week, speaking in San Francisco, Detroit and Boston. Before long, Congress must commence a full debate. Though the military obstacles in Kosovo are different from those in Vietnam -- the Serbian army, for example, is clearly not supported by large segments of the population in Kosovo -- one lesson of Vietnam should be foremost in Mr. Clinton's thinking. In these excruciating situations, the President has to decide, in his own heart and mind, exactly what he wants and then seek the support of the American people and Congress for his military plan.

HEADLINE: The World: Checkered Flags;
Sovereignty Isn't So Sacred Anymore

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
AT the century's last session of the Commission on Human Rights, Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations unveiled a doctrine with profound implications for international relations in the new millennium. The air strikes against Yugoslavia, he said on April 7, showed that the world would no longer permit nations intent on committing genocide to "hide" behind the United Nations charter, which has traditionally safeguarded national sovereignty.
The protection of human rights, he said, must "take precedence over concerns of state sovereignty." "As long as I am Secretary General," said Mr. Annan, the United Nations "will always place human beings at the center of everything we do." This was not the Secretary General acting alone. He was, he acknowledged, only embracing an "evolving" international norm. He also acknowledged that using force to protect human rights poses "fundamental challenges" to the United Nations. 
 In fact, an erosion of sovereignty when it conflicts with human rights standards is reflected in many events of the last decade: the creation of international tribunals to try individuals accused of crimes against humanity in Yugoslavia and Rwanda; Spain's effort to extradite the former Chilean leader, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, from Britain for trial on charges of crimes against humanity, and the impending trial of two Libyans before a Scottish court in the Netherlands over charges that they bombed an American jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland.
To a certain extent, analysts agree, Mr. Annan's own stance is a reaction to his own searing experience as the head of peacekeeping in Rwanda, when more than half a million people were slaughtered as the Security Council withdrew United Nations forces.
Some argue that Mr. Annan has merely blessed a "given" of the political climate today: the growing importance of human rights to the United Nations and many of its 185 members. This was most evident in the Security Council's overwhelming rejection two weeks ago of a resolution condemning NATO's air strikes as illegal on grounds that the Security Council had not authorized them. Only Namibia joined Russia and China, the co-sponsors of the motion, in arguing that Serbia's treatment of its Albanian minority was essentially an internal matter.
Mr. Annan's doctrine, predictably, has won praise from the burgeoning human rights community. But others argue that though well-intentioned, it is naive, dangerous and likely to increase tensions and paralysis within the Security Council.
And at least one close adviser to Mr. Annan worries that intervening to save white Europeans (albeit Muslims) in Kosovo, after having ignored even worse massacres in Rwanda and elsewhere, leaves the United Nations open to charges of selective morality and double standards. Others argue that in a world with some 40 million refugees and displaced people, Mr. Annan's stance risks stretching United Nations resources to unbearable limits.
Herbert S. Okun, a former American diplomat and United Nations adviser on narcotics, warns that going to war to protect people is also perilous. "The use of force," he warns, "is a very blunt instrument on behalf of human rights."
Still others worry that respect for sovereignty has often been a barrier to the expansion of internal conflicts, and has served as a rallying point for collective action against aggressors.
IN speeches and articles last year, Mr. Annan addressed some of these worries even as he signaled his growing anxiety about the violations of rights occurring in Kosovo. Nation-states are not going to disappear, he wrote in the journal "Humanitarian Intervention." Respect for the "fundamental sovereignty, territorial integrity, and political independence of states" will remain a "cornerstone of the international system." Nevertheless, he said last summer in Rome, the principle of sovereignty cannot provide "excuses for the inexcusable." The United Nations charter, he reminded people in England last June, "was issued in the name of 'the peoples,' not the governments, of the United Nations."
Even China, said Kenneth Roth, executive director of Human Rights Watch, has not uniformly blocked humanitarian intervention by the United Nations. For instance, it did not object to the creation of "no-fly zones" in Iraq to protect the Kurdish minority in the north and Shiite Muslims in the south against Saddam Hussein's furious repression. The grosser the oppression (or, more to the point, the less directly it resembles China's own actions in Tibet) the greater Beijing's willingness to tolerate humanitarian intervention. "So even for China the door is not completely shut," Mr. Roth said.
There is, as well, a link between the idea of stopping atrocities and preserving the general peace, another key goal for the United Nations. Mr. Roth argues that failure to respond to brutal internal repression often emboldens would-be aggressors. "Our failure to punish Iraq for its brutal repression of, and use of chemical weapons against, the Kurds in 1988 led Saddam to conclude he could get away with invading Kuwait," he said.
The resort to force, of course, need not be the first or preferred means of intervention. Patiently applied, targeted economic sanctions against Libya eventually prompted Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, to surrender the two men charged with bringing down Pan Am 103 over Scotland. On the other hand, almost a decade of harsh sanctions against Iraq have failed to persuade Saddam Hussein to disclose information about his quest for unconventional weapons.
"The military intervention in Kosovo reflects to some extent the lessons of Iraq and of Rwanda," said one senior diplomat.
THE case for humanitarian intervention in Kosovo was persuasive for both Europe and the United States for different reasons, one senior diplomat asserted. America, an "idea" nation whose national identity derives more from a "value-driven agenda" than from traditional bonding notions of blood, religion or soil, has long been an aggressive promoter of human rights. Also at stake for America is NATO's very purpose and effectiveness as an alliance.
And for Europe, the question of appearing indifferent to repression and brutality was especially evocative. Even Germany, which since World War II has resisted the use of force to solve political problems, did not want to end the century by appearing cold toward an echo of the atrocities it caused 60 years ago. Paraphrasing Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer of Germany, the diplomat said the decision for Germany was between "no more wars" and "no more Auschwitzes." It, like the rest of NATO, chose to go to war this time.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
A Booming Economy That Confuses the Fed

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
It's boom time in America. The United States economy is acting as if it just got a new wind, and growth -- which virtually every forecaster was sure would slow this year -- seems to be accelerating. Unemployment is low and so is inflation.
The seers at the Federal Reserve Board are as puzzled as the rest of us. "Recent performance is both better than expected and better than most of us thought the structure of the economy would allow," said Laurence Meyer, a Fed governor, in a speech last week. 
 The new belief in the vibrancy of the American economy was visible in the stock market last week as investors moved money out of Internet wonders and into companies that actually make stuff. America Online stock fell 13 percent while Caterpillar soared 30 percent. You would think this economic recovery was just starting, rather than in its ninth year. Recessions, investors think, are for other countries.
It was only last fall that there was a consensus that it was just a matter of time until the world's economic illness infected America. There were signs that it had already started, as manufacturing companies reported falling profits and exports declined.
It now looks as if the contagion went the other way. Brazil's recession is less serious than was expected and Asia is recovering. American manufacturers report that exports are picking up.
Meanwhile, American consumers have decided to spend more than ever. "The things that were strong last year have not missed a beat," said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company. Retail sales are up 6 percent over last year, after adjusting for inflation. That is a pace that is unprecedented except when the country is coming out of a recession. The last time we saw such growth was in 1983.
All this suggests that confidence is about as high as it has ever been. Investors believe there will be no recession, and consumers have no fears that their incomes will fall.
In retrospect, it seems clear that the Fed overdid it last fall, when it cut interest rates three times in an effort to stave off world recession and moderate the expected slowing in this country. Instead, it fostered a boom that may be unsustainable and could bring on inflation. It also provided the liquidity needed to push the Dow Jones industrial average up 39 percent since August.
Now the question is whether the Fed will reverse course and start to tighten. If it does, that would certainly put upward pressure on interest rates, and it might dampen both the stock market and the economy.
The answer probably depends on what conclusions the Fed members reach about why the economy has been so strong. If they still believe in conventional forecasting, they probably will tighten. In the past, unemployment rates this low and consumption this strong were deemed sure signs of incipient inflation.
But the old economic indicators do not seem to be working the way they once did, a fact that is reflected in the poor forecasting record of the Fed and most other economists. The Fed members wonder whether much of this can be explained by a surge in computer-related productivity, and whether weakness in the rest of the world is keeping a cap on American wages even when jobs are plentiful.
Most on Wall Street think the Fed is not likely to act soon. "The days of pre-emptive tightening are over," says Mr. Barbera, predicting that action will be delayed until inflation is clearly on the rise. Similarly, Stephen Roach, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley, thinks the Fed should raise rates to at least partly offset last fall's cuts, but says it appears that such a move will come later rather than sooner.
But the bet here is that the Fed will act sooner than most people think. Mr. Meyer, the Fed governor, said last week that a rate increase might be appropriate if the economy continued to grow rapidly, even if inflation did not rise immediately. If that was a hint, it was one that Wall Street was not in a mood to hear.

HEADLINE: The World;
How Globalism Ruined An Asian Success Story

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia

 BODY:
HIS children were weeping and his wife looked shell-shocked. But as the guards led him away to serve a six-year prison sentence last week, Malaysia's ousted Deputy Prime Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, seemed to be prepping himself for the next round of a boxing match.
"Hold fast to the struggle," Mr. Anwar said in a fiery statement just after he was found guilty of corruption. "Love Malaysia. And if we do love Malaysia, then the fight against injustice must be invigorated." 
 While Mr. Anwar, 51, vows he will lead a campaign to unseat Malaysia's strong-willed leader, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, it is not clear he can be much of an insurgent from behind bars. If Malaysia recovers from the ravages of the Asian economic crisis, the 73-year-old Dr. Mahathir seems likely to survive the most serious threat to his 18-year rule.
Still, the downfall of Mr. Anwar shows how outside economic forces can sunder the political culture of even a well-governed country. Before the Asian crisis devastated Malaysia's economy, Mr. Anwar and Dr. Mahathir rarely disagreed. Now, the two men are locked in a feud so bitter that Mr. Anwar likens his former mentor to Hitler, while Dr. Mahathir accuses his protege of being a sodomist.
"The economic crisis unfolded into a political crisis, with changes in regimes throughout the region," said K. S. Jomo, a political economist at the University of Malaya. "That scared Mahathir, and it emboldened Anwar."
Mr. Anwar's wife, Wan Azizah Wan Ismail, believes her husband had become too much of a threat to Dr. Mahathir. "It was a foregone conclusion that he was going to be found guilty," she said.
For two decades, Dr. Mahathir and Mr. Anwar were inseparable, united in a drive to turn this former British colony into Exhibit A of the Asian miracle. With foreign money pouring in, Malaysia became a wonderland of development. American companies built factories to take advantage of the cheap work force, and the living standard rose.
Dr. Mahathir and Mr. Anwar flexed their muscles in different ways. The Prime Minister built the world's tallest skyscrapers in Kuala Lumpur, while Mr. Anwar cultivated an image as a new-style Asian leader. In his book, "The Asian Renaissance," he tried to square Asian values with Western capitalism.
But last year Malaysia got caught in the riptide of globalism, and the strain drove both men to extreme positions. Dr. Mahathir argued that Malaysia should shield itself against the predations of foreign currency speculators by erecting barriers around its markets. Mr. Anwar favored the International Monetary Fund's castor-oil remedy of open markets and high interest rates. He said the Prime Minister was just trying to protect his cronies.
Just when Dr. Mahathir seemed to be on the ropes, he lashed back -- imposing controls on Malaysia's currency markets and sacking his deputy. Three weeks later, Mr. Anwar was arrested and charged with corruption and sex crimes.
It is tempting to cast the feud between Dr. Mahathir and Mr. Anwar in Manichean terms. Mr. Anwar's trial had all the appearances of a railroading. And Dr. Mahathir has won few friends outside Malaysia with his inflammatory remarks about the influence of the financier George Soros and Jewish currency speculators.
In an Op-Ed article in The New York Times on Thursday, written from prison, Mr. Anwar accused Dr. Mahathir of being "a has-been leader who had descended to cruelty in a desperate bid to cling to power."
BUT such a portrayal is simplistic. Political analysts here said Dr. Mahathir mixes populist, anti-Western rhetoric with a sophisticated understanding of the global economy. Even critics credit him for fashioning a harmonious country out of a combustible mixture of Malays, ethnic Chinese and Indians.
Likewise, Mr. Anwar is no helpless victim. Analysts describe him as a skilled and even ruthless politician who did not hesitate to hand out his share of plum Government contracts to solidify his power base. Mr. Anwar has honed his image overseas, through a network of Western-style spin doctors.
In the end, Mr. Anwar's downfall is yet more evidence that global capitalism can be a powerful destabilizing force. It set off poisonous animosities in two leaders who shared a common vision of Malaysia's future. And the resulting power struggle left this once-peaceful and prosperous country sadly diminished.

HEADLINE: The World: Clinton Foreign Policy;
China: a Hot Issue That Takes the Back Burner

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN their new book "Preventative Defense" (Brookings Institution Press), former Defense Secretary William J. Perry and a former Pentagon colleague, Ashton B. Carter, argue that 10 years into the post-cold war, Washington forgets that some nations matter a lot more than others.
There is a short "A list" of nations that could some day pose a threat to "the survival or way of life of Americans" -- a Russia that goes the way of Weimar Germany, or a China that becomes a hostile superpower. 
 Then there is a well-stocked "B list" of "imminent threats to U.S. interests," including the fractious Persian Gulf states and North Korea.
And finally comes the "C list," which the authors say is composed of "the Kosovos, Bosnias, Somalias, Rwandas and Haitis" -- all urgent, but places where American interests are usually hard to define.
On paper, it sounds reasonable and orderly. But the C list looms vivid onlive TV, making it all-consuming for Washington while less dramatic A list problems go to the back burner.
And that appears to be exactly what happened over the last 10 days as China's savvy Prime Minister, Zhu Rongji, drove up to the White House ready to resolve one of the most complex issues in Sino-American relations -- a huge trade deal that is really about China's influence in the world and America's influence on China. Problem was, he arrived at a moment when a President who has pressed "engagement" with China was elsewhere engaged.
The result was a weeklong White House fumble that left the Chinese angry, the President embarrassed, the business community enraged and Congress in disarray. In the end, Mr. Zhu left the United States with a hastily telephoned assurance from Mr. Clinton that China would get into the World Trade Organization this year, with American blessing, if China kept its promises and gave a bit more. But the whole messy handling of China's premier reformer left some Administration officials wondering whether this White House can bomb Belgrade and negotiate with Beijing at the same time.
"This was a classic case of distraction," one White House official conceded late last week, trying to explain why the White House had to issue three separate joint statements with Mr. Zhu in five days.
Mr. Zhu, the man bringing market reforms to China even as millions wander the countryside unemployed, decided earlier this year that China was either going to get globalized fast or get lost in the race. "Either we look like Singapore or we look like Russia," one of his aides commented recently. "And that's not a choice."
So Mr. Zhu offered market-opening concessions in agriculture, telecommunications, banking, insurance and other industries that go far beyond what most American officials thought possible. And the morning of his arrival here, Mr. Clinton made the strongest case yet for ushering China into the World Trade Organization, arguing it would not only mean billions for American companies, but that it would bring the rule of law to China. And, breaking new ground, he argued that an economically weak China was more dangerous to America than a strong China.
HOURS later, though, Mr. Clinton walked away from the deal, at least for the time being. China had not given enough, his aides argued. He was worried, his advisers say, that the Democratic left, backed by the unions, would kill off any deal once they allied with conservatives saying there should be no deal with a China that steals nuclear secrets and represses dissidents.
"The critical middle that you need to support a deal like this is shrinking," said Commerce Secretary William Daley, explaining why the White House needed what he called "a bulletproof deal."
But in trade, nothing's bulletproof. American textile makers will never like a deal that lets China expand its presence in the American market. Nor will steel makers, or steel unions. Many in Congress argue that China has no intention of fulfilling its market-opening promises. But the vast majority of big businesses say that if Mr. Clinton doesn't sign soon, the huge gains made in many areas will be eaten away as soon as Mr. Zhu returns to Beijing and faces bureaucrats screaming: "You gave away what?"
"That's what makes this such a critical moment," said Edward S. Steinfeld, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor who has studied China's state-owned enterprises. "This agreement puts tremendous pressure on China to change its industrial structure, and to some degree its politics.
"It will be painful. And the question is, how can you say that you want a market-based China, enmeshed in a global legal system, and walk away from this?"

HEADLINE: The Value of Stock Options

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Corporate Profits Are Tasty, but Artificially Flavored" (Economic View, March 28), which described corporate accounting for stock options as a cause of overstated profits: 
 Such opinions oversimplify a highly evolved, complex subject. Employee stock options have been a major driver of our booming economy, of our global technology leadership and the current bull market. To gain an appreciation for stock options, just look around the world and see the lack of linkage between management and shareholder interests in many foreign countries. And think back to the demands of institutional shareholders a generation ago for a stronger correlation between results for shareholders and results for management. Today, that correlation is strong, and the results have been powerful for both groups.
Corporate financial statements today include extensive, overly complicated and, in part, meaningless information about stock options. More changes to the accounting methods and disclosures won't change investors' proper focus on cash flow and underlying growth rates in assessing a business.
Executive pay is driven by a formal governance process and by dialogue among the owners of a corporation, their representatives (directors and compensation committees) and management. That is where the discussion can be lively, thoughtful and marketplace-driven.
Because of continuous improvements in corporate reporting, as well as the growth of the Internet and the number of analysts covering stocks, the amount of information available to investors is up dramatically. And the quality of that information has never been better.
 
PHILIP B. LIVINGSTON
Morristown, N.J., April 1
 
The writer is president and chief executive of the Financial Executives Institute, an association of corporate executives.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 20; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1694 words

HEADLINE: Competition for Patients Spurs Some Hospitals Toward Providing Only Private Rooms

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Private rooms in hospitals were once only for those affluent patients willing to pay as much as $300 a day extra for some peace from the chatter, beeping machines and groans coming from the next bed. Now a growing number of hospitals are eliminating shared rooms and offering all patients -- Medicare and Medicaid, rich and indigent -- their own rooms, often at no extra charge.
The shift toward private rooms is largely a byproduct of the revolution wrought by managed care. Most hospitals are under pressure to compete for patients. Insurers used to pay hospitals based on a semiprivate room rate. Now they typically pay the same flat amount no matter what the type of room. 
 Technology is also a factor, as hospitals need more space for increasingly sophisticated life-support devices. Indeed, many hospitals want to build rooms that can be easily converted to intensive care units, which health planners project as a growth area over the 30-year life of a typical hospital building.
So while building private rooms is more expensive than shared rooms, many hospitals say the extra cost is worth it to fill a higher percentage of beds and to prepare for the future.
"Almost everybody is building hospitals with private rooms only," said C. Thomas Smith, president of VHA Inc., a national purchasing and consulting network of 1,850 hospitals.
New York hospitals have not joined the trend, put off, executives say, by high local building costs.
Big university hospitals have recently completed buildings with only private rooms in Chicago and Little Rock, Ark. Construction will start this summer for an all-private medical center in Los Angeles.
Other current projects include a new Florida center of the Cleveland Clinic; a county hospital near San Bernardino, Calif., and a new regional center for the South Jersey Hospital System in Bridgeton.
At 315 square feet, many rooms in the new medical center at the University of California at Los Angeles will be almost as big as some Manhattan apartments. In the new building at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago, the rooms will be 225 square feet, with separate sinks for patients and nurses and a vanity in the hotel-style private bathroom.
The new private rooms have a number of health care advantages, hospital executives say. They help protect patients from infections in the hospital. They also encourage family members to stay with the patient and become more engaged in the patient's care. In the end, that helps because managed care has in many cases shortened hospital stays and patients need all the help they can get, in the hospital and at home.
An independent study found that patients recovered faster in a cooperative care unit at New York University Hospital, where family members stay with them in 40 private rooms, compared with patients in traditional units.
Faye LeDoux, an architectural project director for Ellerbe Becket, a Minneapolis-based firm, added, "If you are in a room with a person who requires a lot of care and a lot of noisy equipment, it can be very stressful for you."
Thelma Waln, recovering from hip surgery after a painful fall, enthused over the all-private attractions of San Bernardino County's new Arrowhead Regional Medical Center in Colton, Calif. They include "my own bathroom, my own TV." Teasing, she told a nurse, "This is going to lead to malingering."
Mrs. Waln, 64, was transferred to Arrowhead on opening day, March 30, from a 1940's building with a radically different ambiance. Her old room had six beds and a television that attracted "20 or 30 people who came in every day" to watch soap operas. She remembers opening her eyes there, still woozy from anesthesia. "I thought I was in a garage," she said.
Hospital executives say the economics of private rooms make sense in many parts of the country. Medicare, which typically covers half of a hospital's budget, pays a flat sum that varies with the diagnosis.
Some managed care plans also pay this way; others negotiate a daily rate for each patient, and some pay a monthly fee for each plan member that is supposed to cover expenses for those who require care.
As a result, the private rooms do not add directly to costs for insurance companies and employer health plans. Instead of billing the patient, many hospitals now absorb the relatively minor costs of the larger, private room.
"If a hospital can do it, great," said Ben Zelman, a vice president of Medical Mutual of Ohio, a big insurance company based in Cleveland.
As they pursue patients, many hospitals have eliminated extra charges for private rooms.
"We were always reluctant to charge a differential rate for a private room," said Gary Mecklenburg, chief executive of Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. "It would not be positive public relations, when somebody is already paying a lot."
A scattering of hospitals around the country have had all-private facilities for a number of years. Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles has long had all-private rooms at no extra charge.
In Cleveland, the University Hospitals system opened Lerner Tower, a 210-bed, all-private unit for adult patients, five years ago. More than 90 percent of the beds are usually occupied, which helps generate above-average profit levels for the system. On average, only 61 percent of available beds are occupied in Cleveland hospitals.
In New York, where space is short and building costs are high, the newer hospitals have not gone the all-private route, although many have luxury accommodations for those who can afford it. "The economics are prohibitive in New York, compared to other places," said Kenneth Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association.
Preliminary plans for a new children's tower at Presbyterian Hospital, for example, include both semiprivate and private rooms.
It would cost the average hospital in New York City $25,000 more a bed to convert to private rooms than it would to convert to two-bed, semiprivate rooms, said Robert Larsen, a principal in the architectural firm Larsen, Shein, Ginsberg & Associates. That would mean $750,000 more for a standard 30-bed floor.
But in most places, in the accelerating race to draw on a shrinking pool of generally sicker patients, it can be easier to fill private rooms than to scramble to match up people by gender and compatible ailments.
Hospitals are building "as many private rooms as real estate and financial conditions will allow," said Larry Neiterman, global director of health care for the Deloitte Consulting firm.
George J. Mann, a professor of architecture at Texas A & M University, said: "The trend is toward a model more like a hotel. At the Holiday Inn or the Marriott, you don't get a stranger as a roommate when you check in."
The downside, he said, is that the patient in a single room "can be pretty isolated and far away, if something happens and you can't reach that emergency cord." The new hospitals rely on electronic patient-monitoring.
Jocelyn Frederick, a principal with Perkins & Will, an architectural firm in Chicago, said, "It is often cheaper to build new buildings with the correct support space for medical technology and the correct floor plan than to convert an older building."
Planners at Northwestern Memorial said that converting a 1940's structure would have cost more than erecting the new building. In some of the old areas, it was just not feasible to install 1990's technology, said Meredith Zelewsky, a spokeswoman for Northwestern.
On May 1 Northwestern Memorial will open the $580 million center, with 400 private rooms and 92 more for intensive care patients. The big teaching hospital will shut an older facility with 680 beds, 200 of which were often empty.
The rooms are equipped with fiber optic wiring so that nurses and doctors can plug into a patient's medical records or digitally stored X-ray images. Specially programmed air systems screen out harmful bacteria to protect rooms with cancer or AIDS patients who have weak immune systems. The systems also screen air coming from rooms with patients who have contagious diseases.
Still, some health care experts see the move toward private rooms as driving up overall health care costs, which are now rising 6 percent a year after several years of slow growth.
"Ultimately the private rooms do drive up the cost of health care," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health care economist at Princeton University. "But it is amazing how cheap the costs per square foot are compared to the costs of supplies and staff."
Hospital buildings cost $120 to $250 a square foot around the country, except in California, where earthquake protection raises the cost, and in New York, where building costs are especially high.
Spending on building and equipment is typically spread over a number of years and represents only about 7 percent of a hospital's annual operating expenditures, with most of that for the equipment, said William O. Cleverly, who heads the Center for Healthcare Industry Performance Studies in Columbus, Ohio.
Buildings with all private rooms, he said, may raise total operating costs, including labor, supplies and capital spending, by five-tenths of 1 percent at most.
Making the rooms at the new U.C.L.A. medical center all private has contributed tens of millions of dollars to the $600 million total cost, said Dr. Michael Karpf, director of the medical center, which is part of a new $1.3 billion research and teaching complex.
But the private rooms will allow more treatment to be done in the rooms, as "the tendency of patients being sicker and sicker" continues, he said. Most of the 525 private rooms are being designed to convert easily to intensive care units.
"We assume that as technology is improved and miniaturized, patients will get more done in their own rooms," Dr. Karpf said. Among other things, they may have a dialysis machine, multiple intravenous drips and an aortic balloon to assist the heart.
As a result, the extra cost will be "well worth it," he said. "If the new building was antiquated 20 years after it was built, it would have wasted a lot of money."
