HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: SLAVS UNITED;
Russia's House Betroths Belarus and Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 17

 BODY:
Politics makes strange bedfellows. Then there is Russian politics, which seemed this week hellbent on the downright weird: a menage a trois of Russia, Belarus and Yugoslavia, bedding a wobbly democracy, a Soviet-style dictatorship and an international pariah three borders removed from either of them in death-do-we-part union.
Barely a week after President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia first proposed it, Russia's lower house of Parliament voted Friday by 293 to 54, with one abstention, for just such a marriage of nations. Belarus's eccentric strongman, President Aleksandr Lukashenko, was in Belgrade on Wednesday, making arrangements with Mr. Milosevic for the linkup. 
 Russian Communists were jubilant.
"Everyone is busy leading a new world order," Gennadi Seleznyov, the Communist Speaker of Parliament's lower house, told the news radio station Echo Moskvy on Wednesday.
"Washington is a leader regarding this idea of a new world order. Therefore, let those of us who do not belong to NATO put our heads together and state what kind of world order we see."
That the union is in fact highly unlikely to take place soon, if ever, was almost irrelevant. Whatever the talk of world order and thumbing Washington's eye, the drumbeat here for marriage with Yugoslavia is far more a matter of domestic politics, not foreign.
And in the context of the despair and helplessness that seem to drive much of Russian politics these days -- despair over Russia's plight and the West's comparative supremacy; anger over the helplessness to do much about it -- talking up a union with Belarus and Yugoslavia begins to look like very good strategy indeed.
"It's like demonstrations near the U.S. Embassy, which reflect not the desire of the majority of Russians to get into a confrontation with the West, but some remnants of some imperial feelings," said Andrei Smirnov, a political writer for the Russian daily Segodnya.
"To the majority of the population, the visibility of confrontation flatters them."
To the Communists and supernationalists who are the major backers of union, the notion is that flattery will get them somewhere in the parliamentary campaigns that are just beginning to crank up across Russia.
Voters will choose all 450 members of Russia's politically dominant lower house in elections this December. Already the idea of reasserting lost Russian glory has become both the subtext of parliamentary politics and a main theme of the house's effort to impeach President Boris N. Yeltsin.
This year's elections in Belarus are canceled, courtesy of a new Constitution Mr. Lukashenko pushed through in a referendum widely condemned as rigged. But from the start, he has based his regime on the proposition that Soviet power should be rebuilt to counter Western influence. In the last year, as Belarus's state-planned economy has run aground, he has used the West more and more as a foil for the country's troubles, and promoted reunification of the old Soviet empire as the solution.
But despite widespread popular support for the idea of unification with Belarus -- and a formal announcement of plans for economic and semipolitical union this winter -- the idea so far has gone almost nowhere. In part, that is because Russia is too preoccupied with its own problems to be able to absorb the 10 million residents of Belarus, who are in even worse economic straits.
In part, it may be that neither Mr. Yeltsin's camp nor Russia's Communists and nationalists want Mr. Lukashenko, a charismatic and cunning politician, as a rival in future elections.
On its face, a union with Yugoslavia seems equally appealing to many Russians. One poll of 3,108 Russians, taken this week by the Moscow-based Center for International Sociological Research, showed that 71 percent of respondents supported a Russia-Belarus-Yugoslavia pact and that more than three-quarters would consummate it now rather than later, after the NATO campaign has ended.
For Mr. Yeltsin, who clearly wants to avoid any military or political entanglement in the Yugoslav crisis, such support has been a problem. The President initially said he would favor a union of the three nations after the Communist Speaker, Mr. Seleznyov, met with him last week.
But since then, his aides have backed away from the idea, calling it premature and even wrongheaded because of the danger that it would drag Russia into a European war.
Mr. Smirnov, of Segodnya, suggests that Mr. Yeltsin's opponents will seize on his foot-dragging in the coming parliamentary elections and the presidential campaign that will follow to attack the President's supporters and any successor he may endorse.
That said, support for a three-nation union is hardly unanimous. And some analysts point out that the idea has serious implications that Mr. Yeltsin has raised obliquely and that Communists and nationalists have yet to discuss.
Almost unmentioned, but clearly on everyone's minds, are race and religion.
Communists and nationalists have promoted the merger as a "pan-Slavic union"; the Patriarch of the Russian Orthodox Church, Alexy II, endorsed it as a "great miracle" and a "guarantee of our common spiritual triumph."
Russia's 20 million Muslims, almost a seventh of the nation's population, may see things differently. Already, leaders of some predominantly Muslim regions in southern Russia have warned that the union threatens to further split Russia's already fractious states.
"Such initiatives have very dangerous implications since they propel the non-Slavic part of the Russian population to adequate measures and steps," Farid Abdullovich Asadullin, the Moscow adviser to the Mufti, the Muslims' spiritual leader in Russia, said in an interview on Friday. "I think this initiative won't find support either in the Cabinet of ministers nor from our President."
Then there is the prospect, however remote, that a union with Yugoslavia would bring with it a mutual defense agreement, the stationing of Russian troops and a direct confrontation with a nuclear-armed NATO.
A number of Russian politicians underscored that prospect this week. "The worst thing Russia can do is respond to insanity with insanity," Grigory Yavlinsky, the liberal leader of the Yabloko political faction in the lower house, said in a statement on Friday. "For the first time in history, it opens the possibility for actual military confrontation between the leading nuclear powers."
